WHITE--Betty Goldstone, 98, on June 15, 2013, in Larchmont, NY. Survived by children Betsy, Frederick, Emily; four grandchildren; four great-grandchildren.

SOROS--Paul, The staff, officers, and Board of the American Austrian Foundation extend heartfelt condolences upon the passing of Paul Soros to his wife, Daisy, and their family. Paul and Daisy have been dedicated, longtime supporters of the work of the Foundation, which Daisy has served notably as a director. Paul's kindness and quiet brilliance will be missed by all of us. William vanden Heuvel, Chairman Thomas J. McGrath, President
SOKOLOW--David, 93, of Sharon, MA died on June 18. Beloved husband of Ethel. Loving father of Susan and Mark Brass, Ira and Judy Sokolow. Cherished grandfather of Adam, Emily and Alex.

SMALL--Trudy N.,MD The Departments of Pediatrics and Laboratory Medicine and the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center deeply mourn the passing of Trudy N. Small, MD, who died on June 14th, 2013. Dr. Small was an internationally recognized pediatric hematologist who made important contributions in the development of improved transplantation approaches for the treatment of patients with advanced leukemia and children with life-threatening genetic disorders of the immune system. Dr. Small received her medical degree from SUNY Upstate Medical University of Syracuse and residency training in Pediatrics at Duke University and the University of Minnesota. After specialty training in Pediatric Hematology/Oncology at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, she joined the faculty in 1987 and thereafter rose to its highest rank of full Member. She was also an Associate Professor of Pediatrics at Weill Cornell Medical College. Dr. Small's research focused on the cellular interactions that control recovery of the immune system after transplantation, and provided the first evidence linking age-related changes in the human thymus with the delayed restoration of cell-mediated immunity observed in older adults after transplantation. She also conducted pioneering studies examining how best to vaccinate patients after transplantation or other cancer treatments to insure full recovery of immunity and protect patients from infection. Her work provided evidence critical to the development of the National Centers for Disease Control's guidelines for vaccination of immunocompromised transplant recipients. Dr. Small's research on lethal genetic immune deficiencies also contributed to more precise characteristics that clarified diagnoses and improved transplantation approaches for curative correction. Dr. Small dedicated her professional life to the care of children who received marrow transplants for life-threatening forms of leukemia and immune deficiency. As a physician and parent, she had a profound understanding of the potentially devastating impact of these diseases on children and their families and how challenging the journey back to health can be. She also had a special way with children that turned fears to confidence and laughter. Dr. Small was beloved by her patients and their families and warmly revered by her many friends and colleagues. She is survived by her husband, Robert Knowles, and her children, Molly and Sam. She will be deeply missed. Richard J. O'Reilly, MD Chair, Department of Pediatrics Melissa S. Pessin, MD, PhD Chair, Department of Laboratory Medicine Jose Baselga, MD, PhD Physician-in-Chief, Memorial Hospital

SCHWELLER--Bertha, of Boca Raton, Florida and New York City passed away on June 17, 2013 after a lengthy illness. Born on June 9, 1923, Ms. Schweller was president of her senior high school class and graduated New York University with an accounting degree. She was a pioneer in the Wine and Liquor industry and was highly successful as a business person at a time when it was extraordinary in a city as competitive as New York City was in the late 1950's. Ms. Schweller was the creator and owner of the highly successful retail business known as Mid-Town Wine and Liquor for over 50 years. In her personal life, she was always known as "great Aunt Bertha" as her generosity and kindness to both friends and family had no limits. She had a passion for life, which she lived to the fullest. Predeceased by her beloved parents, Sarah and Louis Schweller, who owned the landmark restaurant known as SCHWELLER's, her brother Gus, and her sister, Sylvia Kalish (Nee Schweller-Theodore) she is survived by her nephews, Herbert Kalish (Mary), Lewis Schweller (Cathy) and Allan Kalish. Ms. Schweller is also survived by her long time companion, George Bistolfi, and her grandnieces and grandnephew, Sara Sherry (Nee Kalish-Dean), Jordan Schweller, Jessie Kuhn (Nee Schweller-David) and Lara Schweller, all of whom deeply loved and will sorely miss her. The family thanks Ms. Althea Thompson for her highly professional and loving care given to Ms. Schweller for the past several years. Funeral services will be held at 11:00am on Friday June 21st at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus NJ.

He is survived by his nephews; John A. Pane, DDS, of Charlotte, VT, Robert D. Pane, MD, of Boulder CO, Nicholas M. Panebianco, CPA, of Airmont, NY, John A. Panebianco, of Valley Cottage, NY and his niece; Camille Pane-Hunger, MD, of Greenwood Village, CO. Nick was a graduate of Iona College in 1954. He proudly served in the US Army in Germany 1955-1956, after which he worked in the family business, Super Fuel Corp. in New York City in many capacities, most recently as President. He will be missed by his loving nephews and niece and their families, as well as his many cousins, numerous friends, employees and business associates. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9pm Thursday. Mass of Christian Burial, Immaculate Conception Church, Tuckahoe, on Friday, June 21 at 9:30am

OSMAN--Holly. You filled our world with friendship, love, beauty and grace. The dinner parties were just icing on the cake. With all our love to Dick, Sarah, Eric and the Cohen family. Nancy, Andy, Danielle and Caroline

LECKIE--Frederick, a resident of Pelham Manor and New Rochelle, NY since 2005 passed away peacefully at Calvary Hospital, NY on Friday, 14th June 2013. He was 84. Dr. Leckie was born on 26th March 1929 in Dundee, Scotland, the second child of Frederick Leckie and Mary Barclay Leckie. He gained a B.Sc. Degree with First Class Honours in Engineering and was the Engineering Medalist at the University of St. Andrews in 1949. He then left Scotland to take up a position with Mott, Hay & Anderson in London followed by military service from 1951 to 1954 in the Royal Air Force where he was OCTU Sword of Honour winner. He next moved to the US and earned M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in Mechanical Engineering from Stanford University in 1955 and 1958, where he met and married Elizabeth Wheelwright of Greenwich, CT, his wife for 43 years. Upon graduation he spent a year at the Technische Hochschule, Hanover, Germany and then ten years as a lecturer in Mechanical Sciences at the University of Cambridge and Director of Studies and Fellow of Pembroke College. From 1968 to 1978 he was the Professor of Engineering at the University of Leicester, England. For the next decade Fred was a Professor of Mechanical Engineering and Head of the Department of Theoretical and Applied Mechanics at the University of Illinois in Urbana-Champaign and then from 1988 to 2005 as chair of the Department of Mechanical Engineering at the University of California, Santa Barbara. Public service included stints with the US and UK Departments of Energy, the UK Nuclear Inspectorate, the UK Atomic Energy Authority, Euratom, the US Army Corps of Engineers, the Pressure Research Council and numerous committees of the National Science Foundation. Awards included an honorary D.Sc. from the University of Leicester, the Nadai Medal from the American Society of Mechanical Engineering and the Halliburton Award from the University of Illinois. Fred's publishing career spanned 50 years, over 150 journal articles and several books, the most recent published in 2009. Fred is survived by his son Gavin and wife Elizabeth of Pelham Manor, NY and his son Gregor and wife Sylvia of Deerfield, IL and his six grandchildren Hamish, Catriona, Mia, Isabel, Angus and Elspeth, as well as sister-in-law Margaret Canada of Stamford, CT and many nieces, nephews, cousins and close friends all over the world. His parents, wife and son Sean predeceased him. Funeral services will be held at Christ Church, 1415 Pelhamdale Avenue, Pelham Manor, NY at 10am Friday 21st June, 2013 with lunch afterwards at 990 Edgewood Avenue, Pelham Manor. In lieu of flowers the family would like to suggest a contribution to the University of St. Andrews American Foundation Inc. with a note for it to be applied to bursaries for Scottish students in memory of Professor F.A. Leckie. Services by Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Avenue, Pelham 10803 (pelham-funeralhome.com) Telephone: 914-738-1060

He attended McDaniel College, Westminster, MD, and later the University of Richmond, in Richmond, VA, from which he was graduated last month. He played college lacrosse at both McDaniel and Richmond, and was also an enthusiastic hockey player. He is survived by his parents, younger siblings Robert and Margaret, maternal grandmother Margaret Crane Laffan of Greenwich, Ct. and paternal grandfather Warren George Kraft of Cold Spring Harbor. Also surviving are devoted aunts Joanne Laffan, Helen Buckwalter and Anne Thompson, uncle John Kraft and wife Amy, Alan Buckwalter and numerous cousins. A service will be held Friday, June 21 at 4pm at the family home. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the University of Richmond in memory of Warren Gwydir Kraft, Jr. at the following address: Advancement Systems, 28 Westhampton Way, Richmond, VA 23173

KELLY--John J.,Jr., of Yonkers, on June 19, 2013. Loving son of Margaret and the late John J. Sr., devoted brother of Terrence M. (Barbara), Karen (Stephen) Kelly Marcellino and Joy (Patrick) Kelly Corbett. Devoted uncle to Bridget, Mike, Blaine, Julia, Sarah and Rachel. GLADSTEIN--Mike. We have lost a class act in our bridge game. Mike, we will miss you. A grand slam will never feel the same without you. All The Guys

GLADSTEIN--Mathew L.,died on June 18 at his home in Scarsdale, NY. He was 90 years old. "Mike" was born in New York City where he attended Townsend Harris High School. After graduating at 16 years old, he attended C.C.N.Y. for two years before enlisting in the Army Air Corps. During World War II, he served as a bombardier-navigator with the 15th Air Force in Italy, attaining the rank of first lieutenant. Upon his return, Mike attended Columbia University. Following an earlier career as an insurance broker and as President of Glenhaven Ltd., he joined Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in 1970 where he worked to integrate theoretical research with trading strategies utilizing options and derivatives. Today, the presence of professionals with quantitative backgrounds on trading desks is commonplace, but in 1973, a gulf existed between traders and academics, and Mr. Gladstein was one of the forerunners in bringing the two disparate cultures together. After engaging Myron S. Scholes and Robert C. Merton to help implement this effort, Mr. Gladstein co-authored with them, two studies of options that were published in the Journal of Business in 1978 and 1982. Since 1951 he has been a resident of Scarsdale, NY where he was active in community affairs. He served as the first President of the Akerman Institute in New York and as President of Scarsdale Family Counseling Services. He chaired local fundraising efforts on behalf of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, U.J.A., Brandeis University and The Scarsdale United Fund. Mike is survived by his wife of 63 years, the former Edythe Rosenthal, his children, John, Gina and Joshua, and two granddaughters, Anna and Nina Mullen. Mike's intelligence, his laughter, and his love for his family and friends will forever be remembered and missed; he was our greatest cheerleader. There will be a graveside service at 9:45am on Friday, June 21 at the Hebrew Cemetery on Memory Lane in Greenwich, CT. A reception will follow at the Gladstein home at 85 Morris Lane in Scarsdale, NY.

GLADSTEIN--Mathew "Mike" L. The Board of Directors and the members of Quaker Ridge Golf Club are saddened by the passing of our beloved friend and esteemed member of 20 years, Mathew Gladstein. GLADSTEIN--Mathew. Dearest Mike, there will never be ice in my wine again. Al and I will miss you forever and love you longer than forever. Bobbe and Al

He was also a member of The Ridgewood Country Club and enjoyed spending time with his family in Wellfleet, MA. Ken is survived by his beloved wife, Jennifer (nee Young) of Ridgewood, his loving daughter and sons; Katherine Judkins and her husband Tyler of Portland, ME, Kyle Cohen and Alec Cohen, both of Ridgewood. Also surviving is his mother, Jessie (nee Wilkinson) Cohen of Rye Neck, NY, his sister and brother-in-law, Barbara and Michael J. Student and his nephew, Sanford, of Edgemont, NY and his brother and sister-in-law, Donald M. and Olivia Cohen of Huaraz, Peru. Ken was predeceased by his father, Frederick Cohen in 2000. The family will receive visitors on Thursday, June 20, 2-4 and 7-9pm at the Vander Plaat Funeral Home, www.vpfh.com, 257 Godwin Ave. Wyckoff, NJ. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, June 21, 11:00am at West Side Presbyterian Church, 6 South Monroe Street, Ridgewood, NJ 07450. In lieu of flowers, donations in Kenneth's memory may be made to organizations that he generously supported: New Alternatives for Children, Inc., 37 West 26th Street, 6th Floor, New York, NY 10010, Habitat for Humanity-New York City, Attn: James Andrews, 111 John Street, 23rd Floor, New York, NY 10038, or TADA! Youth Theater, 15 West 28th Street, New York, NY 10001.

CHANDRA--Thatsani, of Cherry Hill, NJ, on Tuesday, June 18, 2013. Born in Thailand and resided in Cherry Hill since 1989. Thatsani earned a nursing degree from Chiang Mai University. She later met her husband at the Albert Einstein Medical Center in the Bronx and continued to work at the Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn. She helped her husband advance his practice throughout New Jersey and New York. She was a huge soccer mom that would travel all over the country. She enjoyed cooking for her family and gardening. Beloved wife of Prasanta Chandra, MD. Devoted mother of Dipa (Chris) Chandra, Indra (Christina) Chandra and Prakash (Mayuri) Chandra. Loving grandmother of Owen, Iris, Luke, Katherine, Edward, and Penna. Dear sister of a brother who resides in Thailand and a sister who resides in China. Relatives and friends are invited to her viewings on Wednesday, June 19, 2013 from 2:00 4:00pm and 6:00 8:00pm at the Bell-Hennessy Funeral Home, 420 S. Main St., Williamstown, NJ. Funeral Services will follow at 8:00pm. Cremation private. Condolences and memories may be shared online at www.bell-hennessy.com. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society, 1851 Old Cuthbert Rd., Cherry Hill, NJ 08034 and/or the Virtua Hospital Foundation, 100 Townsend Ave., Berlin, NJ 08009.

Info on services 718-721-9200 at tmquinn.com. In lieu of flowers please make donations to Ronald McDonald House, Greek Division, 405 E. 73rd St, New York, NY 10021.

BERNSTEIN--Adam Laurence, age 36, passed away suddenly at home in Manhattan on June 18. He was the beloved husband of Jessica Manis and the cherished son of Lori Walzer Bernstein and the late Allen J. Bernstein. He also leaves his grandmother, Selma Walzer, a sister, Stacey Stolar, and niece Sarah Stolar, and a loving family and dear friends deeply saddened by this untimely loss. He will always be remembered for his warmth, generosity of spirit and appreciation of life's absurdities. Adam had a keen interest in history, art, music, and antique cars, and a great love of animals. He was a caring friend, teacher and mentor. He had built a successful career in the foodservice and hospitality management industries. He received his undergraduate degree from the S.I. Newhouse School of Public Communications, at Syracuse University and his master's degree from the William F. Harrah College of Hotel Administration, at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas. He was an adjunct professor at Monroe College. Services will be held at 11:30am today at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street. Interment will follow at the Knollwood Park Cemetery section of Mount Carmel Cemetery, Queens.

WEINSTEIN--Jerome J.,on June 13, 2013 of pneumonia. A long-time resident of Sands Point, NY, recently of Great Barrington, MA and NYC. Forever beloved and always remembered. He leaves many loving friends and relatives. Born in 1924 Jerry was raised in Lynbrook, NY, graduated from Harvard University and served in the US Army during WWII. Jerry ran, reoriented, and served as President of Apex Plastic Industries, Inc, Hauppauge, NY. Jerry was a plastics industry leader as well as a local government official serving as Trustee and Mayor of Sands Point and then as North Hempstead Town Councilman. He was handily elected four times and was one of the longest serving councilmembers in recent history. Deeply admired and genuinely loved by everyone who knew him, he leaves behind legions of people who remember his kindness, wit, and unfailing interest in the welfare of others. He is survived by his adored and adoring wife Marjorie, son Jon (Ilana) of Port Washington, daughter Susan Dobuler (Kenneth) of Branford, CT and by his loving grandchildren who will never forget him: Diana Weinstein Mark, Rachelle, and Robert; Zoe Dobuler and the late Paul. Also survived by great-granddaughter Georgia Jane Mark. A memorial service will be held Sunday, June 23, at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, NYC at 3:30pm. Donations in Jerry's memory may be sent to the Paul A. Dobuler Memorial Research Fund, Children's Hospital Trust, 1 Autumn Street, Boston, MA 02215.

WEINER--Diane Elizabeth, 53, of Woodstock, Vermont, beloved wife of JR Rosenthal and mother of Ramona Sky Rosenthal, sister of Jan and Robert Weiner, died of a stroke June 14. She was Assistant Professor of Medical Anthropology at BU Medical School. Diane pioneered the study of terminal diseases in Native Americans of southern California. She loved baking, gardening and walking her four wonderful dogs.

SMALL--Trudy N.,MD The Departments of Pediatrics and Laboratory Medicine and the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center deeply mourn the passing of Trudy N. Small, MD, who died on June 14th, 2013. Dr. Small was an internationally recognized pediatric hematologist who made important contributions in the development of improved transplantation approaches for the treatment of patients with advanced leukemia and children with life-threatening genetic disorders of the immune system. Dr. Small received her medical degree from SUNY Upstate Medical University of Syracuse and residency training in Pediatrics at Duke University and the University of Minnesota. After specialty training in Pediatric Hematology/Oncology at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, she joined the faculty in 1987 and thereafter rose to its highest rank of full Member. She was also an Associate Professor of Pediatrics at Weill Cornell Medical College. Dr. Small's research focused on the cellular interactions that control recovery of the immune system after transplantation, and provided the first evidence linking age-related changes in the human thymus with the delayed restoration of cell-mediated immunity observed in older adults after transplantation. She also conducted pioneering studies examining how best to vaccinate patients after transplantation or other cancer treatments to insure full recovery of immunity and protect patients from infection. Her work provided evidence critical to the development of the National Centers for Disease Control's guidelines for vaccination of immunocompromised transplant recipients. Dr. Small's research on lethal genetic immune deficiencies also contributed to more precise characteristics that clarified diagnoses and improved transplantation approaches for curative correction. Dr. Small dedicated her professional life to the care of children who received marrow transplants for life-threatening forms of leukemia and immune deficiency. As a physician and parent, she had a profound understanding of the potentially devastating impact of these diseases on children and their families and how challenging the journey back to health can be. She also had a special way with children that turned fears to confidence and laughter. Dr. Small was beloved by her patients and their families and warmly revered by her many friends and colleagues. She is survived by her husband, Robert Knowles, and her children, Molly and Sam. She will be deeply missed. Richard J. O'Reilly, MD Chair, Department of Pediatrics Melissa S. Pessin, MD, PhD Chair, Department of Laboratory Medicine Jose Baselga, MD, PhD Physician-in-Chief, Memorial Hospital

SMALL--Trudy. Our hearts are broken for Bob, Molly and Sam. Trudy was a gifted doctor, a wonderful friend and a beautiful person. We will be forever grateful for her loving care of our daughter. Maura and Kevin Sheridan

ROSEN--Murray M. In Memory of Murray M. Rosen Partner and founder of Rosen and Glaser C.P.A.s, P.C. our mentor, colleague and friend. MARWELL--Grace Glass. The Staff and Trustees of the Museum of Jewish Heritage A Living Memorial to the Holocaust are deeply saddened by the passing of Grace Marwell, beloved mother of our director, David. She was cherished as the core of a loving and generous clan, and took great pride in raising a family that embodied the values she held so dear. May her memory be a blessing. Our deepest condolences to David, Judy, Gabe, Nate and Haley, and the entire Marwell family. Robert M. Morgenthau, Chair

LeVINE--David Eliot, 79, died June 3, 2013 in New York City after a brief illness. A graduate of Harvard College (1955) and Columbia Law School (1960), he served as a lieutenant in the United States Navy. Executive Director of the Dramatists Guild of America (1966-1993) and later of counsel to theatrical attorneys DaSilva & DaSilva, he represented theater professionals and appeared as an expert witness in contractual arbitrations on the East and West coasts. He was a member of the Tony Awards Administration Committee, a trustee of the T. Shreiber Studio and Eugene O'Neill Theater Center, and a founder of Broadway Cares/Equity Fights Aids. He is survived by his wife Barbara Grande and beloved cat Smokey. For donations: Bing Center for WM, Dana Farber Cancer Institute, Boston; Blood Bank and Stem Cell Processing Unit, Tufts Medical Center, Boston; The Humane Society.

LECKIE--Frederick, a resident of Pelham Manor and New Rochelle, NY since 2005 passed away peacefully at Calvary Hospital, NY on Friday, 14th June 2013. He was 84. Dr. Leckie was born on 26th March 1929 in Dundee, Scotland, the second child of Frederick Leckie and Mary Barclay Leckie. He gained a B.Sc. Degree with First Class Honours in Engineering and was the Engineering Medalist at the University of St. Andrews in 1949. He then left Scotland to take up a position with Mott, Hay & Anderson in London followed by military service from 1951 to 1954 in the Royal Air Force where he was OCTU Sword of Honour winner. He next moved to the US and earned M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in Mechanical Engineering from Stanford University in 1955 and 1958, where he met and married Elizabeth Wheelwright of Greenwich, CT, his wife for 43 years. Upon graduation he spent a year at the Technische Hochschule, Hanover, Germany and then ten years as a lecturer in Mechanical Sciences at the University of Cambridge and Director of Studies and Fellow of Pembroke College. From 1968 to 1978 he was the Professor of Engineering at the University of Leicester, England. For the next decade Fred was a Professor of Mechanical Engineering and Head of the Department of Theoretical and Applied Mechanics at the University of Illinois in Urbana-Champaign and then from 1988 to 2005 as chair of the Department of Mechanical Engineering at the University of California, Santa Barbara. Public service included stints with the US and UK Departments of Energy, the UK Nuclear Inspectorate, the UK Atomic Energy Authority, Euratom, the US Army Corps of Engineers, the Pressure Research Council and numerous committees of the National Science Foundation. Awards included an honorary D.Sc. from the University of Leicester, the Nadai Medal from the American Society of Mechanical Engineering and the Halliburton Award from the University of Illinois. Fred's publishing career spanned 50 years, over 150 journal articles and several books, the most recent published in 2009. Fred is survived by his son Gavin and wife Elizabeth of Pelham Manor, NY and his son Gregor and wife Sylvia of Deerfield, IL and his six grandchildren Hamish, Catriona, Mia, Isabel, Angus and Elspeth, as well as sister-in-law Margaret Canada of Stamford, CT and many nieces, nephews, cousins and close friends all over the world. His parents, wife and son Sean predeceased him. Funeral services will be held at Christ Church, 1415 Pelhamdale Avenue, Pelham Manor, NY at 10am Friday 21st June, 2013 with lunch afterwards at 990 Edgewood Avenue, Pelham Manor. In lieu of flowers the family would like to suggest a contribution to the University of St. Andrews American Foundation Inc. with a note for it to be applied to bursaries for Scottish students in memory of Professor F.A. Leckie. Services by Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Avenue, Pelham 10803 (pelham-funeralhome.com) Telephone: 914-738-1060

(Barbara), Karen (Stephen) Kelly Marcellino and Joy (Patrick) Kelly Corbett. Devoted uncle to Bridget, Mike, Blaine, Julia, Sarah and Rachel. FARBER--Sam. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the American Folk Art Museum mourn the passing of our great friend and supporter, Sam Farber, who served as a trustee from 1996-2005, and thereafter, served as trustee emeritus. Sam was a driving force behind the formation of the Museum's Contemporary Center; he was also the person most responsible for the establishment of the Henry Darger Study Center. A disciplined thinker, thoughtful, calm, yet persevering, Sam took on many tasks that others avoided, managing projects and cultivating relationships on behalf of the Museum. He served tirelessly as head of the Building Committee and oversaw the construction at 45 West 53rd Street. His leadership and financial generosity allowed the Museum to pursue ideas and ventures that otherwise would not have been possible. A passionate and avid collector of art brut and art of the self-taught, Sam gave important works to the Museum, which greatly enhanced the collection, and also lent his own works generously, helping to raise awareness of and educate the public about this art. We were inspired by him and will continue to be inspired by his vision for what the Museum could be. He was a man of style, grace, humility, and intellect. He will be sorely missed. The Farber family has asked that contributions in his memory be made to the American Folk Art Museum, Administrative Office, 1865 Broadway, 11th Floor, New York, NY 10023.

DIAMANDIS--Peter G. Peter had a flair for living and a warmth and character that we couldn't get enough of. His appetite for life, his curiosity, his love of facts and history were insatiable. He was a natural comic, a legendary storyteller, a bold executive and inspirational leader, but more than anything he loved time off digging in his garden or scratching the head of his faithful dog. Peter met his match in wit and intellect 58 years ago in his wife Joan. Though he loved to play her as the fall gal for his jokes and stories, his respect and love for her as his wife and mother of their six children was as constant as his pride in her. Losing Peter as our friend is the greatest loss of all. We will find solace and laugh together remembering all that we shared--the great trips, the holiday dinners, the golf games, the clack of the croquet ball in Ireland, the Diamandis lectures, the countless and priceless "Peter-isms," but mostly his quiet generosity and unquestionable loyalty. We will miss you, good friend. Carter & Howard, Judy & Aaron

BYERS- Robert Scott. 48, of Clifton, passed away peacefully on June 18, 2013. Born in Passaic, Scott lived in Clifton for most of his life. He was a 1983 graduate of Passaic Valley High School in Little Falls before earning a Bachelor of Science degree in Business Administration from Montclair State College. He was employed as the Director of Events Administration for Macy's Parade and Entertainment Group of New York City. Scott also served as the Chief Archivist for Special Events for Macy's, was the voice of the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade and served as the Head of the Clown Program for the parade. For many years, he was an integral part of the Administration of Macy's Santaland and the Annual Flower Show. He was predeceased by his father, Staff Sergeant William P. Byers. Survivors include: his beloved mother, Barbara (nee Schultz); two sisters, Alice Deuerlein of Tannersville, PA and Beth Erling of Clifton; two brothers, William Byers of Daytona Beach, FL and Stephen Byers of Whitefield, NH; eight nieces and nephews; and five great-nieces and great-nephews. Funeral services will be held Saturday 11:30am at the Bizub-Quinlan Funeral Home, 1313 Van Houten Ave., Clifton. Private cremation to follow. Visiting will be Friday from 4:00-8:00pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Make-A-Wish Foundation (www.wish.org), Gift Processing Center, P.O. Box 6062, Albert Lea, MN 56007-6662. Please visit www.bizub.com for driving directions and online condolences.

BAR--Ralph. On June 20, 2013, at 84. Beloved husband of Edith for 57 years. Father of Michael and Richard. Father-in-law of Mary and Claire. Grandfather of Russell, Emily, Justin and Samantha. Step-grandfather of Samuel and Jessica. Brother of Maurice, and brother-in-law of Marion and Didi. Predeceased by his beloved brother Adolphe. Uncle to all of his dear nieces and nephews. Born in Antwerp, Belgium and a Holocaust survivor. Founder and President of Facet Industries. Former President of the New York Diamond Dealers Club. One of the initial business ambassadors to China. In 2000, the Prince of Belgium bestowed the HRD Lodewijck van Bercken Diamond award for his lifetime commitment to the Antwerp World Diamond Center. We love you and we will miss your kindness, humor, wisdom and devotion to us all. Your spirit will always be with us. We are all better people because of you. Rest in peace. Services Monday 11:15am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

YURMAN--Miriam M. June 19, age 91. Beloved wife of Milton, mother of Rachel (Mike) and Larry (Brigid), grandmother of Mikayla.

ULLMAN--William Anthony, 80, passed away peacefully on June 21, 2013 at his home in Manhattan. Tony was born in New York City on November 2, 1932 to parents Bill and Sue. He was raised in New Orleans where he attended the Newman School and graduated from Tulane in 1954. He served his country as a First Lieutenant in the USAF, spending a year in Korea. Tony was a member of The New York Stock Exchange for over 25 years. He loved tennis and was part of Tulane's undefeated national championship team. He is survived by Nancy, his loving wife of 52 years, son Bill and his wife Tracy, son Tom and his wife Nona, granddaughters Emily, Natalie, Laura, Hannah and Grace and sister Susan Chapro. There will be a Memorial Gathering, Monday, June 24 and Tuesday, June 25, 6-9pm, at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Memorial Service on Friday, June 28 at 11am at Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester, 2125 Westchester Avenue East, Rye, NY. Remembrance may be made to the Ullman Family Fund, Phillips Academy Endowment, Andover, MA 01810.

TEITELBAUM--Surelle, died at 74, on Friday June 21, 2013 of leukemia-related pneumonia. "Sooky" battled fiercely to overcome leukemia over the last 7 months. She was a spitfire all of her life, and in trademark style she fought loud and hard until the end to regain her health and her life. Her only desire was simply to get back to her beloved house in Brooklyn, where her favorite pastime was sitting on her porch in Summer to read her newspapers and play with all of the neighborhood dogs who passed by. Sooky was a devoted mother and wife and was loved by her family, neighbors and friends. We'll all miss her desperately. She is survived by her sons, Joshua and Noah, by her sister and brother-in-law Arline and Hy Grossman and by her sister-in-law Barbara Aber. In lieu of flowers, donations in Sooky's name can be made to the NY Presbyterian/ Weill Cornell "Leukemia Fighters" program. Memorial Services will be held at Nieberg Midwood Chapel in Brooklyn at 12pm on Sunday June 23rd.

SMITH--Dr. Morton, 90, died June 19th. Predeceased by loving wife, Margie. Loving father to Mark, proud grandpa to Melanie. Also survived by Mark's wife, Nancy, her children, Ilysse and Josh, his wife, Katie and their son, Mason. Service Sunday, 10:30am, Schoem's Chapel, W-150 Rte. 4, Paramus, www.schoemschapel.com. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory can be made to Alpha-1 Foundation, 2937 SW 27th Ave. Suite 302, Miami, FL 33133. www.alpha-1foundation.org.

SMALL--Trudy N.,MD The Departments of Pediatrics and Laboratory Medicine and the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center deeply mourn the passing of Trudy N. Small, MD, who died on June 14th, 2013. Dr. Small was an internationally recognized pediatric hematologist who made important contributions in the development of improved transplantation approaches for the treatment of patients with advanced leukemia and children with life-threatening genetic disorders of the immune system. Dr. Small received her medical degree from SUNY Upstate Medical University of Syracuse and residency training in Pediatrics at Duke University and the University of Minnesota. After specialty training in Pediatric Hematology/Oncology at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, she joined the faculty in 1987 and thereafter rose to its highest rank of full Member. She was also an Associate Professor of Pediatrics at Weill Cornell Medical College. Dr. Small's research focused on the cellular interactions that control recovery of the immune system after transplantation, and provided the first evidence linking age-related changes in the human thymus with the delayed restoration of cell-mediated immunity observed in older adults after transplantation. She also conducted pioneering studies examining how best to vaccinate patients after transplantation or other cancer treatments to insure full recovery of immunity and protect patients from infection. Her work provided evidence critical to the development of the National Centers for Disease Control's guidelines for vaccination of immunocompromised transplant recipients. Dr. Small's research on lethal genetic immune deficiencies also contributed to more precise characteristics that clarified diagnoses and improved transplantation approaches for curative correction. Dr. Small dedicated her professional life to the care of children who received marrow transplants for life-threatening forms of leukemia and immune deficiency. As a physician and parent, she had a profound understanding of the potentially devastating impact of these diseases on children and their families and how challenging the journey back to health can be. She also had a special way with children that turned fears to confidence and laughter. Dr. Small was beloved by her patients and their families and warmly revered by her many friends and colleagues. She is survived by her husband, Robert Knowles, and her children, Molly and Sam. She will be deeply missed. Richard J. O'Reilly, MD Chair, Department of Pediatrics Melissa S. Pessin, MD, PhD Chair, Department of Laboratory Medicine Jose Baselga, MD, PhD Physician-in-Chief, Memorial Hospital

OHLANDT--John Frederick, age 90, passed away peacefully on June 20th. He was the beloved brother of Sr. Joanna Ohlandt, CSJ and Katherine Ohlandt-O'Connor, and also leaves a sister-in-law, a brother-in-law and 23 nieces and nephews. He was a graduate of Manhattan College and St. John's Law School, and served in the US Army. He was employed in the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office, and was a Patent Attorney with IBM before establishing his own practice which became Ohlandt Greeley Ruggerio & Perle LLP, from which he retired. He will be remembered as a kind, thoughtful and considerate gentleman. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, 2 to 4 and 7 to 9pm Sunday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Monday, June 24 at 10am.

NATHANSON--Ellen. The 92nd Street Y Board and staff mourn with heavy hearts the passing of Ellen Nathanson, beloved mother of our Board member, Caryn Zucker. Our hearts and prayers are with Carl, Ellen's husband, Caryn and her husband, Jeff, their children Andrew, Elizabeth, Peter and William as well as the entire Nathanson and Zucker families. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

MARWELL--Grace G.,89, June 19 in Mt. Kisco, NY where she'd been a resident for more than 80 years. Born in Brooklyn to Joseph and Bessie Gerber Glass. Married to Edward M. Marwell who predeceased her. Survived by her children Stuart (Vicki), Emily, David (Judy) and Josh (Chitra), and eight grandchildren Nick (Margaret), Elizabeth, Nathan (Haley), Gabe, Tao, Jen, Toby and Anjali. She was a woman of keen intelligence, unfailing grace and playful wit. She is mourned and missed.

KNUDSON--Susan M. 20 November 1958 - 05 June 2013 Daughter of Clifford C Knudson/ Anne M (Robinson) Knudson, spouse, soulmate and mother of three. A strong advocate of public education. spent many years in voluntary service to the children of Arizona. She will be missed for her warmth and wit.
GLADSTEIN--Mathew L. Dearest Mike, we will always miss our Quaker Ridge golf champ. Love, Ruth and Jerry

GEDNEY--Joann. 88, a long-time resident of the East Village, died at home in her sleep on Thursday, the 20th of June. Born in 1925, she was an Abstract Expressionist painter and sculptor. During the '50s and '60s, she was a founding member of the March Gallery, one of the Tenth Street cooperative galleries. Art was her life and she was passionate about it always. She also loved animals and believed that God could be found in the eyes of a dog. She will be missed by her sisters Dr. Judith G. Tobin of Seaford, DE, Dr. Marion J. Gedney of Manhattan and her brother Stanley L. Gedney III of Pearl River, NY, her nieces and nephews and their children. A memorial service will be held on Monday, June 24 at 11:00am at the Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street. Memorial gifts may be made to Mighty Mutts, P.O. Box 1147, New York, NY 10276-1147.

BLOOM--Lewis R.,born in New York City on December 26, 1924, died in Santa Barbara, California on June 18, 2013. Son of the late Mildred Rogers and Charles Bloom. He is survived by his sister, Betty Klausner of San Francisco and her entire family; his cousin Leslie Steinmetz of Santa Barbara; and his partner Clay Tedeschi.
BLOCK--Herman "Pip," born January 4, 1913, died June 20, 2013. Survived by loving children: Diane, Jeffrey, Elliot plus three grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Private Services.

BAR--Ralph. On June 20, 2013, at 84. Beloved husband of Edith for 57 years. Father of Michael and Richard. Father-in-law of Mary and Claire. Grandfather of Russell, Emily, Justin and Samantha. Step-grandfather of Samuel and Jessica. Brother of Maurice, and brother-in-law of Marion and Didi. Predeceased by his beloved brother Adolphe. Uncle to all of his dear nieces and nephews. Born in Antwerp, Belgium and a Holocaust survivor. Founder and President of Facet Industries. Former President of the New York Diamond Dealers Club. One of the initial business ambassadors to China. In 2000, the Prince of Belgium bestowed the HRD Lodewijck van Bercken Diamond award for his lifetime commitment to the Antwerp World Diamond Center. We love you and we will miss your kindness, humor, wisdom and devotion to us all. Your spirit will always be with us. We are all better people because of you. Rest in peace. Services Monday 11:15am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

Her work provided evidence critical to the development of the National Centers for Disease Control's guidelines for vaccination of immunocompromised transplant recipients. Dr. Small's research on lethal genetic immune deficiencies also contributed to more precise characteristics that clarified diagnoses and improved transplantation approaches for curative correction. Dr. Small dedicated her professional life to the care of children who received marrow transplants for life-threatening forms of leukemia and immune deficiency. As a physician and parent, she had a profound understanding of the potentially devastating impact of these diseases on children and their families and how challenging the journey back to health can be. She also had a special way with children that turned fears to confidence and laughter. Dr. Small was beloved by her patients and their families and warmly revered by her many friends and colleagues. She is survived by her husband, Robert Knowles, and her children, Molly and Sam. She will be deeply missed. Richard J. O'Reilly, MD Chair, Department of Pediatrics Melissa S. Pessin, MD, PhD Chair, Department of Laboratory Medicine Jose Baselga, MD, PhD Physician-in-Chief, Memorial Hospital

SILVA--Pedro Pablo, passed away on June 20, 2013, surrounded by his family. Renowned internationally for his massive community art installations, Pedro galvanized over 3,000 people from all walks of life to participate in creating the beautiful mosaic benches surrounding Grant's Tomb. His ability to find the magic unicorn in every surface will be sorely missed by his family; Valerie, Marie-Louise, Antony, Michelle, Rondi, and Gwendolyn. A memorial celebration will be held in September.

ROTHENBERG--Arthur S.,95, died June 17, 2013 at the UConn Medical Center. Born in Brooklyn, NY he lived in West Hempstead, NY retiring to South Egremont, MA in 1990 and moving to West Hartford, CT in 2010. A combat artist in WWII, his paintings have hung in the Pentagon and have been shown at The Brooklyn Museum; the Art Directors Club of New York, and in one-man shows at Hofstra University, the Guild Hall of East Hampton, NY, and a retrospective exhibition at Bard College at Simon's Rock in Great Barrington, MA. An avid sailor, he was a commodore of the Hempstead Bay Sailing Club and a founder of the East Hampton Yacht Club. He is survived by his wife, Enid Weitz Rothenberg; daughter Marna Sag; son Eric P. Rothenberg; son Dan Rothenberg and his wife Kathy Andrews.

PULVERS--Marvin, lived with passion and humor. Lawyer, traveler, author. Loved hot dogs, fatty corned beef, all things Italian, and Rita most of all. Dad and Poppi you'll be with us always. Private service.

PIELENZ--Hanns A. Died June 13, 2013 at his home in Vero Beach, Florida with his beloved wife and daughters by his side. Pielenz, who alternated between residences in Vero Beach, Bonnigheim, Germany and Harbor Springs, Michigan passed away after a brave and valiant battle against myelofibrosis that began more than two years ago. Hanns Alfred Pielenz was born in Heilbronn, Germany on November 22, 1939. After a stint in banking, he returned to school and graduated from the Academy Hohenstein in 1963 in Textile Management-Engineering. He joined Amann/Ackermann Group, a regional textile business that was founded by his maternal great grandfather in 1854. From 1968 until his retirement in 2005, Mr. Pielenz was Chairman and CEO of the company and under his stewardship the provincial textile manufacturing company became a dominant and innovative leader in the global textile industry. Pielenz's contributions to the industry were recognized in 2009 as he was the first recipient of the Otto-Mecheels Medal for his contributions and innovations to the textile industry. While at the helm of Amann, he was also the Chairman of URS, an Atlanta based refrigerated warehouse company and commuted to Atlanta to manage the company. Under his visionary guidance, URS became one of the largest refrigerated warehouse companies in the US before he sold it in 1997. Knowing he would retire from Amann in 2005, he formed a family office in Atlanta, Georgia in 2000, HAP Investment Group, LLC, and used it as a platform for a multitude of investments including real estate, venture capital, angel investing for start-ups and minority ownership in operating companies. Pielenz loved business and was interested in any investment that provided the opportunity to create value as well as fuel his passion for knowledge and his acumen for business strategy. Pielenz was a brilliant business strategist with a personality and presence that was bigger than life. He loved people and they loved him as he left an indelible mark on everyone he interacted with over the years. He was a mentor to many in the business world and was always eager to provide input, guidance, and motivation though he always set high expectations and empowered people to reach them. He leaves behind a legacy few will fulfill in life as his business contributions provided jobs for thousands of people in many different businesses spread around the globe. His business creed was "Close ties to the customer and knowledge of the market are the essentials of business success. The secret is passion." This was not only the motto for his business but his philosophy for living his life as he was passionate about the things he valued. While business strategy was a passion, he dearly loved being in the woods, either hiking with his wife or hunting and he loved golf...though he admitted with pride that his wife was the better golfer. His greatest passion was his family, his wife of 45 years, Christa, who he always referred to as his sweetheart, his daughters, Nici and Katja, and his four grandchildren. Since his diagnosis in 2011, Pielenz worked tirelessly to fund, develop and coordinate resources to find a cure for myelofibrosis. While his efforts were not in time to change his destiny, his legacy will be to continue this research for all of the others suffering from this disease. Hanns Pielenz is survived by his wife, Christa Herzog Pielenz, his daughter Nicola Dowling (Colin), his daughter Katja White (Houston), and his grandchildren Maxie Klemm and Colin, Nicholas and Claire Dowling. The family would like to express its heartfelt appreciation to Dr. Srdan Verstovsek of MD Anderson as well as the entire team in the Leukemia Department who worked tirelessly to help not only Mr. Pielenz but his family on the journey as he battled myelofibrosis. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made in his memory to the MPN Clinical Research Center under the direction of Dr. Srdan Verstovsek, Department of Leukemia (Unit 428), The University of Texas MD Anderson Cancer Center, 1515 Holcombe Boulevard, Houston, Texas 77030 or The Boys and Girls Club of Vero Beach, 1729 17th Ave., Vero Beach, Florida 32960. A memorial service will be held in Vero Beach, Florida in the fall.

Founded and led the Latin American Art Department at Christie's International, retiring as Senior Vice President in 2000. Dear wife of the late John B. Brandreth. Beloved mother of Tonio (Barbara) Palmer and Helena (Stefan) Countess Gatterburg, cherished grandmother of Caroline, Damian, William, Henrik, Therese and Francesca. www.kellyfuneralhome.net.

NATHANSONEllen. The Department of Surgery Advisory Board at The Mount Sinai Medical Center mourns the loss of Ellen Nathanson, beloved mother of Board member and friend Caryn Zucker. NATHANSON--Ellen. Died Friday morning after a long illness. Lifelong resident of NYC. She attended James Madison High School in Midwood, where she met her devoted husband of 55 years, Carl. They both graduated from Brooklyn College. A schoolteacher, an advocate for children, women and civil rights, she was also a longtime champion to improve the conditions of NYC public schools. She later held the position of VP at Dime Savings Bank in their Community Affairs Department. When she retired from banking, she turned to her childhood passion of painting and was determined to begin a new career as an artist rep, selling emerging artists' works on the East End of Long Island. She continued as an art consultant for several years, until declining health made such work impossible. In addition to Carl, Ellen is survived by her three loving children, Michael, Caryn and Steven, their spouses, Tracy, Jeff and Debbie, and seven grandchildren, whom she adored. Service 12:30pm Monday at Temple Emanu-el at Fifth Ave and 65th Street. Burial will be private. She will be greatly missed.

MINCER--Flora Ruth Kaplan, M.D.,age 88, on June 20. Born July 29, 1924, in Philadelphia to Isador Kaplan, M.D., and Mollie Epstein Kaplan. Radiation oncologist (B.A., M.D., University of Pennsylvania) at Montefiore, Albert Einstein, and Calvary hospitals. Devoted wife of Professor Jacob Mincer (died 2006). Adored mother of Daniel (died 1981 from cardiac complications of Marfan Syndrome), Deborah, and Carolyn. Also survived by son-in-law Richard, beloved grandchildren Isaac and Nina, sister Judy, nephew Andrew. Will be remembered for her innate kindness, quick wit, and a passion for flowers, trees, and her sunsets over the Hudson. Donations: New York Botanical Garden or National Marfan Foundation.

MELNIKER--J. Harry, 92, Ben Jacob. Beloved and wonderful husband for 56 years of Margot, devoted father of Jill Roslyn and Lawrence Aron, loving PopPop of Brian Stuart and Haley Rose. A Graduate of the Columbia School of Business, he served in the Army Intelligence Corps in the Pacific during World War II. He spent his professional life in the furniture industry, which he loved, and has served as a Director and Officer of the New York Design Center for the last 20 years. He and Margot were avid travelers, visiting 85 countries from the Arctic to Antarctica. He loved the opera, concerts, and museums; and was a life-long philatelist. Harry loved the company of family and friends. Contributions to the Women's Auxiliary of Temple Emanu-El or your favorite charity will be appreciated.

MARWELL--Grace Glass. The Staff and Trustees of the Museum of Jewish Heritage A Living Memorial to the Holocaust are deeply saddened by the passing of Grace Marwell, beloved mother of our director, David. She was cherished as the core of a loving and generous clan, and took great pride in raising a family that embodied the values she held so dear. May her memory be a blessing. Our deepest condolences to David, Judy, Gabe, Nate and Haley, and the entire Marwell family. Robert M. Morgenthau, Chair

MARWELL--Grace G.,89, June 19 in Mt. Kisco, NY where she'd been a resident for more than 80 years. Born in Brooklyn to Joseph and Bessie Gerber Glass. Married to Edward M. Marwell who predeceased her. Survived by her children Stuart (Vicki), Emily, David (Judy) and Josh (Chitra), and eight grandchildren Nick (Margaret), Elizabeth, Nathan (Haley), Gabe, Tao, Jen, Toby and Anjali. She was a woman of keen intelligence, unfailing grace and playful wit. She is mourned and missed.

LYNCH--Owen M. PhD. Owen M. Lynch, PhD.,of New York City passed away peacefully on April 26, 2013. He was 82 years old. Owen was the Charles F. Noyes Professor of Anthropology at New York University from 1974 until his retirement in 2003. Previously he taught on the Anthropology faculty of SUNY Binghamton. His contributions to urban anthropology and to the study of the Dalit community, formerly known as Untouchables, emotions in Indian life and the politics of emancipation led to his recognition as one of the outstanding scholars of South Asia. His works demonstrated his personal belief that anthropology could be a force of social action and justice. He was a central figure in shaping both the anthropological community and the South Asianist community in New York City. He was loved and respected by his family, students and colleagues, not only for his professional work but for his generosity of time and spirit, his good humor, and his soft-spoken, wise and fully-engaged presence. He was a graduate of Brooklyn Prep, Fordham University and Columbia University. Owen is survived by his brother, John Lynch of East Rockaway, NY, his sister, Betty Dowling of Natrona Heights, PA, and seventeen nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held on Friday, October 25, 2013, at 12:00pm at The Faculty House of Columbia University, 64 Morningside Dr., New York.

LeVINE--David Eliot, 79, died June 3, 2013 in New York City after a brief illness. A graduate of Harvard College (1955) and Columbia Law School (1960), he served as a lieutenant in the United States Navy. Executive Director of the Dramatists Guild of America (1966-1993) and later of counsel to theatrical attorneys DaSilva & DaSilva, he represented theater professionals and appeared as an expert witness in contractual arbitrations on the East and West coasts. He was a member of the Tony Awards Administration Committee, a trustee of the T. Shreiber Studio and Eugene O'Neill Theater Center, and a founder of Broadway Cares/Equity Fights Aids. He is survived by his wife Barbara Grande and beloved cat Smokey. For donations: Bing Center for WM, Dana Farber Cancer Institute, Boston; Blood Bank and Stem Cell Processing Unit, Tufts Medical Center, Boston; The Humane Society.

JOHNSON--Rev. Stanley E. of Lafayette Hill, PA, died June 19, 2013, age 84. He is survived by his wife Sally, four children and six grandchildren. He graduated from Princeton University in 1950. Washington, PA.

HILL--Robert Anthony. 31 December 1927 11 June 2013. Beloved father, husband, grandfather, brother and friend. Bob spent his final weekend as he did countless others, laughing, dining out and engulfed in love by his large family before passing peacefully the following Tuesday. Bob was raised in Washington Heights, NY and discovered a passion for the stage at a young age. Upon discharge from the US Navy, Bob studied acting in NYC earning a scholarship to attend the Royal Academy of Dramatic Arts in London. Returning to New York, Bob performed many of the classics in regional theatre eventually reaching the Broadway stage working alongside Orson Welles in the 1956 production of King Lear. He also succeeded in the comedy genre on a full summer stock tour with Groucho Marx. He gained critical acclaim in a regional production of "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof". Bob married his adoring wife Marcia in 1962 and raised their six children on Long Island. He founded Hedgerow House in 1976, a preeminent publisher of American Folk Art. Semi-retiring to Boca West Country Club in 1989, he enjoyed golf, tennis, good friends and many memorable visits from his growing family. Bob lost his loving wife of 43 years on December 11, 2004. A true gentleman, Bob graced us with his charm and vibrancy; given the gift of laughter he was the life of any gathering with his rich, engaging stories. He displayed a youthful exuberance, even in his final days -often playing on the floor with his grandchildren. Whoever came into his orbit walked away with more, such was his seductive and sunny persona. He bestowed many gifts to his children and grandchildren with his love, kindness, warmth, charisma and enthusiasm for life. Robert is survived by his devoted wife Maxyne, his children Mardi, Karen (Chris), Wendy (Howie), Gina, Bobby (Katie), and Gary (Amy), his grandchildren, Gavin, Lauren, Sophia, Michael, Emma, Megan, Aidan, Brigid, Dylan, Donovan and Daniella, his loving brother Donald, sister-in-law Rosemary, three nieces and one nephew. Dear brother of the late Joseph Hill and brother-in-law to the late Lillian Hill. We will hold you in our hearts forever. There was no one like you, Dad. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory to Hospice by the Sea, Boca Raton.

GOTTHELF--Toby. (1927-2013), beloved daughter of Goldie and Jack Solow, brought up in the Bronx, overlooking Yankee stadium. graduated Taft high school and NYU 1949 majoring in political science. Divorced spouse of the late Theodore J. Gotthelf, incredible mother of Terri, Tommy and Tia; caring step-mother of Nicole and Eric, adoring grandmother of five amazing boys: Tyler, Teddy, Tucker, Wyatt and Levi, loving mother-in-law to Will Obering and to Debbie Gotthelf. Toby's house with its neon Club Toby sign welcomed friends, family and neighbors where food, sweets and love were plentiful. Avid sports fan, bridge master, tennis player, who embraced the energy of New York City. Toby enjoyed boating and the love of the sea. She was an adventurous, fearless traveller who explored the globe extensively with her family. Her life was dedicated to her children, family and friends. Funeral services will be held noon, June 25th at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd, in Manhasset. She will be buried next to her beloved daughter Terri. Now they will be together forever.

GRAETZER--Pamela & Kurt. Pamela (Morrell) aged 63, and Kurt S. aged 66, husband and wife, of Tidy Island, Bradenton, FL and formerly of Allendale, NJ and Tuxedo Park, NY, died in a motor vehicle accident in Mary Esther, FL on Thursday, June 13, 2013. Pamela was the former CEO of Graetzer Communications Corp of Allendale, NJ and more recently a realtor in Florida. Kurt, a Vietnam Veteran, was the retired CEO of MILKPEP famous for the "Got Milk" marketing campaign. Pamela is survived by her son Jesse Tennant and wife Liza. And Kurt by his brothers Peter, Eric and Tony. A Memorial Service is to be held at St. Mary's Episcopal Church, Tuxedo Park on Friday, June 28 at 11am. GEDNEY--Joann. 88, a long-time resident of the East Village, died at home in her sleep on Thursday, the 20th of June. Born in 1925, she was an Abstract Expressionist painter and sculptor. During the '50s and '60s, she was a founding member of the March Gallery, one of the Tenth Street cooperative galleries. Art was her life and she was passionate about it always. She also loved animals and believed that God could be found in the eyes of a dog. She will be missed by her sisters Dr. Judith G. Tobin of Seaford, DE, Dr. Marion J. Gedney of Manhattan and her brother Stanley L. Gedney III of Pearl River, NY, her nieces and nephews and their children. Box 1147, New York, NY 10276-1147.

FELDESMAN--Walter, on June 22, 2013. Beloved husband of the late Lucille. FARBER--Sam. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the American Folk Art Museum mourn the passing of our great friend and supporter, Sam Farber, who served as a trustee from 1996-2005, and thereafter, served as trustee emeritus. Sam was a driving force behind the formation of the Museum's Contemporary Center; he was also the person most responsible for the establishment of the Henry Darger Study Center. A disciplined thinker, thoughtful, calm, yet persevering, Sam took on many tasks that others avoided, managing projects and cultivating relationships on behalf of the Museum. He served tirelessly as head of the Building Committee and oversaw the construction at 45 West 53rd Street. His leadership and financial generosity allowed the Museum to pursue ideas and ventures that otherwise would not have been possible. A passionate and avid collector of art brut and art of the self-taught, Sam gave important works to the Museum, which greatly enhanced the collection, and also lent his own works generously, helping to raise awareness of and educate the public about this art. We were inspired by him and will continue to be inspired by his vision for what the Museum could be. He was a man of style, grace, humility, and intellect. He will be sorely missed. The Farber family has asked that contributions in his memory be made to the American Folk Art Museum, Administrative Office, 1865 Broadway, 11th Floor, New York, NY 10023.

ERWIN--Jean Sindelka, died peacefully in her sleep on May 10, 2013 at the age of 92. She was the widow, since May 1966, of Otakar Stanley Sindelka Erwin. She was the daughter of Senator Austin W. Erwin and Ruth Chase Erwin of Geneseo, NY. She was dearly loved by her family and friends. She will be greatly missed and well-remembered. She is survived by her three children, John S. Erwin, Jeanne Linnes of New York City, Austin Erwin of London, and five grandchildren Schuyler and Alexa Linnes and Adrian, Kristine and Robert Erwin.

ELLMAN--Lawrence (Larry), died Monday at Mt Sinai Hospital at the age at 86. He was an innovative restaurateur who created many theme restaurants, among them The Cattleman, Steak and Brew, and Beefsteak Charlie. He is survived by his wife Kitty LaPerriere, sister Lyn, children Kevin (Ruth), Nikki, Sean (Dani), Eden (Larry), six grandchildren and step-daughter Melanie. Larry was a generous, life affirming, adventurous man whose heart lived in music. His loving presence will be deeply missed.

EDDY--Rev. Norman. June 21, 2013 Loving husband of the late Rev. Dr. Margaret Ruth Eddy, loving father of Rebecca Eddy Feuerstein, Tim Eddy, and Martha Eddy, loving grandfather and great-grandfather. Born in New Britain, CT in 1920, he was a WWII veteran, joining the American Field Service as a volunteer ambulance driver after Pearl Harbor. He was attached to the British 8th Army through the war. A graduate of Yale, '42, he went to Union Theological Seminary. He was an early member of the East Harlem Protestant Parish group ministry and co-pastor with his wife of the East 100th St. Church. He was a pioneer in the treatment of narcotics addicts; in urban renewal housing as conceived by the residents of East Harlem, and community organizing with a spiritual foundation. He was a founder of the East Harlem Narcotics Committee; the Metro North Citizen's Committee; East Harlem Interfaith; the East Harlem Credit Union, the East Harlem Urban Center, and a founder of the Association of Neighborhood Housing Developers. He was a mentor to many. He constantly challenged people to live their lives guided by the Holy Spirit. Wake and viewing on Friday, June 28, 5-8pm at Church of the Resurrection 325 E. 101 St., New York, NY. Funeral Service-June 29, 11am-Church of the Resurrection. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to: New York Theological Seminary Margaret and Norman Eddy Program Center for Spiritual Coordination and Community Well-being. 425 Riverside Drive, Suite 500 New York, NY 10115.

DUKES--Stella Marie, a longtime resident of Saddle River and Allendale, NJ, died on June 19 at age 86 after a brief illness. Born in New York City in 1926, her lifelong passions were her family, her faith and her art. Mrs. Dukes' interest in art was sparked by the gift of a brownie camera on her ninth birthday. She went on to become an accomplished painter, sculptor and photographer, whose work was frequently exhibited. She studied in New York at The New School, The Art Students League, and with John Howard Sanden at the Portrait Institute. Mrs. Dukes was active in the Ridgewood, NJ Art Association, the Ridgewood Art Institute, Salute to Women in the Arts, the Valley Hospital Auxiliary, and the Women's Club of Ridgewood. Mrs. Dukes was predeceased by her beloved husband of more than 47 years, Thaddeus (Ted) A. Dukes, an executive vice-president with Ingersoll-Rand, and by three sisters. She is survived by her sister Florence Lockwood of Jackson Heights, NY, her daughter Carol Browne of Greenwich, CT, and her son Douglas Dukes of Danville, CA. She is also survived by six grandchildren, Chris, Alex, David, and Will Browne, Craig Dukes and Sara Johnson; three great-grandchildren, Ella and Grace Browne and Jack Johnson; as well as many nieces and nephews; she was know affectionately to all as "Gigi." In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Stella Dukes Memorial Fund for the Arts, addressed to Mary Stampleman, The Allendale Community for Mature Living, 85 Harreton Road, Allendale, NJ 07401.

DEARING--Peter Grubb, 66, died peacefully after an 18-month battle with cancer on June 18th, at home in Manhattan. Born in 1947 in Louisville, KY, Peter graduated from St. George's School (Rhode Island) in 1965. He received a B.A. in history from Harvard in 1969, then joined the Navy, became a Lieutenant JG, and served for three years as Engineering Officer aboard the USS Van Voorhis, a destroyer escort. Peter earned a law degree from Case Western Reserve in 1975 and an MBA from Columbia in 1980. After early careers in law and advertising, Peter discovered his calling as an educator, and spent more than 20 rewarding years on the faculty at the Winston Preparatory School in the city, teaching learning disabled high school students. He is survived by his wife, Jeffrey Zeiler; son, Peter S. Dearing, daughter, Stewart C. Dearing all of New York City; and sister, Peggy Hooker, of New Canaan, CT. He was predeceased by his older brother, A. Chenault Dearing. There will be a private service at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in the city. Donations may be made in Peter's name to the National Down Syndrome Society in honor of his friend, Carson Goodwin.

CORYELL--Vincent H. Jr.,Advertising Television Producer, WWII Veteran, an Army squad leader who served in both the European and Pacific operations from 1943 to 1945, died of a stroke on April 6th at Glen Lake, Castleton, Vermont in a home owned by his family for generations. He was 87. Mr. Coryell started his career as an advertising television producer at the William Esty Co. before moving on to N.W. Ayer, Doyle Dane Bernbach and Ted Bates advertising agencies and was VP, Director of TV Production at McDonald Little and the Gardner Advertising Agency in St. Louis. Born in Brooklyn on September 11, 1925, Mr. Coryell was married to Winifred A. Ruskin, deceased. They had two children, Bradford V. Coryell, deceased. Vince Coryell is survived by Sheryl Coryell, a psychotherapist in the Bay Area.

Brown, III, nephew Melville Brown, and seven grandchildren. A Memorial Service celebrating his life will be held in The Community Church, 48 Briarcliff Road, Mountain Lakes on June 25th at 1:00pm For online condolences please visit codeymackeyfh.com. BROOKS--Russell. The partners of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy LLP mourn the passing of our friend and partner Russell Brooks, who passed away suddenly on June 8. He was 74. Russ joined Milbank in 1965, became a partner in 1973 and later served as Practice Group Leader of the Litigation Group. He was responsible for many high profile matters including antitrust litigation for The New York Stock Exchange and trusts & estates litigation such as the Doris Duke will contest and the Estate of Charles Shipman Payson. He also served as lead trial counsel in many major cases. Russ wrote and lectured frequently. He was a Fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers. He graduated from Dartmouth College and Columbia University School of Law, where he was a Harlan Fiske Stone Scholar. He previously taught at Columbia Law School. A public memorial service will be announced at a later date. Our deepest sympathies to Russ's wife Pat, his daughter Sarah and son Sam, and to his entire family.

BRODLIEB--Linda Nicole, on June 21, 2013. Beloved mother of Andrew and Samantha. Dear mother-in-law of Jacob Starnes. Loving sister of Robert Weinstein and Richard Treston. Services today 2pm at "Gutterman's", 8000 Jericho Tpk., Woodbury, L.I. Interment to follow at the New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, L.I.

BRAUNSTEIN--Michael, 67, of Columbus, OH, died at his home on Saturday, June 15, after a brief battle with pancreatic cancer. Michael was a loving husband, father and grandfather and an inventor, humorist, songwriter, and serial entrepreneur. Michael was born in Wooster, OH on September 22, 1945 to Carl and Sara Braunstein. Although born with a clubfoot, he surpassed his disability and he marched with the Wooster High School band in the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade. Michael also achieved national recognition as a champion debater. He graduated from Northwestern University in 1967 and from Harvard Business School in 1970. He first became an entrepreneur at age 19, when he launched a paper flower company that counted Neiman Marcus and Avis Rental Cars as clients. Upon returning to Ohio, he became a real estate syndicator and developer. In 1974, he founded Provident United Inc., a multi-family and retail property management company. In 1993, he developed Lane Woods Preserve, an 80 acre residential community which celebrates Colonial Revival American architecture. An avid golfer, he was a member of Scioto Country Club for over thirty years and the Muirfield Village Golf Club for over twenty. Michael's passion for bringing delight to others led to countless writings and inventions, most notably a line of lawn mowers and home furniture which adhered to a design principle he coined as "funny functionalism." His infectious smile will be missed by his surviving family: wife, Suzanne; children, Jordan (Brooke), and Whitney; grandchildren, Simone and Calvin; and sister, Carole Brown, of Tucson, AZ. A Memorial Service to celebrate his life will be held at Muirfield Village Golf Club, 5750 Memorial Drive, Dublin, OH on Saturday, June 29, 2013 at 6pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to continue his support of the Ponseti International Association at the University of Iowa: (www.ponseti.info) Michael would have wanted everyone to celebrate life and life at its absurdities, as he did every day. www.schoedinger.com

BLOOM--Lewis R.,born in New York City on December 26, 1924, died in Santa Barbara, California on June 18, 2013. Son of the late Mildred Rogers and Charles Bloom. He is survived by his sister, Betty Klausner of San Francisco and her entire family; his cousin Leslie Steinmetz of Santa Barbara; and his partner Clay Tedeschi.
BLOCK--Herman "Pip," born January 4, 1913, died June 20, 2013. Survived by loving children: Diane, Jeffrey, Elliot plus three grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. Private Services.

BAR--Ralph. On June 20, 2013, at 84. Beloved husband of Edith for 57 years. Father of Michael and Richard. Father-in-law of Mary and Claire. Grandfather of Russell, Emily, Justin and Samantha. Step-grandfather of Samuel and Jessica. Brother of Maurice, and brother-in-law of Marion and Didi. Predeceased by his beloved brother Adolphe. Uncle to all of his dear nieces and nephews. Born in Antwerp, Belgium and a Holocaust survivor. Founder and President of Facet Industries. Former President of the New York Diamond Dealers Club. One of the initial business ambassadors to China. In 2000, the Prince of Belgium bestowed the HRD Lodewijck van Bercken Diamond award for his lifetime commitment to the Antwerp World Diamond Center. We love you and we will miss your kindness, humor, wisdom and devotion to us all. Your spirit will always be with us. We are all better people because of you. Rest in peace. Services Monday 11:15am at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.
ARLAK--Stephen, 97. Graduated from NYU. Veteran of WWII. He worked for General Motors and the IRS in Manhattan. His pleasant disposition will be missed by all. Visit: www.legacy.com
