PIERCE--Patricia H. April 8, 1925 -December 31, 2012. Remembered and missed.

NOTTERMAN--Joseph Melvin, passed away on June 28, 2013 in Princeton, NJ. He was born in Brooklyn on January 14, 1923 and moved with his family with the first group of settlers to the New Deal Community of Roosevelt, New Jersey when he was thirteen. In Roosevelt, he was a paperboy and boy scout. He graduated from Trenton State College with Honors, served in the U.S. Army during World War II, and was a member of General MacArthur's staff in the Occupation Forces in Japan. After the War, he attended graduate school at Columbia University and received his PhD in Psychology in 1950. In 1947, Professor Notterman married his childhood sweetheart, Rebecca Feldsher. From 1956 to the present, the couple made their home in Hightstown, NJ on the farm where Rebecca grew up. He was Professor of Psychology at Princeton University, joining the faculty in 1956, and served as Chairman of the department during the 1960's. In addition to his work in Experimental Psychology at Princeton, he was also a trained psychoanalyst. His passions included farming, art collecting, travel, and his grandchildren. He is survived by his wife of 66 years, Rebecca Notterman, MD, his children Abby and Daniel, and four grandchildren. Funeral Services will be held at the Roosevelt Synagogue at 12:30pm on Sunday, June 30.

MILLER--Saul, On June 21, 2013 at age 90. Born in East New York on March 4, 1923. The "Lox Man", beloved son of Becky and Sam Miller, brother to Frances, Ruby, Florence, and Esther. A proud Navy veteran of WWII, and a loving uncle, great-uncle and great-great-uncle to 46 nieces and nephews, who loved him dearly. Saul had countless friends, whom he loved to "treat to care packages". His passions ranged from horse racing to smoked fish, as well as getting in a third or fourth mile in the neighborhood park, even at 90. His generosity and robust spirit will live on in all those he touched. He will be missed dearly, and his memory cherished.

McKENNA--Theresa. New Visions for Public Schools mourns the passing of our dear friend and former colleague, Theresa McKenna. Hughes President, New Visions for Public Schools

McKENNA--Theresa. With deep sorrow, Hudson Guild announces the untimely death of our colleague and friend, Theresa McKenna. As Director of Development and External Relations, Theresa made a tremendous mark on Hudson Guild. She lead the effort to rebuild the Guild's fundraising operation and dramatically increased support for our essential social and human services programs. Beyond her substantial skill and ability, Theresa embodied the joy, optimism and sense of possibility that exists at the Guild. She clearly relished her interactions with the children, teens and adults in our programs, and was as invested in the people at the Guild as she was in her job. Theresa was creative, tenacious and resourceful, and was forthright and reliable. Importantly, she was also always quick with a laugh. All of us at Hudson Guild are stunned by this news, and Theresa will truly be missed here. We share our sorrow with all those who loved Theresa, and whom she loved. Viewing is Sunday, June 30, 4-7pm, Riverside Memorial Chapel, Funeral Mass is Monday, July 1, 10am, Church of the Blessed Sacrament. Community Gathering, directly following funeral, at Hudson Guild. Family has indicated that, in lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hudson Guild.

MADELL--Dr. Warren, 91, of Lakewood Ranch, FL, passed away with George and Nancy at his side, Sunday, June 23, 2013, at Sarasota Memorial Hospital. He was born in the Bronx, NY, February 2, 1922. He was predeceased by his wife, Doris Piller Madell. He is survived by his daughter Nancy Turon and son-in-law, George Turon, Lakewood Ranch, FL; his granddaughter, Jennifer Lyn Charles, Larkspur, CA; and his brother, Dr. Harvey Madell, Wellington, FL. Dr. Madell graduated from New York University School of Medicine in 1946 and practiced OBGYN in Bay Shore, NY. He was also Chief of Obstetrics at Southside Hospital in Bay Shore. Dr. Madell and his wife Doris retired to The Fountains Country Club in Lake Worth, FL in 1984. He moved to Lakewood Ranch in 2012 to live with his daughter Nancy and his son-in-law, George. He was a kind, generous and wonderful man. He touched the lives of all who knew him in a very special way. He will be greatly missed but will always be in our hearts. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Heart Association.

MADDEN--Sydelle. Our condolences to Steve, John, and the Madden Family on the passing of their beloved mother. Our thoughts and prayers are with you during this time. Hector R. Romo, Silvia Villegas de Romo and all of the Shoe-Net personnel

LONG--Joan. On Thursday, June 20th, 2013 Joan D. Long relaxed her hold on the world she fiercely loved. A graduate of the Rhode Island School of Design, Columbia University, and Fordham University, Joan was a painter, ceramist, and dedicated recreational therapist. Joan was tender, elusive, practical, wildly inventive, and gave aesthetic consideration to all of her endeavors. She gently but relentlessly pushed for clarity in her work, in art, and in matters of the heart. Like Charlotte A. Cavatica, the noble spider of children's literature, Joan leaves a generation of descendants born of her encouragement and wise counsel. Dear friend, sister, cousin, and aunt, you are irreplaceable. A memorial service for Joan will be announced at a later date

KOLCHIN--Kate. Age 92, on June 25, 2013. Born Kate Weil in New York City in 1920, she married Ellis Kolchin, a mathematician at Columbia University, in 1940; they were a devoted couple until his death in 1991. Kate was a graduate of The Walden School, New York University, and Columbia University Teachers' College, where she specialized in early childhood education. She taught at schools including Reece and Calhoun before becoming a director of Head Start programs at two New York City centers and an Educational Consultant at the New York City Department of Health, working on licensing standards and regulations for the city's day care centers. After her retirement in 1985, she was an Adjunct Assistant Professor at City College, supervising student teachers. She devoted herself to advocacy for children as an NGO representative to UNICEF, and as a member of OMEP (World Organization for Early Childhood Education), the National Association for the Education of Young Children, the Citizens Committee for Children, and the Women's City Club. In recent years, she was active in the Morningside Village community organization. She is survived by her son Peter of Newark, DE, daughter Ellen Hardy of Prairie Village, KS, two grandsons, and a host of relatives, friends, and admirers, who will deeply miss her warmth, generosity, and engagement with life. A memorial will be held at a later date.

"A Celebration of her Life: Leslie Gillette Jackson" will take place at Truro Center for the Arts at Castle Hill, Truro, MA 02666, Saturday, August 3, 2013, between 2 and 4 pm.

ISRAEL--Joan Ross, found her freedom on June 23, 2013. Caring and inspiring ex-wife of Justin, mother of Johnny, Lynn, ex-husband, Jon, Diane and partner, Lindsey, Rob and wife, Renee; grandmother of Jorin, Avi, Mason, Caden, and Kyla. Graduate of Sarah Lawrence College. Longtime Scarsdale, NY resident. Joan said, "In order to grow, one can't be timid...After raising and helping children to grow and stretch and be whatever they decided they wished, I turned to creating forms in rocks...I wanted to make a female statement, and yet when someone looked at my rock, I wanted them not to know if they had been done by a man or a woman; person art" Sculptor, painter, landscape designer, TV host, naturalist and birder. Courageous, visionary, honest, loving, vulnerable, elegant, beautiful, sensual, adventurer, athlete. She also said, "Be yourself, be free." Mom, fly free! In Joan's honor, donations can be made to ARC of Westchester. 265 Saw Mill River Road, Hawthorne, NY 10532.

HOLDERNESS--Sheila. Sheila Garvan Holderness, died last Sunday, June 23, 2013 at home in Brooklyn Heights, at the age of 73. Her death was unexpected but peaceful, and came upon her while she was engaged with her beloved Sunday New York Times crossword puzzle. She is survived by her loving daughters, Claire Crockett Holderness of Brooklyn, and Julia Simms Holderness of Cambridge, Mass., and her grandchildren, Soroush Crockett Vakhshoori and Shahrzad Holderness Vakhshoori, also of Cambridge. Sheila was born in Chicago on October 19, 1939 to Lucy Janis Garvan and Thomas Garvan, a police detective. The first person in her family to graduate from high school, she attended Trinity College in Washington, D.C. on a full scholarship, and then won a prestigious Woodrow Wilson Fellowship, which she used to earn an M. Phil. in American Studies at Yale. One of the few female students at Yale at the time, she throve. Following her marriage to Algernon Sidney Holderness, Jr., Sheila moved from New Haven to New York and exchanged academia for a busy life of motherhood and volunteering. She was moved by a deep concern for people in need, in particular girls, women, and recent immigrants. She sat on the national boards of Girls Incorporated and the Association of Junior Leagues, among others; locally, she sat on the boards of the Brooklyn Historical Society, the Brooklyn Hospital Center, Colony-South Brooklyn Houses, the Packer Collegiate Institute, the Junior League of Brooklyn (of which she was President), and the Korean-American Family Service Center. In her mid forties, Sheila began working full-time. She was Executive Director of the New York Women's Foundation, and later directed development at the NOW Legal Defense and Education Fund, New York Immigration Coalition, and Girl Scouts Council of Greater New York. She was a mentor to her younger colleagues and a friend to many, including the ladies of Mrs. Field's Literary Society, a Brooklyn Heights institution of which she was a member for forty years. As busy as she was, Sheila read voraciously. She travelled the globe. She loved gardening, the arts, and animals, especially baby animals, and she vied with human children for a chance to pet them at the springtime farmers' market. More than anything, Sheila loved her family. Sheila Holderness was brilliant, witty, passionate, fierce, stubborn, and constantly curious. She would deny herself without hesitation, if it meant that she could help someone she cared about. She was a loving, generous mother and grandmother. She was a self-made woman in every respect, steady in her response to life's ups and downs. She always landed on her feet. A memorial service for Sheila will be held in the fall (details to follow). Donations may be made in Sheila's memory to Girls Incorporated: www.girlsinc.org or 120 Wall Street, New York, NY 10005; (212) 509-2000.

HERSHBAIN--Frances (nee Gutelewitz), on June 24, 2013 at age 102. Predeceased by husband Max. Survived by children Richard Hershbain and Judy Greenstein. Beloved grandchildren, Mark and Esta Greenstein, Jennifer Greenstein and Zoe Bermet, Sharon and Mark Papagni. Adored great-grandchildren, Stefani and Jenna Greenstein, Jessica and Stephen Papagni. HALPERN--Madelyn Ann, beloved mother, grandmother, sister, aunt, friend, died Friday, June 28, 2013 at age 79. Madelyn is survived by her six children, thirteen grandchildren, sister, nieces and nephews. Madelyn was creative, beautiful, brilliant and passionate. Her professional teaching career spanned over 20 years. Madelyn was a truly wonderful woman and will be missed greatly by all who knew her. For information please contact Hellman Memorial Chapels at 845-356-8600.

GUTCHEON--Jeffrey. Composer, arranger, songwriter, author, designer and architect, died in New York on June 23d following a long struggle with Lewy body dementia. Born in New York City in 1941, Jeffrey was Phi Beta Kappa at Amherst College, then earned a B. Arch from MIT. He played piano and organ in many styles (rock, country, gospel), and performed and recorded with, among others, Gladys Knight, Willie Nelson, Steve Goodman, Ringo Starr, Great Speckled Bird, and Geoff and Maria Muldaur. The album he released with his band Hungry Chuck (Bearsville records, 1972) has achieved cult status, the subject of numerous bootlegs and re-issues. He designed recording studios, most notably the Hit Factory on 48th St. He was one of the great stride piano players of his generation, and the original musical director of Ain't Misbehavin' the first hit non-book musical, which won the Tony award for Best Musical 1978. A polymath, he was also a force in the American art quilt movement, and authored or co-authored several iconic books on the subject. Jeffrey designed and distributed innovative fabric patterns for two decades through his company, Gutcheon Patchworks, and taught quilting and fabric arts to fans around the world. He served as president of the board of the Haystack Mountain School of Crafts in Deer Isle, Maine and is a member of the Quilters' Hall of Fame. He recorded four albums with the Texas band Lost Country before declining health forced his retirement. He is survived by his son David Gutcheon, his sister Peppi Graves, Ed Graves and his niece Lucy Graves, and is mourned by extended family and friends from the many worlds in which he lived his life. A memorial will be held in New York in the fall, and donations may be made in his honor to The Jeffrey D. Gutcheon 1962 Music Fund by contacting the Amherst College Development Office.

GUMPORT--Margot Loebl. The Dalton School is deeply saddened by the passing of Margot Gumport, a faculty member for over fifty years, an alumna, former parent and grandparent. Margot possessed a profound passion and commitment to our school. We have lost a beloved member of our Dalton community. We extend our condolences to the Gumport family. Ellen C. Stein Head of School

GUMPORT--Margot Loebl, a high school science teacher at the Dalton school for over 50 years and widow of Dr. Stephen L. Gumport, died peacefully at home following a brief illness aged 89 on June 28 with her children at her side. Mrs. Gumport attended the Dalton school (Class of 1941), Bennington College (Class of 1945), and did graduate work in biochemistry at Columbia University. From 1947 to 1948 she worked as an assistant in biochemistry at Memorial Hospital and for the next decade she did biochemical research at Cornell Medical School. She returned to Dalton in 1959 as a teacher. During her Dalton career she taught chemistry, biology, physics, and French and served for many years as the chair of the science department and dean of the high school. Mrs. Gumport retired from teaching at Dalton in January of this year. In addition to teaching, Mrs. Gumport was formerly president of National New York Packing and Shipping Company, a shipping and expediting company founded by her father, Andrew W. Loebl. Her mother, the former Florence Weinberg, was an artist. The family is particularly grateful for the loving care provided throughout Margot's last days by her helper of many years, Angela Mariussi. She was predeceased by her youngest son, Daniel, and survived by sons Leonard, Michael, and Jonathan, nine grandchildren, and her god-daughter Liza Kronenberger Wanklyn. In lieu of flowers, her family suggests donations be made to The Dalton School. A memorial service is being planned for September.
GRENKER--Louise. Nanny, thinking of you always. And to quote Barry "Here's proof that if you live long enough, anything is possible." Love, Sara, Yasmine, Nahid & Nik

GREENFELD--Sandra. January 1, 1926-June 27, 2013. The life of the party. Survived by husband, Dr. Harry Garbus, children Dale Greenfeld (Patrick Cunningham) Henry Greenfeld (Melea) and grandchildren Hannah and Ashley. Predeceased by loving husband and father, Aaron Greenfeld. Service Sunday, June 30, 11:30am, Boulevard-Riverside-Hewlett Chapel, Hewlett, NY.

FIELDS--Janet, 54, courageous and beloved daughter of Suzanne and Stephen Fields, adored sister of Nancy and Jon Bauer and Ken and Maria Fields and loving aunt of Jeff and Laura Bauer, Sarah, Haley, and Greig Fields. Funeral Service 11am Sunday, June 30, 2013 at Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 East Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, NY 10543. 914-381-1809.

FADEM--Jessica Ann. August 4, 1958-June 26, 2013. Mother of beloved son Samuel Jack Horowitz. Treasured daughter of Rhoda Fadem Ashley. Mourned by loving siblings Randall E. Fadem, Leslie K. Fadem (Greg Childs), Pamela S. Fadem, David A. Jonas (Susannah), Julian J. Jonas (Kazuko), Barbara J. Ashley, Karin L. Ashley (Dan Roth), Peter M. Horowitz (Sam's dad), and by cousins Wendy and Paul Mlinar. And by nieces and nephews Adam and Jessie, Isao and Julia, Emma, Rose and Adam, Hanae, and Alex. Touched all who knew her with her wit, generous heart and joyous laugh. Dancer, foodie, voracious reader, homeopath, enthusiastic gardener, cat lover, and all around wonderful person. The world has lost a great treasure. Donations in her memory may be made to: www.calvaryhospital.org (designate donations to the Brooklyn hospice). A private memorial will be held in the future.

ERLEBACHER--Martha Mayer, age 75, of Elkins Park, Pensylvannia, died on June 22, 2013. She was devoted wife of the late Walter S. Erlebacher and the loving mother of Adrian Erlebacher and Jonah Erlebacher. She is also survived by her brother, Edward Mayer, and by four grandchildren. Services will be private. Memorial contributions may be made to the New York Academy of Art, for the Martha and Walter Erlebacher Scholarship Fund. (www.nyaa.edu). Baron Rowland Funeral Home (www.baronrowlandfh.com)

EPSTEIN--Tillie. Born Tillie Schwartz on November 1, 1920. Passed on June 24, 2013 at the youthful age of 92. Affectionate, dedicated mother to Phillip, Nathaniel, and Joseph. Loving wife to Sol. Vibrant grandmother to Cheryl, Melissa, Samantha, and Benjamin. Beloved sister to Rose and Stanley. Compassionate aunt to Rita, Bernard, Harriet, Martha, Leonard, Joe, and Michael. She was a teacher, an artist, a caretaker, and a master bridge player. The most unbelievable person we will ever know. She touched the life of every person she crossed paths with, no matter how fleetingly. She loved everything about life. She will be genuinely missed.

EISNER--Natalie Iris, 91, died February 21, 2013. Natalie was born September 28, 1921 to the late Anna and Nathan Shorser in New York. She resided much of her life with her beloved late Edward J. Eisner in Fort Lee, NJ before they moved to Palm City, FL. Natalie and Ed enjoyed more than 50 years of marriage. No one was more devoted. Natalie is survived by her son Bart Eisner (and wife Trish), daughter Jill Lewis (and husband Joseph M.), and four grandchildren: Adam Siegal (and wife Robin), Chris Siegal (and wife Pat), Nicole Sodoma (and husband Ron), and Blaine Eisner. She also had eight beautiful great grandchildren. Natalie cherished her family and friends through whom her spirit, kindness, and loyalty live. A small private service in her honor will be held on Tuesday, July 2, 2013 at 11:30am at Cedar Park and Beth El Cemeteries in Paramus, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to the American Cancer Society.

DUFFY--Jean Ann, 89, of Waterford, CT, daughter of the late Francis V. and Mary (Courtney) Duffy died on June 27th, at the William W. Backus Hospital in Norwich, CT. She was predeceased by her sister, M. Eileen Kelleher and brothers, Hugh V. and Francis P. Duffy and was a beloved aunt to nephew Michael F. Kelleher of Maryland, nieces Mary Courtney Kelleher of Connecticut, Edwina Duffy of Pennsylvania, Deborah Knecht and Barbara Chemidlin of New Jersey, Sara Ann Klemmer and Colleen Halloran of Mass, Jane Sobolov of New Hampshire, Deirdre Delmonte and Elaine Grimm of New York, Joyanne Simpson of Florida and Kathleen Belinga of South Carolina as well as to numerous great and great-great-nieces and nephews. Surviving also is sister-in-law, Dorothy (Dooley) Duffy of New Jersey. Throughout life, Jean was sustained by cherished friends, her faith, and a family to whom she always gave and received much love. Jean attended St. Angela Hall and Manhattanville College and resided in Brooklyn, Manhattan and Bronxville, NY as well as Stonington, Norwich and Waterford, CT. She retired after many years with Double-Dell Publishing in Manhattan. Volunteer work occupied her wherever she lived including at Westerly Hospital and Backus Hospital, and as a driver for Meals On Wheels and American Cancer Society's Road to Recovery Program. A Mass of Christian will be held on Monday, July 1st at 11am at Sacred Heart Church in Norwichtown, CT. Burial will be at Calvary Cemetery in Queens, NY at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Association of Retarded Citizens (ARC) of New London, 125 Sachem St. Norwich, CT 06360. The Cummings-Gagne Funeral Home is entrusted with the services. To share a condolence with the family, visit: www.cummings-gagnefh.com.

CORRIGAN--Robert J.,of Wilton, CT, passed away at his home on June 26, 2013. Born August 14, 1940 to Helen and Joseph Corrigan he was raised in Babylon, NY. A graduate of Seton Hall High School, he went on to receive a Bachelor of Science degree in Electrical Engineering from Manhattan College in 1962. He also held a Masters in Industrial Administration from Union College. During his 32-year career with IBM he assumed increasing responsibilities holding managerial positions in the U.S. and in France. Ultimately he became an IBM Vice President, and President and CEO of the IBM PC Company. Following his retirement from IBM in 1994, he was President and CEO of IMAX Corporation in Toronto, Canada. He is survived by Jeanne (Owens) his loving wife of 49 years. Their five sons and spouses: Robert Jr. (Julie), Timothy (Christine), Paul (Kellie), David, and Kevin (Carolina); 12 grandchildren: Shannon, Katie, Jack, Madeline, Thomas, Charlotte, Amelia, Harry, James, Norah, Oscar, Bella. Also, his brothers Michael Corrigan of Mattapoisett MA and Joseph Corrigan of Poughkeepsie, NY, a niece and two nephews. Visitation will be at Collins Funeral Home, 92 East Avenue, Norwalk, CT 203-866-0747 Saturday 4pm-8pm; Sunday 4pm-8pm. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 10am at Our Lady of Fatima Church, Route 7, Wilton, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to St. Francis Friends of the Poor, 155 W 22nd St., New York, NY 10114, Attn: Fr. John Felice.
CONNOLLY--Virginia Yates, wife of Eugene Thomas Connolly, died at home in Redding, CT on June 25, 2013.

CONNELLY--Thomas Maurice, III born September 16th, 1930 died peacefully on Nantucket, June 23, 2013. He was born in New York City, the son of Alice Craven Connelly Mara and Thomas M. Connelly, II. He attended All Hallows High School and the Taft School. He graduated from Yale College in 1952 and from Harvard Business School in 1957. He served in the US Army from 1953-1955. He was married to Fanny Alice Martin in 1954. The marriage ended in 1975. He married Margret Ward in 1982 who passed away in 2006. He is survived by his loving companion, Cam Dutton, his four children, their spouses and his seven grandchildren. Contributions can be made to Palliative & Supportive Care of Nantucket.

COLEMAN--Elisabeth. As VP of international public affairs at American Express for 14 years, Elisabeth was a strong, tireless leader whose global sensitivities (and finesse) set the standard. As a dear friend, she was compassionate, generous and funny, with a warm, winning smile and infectious laugh. Her style, grace and embrace of life inspired us and we miss her terribly. Her AmEx Friends

COLEMAN--Elisabeth, 68, of Manhattan, passed away on June 20 after a brief illness. Elisabeth, known to many as "Lala," began her career as a magazine researcher at Newsweek and was a plaintiff in the groundbreaking sex discrimination suit against the magazine in 1970. The suit launched her career as a journalist and television correspondent for KQED in San Francisco and ABC news. In 1976, then California Governor Jerry Brown appointed her as his press secretary, a post she held until 1978, when she married Rock Brynner, the son of actor Yul Brynner, and returned to New York. They subsequently divorced and she began a career in public relations and communications, initially with her own company, Coleman Productions, from 1984-88 and then at Ernst & Young as director of public relations from 1988-90. She joined American Express in 1990 and during her 14 years with the company, she worked around the globe, lived in Hong Kong for two years as head of Asian public affairs, and rose to be vice president of international public affairs and communications. She retired in 2004 and was writing a memoir at the time of her death. Lala was beloved by her brothers, Jack Coleman of Philadelphia, and Francis Coleman of Bloomfield, NY, her half-sister Sally Van Devanter of Westport, CT, her stepmother Elisabeth Laperouse Coleman of Themines, France, and her six nieces for her warmth, devotion and great sense of humor. She will also be deeply missed by her many friends from the media, the Tibetan Buddhist community, and many other walks of life. Funeral arrangements are private. A celebration of her life will be held and announced at a future date. Contributions in her memory may be made to Jewel Heart at www.jewelheart.org or the ASPCA at 424 E. 92nd St., New York, NY 10128.

CHAMI--Andree, 63 years old. Beloved daughter of the late Jean and Marie Chami, devoted sister, and cherished aunt. A dedicated and conscientious executive administrator in human resources , she worked at The United Nations for over thirty years. Andree was full of life and a world traveler, a lover of fine food and wine, an elegant dresser, devoted to staying fit, an avid opera and theatergoer, and a quintessential New Yorker. When attending the movies, which she often liked to do, she never failed to order a big bag of popcorn and a Diet Coke. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call Sunday, June 30, 2013 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, NYC 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Monday, July 1, 9:30am at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Ave at 66 St, NYC.

BOYUM--Asmund. On June 25, Asmund Boyum of Brooklyn Heights and Cornwall, Connecticut, passed away quietly in the company of his wife, Joy Gould Boyum, after a heroic battle with emphysema. Born in Norway's fjord country and educated at Trondheim University, he first came to America on a Fullbright grant in 1952 and remained to complete a doctorate at Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute. He married in l960 and settled in Brooklyn Heights, working first as a chemical engineer at Hydrocarbon Research and then at Englehard Industries where he rose to Vice President and General Manager of Catalytic Sales and the company's German affiliate. He had a wonderful life filled with family, travel, friends, and his two great passions, skiing and bridge. He is survived by his loving wife, the children and grandchildren he adored and was so proud of, David Boyum and his wife, Alexes Hazen, their children Spencer and Sydney, his daughter, Ingrid Ellen and her husband David Ellen, their children Audrey and Jacob, his sister-in-law Naomi Segall, and his extended, loving Norwegian and American families. Services are private.

BERKOVITCH--Boris Samuel, titan, wit, intellect, departed this world on May 23, 2013 in Santa Fe, NM. He was 92. Born in Odessa, Russia, he immigrated to New York as a boy with parents Samuel and Pauline (Kitaer) Berkovitch. He honed his vast knowledge of history at George Washington High School, earned his bachelor's degree at New York University, and enlisted in the US Marine Corps as a private in 1942. He attained the rank of Captain during two tours of duty that included combat at Roi-Namur in the Marshall Islands in 1944. He earned the LLB from Columbia Law School in 1949. After working in politics and as deputy superintendent of the New York State Department of Banking, Berkovitch joined Morgan Guaranty Trust Co. as a vice president in 1966. He retired in 1986 as vice chairman of the board. He enjoyed a 51-year marriage to Barbara Ellen Sinclair Berkovitch. Barbara pre-deceased him in 2011. He is survived by his loving daughter, Ellen Berkovitch, of Santa Fe, and stepdaughter Joanne VanAllsburg, of Dublin, Ohio. A celebration of his life will occur on July 20th in Santa Fe. Email eberkgm@gmail.com.

BECKER--Alma, 67, nationally recognized theater director, devoted wife and friend and influential instructor at Skidmore College Department of Theater died at her home in Saratoga Springs, NY on June 2, 2013, after a long illness. Alma's commitment to American playwriting was the main focus of her career for years. She was Resident Director at New Dramatists in New York City where she received the National Endowment for The Arts Directing Fellowship and Jerome Foundation Directing Grant and Resident Director at Eureka Theater of San Francisco (1978-1981); Bay Area Playwrights Festival in California and guest artist at numerous colleges and regional theaters. Her career path led her the east coast, then to San Francisco and finally back to New York City in 1981. She traveled extensively with her second husband, Steve Coats. In 1987, Ms. Becker was invited to direct at Skidmore, which began a 26 year relationship with the college. Alma is survived by her husband of 33 years and beloved nieces and nephews. She leaves behind an extraordinary legacy of mentoring, community service and a lifetime of devotion to Theater Arts. She was a beacon to all who knew her. Online remembrances may be made at: www.burkefuneral- home.com

AZARIA--Albert, was born in Harlem, NY 86 years ago. He was a resident of North Miami, FL for the past 35 years, formerly of Queens, NY. Mr. Azaria passed away on June 25, 2013 in his home. He attended one year of college at F.I.T. and he served our country in the Air Force from 1945-1946. Mr. Azaria was a dress manufacturer and the owner of the following companies, Sherwood Fashions, Samuel Scott, Simon Sez and A1Azaria, Inc. He was also a member of Alzheimer's Notables and the Sephardic Jewish Brotherhood. He will be deeply missed by his beloved wife Ruth Azaria (Altchek) for the past 62 years. He was a loving father of Stephanie Azaria, Elise Azaria and Hank (Katie) Azaria, cherished grandfather of Amanda Lane, Ethan Von Lindern, Molly Von Lindern and Hal Azaria. Chapel service on Friday June 28, 2011 12:00pm at Levitt-Weinstein 18840 W. Dixie Highway North Miami Beach, FL 33180, interment to follow at Menorah Gardens in Southwest Ranches. Contributions in his memory may be made to Season's Hospice 5200 NE 2nd Ave., Miami, FL 33137.

AUSTIN--Robbie. Once upon a time, about 66 years ago, there was a little boy named Robbie Austin, who was a hell-raiser but a sweet one, who made a lot of people laugh -- who went to summer camp and tamed a raccoon, and went in the cockpit of a fighter jet, and wasn't much good in school, except for writing, which he loved and wanted to do when he grew up (which he never quite did). And later he lived in Spain, like his hero Hemingway, and ate fresh figs, and chased a lot of girls. Later on, back in New York, he met the love of his life, Diane. They were together for over 30 years. He went into advertising, where he was a big success, and invented the slogan, "Everybody Doesn't Like Something, But Nobody Doesn't Like Sarah Lee". He loved advertising until he hated it, so he quit to be a writer, and then the hard times came, and never quite left, and he died too young, on June 3, 2013. He was a total original. Once you met him, you never forgot him. We never will, and will love him always -- especially Diane, Robin, and Gennaro, and Josh and Zack, and Sue and Steve, and Kenny and Nancy and Janet.

AHEARN--Joseph D.,on June 22, 2013, of Manhattan formerly of Brooklyn. Attorney and member of the N.Y.A.C. son of the late William and Juliette (nee Cahill). Brother of Juliette and the late William Jr. (the late Margaret), the late Elizabeth Flaherty (the late Joseph) and the late Thomas C. Uncle of Joseph Flaherty (Renee), granduncle of Kathleen and Joey. Godfather of Thomas Dockery, Ellen DeBlacker, Elizabeth Gregory and Raquel Loeper. Burial was in Calvary Cemetery.

PILCH--Todd David. 7/1/61 - 1/15/99. Happy Birthday in Heaven. We are all thinking of you today. You left us too soon. Missed you at the wedding. With all our love, Mom, Sue, Richard, Jackie and Josh
BOOKSTAVER--Doug (7/60- 7/30/92)/m. It's the laughter we will remember whenever we remember the way we were. Mumsie, Bobbi, and Julie
PIERCE--Patricia H. April 8, 1925 -December 31, 2012. Remembered and missed.

NARANJO--George, 62, of Forest Hills, NY passed away on June 29, 2013. A beloved husband, an inspiring brother and a most honorable man. A truly dedicated fitness professional. He had an unfailing commitment to his family, clients and everyone he touched. The world is less without him now.

MELAMED--Syma Krichefsky, on June 29 at age 90. The greatest! Predeceased by her husband, Lou, in 2005, she is survived by her children, Jill (Bernadette Flagler) and Fred (Leslee); Grandchildren, Lee and Alec; niece, Phyllis Sondes; Nephews, Ricky Kane, Benny Kane, Freddy Freifeld (Karen), Philip Freifeld (Helen); sister-in-law, Rhoda Kane; and many friends but three particularly special and dear ones: Rosie Tobias Shaw, Colette Mincu, and Jillieon Davids. She was also predeceased by her beloved siblings, Marty Kane and Sylvia Freifeld. The social and family nexus; the glue that held the glue together; a powerhouse, matriarch who will be tremendously missed.

MANDELL--Emily, 95, of Lynbrook, NY, beloved wife of the late Samuel, devoted mother and mother-in-law of Ellen and James Edmundson, Andrew and Marilyn Mandell, grandmother of Spencer. Funeral: July 1, at 10:30am, New Montefiore, Farmingdale, NY.

LONG--Joan. On Thursday, June 20th, 2013 Joan D. Long relaxed her hold on the world she fiercely loved. A graduate of the Rhode Island School of Design, Columbia University, and Fordham University, Joan was a painter, ceramist, and dedicated recreational therapist. Joan was tender, elusive, practical, wildly inventive, and gave aesthetic consideration to all of her endeavors. She gently but relentlessly pushed for clarity in her work, in art, and in matters of the heart. Like Charlotte A. Cavatica, the noble spider of children's literature, Joan leaves a generation of descendants born of her encouragement and wise counsel. Dear friend, sister, cousin, and aunt, you are irreplaceable. A memorial service for Joan will be announced at a later date
LIEBERMAN--Arthur Gerald. February 12, 1926 - June 22, 2013. Survived by wife Sherry, daughters Joy Sklaver, Dana Hofstetter, sister Lillian and five grandchildren. South Florida National Cemetery.

KAUFMAN--Lucille, on June 29, 2013. Beloved wife of Theodore (Ted). Wonderful mother of Stephen and mother-in-law of Liz. Cherished grandmother of Jaime and Lindsay. Services Tuesday, 1:30pm at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hunter College Foundation or the 92nd Street Y.

HAMERSCHLAG--Robert W. 89, died in Kenwood, CA, June 25. Born in NYC, he attended Friends School and NYU. He worked for the U.S.T.R. as a trade negotiator during the Kennedy and Tokyo rounds in Geneva, served as US Consul in Istanbul and as commercial attache for the US Department of State in Oslo, where he met his wife Lille. He leaves behind his wife, son Erik, daughter Kari and grandchildren Ole and Elsa.

GUMPORT--Margot Loebl, a high school science teacher at the Dalton school for over 50 years and widow of Dr. Stephen L. Gumport, died peacefully at home following a brief illness aged 89 on June 28 with her children at her side. Mrs. Gumport attended the Dalton school (Class of 1941), Bennington College (Class of 1945), and did graduate work in biochemistry at Columbia University. From 1947 to 1948 she worked as an assistant in biochemistry at Memorial Hospital and for the next decade she did biochemical research at Cornell Medical School. She returned to Dalton in 1959 as a teacher. During her Dalton career she taught chemistry, biology, physics, and French and served for many years as the chair of the science department and dean of the high school. Mrs. Gumport retired from teaching at Dalton in January of this year. In addition to teaching, Mrs. Gumport was formerly president of National New York Packing and Shipping Company, a shipping and expediting company founded by her father, Andrew W. Loebl. Her mother, the former Florence Weinberg, was an artist. The family is particularly grateful for the loving care provided throughout Margot's last days by her helper of many years, Angela Mariussi. She was predeceased by her youngest son, Daniel, and survived by sons Leonard, Michael, and Jonathan, nine grandchildren, and her god-daughter Liza Kronenberger Wanklyn. In lieu of flowers, her family suggests donations be made to The Dalton School. A memorial service is being planned for September.

GLAZER--Dr. William M. "Bill", March 31st, 1947- June 23rd, 2013. He died as he lived- with wisdom, clarity, courage and grace- surrounded by his Roz and their cherished children Aaron, Hilary and Jacob; daughters-in-law Dalia and Illana; and five grandchildren Solomon, DvorahLeah, Samuel, Isaac and Ziva. We will miss his guidence, humor and passion for life and all its blessings. Jill and Ken Iscol

FRAWLEY--Kathleen A. JD, MS, RHIA, FAHIMA, Devoted daughter of Kathleen and the late John. Beloved sister of John (Mary), Patrick, George (Eileen), James (Vicki), Thomas (Mary), Mary (Andrew) and Anne. Proud aunt to eleven nieces and nephews and one great-nephew. Kathleen was a highly respected and accomplished professional. She was Professor and Chair of the Health Information Technology program at DeVry University, New Brunswick, NJ and President of the American Health Information Management Association. Family will receive friends at Shook's Cedar Grove Funeral Home, 486 Pompton Ave., Cedar Grove, NJ on Monday and Tuesday 4-8pm. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, 11am at Our Lady of the Lake Church, Verona, NJ.

BERNATSCHKE--Wynne Miller, died peacefully on June 22nd in NYC. She was the niece of Glen Miller and an accomplished singer. She was also the devoted wife of the late Rudolf A. Bernatschke, a portrait artist. Wynne was a member of the Pen and Brush and the Friars clubs in New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to The Heritage Foundation, 214 Massachusetts Ave. NW. Washington, D.C. 20002.

KNOPF--Armand. Dearest Daddy, missing and loving you every day. S, B and J

COHEN--Elias A. Although 61 years have passed since our beloved founder, Elias A. Cohen, passed away on July 2, 1952, he is still remembered with love and reverence by the thousands of deserving boys and girls who were privileged to come to his Tranquillity Farm and Camp for a few fun filled weeks each summer since July 1st, 1919. In the spirit of Noblesse Oblige his devoted family, his many loyal friends and a grateful Alumni are all helping to perpetuate his Tranquillity Camp as a living monument to this great American humanitarian. We are proud to announce that Tranquillity is now celebrating its 95th year. Tranquillity Camp, Inc.Earlton, NY Richard Lawrence, President
COHEN--Elias A. Ever present in our thoughts, we lovingly recall our E.A.Cohen who left us 61 years ago on July 2, 1952. The Cohen Family The Elias A. Cohen Foundation

SMITH--Trudie, 80, a long-time New York Times employee, passed away on June 28th, 2013. She is survived by her husband Stanley Smith of Lake Ariel, PA, daughter Karen Singer of Forest Hills, NY and son Steven Smith of Lexington, NC, as well as her grandchildren Sophia, Abigail, Hannah, Zachary, Jordan and Sammy. Trudie came to the NY Times in 1965, following several years at the NY Herald Tribune. She worked first in Production, followed by the Employee Assistance and Idea Award programs. She left NYC after retiring in 1991 and lived in Lake Ariel, PA volunteering her time with several community groups, including the Hamlin, PA library. With a real sense of adventure, Trudie and Stanley left London on their honeymoon in 1952 for NYC. She remained close with her family in England. A strong and courageous woman, Trudie was also a two-time cancer survivor. She will be greatly missed by her family and countless friends. Services were held in Honesdale, PA on June 30th.

NARANJO--George, 62, of Forest Hills, NY passed away on June 29, 2013. A beloved husband, an inspiring brother and a most honorable man. A truly dedicated fitness professional. He had an unfailing commitment to his family, clients and everyone he touched. The world is less without him now.

MELAMED--Syma Krichefsky, on June 29 at age 90. The greatest! Predeceased by her husband, Lou, in 2005, she is survived by her children, Jill (Bernadette Flagler) and Fred (Leslee); Grandchildren, Lee and Alec; niece, Phyllis Sondes; Nephews, Ricky Kane, Benny Kane, Freddy Freifeld (Karen), Philip Freifeld (Helen); sister-in-law, Rhoda Kane; and many friends but three particularly special and dear ones: Rosie Tobias Shaw, Colette Mincu, and Jillieon Davids. She was also predeceased by her beloved siblings, Marty Kane and Sylvia Freifeld. The social and family nexus; the glue that held the glue together; a powerhouse, matriarch who will be tremendously missed.
KURZ--Jules. Beloved husband of Anne. Devoted father of Helene Boris and Gary Kurz. Adored grandpa of Mia, Addie and Nate.

KLIMERMAN--Dorothy, 95, on June 30, 2013, wife of the late David for 71 years; mother of Edward (Janet); grandmother of Allison (Mark), Caroline (Patrick), Matthew and Alex; great-grandmother of Jonah, Gabriel, Morrie and Regan. Services 12:30pm Wednesday at Sanctuary of Abraham & Sarah Mausoleum Chapel, Paramus, NJ.
KAZHDAN--Naum. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Naum Kazhdan, associated with The New York Times from May 24, 1982 until retiring on August 13, 2005.

KAUFMAN--Lucille. The Hunter College community mourns the loss of a dear friend, loyal alumna and generous benefactor. A founding member and past vice chair of the Hunter College Foundation, Lucille contributed her time and extraordinary service to Hunter. Our heartfelt condolences to her husband Ted; her son Stephen; her sister Barbara and their families. We will sorely miss her presence on our campus. Lisa Witten, Chair and Klara Silverstein, former Chair, Hunter College Foundation and Jennifer J. Raab President, Hunter College.

KAUFMAN Lucille. Shaaray Tefila records with deep sorrow the death of our longtime cherished member. Heartfelt condolences are extended to her husband Ted, son Stephen, and their loved ones. May her memory be for blessing. Rabbi Jonathan A. Stein Michael Starr, President

KAUFMAN--Lucille, on June 29, 2013. Beloved wife of Theodore (Ted). Wonderful mother of Stephen and mother-in-law of Liz. Cherished grandmother of Jaime and Lindsay. Services Tuesday, 1:30pm at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hunter College Foundation or the 92nd Street Y.

HAMERSCHLAG--Robert W. 89, died in Kenwood, CA, June 25. Born in NYC, he attended Friends School and NYU. He worked for the U.S.T.R. as a trade negotiator during the Kennedy and Tokyo rounds in Geneva, served as US Consul in Istanbul and as commercial attache for the US Department of State in Oslo, where he met his wife Lille. He leaves behind his wife, son Erik, daughter Kari and grandchildren Ole and Elsa.

HAAG--Audrey Lucille Summers, passed away on June 30, 2013 at 87. She was surrounded by her loving family. Born on Long Island, daughter of Willis M. and Lucy M. Summers, Audrey was a graduate of Adelphi University with a bachelor of science degree in nursing. She proudly served in the US Cadet Nurses Corps during WWII. A resident of Islip, New York, for more than 50 years, Audrey was active in many civic groups within her community. Audrey was best known on Long Island as owner of Puddle Duck Ltd., a high-end children's clothing boutique in West Islip. Audrey, with her business partner Jean Fleri Donahue, embarked on their new career in retail at the ages of 55. Audrey's sense of style and taste was undeniably visible on children of the South Shore for over 30 years. Audrey is survived by her children, daughter Jan and husband John Veryzer of Wellesley, MA, daughter Kathryn Clauss of Greenwich, CT, son Jon and Kelley Dominique of Oak Island, NC, son Larry Haag and wife Susan Fisher Haag of New York City, and daughter Martha Haag and spouse Jean Mills of Accord, NY. In addition, to her fifteen grandchildren, Christine Watt, Jennifer Sundstrom, John Hicinbothem, Bryan North-Clauss, Melissa Malone, Lindsay Sheehy, Ashley Clauss, Duncan Clauss, Ben Haag, Taylor Haag, Brendan Haag, Lauren Haag, Max Basch, Peter Basch, and Harrison Basch, she has twelve great grandchildren. Audrey will be missed for her strength of character, her grace, and most of all, her love of family.

GUMPORT--Margot Loebl, age 89, a high school science teacher at The Dalton School for over 50 years and widow of Dr. Stephen L. Gumport, died peacefully at home with her children at her side on June 28th following a brief illness. Margot graduated from The Dalton School ('41) and Bennington College ('45). She went on to study biochemistry at Columbia University, worked 1947-1948 as an assistant in biochemistry at Memorial Hospital and, for the next decade, did biochemical research at Cornell Medical School. She returned to Dalton in 1959 as Mrs. Gumport, a teacher. During her Dalton career, Mrs. Gumport taught chemistry, biology, physics, and French and served for many years as the chair of the science department and dean of the high school. In January of this year, Mrs. Gumport retired from Dalton. Margot's father, Andrew W. Loebl, founded National New York Packing and Shipping Company. Margot's mother, the former Florence Weinberg, was an artist. While teaching, Margot served as president of her father's firm and also as a director of National Screen Service Corporation. Margot was a New Yorker, and her happiest endeavor was building a family in her childhood city with her husband, Steve, a surgeon and professor at NYU. She is survived by sons Leonard of South Pasadena, CA (wife Wendy; children Anna, Tom, Mary), Michael of Summit, NJ (wife Pamela; children Alex, Max), and Jonathan of New York City (child Elizabeth). She was predeceased by her youngest son, Daniel, of Pasadena, CA (wife Nora; children Michelle, Nicole, Matthew). The family thanks all of Margot's friends, colleagues and students and especially Maggie Hamilton, Angela Mariussi, Dr. Daniel Roses, Rita Salzman and her son Jeffrey, Dr. Julia Smith, and Liza Kronenberger Wanklyn and her daughter Amy. In lieu of flowers, Margot's family suggests donations to The Dalton School. A memorial service is planned for September.

GLAZER--Dr. William M.,of Menemsha, MA and Key West, FL, died at home in Menemsha on Sunday, June 23 surrounded by his family. The cause of death was appendiceal cancer. Dr. Glazer was born March 31, 1947 to his parents Irma and Harry Glazer of Newington, CT. He graduated from Clark University in 1969, and the University of Connecticut School of Medicine in 1973. He completed his residency in psychiatry at Yale University in 1978. After completing his residency, he went into private practice and was the President of Glazer Medical Solutions. He was a clinician, researcher, lecturer, consultant and had been involved with continuing medical education since he began on the faculty of the Departments of Psychiatry first at Yale University (1978-1994) then at Harvard University (1994-2006). His research and teaching has generated the publication of hundreds of papers, chapters and multimedia educational materials. He lectured nationally for over 25 years on themes related to the diagnosis, treatment and management of severe and persistent psychiatric illnesses. He was a recognized expert in the areas of schizophrenia, tardive dyskinesia, managed care and psychpharmacology. He leaves behind his wife Roseline, children Aaron, Hilary and Jacob along with daughters-in-law Dalia, and Illana, grandchildren Solomon, DvorahLeah, Samuel, Isaac, and Ziva. He also leaves behind his father Harry, brother Dan and sister-in-law Paula. Dr. Glazer was Commodore of the Menemsha Pond Sailboat fleet for 20 years. He was loved and admired by many friends and colleagues on the Vineyard, Connecticut and Key West along with his patients for whom he cared very deeply. He looked forward to Vineyard summers as two-star general of his "Menemsha Army" of five grandchildren. Donations may be made in his name to Daybreak Clubhouse, Vineyard Haven, P.O. Box 1993, Vineyard Haven, MA 02568.

GEULA--Jessica, 42 years. It is with profound sorrow that we mourn our Jessica who left us too soon. She leaves behind her mother Roberta, father David, sisters Nikki (Damon) and Monica (Asher), her nieces and nephews, Chloe, Ryder, Tatiana and Austin. A beautiful force of nature, she will be missed but never forgotten. Burial will be in Miami. Family will receive condolence calls on Monday, July 8th at 5pm in New York at Park East Synagogue 164 East 68th St.

FREUND--Marcella Coleman. A remarkable woman. Born in New York City in 1907 and a lifelong resident, Marcy celebrated her 105th birthday last December, mental faculties intact and looking great (as in the photo above). For several decades, she partnered with her beloved husband of 45 years, Sylvan Freund, in running Decorative Plant Corp., the company that pioneered outdoor displays on Fifth Avenue and was responsible for the sculpted angels that are still the centerpiece of Rockefeller Center at Christmastime. Although widowed almost 40 years ago, Marcy continued to live a full and fruitful life right to the end, sustained by her strong faith in the Almighty. A talented artist, she was also an active participant in several continuing education programs and traveled on her own to numerous countries. On the occasion of Marcy's 105th birthday, President Obama wrote that she should "take pride in all you have accomplished," Governor Cuomo called her "an extraordinary individual," and Mayor Bloomberg said she was "an inspirational role model for us all." Marcy counseled and showered affection on her son, Jim, and grandsons, Erik and Tom, doted on her great-granddaughters, Delilah and Paige, and touched the lives of other family members and friends too numerous to mention. There's a big void in all our lives now, and we will miss her greatly. A service will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, Madison Avenue and 81st Street, at 11:30am on Monday, July 8th and her family will be receiving friends from 5-8 that evening at the home of Jim and Barbara Fox Freund. Contributions in Marcella Freund's memory may be made to Eighth Church of Christ, Scientist, 103 East 77th Street, NYC 10075.

FORCHHEIMER--Rudolph. The congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its longtime, devoted member and extends sympathy to his bereaved family. Helene K. Gray, President Jonathan E. Blake, Rabbi Jill Abramson, Cantor

FLANZER--Louis, died peacefully at home in Longboat Key Florida on June 30th, with his loving wife Gloria by his side. He was a man of many interests. Besides his steadfast love and devotion to Gloria, his wife of 66 years, he was a successful real estate developer and manager, businessman and a dedicated philanthropist. His philanthropic interests were varied, including hospitals and healthcare, substance abuse, and Jewish charities. Lou had a particular interest in building bridges between differing faiths and societies. He was a proud veteran of the United States Army and served the country honorably during World War II. Lou was fearless - he overcame his unease at flying by becoming a licensed pilot. A man of warmth and good cheer, Lou Flanzer was the consummate gentleman. He will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Services will be private.

FLANZER--Louis, 94, of Scarsdale, New York, and Longboat Key, Florida, died yesterday at his Florida home. Born in Brooklyn, he had a quick mind and an independent spirit, and at six years old he was invited to join his adult neighbors playing chess in the park. As a sergeant in the army during World WarII he refused a promotion to stay with his men. After the war he re-joined Flanzer & Son, expanding the business for his father and his brother-in-law. He later became a successful real estate investor and an avid golfer. Facing a fear of flying in the 1960's, he conquered it by learning to fly himself. He got his pilot's license and then gave flying lessons to both his children. His daughter, Jan Flanzer, and her daughter, Jessica Lerner, lovingly remember his wonderful sense of humor, his love of learning and travel, and his respect for truth. His huge smile and twinkling eyes lit up a room, and it was impossible not to smile along with him. He was always ready with a brilliant idea. His passion for the Brooklyn Dodgers survives today in his daughter and granddaughter as a true love of the game. His son, Richard, and Richard's children, David, Ryan, and Jordan Flanzer, will always recall his advice to pursue their dreams fearlessly and with determination. We remember him with tremendous love. He is in our hearts always.

COHEN--Barbara (Krames), July 11, 1938-July 1, 2013 of Newton, MA. Daughter of the late Claire and Abraham Krames. Beloved wife of Sanford Cohen for 54 years. Alumna of CCNY and Boston University. Elementary school teacher, gifted sculptor and avid reader. Passionate about progressive social causes. Above all, a devoted wife, mother and grandmother. A caring aunt, sister-in-law, cousin and friend. Dearly loved mother of Craig Cohen, Deborah Cohen and Lisa Russman. Devoted grandmother of Dara, Jared, Morgan, Benjamin, Abigail, Alyssa, Mia and Sadie. Cherished mother-in-law of Lara, George and Matthew. Her elegance, beauty and kindness was recognized and admired by all who knew her. She will be missed by all. Services at the Temple Shir Tikva, 141 Boston Post Road, Wayland, MA on Wednesday, July 3 at 1:00pm. Interment at Sharon Memorial Park, Sharon, MA. Memorial observance at the home of Deborah and George following the interment 5:30-8:00pm, Thursday 1-3pm and Friday 3-5pm. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to HHT Foundation (hht.org).

CHAVKIN--Muriel (Micky), age 90, of Verona, died July 1 due to complications from a recent fall. Micky will be missed by all those who knew her for her forthright and caring nature. She is survived by her son, Arnold, his wife, Laura and her many nieces and nephews of whom she was very fond. She was predeceased by her husband Saul and her daughter Terry. Graveside services will be Wednesday, July 3, 11am, Mt. Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, NJ.

CENTOLA--Gary Dennis, 64, beloved husband of Kathleen Gefell, died peacefully on June 30, 2013 at his home in Poughquag, NY surrounded by his family. Gary, a former Assistant District Attorney of New York City, was a partner at the law firm of Rivkin Radler. He will be remembered for his love of family and friends, his generous heart, his intelligence and humor, his love of music, and his amazing guitar leads. Gary is survived by his wife of 42 years, Kathleen Gefell, brother Ron (Anna), sister Elaine, and his beloved niece and nephew who loved him like a father, Jacqueline Sechler Klein (Danny) and Brian Clyde Sechler (Alexandra). He is also survived by nieces and nephews, Jennifer, Mark, Justin, Cory, Taylor, James, and Lily; four grand nieces and nephews, Oscar, Penelope, Tyler, and Charlotte; and a loving extended family of sisters and brothers-in-law, Patricia (Walter), Sharon (Kevin), Allen (Kathy), and Eileen (Richard). "He was and always will be our Patriarch." In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Sloan Kettering-Mesothelioma Research. Memorial services will be held on Friday, July 12th at 3:30pm at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amerstdam, Manhattan.

BEER--Murray. The officers and members of the Boards of Trustees of the Jewish Home Family note with profound sorrow the passing of our past Jewish Home at Rockleigh board member, long time supporter, and very dear friend, Murray Beer. Murray was a special person who helped many Jewish and communal causes, and made special commitments to helping the elderly in our community. He will be missed. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife Lovey, brother and sister-in-laws Paul and Malka and Arline Herman, his children Ingrid, Michele and Richard, James and his five beloved grandchildren. May his name be for a blessing. Eli Ungar, Chairman Charles P. Berkowitz, President and CEO

BEER--Murray L. We mourn the passing of our dear friend and long-time client, Murray Beer, adoring husband of Lovey, most caring father of Ingrid, Michele and Jimmy and beloved brother-in-law of our cherished partner, Paul Herman. We think that Murray always had a gleam in his eye because G-d lead him to find and marry Lovey, the love of his life. They made such beautiful music together for over 56 years and created a beautiful family that has always been all for one and one for all. We will always remember Murray as a very kind, sweet and compassionate person and we will miss him. We send our heartfelt condolences to Lovey, Paul and all of the members of the Beer/Herman families. Herrick, Feinstein LLP
BEER--Murray L. Loving and loved brother-in-law, whose dedication to family and community were exemplary. His love, humor and joie de vivre will be very much missed. Arline, Malka and Paul

BEER--Murray L. His adoring love of Aunt Lovey and family, along with his unflagging devotion to Israel and the Jewish community inspires us. We will always cherish the memory of his strong hugs and clever puns. Rachel, Andy, Murry, Tali and Josh

BEER--Murray L.,beloved husband of Lovey Beer nee Herman for 56 years, father and grandfather, passed away June 30th. Adoring son of the late Yetta and Henry Beer and beloved son-in-law of the late Miriam and Murry Herman. Brother of the late Beverly Belkin and Joan Baron. Brother-in-law of Malka and Paul Herman, Arline Herman and the late Howard Herman and Irvin Belkin. Father of Ingrid Beer, Michele Beer Chazkel, James Beer and father in law of Richard Chazkel. Founding Member Bergen County Lubavitch. Founder of Globe Mortgage Company. Private Shiva, no visitors please.

ACKLEY--Jim. Temple Shaaray Tefila records with deep sorrow the death of our longtime cherished member. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife Diane, daughter Rachel (Andrew) Borek, and their loved ones. May his memory be for blessing. Rabbi Jonathan A. Stein Michael Starr, President

STANBACK--Thomas Melville, III. Born April 9, 1950; died peacefully on June 29, 2013. SCHMIERER--Muriel, 89, of Jericho Long Island, died early Monday, July 1, 2013 at home. Devoted wife of the late Dr. Bernard Schmierer, loving mother of Dr. Edwin Schmierer, Mark Schmierer and Dr. Jeffrey Schmierer and their spouses. Adored grandmother of Michelle, Robyn, Benjamin, Rebecca, Jordana, Marissa, and Rachel; cherished great-grandmother of Aubrey. Born and raised in Brooklyn, Muriel was selflessly devoted to her family, for more than 50 years, an active Owner of Camp Starlight in Starlight, PA and for more than 50 years a devoted member and participant of the Jericho Jewish Center in Jericho, Long Island. May her memory be eternal. Funeral services were held at IJ Morris, Dix Hills on Tuesday, July 2, 2013 with interment at the Wellwood Cemetery in Pinelawn, NY. In Lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Muriel's name to Hope Lodge of the American Cancer Society, www.cancer.org, the Leukemia Society, www.lls.org, or to a charity of choice.

KLEINMAN--Abraham "Foxy", 93. Unrelenting in devotion to his Marjorie, bride of 73 years, loyalty and generosity to beloved children and grandchildren, with a warm quip for everyone else. Lisa Witten, Chair and Klara Silverstein, former Chair, Hunter College Foundation and Jennifer J. Raab, President, Hunter College.

JUSTER--Ann E.,58, of Harrison, NY. Died suddenly Sunday, June 30, 2013. Much loved daughter of Doris Juster and the late Martin W. Juster. Devoted mother to Michelle and Joshua. HOOD--Frederick Emmart. "Ted", 86, of Portsmouth, Rhode Island, an internationally heralded yachtsman, sail maker, yacht designer and builder, died Friday, June 28, 2013 surrounded by his family. He is survived by his beloved wife of 58 years, Susan Blake Hood; his children Richard Hood and wife Carroll McGrath Hood, Frederick Hood and wife Anne Vandromme-Hood, Robert Hood and wife Sarah Hood, and Nancy Hood-MacLeod and husband Norman MacLeod. In addition, the deceased leaves eight grandchildren: Helen, Stedman, Alex, Alyssa, Heidi and Benjamin Hood, and Skyelar and Taylor MacLeod. Brother Bruce Hood predeceased Ted. He also leaves his loving caregivers, Nancy and Kristy Neronha. Burial will be private. A celebration of Ted's life will be held in Newport later this summer. Full obituary and condolences available at: memorialfuneralhome.com.

HABER--Sylvia, a lifelong resident of Manhattan, passed away peacefully on July 1, 2013. She was the beloved wife of 70 years of Milton M. Haber. She is survived by her daughter Sarah and her husband Lester Fliegel of Westfield, NJ; her son Martin and his wife Irene Haber of New York, NY; her grandsons Bob and Len Fliegel and Doug Haber and his wife Fawn; as well as great-grandsons Tyler and Aidan Haber.

GUMPORT--Margot Loebl, age 89, a high school science teacher at The Dalton School for over 50 years and widow of Dr. Stephen L. Gumport, died peacefully at home with her children at her side on June 28th following a brief illness. Margot graduated from The Dalton School ('41) and Bennington College ('45). She went on to study biochemistry at Columbia University, worked 1947-1948 as an assistant in biochemistry at Memorial Hospital and, for the next decade, did biochemical research at Cornell Medical School. She returned to Dalton in 1959 as Mrs. Gumport, a teacher. During her Dalton career, Mrs. Gumport taught chemistry, biology, physics, and French and served for many years as the chair of the science department and dean of the high school. In January of this year, Mrs. Gumport retired from Dalton. Margot's father, Andrew W. Loebl, founded National New York Packing and Shipping Company. Margot's mother, the former Florence Weinberg, was an artist. While teaching, Margot served as president of her father's firm and also as a director of National Screen Service Corporation. Margot was a New Yorker, and her happiest endeavor was building a family in her childhood city with her husband, Steve, a surgeon and professor at NYU. She is survived by sons Leonard of South Pasadena, CA (wife Wendy; children Anna, Tom, Mary), Michael of Summit, NJ (wife Pamela; children Alex, Max), and Jonathan of New York City (child Elizabeth). She was predeceased by her youngest son, Daniel, of Pasadena, CA (wife Nora; children Michelle, Nicole, Matthew). The family thanks all of Margot's friends, colleagues and students and especially Maggie Hamilton, Angela Mariussi, Dr. Daniel Roses, Rita Salzman and her son Jeffrey, Dr. Julia Smith, and Liza Kronenberger Wanklyn and her daughter Amy. In lieu of flowers, Margot's family suggests donations to The Dalton School. A memorial service is planned for September.

GREEN--Murray, 90 years old, died on July 1, 2013. Beloved husband of Mae. Devoted father of Aileen and Stuart, Susan and Donald, and Eric and Iris. Cherished grandfather of Michel, Adam, Lara, Avery, Sarah and Andrew. Adored great-grandfather of Jackson and Tessa. Donations may be made to the Samuel Field YM & YWHA.

FREUND--Marcella Coleman. A remarkable woman. Born in New York City in 1907 and a lifelong resident, Marcy celebrated her 105th birthday last December, mental faculties intact and looking great (as in the photo above). For several decades, she partnered with her beloved husband of 45 years, Sylvan Freund, in running Decorative Plant Corp., the company that pioneered outdoor displays on Fifth Avenue and was responsible for the sculpted angels that are still the centerpiece of Rockefeller Center at Christmastime. Although widowed almost 40 years ago, Marcy continued to live a full and fruitful life right to the end, sustained by her strong faith in the Almighty. A talented artist, she was also an active participant in several continuing education programs and traveled on her own to numerous countries. On the occasion of Marcy's 105th birthday, President Obama wrote that she should "take pride in all you have accomplished," Governor Cuomo called her "an extraordinary individual," and Mayor Bloomberg said she was "an inspirational role model for us all." Marcy counseled and showered affection on her son, Jim, and grandsons, Erik and Tom, doted on her great-granddaughters, Delilah and Paige, and touched the lives of other family members and friends too numerous to mention. There's a big void in all our lives now, and we will miss her greatly. A service will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, Madison Avenue and 81st Street, at 11:30am on Monday, July 8th and her family will be receiving friends from 5-8 that evening at the home of Jim and Barbara Fox Freund. Contributions in Marcella Freund's memory may be made to Eighth Church of Christ, Scientist, 103 East 77th Street, NYC 10075.

FORCHHEIMER--Rudolph. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Mr. Rudolph Forchheimer of Rye, NY, a dedicated supporter of the Technion for more than three decades, and a past vice president of the ATS New York Metropolitan Region. The family foundation's support of the Technion has included the Forchheimer Foundation Endowment Fund, the Julia and Leo Forchheimer Student Dormitory, the Forchheimer Guest House, and the Leo and Julia Forchheimer Faculty Center. Together with his wife, Hilda, Mr. Forchheimer was a Technion Guardian, a designation reserved for those who have reached the highest level of commitment. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Scott Leemaster, President Joel S. Rothman, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President

FORCHHEIMER--Rudolph. The Leo and Julia Forchheimer Foundation mourns the passing of our long-time President, Rudolph Forchheimer. As a nephew of the founder, Leo Forchheimer, he served as an officer and director of the Foundation since its beginning. He was a strong supporter of Jewish causes both in the US and Israel and leaves a legacy of important charitable works. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Hilda, daughters, Audrey and Constance and their husbands and grandchildren. Michael G. Jesselson Barbara Kamen Donald A Hamburg Directors.

FLANZER--Louis. We mourn the loss of our dear friend Louis Flanzer. Lou was a fine man who was fiercely loyal to those he loved and cared for and will be greatly missed. He was passionate in his interests in business as well as his relish for Longboat Key, philanthropy, travel, golf, cars and most importantly, his love of his wife Gloria. He was always anxious to share with others, be it his broad experiences or his hobbies and was always committed to honesty and fairness to people of all stripes. He was interested in people and not their labels. He unselfishly shared his advice when sought and his good fortune for the greater good of humanity. He handled life's successes and setbacks with equanimity, setting a fine example for those inclined to learn from him. His passing leaves a void that will hopefully be filled with the warm memories of better times. Our deepest sympathy to his devoted wife Gloria, his sister Beatrice and all others who loved him. Marcia & Eric Kaplan

FLANZER--Louis, Columbia University Medical Center mourns the passing of our friend Louis Flanzer. As benefactors of our university, he and his wife, Gloria, have had an extraordinary impact on our work in cardiology and ophthalmology. All of us at Columbia are deeply grateful for his generosity, and offer our condolences to his family. Lee Goldman, MD Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine and Executive Vice President, Columbia University Allan Schwartz, MD Chief, Division of Cardiology Vice Chair, Department of Medicine

FLANZER--Louis. The Board of Directors, management and staff of White Plains Hospital mourn with extreme sorrow the passing of our dear friend, board member and benefactor, Mr. Louis Flanzer. For more than 30 years, his support and inspirational leadership helped to create the Flanzer Pavilion and the Flanzer Center for Emergencies and Critical Care. His endearing nature and warm spirit will be missed by all of us. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his beloved wife, Gloria and their entire family. J. Michael Divney, Chairman of the Board Jon B. Schandler, CEO Susan Fox, President

FLANZER--Louis, died peacefully at home in Longboat Key Florida on June 30th, with his loving wife Gloria by his side. He was a man of many interests. Besides his steadfast love and devotion to Gloria, his wife of 66 years, he was a successful real estate developer and manager, businessman and a dedicated philanthropist. His philanthropic interests were varied, including hospitals and healthcare, substance abuse, and Jewish charities. Lou had a particular interest in building bridges between differing faiths and societies. He was a proud veteran of the United States Army and served the country honorably during World War II. Lou was fearless - he overcame his unease at flying by becoming a licensed pilot. A man of warmth and good cheer, Lou Flanzer was the consummate gentleman. He will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Services will be private.
