HAGENDORF--Scott. 1958 - 2006 Happy Birthday Baby Brother. Not a day goes by that we don't think of you, miss you, love you. In our hearts you will remain "Forever Young" "What's up with That"? Your Loving Family

THAU--Irving J.,74, of Pacific Palisades, CA, passed away peacefully at home surrounded by his two sons after he bravely confronted and fought a battle with Pancreatic Cancer. Irving will be remembered by the many lives he touched. Born Irving Joseph Thau on June 14, 1939 in New York City. He graduated from CCNY with a bachelors degree in accounting. Irving's passion for numbers and brilliant mind lead him to a distinguished career as a CPA and business executive that spanned over 50 years in both New York and Los Angeles. Irving was a devoted and loving husband, father and grandfather, as well as a treasured friend. His boundless love for his family, passion for golf, love of travel, generosity, kindness and integrity inspired all who knew him. Irving was a true gentleman with impeccable taste, an appreciation for the arts and an unwavering love for his family. He is survived by his sons Andrew and David Thau; daughters in law, Rachel and Christina Thau; grandchildren, Jake, Julia, Maxwell and Alexandra of Los Angeles, CA; and sister, Beverly Gracy of New York.

ROGERS--Babette Block, of Ticonderoga, NY died peacefully on July 2, 2013, survived by her loving husband of 48 years, Michael Rogers, and her devoted sons, John K. Urice and Stephen K. Urice. A memorial service will be held later this summer.

McSHANE--Terence F. Author of "The Death of Jimmy Hoffa," died June 28 in Naples Florida. Born October 22, 1927 in NYC to Felix Jerome and Lillian Donnelly McShane. Predeceased by sister Alice Charoglu; brothers John, Joseph, Gerard and Jimmy. Graduate Cardinal Hayes. Was St. Bonaventure University National Alumni Association President and member Board of Trustees. WWII Navy Vet. FBI investigator of Jimmy Hoffa for a decade, then Chairman of the Board of Monitors of the IBT (Teamsters Union.) President of Trustee Management Inc., a SEC Investment firm. Director/Vice President levels of Hayden, Stone Inc., Blyth & Co., Wertheim & Co. Dillon Read & Co., and Greenspan O'Neil (Alan Greenspan's private investment, economic advisory firm.) Surviving are his wife Mary Lockwood, children Terry (Hilary), DeeDee Crouch (Michael), Dru Moeller (Steven), Casey (Melissa), nine grandchildren, two great-grandchildren. Donations in his memory to The University Glee Club of NYC. Inurnment will be in the Columbarium of Arlington National Cemetery.

MAYER--William D.,78 years old, died on July 2nd. Beloved father of Debbie and Sandy, and father-in-law of Jimmy Roberts; Proud papa of Jackson, Aidan, and Daniel Roberts; Loving partner of Carol Brecher; Devoted brother of Marion J. Rosley. We will forever miss your optimism, humor, enthusiasm, and love of life. A Memorial Gathering will take place at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., this Monday and Tuesday evening, July 8th and 9th from 6:00-8:30pm. Contributions in his memory may be made to NYU School of Medicine.

MACK--Ilene. August 27, 1938 - July 3, 2013. Loving mother, grandmother and sister. Deeply beloved by all her family and friends. Services will be held at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel 630 Amsterdam Ave on July 5th at 11:30am. Donations in her name may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center.

LUFKIN--Cynthia. Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center mourns the death of Cynthia Lufkin, one of the Center's most cherished, inspired, and inspiring philanthropists. An ardent and creative advocate for women with breast cancer, Mrs. Lufkin funded The Cynthia Lufkin Fitness and Seminar Room at Memorial Sloan-Kettering's Evelyn H. Lauder Breast Center. Her generosity created a serene and beautiful space in which our patients receiving treatment for breast cancer can participate in private and group exercise classes, group therapy programs, and an open studio art therapy program, among other activities. Mrs. Lufkin's altruism, energy, imagination, and friendship will be deeply missed. We extend our deepest condolences to her husband, Dan, her children, Schuyler Hazard, and Aster Lee and Daniel Patrick Lufkin, and the other members of her family. Craig B. Thompson, MD President Douglas A. Warner III Chairman, Boards of Overseers and Managers

LUFKIN--Cynthia. The Breast Cancer Research Foundation grieves the passing of Cynthia Lufkin, our dedicated Vice Chairman and beloved friend. Cynthia's generosity, commitment and leadership were invaluable. Her warmth, intelligence and beauty will be sorely missed. She inspired and touched us all with her sparkling and joyful presence. Our hearts go out to her husband, Dan, and her beautiful children, Schuyler, Aster Lee, and Daniel Patrick, all of whom she loved dearly. Leonard A. Lauder, Co-Chairman Kinga Lampert, Co-Chairman Myra J. Biblowit, President Larry Norton, MD, Scientific Director Clifford Hudis, MD, Scientific Advisory Board Chairman Margaret Mastrianni, Deputy Director BCRF Board of Directors BCRF Advisory Board, Leaders Council and staff

LUFKIN--Cynthia. We mourn the passing of Cynthia Lufkin, beloved wife of Dan Lufkin, longtime friend and benefactor, through the Peter Jay Sharp Foundation, of the New-York Historical Society. Cynthia's intelligence and beauty, her commitment to medical research and science, and her strength in the face of adversity inspire us all. Our hearts go out to Dan and to all of Cynthia's family. Roger Hertog, Chairman Pam B. Schafler, Vice Chair Louise Mirrer, President & CEO

LINDER--Bert, whose tireless energy and open spirit benefited the Jewish Reconstructionist movement over many years, died on June 28. He served as treasurer on the board of the Reconstructionist Rabbinical College and was a founding member of West End Synagogue in New York City. RRC joins in mourning with his beloved family: his wife Bliss Siman, their children, partners and grandchildren. His memory surely will be a blessing.

KARP--Deborah Burstein, age 89, died peacefully on Tuesday, July 2, 2013. She was predeceased by her husband of 58 years, Rabbi Abraham J. Karp. She is survived by her two sons, Hillel (wife Arlene) and David (wife Barbara), by six grandchildren, Sarah (husband Eldad Malka), Beth, Ben, Joshua (wife Rona), Aaron (wife Carla), and Rachel, and by two great-grandchildren, Elan and Aviv Malka. Born and raised in New York, she attended Hunter College High School and Barnard College. She received MA and PhD degrees from Columbia University, the PhD when she was 65 years old. A woman of valor, she was an example for her family and those around her. She authored three books on Jewish history for grade school students, and collaborated with her husband on his many publications. Funeral services were held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Amsterdam and 91st Street, at 9:30am, Wednesday July 3, 2013. Shiva will be held from Wednesday to Tuesday, July 9, at 3333 Henry Hudson Parkway, Apartment 22E, Bronx, New York. Donations may be given to the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, 3080 Broadway, NYC, or the charity of your choice.
JUSTER--Ann. Deepest condolences are extended to my dear friend Doris and family on the untimely demise of her beautiful, caring and precious daughter, Ann. Estelle Cohen and Family

HOCHBERGER--Samuel Michael. On July 2 in Havertown PA, after a valiant battle of several years with myelodysplastic syndrome, at the age of 90. Predeceased by beloved wife of 58 years, Jane Weiss Hochberger. Longtime resident of Dunwoody Village, Newton Square PA, and Villanova PA. Adored father of Ruth (Martin Flumenbaum) of New York NY, Larry, of Bryn Mawr PA, and Michael (Shelley Dropkin), of New York NY. Doting grandfather of Martha, David and Judy Flumenbaum, and Nathan, Rachel, Jacob and Eric Hochberger. Predeceased by sisters Sadye Freeman, Agnes Aron, Beatie Minstein and Laura Regenbogen. Born and raised in New York, NY. Proud alumnus of Stuyvesant High School and Colorado School of Mines, where he played varsity football and baseball. Captain in U.S. Army during World War II in the European Theatre, where he received the Bronze Star for construction of a bridge over the Roer River (Germany) while under mortar and artillery fire, and fought at the Bridge at Remagen. A mining engineer, he built the largest explosives distributor business in Pennsylvania and Maryland, Maurer & Scott, Inc., and Blasting Supplies, Inc. Generous to a fault, rugged individualist, enthusiastic tennis player, intrepid traveler, avid debater of politics, frustrated Phillies and Eagles fan. Former vice president of Main Line Reform Temple. Contributions welcome to Colorado School of Mines, P.O. Box 4005, Golden CO 80402, or Beth Chaim Reform Congregation, Box 1198, Malvern PA 19355. Funeral service private.

GOLDMAN--Louis. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) are saddened by the loss of Louis Goldman of Naples, Florida, stepfather of ATS Senior Vice President of Development Beth Wilner. Mr. Goldman founded the ATS Naples Chapter and served as its Chairman since 2008. A dedicated Technion supporter, he established the Roslyn Goldman Memorial Student Loan Fund and provided support for a graduate student dormitory. We offer our heartfelt condolences to the Wilner and Goldman families. American Technion Society Scott Leemaster, President Joel S. Rothman, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President

FLANZER--Louis, died peacefully at home in Longboat Key Florida on June 30th, with his loving wife Gloria by his side. He was a man of many interests. Besides his steadfast love and devotion to Gloria, his wife of 66 years, he was a successful real estate developer and manager, businessman and a dedicated philanthropist. His philanthropic interests were varied, including hospitals and healthcare, substance abuse, and Jewish charities. Lou had a particular interest in building bridges between differing faiths and societies. He was a proud veteran of the United States Army and served the country honorably during World War II. Lou was fearless - he overcame his unease at flying by becoming a licensed pilot. A man of warmth and good cheer, Lou Flanzer was the consummate gentleman. He will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Services will be private.

FLANZER--Louis. We at NewYork-Presbyterian are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend Louis Flanzer. Strongly committed to improving health care, Louis and his beloved wife, Gloria, have served as both leaders and family in advancing our cardiac and ophthalmology programs and in providing the most welcoming environment for our patients. The Flanzers have always been there on behalf of our Hospital and our patients. John J. Mack, Chairman Herbert Pardes, M.D., Executive Vice Chairman Steven J. Corwin, M.D., CEO Allan Schwartz, M.D., Chief, Cardiology

FLANZER--Louis. The faculty and staff of the Department of Ophthalmology at Columbia University Medical Center mourn the loss of Louis Flanzer, a soft-spoken, elegant gentleman, who was a long-time member of our Board of Advisors and a major benefactor. He and his wife, Gloria, propelled the Edward Harkness Eye Institute forward by paving the way for many important projects, including the recent Gloria and Louis Flanzer Vision Care Center on Manhattan's East Side. We express our deepest condolences to Gloria, and the entire family. He was a truly special person. George A. Cioffi, MD, Chairman Stanley Chang, MD, Chairman Emeritus Columbia University Department of Ophthalmology

DiSALVO--Norman. January 15, 1939- July 1, 2013. Executive director of engraving at Tiffany & Co. at the Flagship 5th Ave. Store. Began at 17 in 1956 and for some 40+ years. Took a small sleepy department of hand engraving to the artistic heights with clients like Mrs. Jacqueline Onasis, the Empress of Iran, David Merrick, Bruce Weber, Brook Fields, Madonna, and countless personalities from The White House, theater and film. Flew with President Johnson on Air Force 1 to South America as a personal hand engraver for gifts to foreign dignitaries. Truly a great humanitarian, loved dogs. Contributed to ARF in South Hampton where he has a summer residence. He also had a winter residence in Fort Lauderdale. Survived by family and loving friends and a chocolate lab named Bosco. Always thank you for being you. Enjoy paradise.

ADAMS--Ruth Annette, nee Richmond, of Clifton, NJ, formerly of New York City, and Beach Haven, NJ, died peacefully at her home in Country Club Towers on June 27th at the age of 93. Donations in her memory may be made to the United Jewish Appeal or The Jewish National Fund.

WARSHOW--Nancy Lewis. A long time resident of Sands Point, New York died peacefully surrounded by her family on July 3rd, 2013 from Acute Leukemia at the age of 85. She was the daughter of Lawrence Lewis and Daisy (Flusser) Lewis of West Orange, New Jersey and was born February 12,1928. A graduate of William Smith College; she became an elementary school teacher. Nancy was married July 14, 1953 to Alan Warshow of New York City, after they fell in love at first sight on the beach in Hollywood, Florida 60 sixty years ago. Nancy was a loving and dedicated wife and mother of Leslie, John and Susan. Nancy enjoyed the New York Philharmonic, all types of music from the Beatles to Beethoven, gardening and flower arranging, exercising, reading, tennis and traveling. She loved the ocean and the beach, especially her yearly trips to the Caribbean with her family. She hosted wonderful themed parties for her children, friends, relatives, and even for the family Labrador Retreiver Happy. Among her passions were volunteering for the Port Washington Public Schools, and the Health Education Department at North Shore University Hospital. She was diagnosed with Multiple Sclerosis 35 years ago and never let it get the best of her. She continued her swimming and exercising on a daily basis throughout her life. Nancy is survived by her devoted husband Alan, three loving children, Leslie (and her husband Keith, son Jason), John (and his wife Jenny, sons David and Ethan), and daughter Susan (and her partner Bryan), and a sister Shirley Beren. The family wishes to thank doctors Wadler and Blanck for the compassionate care they provided for over 35 years, that allowed Nancy to live with dignity and determination. We are grateful for all the excellent care she received from her caregivers the last five years. Memorial Services will be at Port Jewish Center, 20 Manorhaven Blvd., Port Washington, NY on Sunday, July 7th, 2013 at 1:30pm. The family will be sitting Shiva following services and on Monday, July 8th from 7-9pm at Nancy and Alan's home. Memorial contributions may be made to the Long Island Chapter of National MS Society(Chapter Services), Sierra Club or Southern Poverty Law Center, charitable organizations whose work was of great importance to her.

STERNBERG--Muriel, 93 years old, passed away on July 3, 2013. Beloved wife of Seymour for 41 years. Devoted and cherished mother of Ronald (Irene), Leonard (Marshall) and Sara. Adored grandmother of Julian, Alison (David), Molly (Avery) and Scott. And very proud great-grandmother of Safi. Much loved aunt and sister. Muriel was known to say, "You get out of life what you put into it". She fully epitomized those words until her last days. Graveside services will be held on Friday, July 5. Shiva will be held at Ron and Irene's home on Sunday and Wednesday 2:00-5:00 and 7:00-9:00pm, and Sara's home on Monday and Tuesday 2:00-5:00 and 7:00-9:00pm. Donations may be made to the 92nd Street Y, SAJ Synagogue or The Merrick Jewish Center.

MOTZ--Minne, died June 26, 2013 at the age of 98. She and her husband, Lloyd, who died in 2004, lived in Washington Heights NYC for most of their lives and enjoyed summers at their country house in Lake Luzerne, NY. She was a graduate of Brooklyn College and received a Masters Degree in Library Science from Columbia University's Teachers College. Her husband Lloyd Motz who died in 2004 was a professor of physics and astronomy at Columbia University. Minne was the head of libraries for the New York City Board of Education. She was also a children's book editor and consulted for several publishing houses. She was an avid supporter of the arts and for decades maintained subscriptions with The New York City Ballet, American Ballet Theatre, Alvin Ailey Dance company and The New York Philharmonic. She was a lifelong supporter of the American Civil Liberties Union ( ACLU). She enjoyed gardening, reading poetry and The New York Times daily and swimming in 4th lake, Lake Luzerne. Minne was known to all of her friends and neighbors for her love of butterflies, her passion for purple, and her extensive hat collection. Minne is survived by a son, Robin; a daughter, Julie; three grandchildren, Jeremy, Nicole and Benjamin; and two great-grandchildren, Isabella and Aidan Wilson. Funeral service 11am Sunday at Gutterman and Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to the The Lloyd Motz Scholarship Fund and mailed to: Columbia College 622 West 113 Street, 3rd Floor New York, NY 10025

STANBACK--Thomas Melville, III. Born April 9, 1950; died peacefully on June 29, 2013. Tom graduated from Riverdale ('68), Amherst (BA '72), and Columbia (MBA '82), and studied musicology at U Chicago. He worked at autism and music non-profits. He is survived by wife Michaeline Bresnahan; children Emily and Charles; parents Thomas and Margaret; siblings Margaret, Robert, William, and Florence; and a wide circle of adoring friends. Tom's beloved brother Maxwell predeceased him. Funeral: 3pm, Saturday, July 6, St. John's Episcopal, Larchmont, NY.

MILLER--Evelyn, 82, died July 1, 2013 in New York. Beloved sister of Harvey (Eleanor) Miller and Zelda (Julian) Block, cherished aunt and great-aunt, and friend to many. A graduate of Hunter College, she had a 38-year career with NYC schools. Donations may be made to Hunter College and the ADL.

MAYER--William D. We are fortunate to have been mentored by a master, William D Mayer. He taught us to have humility, patience, and a deep respect for people. When we were confronted by challenges, Billy was the Force that showed us the Light. Billy valued his independence, embraced a full life, loved his family, partner, and friends. He was gentle and kind and had a great sense of humor .We will always remember him for the wisdom he imparted to us. The warmth of his loving friendship helped make us who we are today. May his memory be a blessing Stephen Silberman and Ricky Solomon

MAYER--William D.,78 years old, died on July 2nd. Beloved father of Debbie and Sandy, and father-in-law of Jimmy Roberts; Proud papa of Jackson, Aidan, and Daniel Roberts; Loving partner of Carol Brecher; Devoted brother of Marion J. Rosley. We will forever miss your optimism, humor, enthusiasm, and love of life. A Memorial Gathering will take place at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., this Monday and Tuesday evening, July 8th and 9th from 6:00-8:30pm. LUFKIN--Cynthia. You have been my dear friend and confidante for almost 30 years. I will always remember and admire your strength, wisdom and character. I miss you already. My thoughts and condolences go out to Dan, Sky, Aster Lee and Patchy. Thinking of You, Suzanne
LUFKIN--Cynthia. We mourn the loss of a dear friend whose warmth, joy and caring embraced all those privileged to have known her. With love to Dan and their family. Somers and Jonathan Farkas

Cynthia's generosity, commitment and leadership were invaluable. Her warmth, intelligence and beauty will be sorely missed. She inspired and touched us all with her sparkling and joyful presence. Lauder, Co-Chairman Kinga Lampert, Co-Chairman Myra J. LUFKIN--Cynthia. Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center mourns the death of Cynthia Lufkin, one of the Center's most cherished, inspired, and inspiring philanthropists. An ardent and creative advocate for women with breast cancer, Mrs. Lufkin funded The Cynthia Lufkin Fitness and Seminar Room at Memorial Sloan-Kettering's Evelyn H. Lauder Breast Center. Her generosity created a serene and beautiful space in which our patients receiving treatment for breast cancer can participate in private and group exercise classes, group therapy programs, and an open studio art therapy program, among other activities. Mrs. Lufkin's altruism, energy, imagination, and friendship will be deeply missed. We extend our deepest condolences to her husband, Dan, her children, Schuyler Hazard, and Aster Lee and Daniel Patrick Lufkin, and the other members of her family. Craig B. LUFKIN--Cynthia Joy. Washington Depot, Ct, 1962 2013. Cynthia Lufkin, prominent philanthropist and civic leader in New York and Connecticut, and wife of the co-founder of the Investment banking firm of Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette, died the morning of July 3, 2013 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Hospital from complications of breast and lung cancer. She was 51 years old. Cynthia was born in Somerville, NJ. She graduated from Trinity College in Hartford, CT. with a degree in biochemistry, during which she was awarded a fellowship in immunology from the University of Connecticut Medical School. She served on the Advisory Council of Trinity College in later years. She was elected to the Board of Directors of The Breast Cancer Research Foundation, where she served as Co-Chair. Cynthia was instrumental in support of the Breast Cancer Research Foundation- Peter Jay Sharp Foundation funded project at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center on the development of a DNA vaccine for Melanoma, vaccine research led by Drs. Larry Norton, Alan Houghton and Jedd Wolchok. Cynthia had dedicated much fundraising and consciousness-raising energy to the Breast Cancer Research Foundation, driven largely by a need to show women who are recently diagnosed that they can get through it and that life does go on. Her understanding of biochemistry helped in developing, with Memorial Sloan-Kettering, the nutrition and fitness aspects of integrated medicine for cancer patients, and the Cynthia Lufkin Center for Nutrition and Fitness, at the Evelyn Lauder Breast Cancer Center, serves as a focus for this endeavor today. To honor her husband's life-long work, in conjunction with National Audubon Society, she created the annual $100,000 Dan W. Lufkin Prize for Environmental Leadership to recognize "feet on the ground" service to the environment. The first recipient of this award was George Archibald, founder of The International Crane Foundation. In 2008, Cynthia was awarded The American Cancer Society Mother of the Year. She served on the board of trustees of Rumsey Hall School in Washington Depot, Ct. She served as a Vice Chair of the Museum of the City of New York Director's Council. She served on the board of the Women's Committee of the Central Park Conservancy. She previously served as a Vice-Chair of Safe Horizon, the nation's leading victim assistance, advocacy, and violence prevention organization. Friends of Cynthia loved her. She was beautiful and intelligent, generous and kind, and more than all, she was loyal. She had an infectious laugh that heralded her love of life and family. She was an accomplished woman in so many ways, but most particularly, she would want to be remembered as an extraordinarily caring and loving wife and mother to her two daughters and one son. She is survived by her husband, Dan, her three children, Schuyler Hazard, Aster Lee Lufkin, Daniel Patrick Lufkin, her mother, Joyce Ford and her brother, Don Henry. There will be a service at the Dune Church in Southampton, Friday, July 12 at 4pm. In lieu of flowers, gifts to honor Cynthia's life can be made to The Breast Cancer Research Foundation, 60 East 56th Street, 8th Floor, New York, NY 10022

FEINGOLD--Pauline (Polly), died June 25, 2013. Born in Lynn, MA, in 1928, she moved to New York in the 1960s. She served as Deputy Commissioner of the NYC Department of Corrections and later Housing and Preservation Development as well as on the Advisory Board of the Women's Prison Association and headed Women in Criminal Justice for many years. She worked for Robert F. Kennedy in the 1960s and was President of the City Club and a member of the Park River Independent Democratic Club. Feisty in her 80s, she handed out flyers and campaign buttons for Democratic candidates on the Upper West Side. She is survived by her nieces from Massachusetts. She will be missed by family and friends. Contributions in her memory may be made to WNYC at www.wnyc.com

FARLEY--Thomas R.,of West Orange, NJ died on Wednesday July 3rd, 2013. Born in Newark, NJ on November 21st, 1926, Thomas graduated from Seton Hall Preparatory School in 1944, from the University of Notre Dame in 1950, he earned his CPCU and he received his LLB from Rutgers Law School in 1955. He taught Corporate Finance at St. Peter's College from 1956 to 1957. He was elected County of Essex Freeholder in 1966 where he served as Deputy Director and Chairman of the Finance Committee. In 1971, he was appointed Surrogate of the county. In 1970, he was appointed to serve as a member of the Apportionment Commission of the State of New Jersey. He was also a member of the State Commission of Investigation (SCI). Thomas served as Judge of the Superior Court of New Jersey from 1977 to 1981. In 1967-68, he was part owner of the Jersey Jays, a professional football team. Thomas was the Grand Marshall of the West Orange St. Patrick's Day Parade in 1984. He was one of the founders of the Short Hills National Bank, and a member of the Board of Directors of Hudson United Bank from 1994 to 2001. Thomas was a member of the Board of Trustees of Seton Hall Preparatory School for the past 25 years. He was a member of the Essex County Country Club since 1967. During WWII from 1944 to 1946, Thomas served in the US Navy as a Signalman attached to the USS Wichita, a heavy cruiser. He was among the first to land at Nagasaki, Japan two weeks after the destruction of the city by the atomic bomb on August 9th, 1945. For the service he rendered to his country Thomas received the New Jersey Distinguised Service Medal. He was working on a "Memoir of an Eighteen Year Old Sailor; Atomic Bombs, Nagasaki, and the Liberation of Prisoners of War". Thomas had a great love of America and was a life-long sports fan. He was an avid collector of historical, political, and brewery memorabilia. His memory was incredible, he loved to read, and had an insatiable appetite for knowledge in a broad range of subjects. He had a quick wit and a sense of humor that would catch you off guard. Loyalty to family and friends was a hallmark of his life. He is survived by his wife, Nancy Farley, his daughter, Meghan Farley Astrachan (Isaac-Daniel), and his grandson, Aidhan Farley Astrachan. He was predeceased by his daughter Anne Farley, his brother James P. Farley, and his sister Maryrose F. Swift. Visitation will be held at the Quinn Hopping Funeral Home of Livingston, 145 East Mount Pleasant Avenue, Livingston (NJ) on Monday July 8th from 4 to 8pm. The Funeral Mass will be offered at St. Joseph's Church, 44 Benvenue Avenue, West Orange, NJ on Tuesday July 9th at 10am, followed by the interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, 225 Ridgedale Avenue, East Hanover, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Honorable Thomas R. Farley Scholarship Fund at Seton Hall Preparatory School, 120 Northfield Ave., West Orange, NJ 07052

WRISTON--Barbara, died peacefully at home July 2, 2013, three days after her 96th birthday. Daughter of Ruth B. and Henry M. Wriston (President of Brown University 1937-1955); sister of Walter B. Wriston (Chairman of Citicorp 1968-1984); fond sister-in- law of Kathryn D. Wriston; beloved aunt of Catherine W. Quintal (husband Richard) and great-aunt of Christopher W. Quintal (wife Sara) and Barbara Catherine Quintal. An Art Historian and Museum Educator, Barbara received a B.A. from Oberlin University, an M.A. from Brown University and, in 1977, an Honorary D.Litt from Lawrence University. She began her distinguished career at the Museum of Arts at the Rhode Island School of Design in 1939; in 1944, she became a Lecturer at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston; and in 1961 was appointed Executive Director of Museum Education at the Art Institute of Chicago. Barbara was a Life Trustee of Chicago's Newberry Library; a Benjamin Franklin Fellow of the Royal Society of Arts in London; Trustee of the New York Public Library and Kentucky's Frontier Nursing Service. Her scholarly and entertaining book, "Rare Doings At Bath" was published by the Chicago Art Institute in 1978. Through her generous support and love for Lawrence University, she helped create and fund the Wriston Art Center Galleries there. In 1980, Barbara "retired" and moved to New York City; she became very involved with the Metropolitan Museum of Art, joining the Friends of The American Wing and the Visiting Committee for the Department of American Decorative Arts (which were her passion). In her later years, she endowed a Curatorship in the American Wing of the Museum in memory of her mother. Refusing to be outshone by her famous father and brother, Barbara was a brilliant, talented, gallant and indomitable figure; an ardent feminist, gifted educator, intrepid traveler to all parts of the globe, and a devoted daughter, sister, aunt, sister-in-law and friend. A Memorial service will be planned later this summer. Donations in Barbara's memory can be made to the Wriston Art Center at Lawrence University; to the Barbara Wriston Scholarship Fund at Lawrence; or to the Newberry Library.

We will miss her brilliance, love of law, and most of all her kindness and generosity. She is predeceased by her father Joseph Aloysius Tracy Esq. and mother, Rosemary Patricia Tracy. She is survived by her daughter Keelyn Tracy Crowe and loving sisters and brothers, Regina Tracy-Semmes, Mary Elizabeth, "Emie" Barnes, William "Moses" Tracy, Joseph A. Tracy Jr., Rosemary Maxfield and Michael Tracy. She will be missed by her family, friends, nephews and nieces - Shawn, Shelby, Heather, Abigail, Charlie, Kevin, Dylan, Ryan, Cameron, Carleigh, Colby, Jack, Madeline and Myles. The Rumsey Hall Family extends its deepest sympathy to Cynthia's husband Dan, her joyful children Schuyler Hazard, Aster Lee and Daniel Patrick, her extended family and friends. Our sorrow is balanced to some small degree by the fact that we had the privilege of working with Cynthia as a devoted mother and active member of the Board of Trustees. Cynthia loved this year's "Be Strong, Spread Joy" School theme. We can honor her by doing just that.

LUFKIN--Cynthia Joy. Washington Depot, Ct, 1962 2013. Cynthia Lufkin, prominent philanthropist and civic leader in New York and Connecticut, and wife of the co-founder of the Investment banking firm of Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette, died the morning of July 3, 2013 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Hospital from complications of breast and lung cancer. She was 51 years old. Cynthia was born in Somerville, NJ. She graduated from Trinity College in Hartford, CT. with a degree in biochemistry, during which she was awarded a fellowship in immunology from the University of Connecticut Medical School. She served on the Advisory Council of Trinity College in later years. She was elected to the Board of Directors of The Breast Cancer Research Foundation, where she served as Co-Chair. Cynthia was instrumental in support of the Breast Cancer Research Foundation- Peter Jay Sharp Foundation funded project at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center on the development of a DNA vaccine for Melanoma, vaccine research led by Drs. Larry Norton, Alan Houghton and Jedd Wolchok. Cynthia had dedicated much fundraising and consciousness-raising energy to the Breast Cancer Research Foundation, driven largely by a need to show women who are recently diagnosed that they can get through it and that life does go on. Her understanding of biochemistry helped in developing, with Memorial Sloan-Kettering, the nutrition and fitness aspects of integrated medicine for cancer patients, and the Cynthia Lufkin Center for Nutrition and Fitness, at the Evelyn Lauder Breast Cancer Center, serves as a focus for this endeavor today. To honor her husband's life-long work, in conjunction with National Audubon Society, she created the annual $100,000 Dan W. Lufkin Prize for Environmental Leadership to recognize "feet on the ground" service to the environment. The first recipient of this award was George Archibald, founder of The International Crane Foundation. In 2008, Cynthia was awarded The American Cancer Society Mother of the Year. She served on the board of trustees of Rumsey Hall School in Washington Depot, Ct. She served as a Vice Chair of the Museum of the City of New York Director's Council. She served on the board of the Women's Committee of the Central Park Conservancy. She previously served as a Vice-Chair of Safe Horizon, the nation's leading victim assistance, advocacy, and violence prevention organization. Friends of Cynthia loved her. She was beautiful and intelligent, generous and kind, and more than all, she was loyal. She had an infectious laugh that heralded her love of life and family. She was an accomplished woman in so many ways, but most particularly, she would want to be remembered as an extraordinarily caring and loving wife and mother to her two daughters and one son. She is survived by her husband, Dan, her three children, Schuyler Hazard, Aster Lee Lufkin, Daniel Patrick Lufkin, her mother, Joyce Ford and her brother, Don Henry. There will be a service at the Dune Church in Southampton, Friday, July 12 at 4pm. In lieu of flowers, gifts to honor Cynthia's life can be made to The Breast Cancer Research Foundation, 60 East 56th Street, 8th Floor, New York, NY 10022

LUFKIN--Cynthia. The Breast Cancer Research Foundation grieves the passing of Cynthia Lufkin, our dedicated Vice Chairman and beloved friend. Cynthia's generosity, commitment and leadership were invaluable. Her warmth, intelligence and beauty will be sorely missed. She inspired and touched us all with her sparkling and joyful presence. Our hearts go out to her husband, Dan, and her beautiful children, Schuyler, Aster Lee, and Daniel Patrick, all of whom she loved dearly. Leonard A. Lauder, Co-Chairman Kinga Lampert, Co-Chairman Myra J. Biblowit, President Larry Norton, MD, Scientific Director Clifford Hudis, MD, Scientific Advisory Board Chairman Margaret Mastrianni, Deputy Director BCRF Board of Directors BCRF Advisory Board, Leaders Council and staff

LERNER--Susan Goodstein, 72, on July 5, 2013. Beloved wife of Laurence, mother of Elisabeth and Marc, mother-in-law of Nina Rifkind and sister of Robert Goodstein. We were fortunate to have her as part of our family for as long as we did. She shared her wealth of knowledge, kindness, compassion, grace and humor very generously. She leaves behind a legacy of love and good deeds. Graveside service Tuesday, July 9, 2013, 11:00am at Union Fields Cemetery. Shiva private. Donations in her memory may be made to: Career Transition for Dancers.

KRUBINER--Sheldon, (91), of Lawrence, NY. Beloved husband of Marilyn, for 69 years, devoted father of Patrice Greenfield, Michael Krubiner (Casey), and Jane Berardi (Michael), grandfather and great-grandfather.

KORONES--Dr. Sheldon Bernarr, died early Wednesday morning in his home in Memphis, TN. He was 89 years old. Born and raised on the Lower East Side, Dr. Korones graduated from Seward Park High School, the University of Tennessee at Knoxville, and the University of Tennessee School of Medicine in Memphis. He did his pediatric training at Boston City Hospital and Columbia Babies Hospital in New York City, and post-graduate work at Children's Medical Center, Boston. Married to Judith Kest of Mount Vernon, NY, in 1952, he returned to Memphis in 1954. In 1968, he left a busy private practice to launch what would become one of the largest neonatal intensive care units in the country, a unit that now bears his name. He held numerous university appointments, and at the time of his retirement in 2009 was Alumni Distinguished Service Professor of Pediatrics and Obstetrics and Gynecology. He is survived by his wife, Judith Korones; his brother N. David Korones; a son, Dr. David Korones of Rochester, NY, and daughter, Susan Korones Gifford, of Montclair, NJ, and four grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to the Sheldon B. Korones Newborn Center, Temple Israel in Memphis, TN, or the Mid-South Food Bank.

KISSICK--Dr. William Lee, age 81, died peacefully in Denver, Colorado on June 30, 2013, surrounded by his family. He was born in Detroit, Michigan, on July 29th, 1932. He earned his B.A., M.D., Master's of Public Health and PhD from Yale University. He served in the US Public Health Service, under Presidents Kennedy and Johnson. Dr. Kissick was one of two physicians who drafted the Medicare Act (1965). Following that, he was the George Seckel Pepper Professor of Medicine for the University of Pennsylvania, School of Medicine. Dr. Kissick was a lifelong Yale supporter, serving as Fellow of the Yale Corporation from 1987-1993. For his distinguished service to Yale, he was awarded the Yale Medal (1996). He is survived by his loving wife, Priscilla Dillingham Kissick, and his children; Will, Rob, Jon and Liz and her husband Brad, and grandchildren; Carrie Kissick, Eliza Kissick, Emma Richards and Samuel Richards. There will be a private memorial service. In lieu of flowers, gifts may be made to the Dr. William Kissick M.D. Scholarship Fund at the Wharton School, University of Pennsylvania, 3620 Locust Walk, Philadelphia, PA 19104.

KARP--Deborah Burstein, age 89, died peacefully on Tuesday, July 2, 2013. She was predeceased by her husband of 58 years, Rabbi Abraham J. Karp. She is survived by her two sons, Hillel (wife Arlene) and David (wife Barbara), by six grandchildren, Sarah (husband Eldad Malka), Beth, Ben, Joshua (wife Rona), Aaron (wife Carla), and Rachel, and by two great-grandchildren, Elan and Aviv Malka. Born and raised in New York, she attended Hunter College High School and Barnard College. She received MA and PhD degrees from Columbia University, the PhD when she was 65 years old. A woman of valor, she was an example for her family and those around her. She authored three books on Jewish history for grade school students, and collaborated with her husband on his many publications. Funeral services were held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Amsterdam and 91st Street, at 9:30am, Wednesday July 3, 2013. Shiva will be held from Wednesday to Tuesday, July 9, at 3333 Henry Hudson Parkway, Apartment 22E, Bronx, New York. Donations may be given to the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, 3080 Broadway, NYC, or the charity of your choice.

JUSTER--Ann E.,58, of Harrison, NY. Died suddenly Sunday, June 30, 2013. Much loved daughter of Doris Juster and the late Martin W. Juster. Devoted mother to Michelle and Joshua. Beloved sister to Gary and Howard, caring sister-in-law to Karen and Beth, and loving aunt to Michael and Matthew. Cherished and loyal friend to many. A lifetime of exceptional giving to causes she was passionate about including the Arthritis Foundation, the Hospital for Joint Diseases, Pet Rescue, and the American Diabetes Association. She will be missed by all and in our hearts always. Graveside services were held at Sharon Gardens. Donations in her memory may be made to the American Diabetes Association.

JONES--Ruth, (nee Nagel). October 29, 1920 to June 14, 2013. Ruth Margaret Nagel was one of the first children of Hollywood, born in the movie colony to silent screen star Conrad Nagel and Ruth Helms Nagel. Her father played opposite such leading ladies as Greta Garbo, Gloria Swanson, Norma Shearer and Marion Davies. He was a founder of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts & Sciences, serving as its third president, and hosted the Academy Awards three times. Ruth attended the Westlake School for Girls and graduated from Wellesley College in 1942, majoring in English. In 1946, she married Thomas Victor Jones who became the longtime CEO and Chairman of Northrop Corporation. She was a founding member of the Blue Ribbon, a group that supports The Music Center of Los Angeles and was a member of The Colleagues, a Santa Monica-based charity that supports care for abused and neglected children. She remained an ardent champion of Wellesley College and provided funding for the Ruth Nagel Jones Theatre a showcase for student productions. She was an avid reader, garden lover and cherished her beloved pug, Uva. She is survived by her husband of 67 years, their daughter Ruth Marilyn Jones, son Peter Thomas Jones, and granddaughters Annie and Rosie Jones. She died at home after a short illness. In lieu flowers, please consider a donation to the Los Angeles Public Library.

JOLIS--Mona, passed away peacefully on July 5, 2013. Born in Bucharest, Romania she immigrated to the USA in 1968. Soon after her arrival in New York City she met the love of her life, Albert Jolis whom she eventually married. Mona lived in New York City and devoted her life to helping many of her dear friends and her immediate family. She is survived by her brother Dinu, her nieces Marina and Ena, her nephew Philippe and numerous close friends, especially Mariuca, Marisa, Dimitri, Ingrid, Stanley and Sharon. She will be deeply missed by all and her wisdom as well as spirit of devotion, kindness and generosity will live on forever. Services will take place on Sunday at 2pm at Provenzano Lanza Funeral Home, 43 2nd Ave., New York, NY.
ISRAEL--Kenneth M. We mourn the death of our cherished member and extend deepest sympathies to his family. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York

HOLAND--Sidney Joshua. Beloved Husband, Father, Saba, Brother and Uncle. Sidney's life is a testimony to love, resilience and integrity. He was born in Poland and fled to Siberia during World War II where he spent much of his childhood struggling to survive. He moved to Israel in 1957 and served in the Israeli Army where he met the love of his life, Tzipora Rapaport, his wife of 52 years. Sidney emigrated to the United States in 1961 speaking no English and with no formal education, initially working as a plumber's apprentice. He went on to found the ALFA Piping Corporation, one of the preeminent air conditioning and piping contractors in New York City. Under Sidney's leadership, their work has included the renovation of Carnegie Hall, the 911 Memorial and virtually every hospital and university in New York City. Sidney was beloved by all who knew him for his compassion, humility, wisdom and kindness. He was a generous philanthropist and a strong supporter of the Friends of the Israel Defense Forces (FIDF), which provides scholarships and assistance to former Israeli Soldiers. His greatest accomplishments, however, are his two beautiful daughters, Sharon and Adina, and five exceptional grandchildren, Evan, Nicole, Zachary, Justin and Tyler. Many have already gone on to college educations and earn advanced degrees, things that a boy from Poland could never have imagined. Sidney lived the American dream. He would kiss the ground and pronounce "God Bless America" each time he returned home from a trip abroad. He passed away on July 4th. Funeral services will be held, Monday, July 8, 11:30am at Sinai Chapels, Fresh Meadows, NY. Donations in Sidney's honor may be made to FIDF of North Miami Beach. Sidney will be missed by all who knew him. He will never be forgotten.

HOGENAUER--Alan Krahe, 71, world traveler. Died June 29-30 walking in California desert, 122 degree heat. Brother of Bruce, Clare. Father of Meg, Bill, Justin. Grandfather of Jennah, Kendall, Kelsey, Will, Jack. Husband of Srivara. Professor, Loyola Marymount Univ., Los Angeles. For more details please call 917-595-9357.

HOCHBERGER--Samuel Michael. On July 2 in Havertown PA, after a valiant battle of several years with myelodysplastic syndrome, at the age of 90. Predeceased by beloved wife of 58 years, Jane Weiss Hochberger. Longtime resident of Dunwoody Village, Newtown Square PA, and Villanova PA. Adored father of Ruth (Martin Flumenbaum) of New York NY, Larry, of Bryn Mawr PA, and Michael (Shelley Dropkin), of New York NY. Doting grandfather of Martha, David and Judy Flumenbaum, and Nathan, Rachel, Jacob and Eric Hochberger. Predeceased by sisters Sadye Freeman, Agnes Aron, Beatie Minstein and Laura Regenbogen. Born and raised in New York, NY. Proud alumnus of Stuyvesant High School and Colorado School of Mines, where he played varsity football and baseball. Captain in U.S. Army during World War II in the European Theatre, where he received the Bronze Star for construction of a bridge over the Roer River (Germany) while under mortar and artillery fire, and fought at the Bridge at Remagen. A mining engineer, he built the largest explosives distributor business in Pennsylvania and Maryland, Maurer & Scott, Inc., and Blasting Supplies, Inc. Generous to a fault, rugged individualist, enthusiastic tennis player, intrepid traveler, avid debater of politics, frustrated Phillies and Eagles fan. Former vice president of Main Line Reform Temple. Contributions welcome to Colorado School of Mines, P.O. Box 4005, Golden CO 80402, or Beth Chaim Reform Congregation, Box 1198, Malvern PA 19355. Funeral service private.

HEALY--Harold J.,88 years old, died on July 5, 2013. Beloved husband of Judith for 57 years. Son of the late Martin of Ballylea and Della of Shragh, Ireland. Brother-in-law of Laura Higgins and Anthony Spina. Much loved uncle of James Higgins, Judith Faiella, John Higgins, Laura Mannino and Monica Spina; granduncle of Wayne Higgins. World War II Navy veteran ("Seabee"), serving his country in the Pacific theater, '43-'46. Former history teacher at W. Trespar Clarke High School from 1954 to 1986. Graduate of Fordham College, Cl 49. Resident of Lloyd Neck for 51 years, serving the community for fifty years in various positions including the Zoning Board of Appeals of the Village of Lloyd Harbor (30 years), the Board of Directors of the Fiddler's Green Association, and the Chair of the Road Committee of the same. Viewing Sunday, July 7, 2013, 2-4pm and 7-9pm, M. A. Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Ave., Huntington Station, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 9:45am at St Edward the Confessor RC Church, Syosset, NY. Internment at Gate of Heaven, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Edward the Confessor, Syosset, or the Seminary of the Immaculate Conception, Lloyd Harbor, NY.www. maconnellfuneralhome.com

GLAZER--Dr. William M. "Bill", March 31st, 1947- June 23rd, 2013. He died as he lived- with wisdom, clarity, courage and grace- surrounded by his Roz and their cherished children Aaron, Hilary and Jacob; daughters-in-law Dalia and Illana; and five grandchildren Solomon, DvorahLeah, Samuel, Isaac and Ziva. We will miss his guidence, humor and passion for life and all of its blessings. Jill and Ken

GLAZER--Dr. William M.,of Menemsha, MA and Key West, FL, died at home in Menemsha on Sunday, June 23 surrounded by his family. The cause of death was appendiceal cancer. Dr. Glazer was born March 31, 1947 to his parents Irma and Harry Glazer of Newington, CT. He graduated from Clark University in 1969, and the University of Connecticut School of Medicine in 1973. He completed his residency in psychiatry at Yale University in 1978. After completing his residency, he went into private practice and was the President of Glazer Medical Solutions. He was a clinician, researcher, lecturer, consultant and had been involved with continuing medical education since he began on the faculty of the Departments of Psychiatry first at Yale University (1978-1994) then at Harvard University (1994-2006). His research and teaching has generated the publication of hundreds of papers, chapters and multimedia educational materials. He lectured nationally for over 25 years on themes related to the diagnosis, treatment and management of severe and persistent psychiatric illnesses. He was a recognized expert in the areas of schizophrenia, tardive dyskinesia, managed care and psychpharmacology. He leaves behind his wife Roseline, children Aaron, Hilary and Jacob along with daughters-in-law Dalia, and Illana, grandchildren Solomon, DvorahLeah, Samuel, Isaac, and Ziva. He also leaves behind his father Harry, brother Dan and sister-in-law Paula. Dr. Glazer was Commodore of the Menemsha Pond Sailboat fleet for 20 years. He was loved and admired by many friends and colleagues on the Vineyard, Connecticut and Key West along with his patients for whom he cared very deeply. He looked forward to Vineyard summers as two-star general of his "Menemsha Army" of five grandchildren. Donations may be made in his name to Daybreak Clubhouse, Vineyard Haven, P.O. Box 1993, Vineyard Haven, MA 02568.

GEULA--Jessica, 42 years. It is with profound sorrow that we mourn our Jessica who left us too soon. She leaves behind her mother Roberta, father David, sisters Nikki (Damon) and Monica (Asher), her nieces and nephews, Chloe, Ryder, Tatiana and Austin. A beautiful force of nature, she will be missed but never forgotten. Burial will be in Miami. Family will receive condolence calls on Monday, July 8th at 5pm in New York at Park East Synagogue 164 East 68th St.

FRIEDMAN--Stuart W.,74, President, Manhattan Health Plan, first NYC HMO. Began career in plastics and retired as President of Birch & Davis Health Management Corp. A graduate of University of Southern California, past president of Mensa Education Research Foundation, Met Opera patron, director of Mind-Alliance Homeland Security. Survived by wife Enid, children Gregg and Nancy, Janice and Ian, four grandchildren. Donations to Lautenberg Cancer Center, Hebrew University, Jerusalem.

FREUND--Marcella Coleman. A remarkable woman. Born in New York City in 1907 and a lifelong resident, Marcy celebrated her 105th birthday last December, mental faculties intact and looking great (as in the photo above). For several decades, she partnered with her beloved husband of 45 years, Sylvan Freund, in running Decorative Plant Corp., the company that pioneered outdoor displays on Fifth Avenue and was responsible for the sculpted angels that are still the centerpiece of Rockefeller Center at Christmastime. Although widowed almost 40 years ago, Marcy continued to live a full and fruitful life right to the end, sustained by her strong faith in the Almighty. A talented artist, she was also an active participant in several continuing education programs and traveled on her own to numerous countries. On the occasion of Marcy's 105th birthday, President Obama wrote that she should "take pride in all you have accomplished," Governor Cuomo called her "an extraordinary individual," and Mayor Bloomberg said she was "an inspirational role model for us all." Marcy counseled and showered affection on her son, Jim, and grandsons, Erik and Tom, doted on her great-granddaughters, Delilah and Paige, and touched the lives of other family members and friends too numerous to mention. There's a big void in all our lives now, and we will miss her greatly. A service will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, Madison Avenue and 81st Street, at 11:30am on Monday, July 8th and her family will be receiving friends from 5-8 that evening at the home of Jim and Barbara Fox Freund. Contributions in Marcella Freund's memory may be made to Eighth Church of Christ, Scientist, 103 East 77th Street, NYC 10075.

FLANZER--Louis. The Board of Directors, management and staff of White Plains Hospital mourn with extreme sorrow the passing of our dear friend, board member and benefactor, Mr. Louis Flanzer. For more than 30 years, his support and inspirational leadership helped to create the Flanzer Pavilion and the Flanzer Center for Emergencies and Critical Care. His endearing nature and warm spirit will be missed by all of us. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his beloved wife, Gloria and their entire family. J. Michael Divney, Chairman of the Board Jon B. Schandler, CEO Susan Fox, President

FEINGOLD--Pauline (Polly), died June 25, 2013. Born in Lynn, MA, in 1928, she moved to New York in the 1960s. She served as Deputy Commissioner of the NYC Department of Corrections and later Housing and Preservation Development as well as on the Advisory Board of the Women's Prison Association and headed Women in Criminal Justice for many years. She worked for Robert F. Kennedy in the 1960s and was President of the City Club and a member of the Park River Independent Democratic Club. Feisty in her 80s, she handed out flyers and campaign buttons for Democratic candidates on the Upper West Side. She is survived by her nieces from Massachusetts. She will be missed by family and friends. Contributions in her memory may be made to WNYC at www.wnyc.com

FARLEY--Thomas R.,of West Orange, NJ died on Wednesday July 3rd, 2013. Born in Newark, NJ on November 21st, 1926, Thomas graduated from Seton Hall Preparatory School in 1944, from the University of Notre Dame in 1950, he earned his CPCU and he received his LLB from Rutgers Law School in 1955. He taught Corporate Finance at St. Peter's College from 1956 to 1957. He was elected County of Essex Freeholder in 1966 where he served as Deputy Director and Chairman of the Finance Committee. In 1971, he was appointed Surrogate of the county. In 1970, he was appointed to serve as a member of the Apportionment Commission of the State of New Jersey. He was also a member of the State Commission of Investigation (SCI). Thomas served as Judge of the Superior Court of New Jersey from 1977 to 1981. In 1967-68, he was part owner of the Jersey Jays, a professional football team. Thomas was the Grand Marshall of the West Orange St. Patrick's Day Parade in 1984. He was one of the founders of the Short Hills National Bank, and a member of the Board of Directors of Hudson United Bank from 1994 to 2001. Thomas was a member of the Board of Trustees of Seton Hall Preparatory School for the past 25 years. He was a member of the Essex County Country Club since 1967. During WWII from 1944 to 1946, Thomas served in the US Navy as a Signalman attached to the USS Wichita, a heavy cruiser. He was among the first to land at Nagasaki, Japan two weeks after the destruction of the city by the atomic bomb on August 9th, 1945. For the service he rendered to his country Thomas received the New Jersey Distinguised Service Medal. He was working on a "Memoir of an Eighteen Year Old Sailor; Atomic Bombs, Nagasaki, and the Liberation of Prisoners of War". Thomas had a great love of America and was a life-long sports fan. He was an avid collector of historical, political, and brewery memorabilia. His memory was incredible, he loved to read, and had an insatiable appetite for knowledge in a broad range of subjects. He had a quick wit and a sense of humor that would catch you off guard. Loyalty to family and friends was a hallmark of his life. He is survived by his wife, Nancy Farley, his daughter, Meghan Farley Astrachan (Isaac-Daniel), and his grandson, Aidhan Farley Astrachan. He was predeceased by his daughter Anne Farley, his brother James P. Farley, and his sister Maryrose F. Swift. Visitation will be held at the Quinn Hopping Funeral Home of Livingston, 145 East Mount Pleasant Avenue, Livingston (NJ) on Monday July 8th from 4 to 8pm. The Funeral Mass will be offered at St. Joseph's Church, 44 Benvenue Avenue, West Orange, NJ on Tuesday July 9th at 10am, followed by the interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, 225 Ridgedale Avenue, East Hanover, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Honorable Thomas R. Farley Scholarship Fund at Seton Hall Preparatory School, 120 Northfield Ave., West Orange, NJ 07052

EVANS--Linda, Y&R publicist, magazine editor, loving mother, wife of George Evans and longtime Darien, CT resident passed away June 22, 2013. As she promised, life was never dull with her! A fall memorial is being planned. Donations may be made to loon.org to help protect the New Hampshire loons that Linda loved.

DEUTSCH--Leah. Temple Beth El of Cedarhurst mourns the passing of our longtime and beloved member Leah Deutsch. We extend condolences to her daughters and the entire Deutsch family. Rabbi Sholom Stern Richard Holland, President

CLAY--John Peter, passed away peacefully on Monday 24th June 2013, aged 78, following a long illness. Beloved husband of Jennifer for 41 years. Greatly mourned by all family members, friends and colleagues. No flowers, please; a private family funeral has taken place and a memorial meeting will be held at a later date. Donations, if desired, to The Queen's College, Oxford, or St Paul's School, Lonsdale Road, London, England, SW13 9JT.

CHANEN--Anne D.,Passed away on July 5, 2013, in West Orange, New Jersey. Formerly of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania and Tucson, Arizona. Born April 14, 1918 to the late Alex and Leah Harris. Beloved wife of the late Hyman Chanen. Adored mother to Larry Chanen and his spouse Jack Burkhalter, and the late Rochelle (Michael) Sulman. Beloved grandmother to Stacy (Mordechai) Sulman Kahana and Erik (Dara Less) Sulman and great-grandmother to David, Mikaela and Yarden, Raya and Michael. Loving sister to the late Sylvia (Ascher) Penn and Arnold (Ethel) Harris. Cherished aunt, great-aunt and great-great-aunt, and beloved friend to many. Anne was a community leader in the Philadelphia area, serving as chair of the Northeast Philadelphia Jewish Community Relations Council and a leader of the Women's Division of the Jewish Federation of Greater Philadelphia, among other organizations. In her later years, she served as volunteer coordinator for the United Way. She was active in civil rights and interfaith relations. She had a beauty of spirit, a radiant smile and an unsinkable optimism. Her generous love, warmth, and inner strength will live through us all. Services and Interment will be on Monday in the Philadelphia area. Donations in Anne's memory can be made to Daughters of Israel Geriatric Center, West Orange, New Jersey, or to the Jewish Community Relations Council of the Jewish Federation of Greater Philadelphia. Platt Memorial Chapels, Cherry Hill, NJ.

CENTOLA--Gary Dennis, 64, beloved husband of Kathleen Gefell, died peacefully on June 30, 2013 at his home in Poughquag, NY surrounded by his family. Gary, a former Assistant District Attorney of New York City, was a partner at the law firm of Rivkin Radler. He will be remembered for his love of family and friends, his generous heart, his intelligence and humor, his love of music, and his amazing guitar leads. Gary is survived by his wife of 42 years, Kathleen Gefell, brother Ron (Anna), sister Elaine, and his beloved niece and nephew who loved him like a father, Jacqueline Sechler Klein (Danny) and Brian Clyde Sechler (Alexandra). He is also survived by nieces and nephews, Jennifer, Mark, Justin, Cory, Taylor, James, and Lily; four grand nieces and nephews, Oscar, Penelope, Tyler, and Charlotte; and a loving extended family of sisters and brothers-in-law, Patricia (Walter), Sharon (Kevin), Allen (Kathy), and Eileen (Richard). "He was and always will be our Patriarch." In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Sloan Kettering-Mesothelioma Research. Memorial services will be held on Friday, July 12th at 3:30pm at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amerstdam, Manhattan.

BEER--Murray. An extraordinary man whose love, generosity, humor and wisdom enriched our lives. We cherished our friendship with him and his beloved wife, Lovey. He was a phenomenal mentor and menche. He will live in our hearts forever. Nancy and Howard Brown

BATKIN--Sanford, 87, peacefully passed away on July 5th, 2013 at his home in Lake Worth, FL. Sandy was a beloved and noted jeweler on 47th Street for over 50 years, where he befriended thousands of customers. He was always described as a "good man" with the utmost of integrity. Sandy leaves his loving and devoted wife of 26 years, Barbara (nee Guercio) and three daughters; Ronnie, Debra and Ilisa, three step-children; Terri, Lisa and Lawrence, as well as 12 grandchildren and a great-grandchild. Sandy, we'll miss you. You were the ultimate diamond. John and Monique Guffey
AUSTIN--Robert, (Robby) of a heart attack at 66. Son of the late Bud Austin, stepson of Connie Austin and my bonus big brother. Hug Bud for me. I'll love you always, Anita

AUDETTE--Anna Held, a distinguished teacher and artist whose paintings of industrial ruins and obsolete machinery chronicled the decline of American industry, died on June 9th after a long illness. She was 74 years old. After graduating from Yale with an MFA she started what would be her life's career at Southern Connecticut State University, teaching drawing and printmaking. Her own work evolved from printmaking to painting around 1980, and her works are in numerous museums and private collections. She is survived by her husband of 49 years, two daughters and three grandchildren. Donations may be made to the Association for Frontotemporal Degeneration.

SHAPIRO--Romie. The family and close friends of Romie Shapiro deeply mourn his passing at the age of 104. Devoted husband of 80 years to Blanche, Romie was a notable international philanthropist, scholar and an irreplaceable pillar of the Jewish community. Romie was born in 1910 in London, England. Son of Esriel and Jenny Shapiro, Romie practiced law in England for several years before he met Blanche, his soulmate and the love of his life. Blanche and Romie were married and came to the United States in 1941. In 1942, Romie became Chairman of the Board and Executive Director of A.J. Hollander & Co. and an international partner of the firm. In 1977 Romie and Blanche Shapiro founded the Friends of Bezalel Academy of Arts, Jerusalem. Romie was its President, Chairman and Chairman Emeritus. He also served for many years as Chairman of the Board of Governors of the Bezalel Academy itself, which awarded him the "Yakir Bezalel (Worthy of Bezalel) Award" in 1983. The Blanche and Romie Shapiro School of Fine Arts of the Bezalel Academy is an enduring tribute and legacy to an extraordinary couple. In 1942, Romie became Chairman of the American Friends of the Israel Museum where he served as Treasurer and member of its Board. Romie was also a life trustee of the Jewish Museum of New York City. He served on the Board of Trustees of the American-Israel Cultural Foundation and in 1966 he was honored with their King Solomon Award. Romie was also a member of the Board of the Benjamin Cardozo School of Law. Romie, together with his beloved wife of 80 years, Blanche, was a philanthropist, patron of the arts, and supporter of Jewish education. Romie's autobiography, So Far So Good, was dedicated to his wife with the inscription: "If another person's good qualities far outshine our own, there is no recourse but love." -Goethe. To know Romie was to love him. He was an inspiration to all who met and knew him. Romie is survived and deeply mourned by Blanche, close friends, family and members of the Bezalel community. His funeral will be held Monday, July 8th at 11am at Park East Synagogue, 163 East 67th Street. On behalf of the Friends of Bezalel; Ilan Kaufthal, Chairman; Bathsheva Rifkin, President; & Sivia Loria, Vice President

SHAPIRO--Romie. The Board and staff of the American Friends and the Israel Museum mourn the death of our long time friend. Romie served AFIM first as Treasurer, then as President and Board Chairman for over a decade. He and Blanche supported nearly every Museum department, especially enriching our holdings in Modern Art. We extend heartfelt condolences to Blanche, his bride for 80 years. Stephen Lash, Judy Steinhardt, AFIM Board Co Chairs James Snyder, IMJ Anne and Jerome Fisher Director Monique Birenbaum, AFIM Executive Director

SHAPIRO--Romie. The entire Hebrew Home at Riverdale community is deeply saddened at the loss of Romie Shapiro. For decades, Romie recognized the Hebrew Home's leadership in caring for older adults and was a stalwart supporter of many of the Hebrew Home's award winning services. His confidence in our work will always be an inspiration. We extend our condolences to the entire Shapiro family. May his memory be a blessing. The Hebrew Home at Riverdale Jeffery Maurer, Chairman Daniel Reingold, President and CEO

SCHIFF--Dr. Alvin I. The Yeshiva University family is deeply grieved by the passing of our revered alumnus, Dr. Alvin I. Schiff, of blessed memory, the beloved husband of Miriam Schiff. An alumnus of Yeshiva College and the Ferkauf Graduate School of Psychology from which he received his BA and PhD, respectively, he rose to international fame because of his outstanding leadership in the global field of Jewish education for which he was awarded the President's Prize in Jewish Education in Israel in February 2005. At Yeshiva University, he was the Irving I. Stone Distinguished Professor of Jewish Education. He founded and directed the Graduate School of Jewish Education in 1959 which was renamed in 1982 as the Azrieli Graduate School of Jewish Education and Administration. As an admired member of the Board of Trustees of the Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary for many years, he helped to formulate significant professional training programs. On the world scene he played the founding role in the post High School Program in Israel (Tochnit Yod Gimel), the Hidon Tenakh Bible contest in the U.S., The Salute to Israel Parade and the March of the Living USA. He authored more than a dozen books, several hundred articles and research papers relating to the status of Jewish education and was editor of The Journal of Jewish Education from 1967-1997. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife Miriam, their children Debra Karen (and Michael) Block, Linda Susan (and Arthur) Poleyeff, their six grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. May the entire family and all who loved him be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President

MOORE--Sanford Earl, born October 10, 1928, died July 7, 2013, after a prolonged illness. Sandy was the son of Pauline Komar Moore and Robert JC Moore. He was an attorney and CPA and was involved in the foundation of both the NY and American Associations of Attorney-CPAs. Sandy was raised in Brooklyn. He went to Rutgers University at age 15 and graduated at 18 with a BS in mathematics. He was a member of Phi Epsilon Pi fraternity. He attained a master's in accounting from NYU. He received his law degree from New York Law School. Sandy married Elaine Wolfson whom he met at her Sweet 16 party. They were married for 63 years. In addition to his wife, Elaine, he is survived by four children and their spouses, Cathy (Stephen Gheen), Douglas (Neva), Leanne (Richard Gumer), Ross (Beth), grandchildren: Carrie Gheen, Jared Moore (Caitlin Morey), Alexander Gumer, James Gheen, Caroline Gumer, Allie Moore and Eva Moore; and a sister, Barbara Steiner, brother-in-law, Edwin Steiner, and their families. Funeral is at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., NYC, at 11:30 on Monday, July 8, 2013. Shiva will be immediately afterwards at the home of Leanne and Rich, 200 East End Ave., NYC., until 9pm. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Parkinson's Foundation or the American Heart Association.

McCARTHY--Janis E.,age 91, died peacefully at home on July 5. She was pre-deceased by her husband of 45 years, Allen D. McCarthy. Janis is survived by her children: Patricia, Allen Jr., James, Mary Detwiler, Elizabeth Frumberg, and Carey; and pre-deceased by Jane and William. She is also survived by her 19 grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. Born and raised in Bridgeport, CT, she attended Laurelton Hall School and Cedar Crest College. After marrying Allen, they moved to New York City and later Long Beach, NY, to raise their eight children. Deeply religious, she was a member of both the Rosary Altar Society, Catholic Daughters, and was a Franciscan of the Third Order. She was deeply committed to the AHRC and was given a key to the City of Long Beach as well as a day in her honor. Janis will be sorely missed by both family and friends, whose lives she forever enriched. A wake will be held at Jordan's Funeral Home, 302 Long Beach Rd., Island Park, NY, at 2-4pm and 7-9pm on July 9. A Funeral Mass will be held at St. Ignatius Martyr Church, 721 W. Broadway, Long Beach, NY at 10am on July 10. Donations can be made to the AHRC Nassau, 189 Wheatley Rd, Brookville, NY 11545.

LUFKIN--Cynthia. The Juilliard School community deeply mourns the passing of Cynthia Lufkin. With her beloved husband Dan she was an important Juilliard supporter and co-chaired the most successful benefit in the School's history. Her great courage and elegance stood as a model for us all. We send our sincere condolences to Dan and her entire family and friends. Bruce Kovner, Chair Joseph W. Polisi, President

LUFKIN--Cynthia. The HELP USA organization extends deepest sympathies to Dan Lufkin and the family of their long time friend and generous supporter, Cynthia Lufkin. Ms. Lufkin's deep commitment to providing opportunity and homes for victims of Domestic Violence and others in need will continue to inspire HELP USA.

LUFKIN--Cynthia. We mourn the loss of our dear and courageous friend, Cynthia Lufkin. Her generous, caring spirit has enriched our lives and inspired us to be better. Heartfelt condolences to her loving husband, Dan Lufkin and their beautiful family. Maria Cuomo Cole and Kenneth Cole

LUFKIN--Cynthia. The Board of Trustees and Director's Council of the Museum of the City of New York mourn the loss of Cynthia Lufkin, a longtime supporter, much loved friend, and an invaluable chairman of the Director's Council.

LERNER--Susan, Goodbye to our dear friend, a consummate New Yorker who lived life to the fullest. While managing real estate and other investments, Susan, a bright and curious person, also found time to travel the world and to serve for decades as a volunteer tutor in the NYC schools. She enjoyed and supported many theatre companies, museums, the New York City ballet and two synagogues. A loving wife and mother to Larry, Elizabeth, Marc, and daughter-in-law Nina. She was a great friend who was generous with her advice and counsel. Susan, we loved you and will sorely miss you. Lana and Jack

LERNER--Susan Goodstein, 72, on July 5, 2013. Beloved wife of Laurence, mother of Elisabeth and Marc, mother-in-law of Nina Rifkind and sister of Robert Goodstein. We were fortunate to have her as part of our family for as long as we did. She shared her wealth of knowledge, kindness, compassion, grace and humor very generously. She leaves behind a legacy of love and good deeds. Graveside service Tuesday, July 9, 2013, 11:00am at Union Fields Cemetery. Shiva private. Donations in her memory may be made to: Career Transition for Dancers.

LANDAU--Jacques, 96 years old of Jackson Heights, NY, passed away July 1, 2013. He is survived by his beloved wife of 67 years, Noemi. Services will be held at Conway Funeral Home at 82-19 Northern Blvd, Jackson Heights on Monday, July 8. Visitation at 7pm, Service at 8pm. Donations in his memory may be made to Selfhelp Community Services at selfhelp.net.

HOROWITZ--Minna, on July 6. A lifelong advocate for social justice, inveterate upper west sider. She loved her family dearly; sisters and brothers: Miriam Reisman, Elliot Horowitz, Philip and Estelle Horowitz, and the late Lee and Al Dorin; nine nieces and nephews; nine great-nieces and nephews; and one great-great-niece. We will miss her incredible spirit.

HOLAND--Sidney Joshua. Beloved Husband, Father, Saba, Brother and Uncle. Sidney's life is a testimony to love, resilience and integrity. He was born in Poland and fled to Siberia during World War II where he spent much of his childhood struggling to survive. He moved to Israel in 1957 and served in the Israeli Army where he met the love of his life, Tzipora Rapaport, his wife of 52 years. Sidney emigrated to the United States in 1961 speaking no English and with no formal education, initially working as a plumber's apprentice. He went on to found the ALFA Piping Corporation, one of the preeminent air conditioning and piping contractors in New York City. Under Sidney's leadership, their work has included the renovation of Carnegie Hall, the 911 Memorial and virtually every hospital and university in New York City. Sidney was beloved by all who knew him for his compassion, humility, wisdom and kindness. He was a generous philanthropist and a strong supporter of the Friends of the Israel Defense Forces (FIDF), which provides scholarships and assistance to former Israeli Soldiers. His greatest accomplishments, however, are his two beautiful daughters, Sharon and Adina, loving son-in-law, Jeff, and five exceptional grandchildren, Evan, Nicole, Zachary, Justin and Tyler. Many have already gone on to college educations and earn advanced degrees, things that a boy from Poland could never have imagined. Sidney lived the American dream. He would kiss the ground and pronounce "God Bless America" each time he returned home from a trip abroad. He passed away on July 4th. Funeral services will be held, Monday, July 8, 11:30am at Sinai Chapels, Fresh Meadows, NY. Donations in Sidney's honor may be made to FIDF of North Miami Beach. Sidney will be missed by all who knew him. He will never be forgotten.

HAMILTON--Frances Rosemary, on July 4, 2013 at age 97. Beloved daughter of the late Clyde R. and Frances A. Hamilton. Loving sister of the late John R. and Walter C. Hamilton. Dear aunt of Clara Fagan and Julie Taylor. Independent woman who ran her own business and her own life. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday 10am at St. Jean the Baptist Church, 76th St. and Lexington Ave., NYC. Interment to follow at Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY.

FISHMAN--Alice R. died July 6. Beloved wife of Dr. Melvin I. for 59 yrs. Loving mother of Barry and Charles (Nancy). Cherished grandmother of Alexa and Kimberly. Former Mayor of Russell Gardens. Chair of Great Neck Cable Commission. Funeral Wednesday 11:30am Nassau North Chapel Great Neck.

DUDELSON--Joyce M. May 23rd, 1950 July 4th, 2013. Loving wife of Mark Dudelson and devoted mother to Alexander Dudelson. Loving daughter of Sarah Mart and Bernard (2008). You always counted your garden by the flowers that bloomed and not by the leaves that fell. We will always love you. Memorial Donations can be made to the JDRF New York Chapter; www.JDRF.org

CHANEN--Anne D.,Passed away on July 5, 2013, in West Orange, New Jersey. Formerly of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania and Tucson, Arizona. Born April 14, 1918 to the late Alex and Leah Harris. Beloved wife of the late Hyman Chanen. Adored mother to Larry Chanen and his spouse Jack Burkhalter, and the late Rochelle (Michael) Sulman. Beloved grandmother to Stacy (Mordechai) Sulman Kahana and Erik (Dara Less) Sulman and great-grandmother to David, Mikaela and Yarden, Raya and Michael. Loving sister to the late Sylvia (Ascher) Penn and Arnold (Ethel) Harris. Cherished aunt, great-aunt and great-great-aunt, and beloved friend to many. Anne was a community leader in the Philadelphia area, serving as chair of the Northeast Philadelphia Jewish Community Relations Council and a leader of the Women's Division of the Jewish Federation of Greater Philadelphia, among other organizations. In her later years, she served as volunteer coordinator for the United Way. She was active in civil rights and interfaith relations. She had a beauty of spirit, a radiant smile and an unsinkable optimism. Her generous love, warmth, and inner strength will live through us all. Services and Interment will be on Monday in the Philadelphia area. Donations in Anne's memory can be made to Daughters of Israel Geriatric Center, West Orange, New Jersey, or to the Jewish Community Relations Council of the Jewish Federation of Greater Philadelphia. Platt Memorial Chapels, Cherry Hill, NJ.

CAPLAN--Arthur I. 92, beloved husband of Harriet for 71 years, passed away on July 5, 2013. Devoted father of Robert (Francine), Richard (Dolores) and Debra (Jack), proud grandfather of Amy, Colin, Michael, Ariel, Nicholas, Max, Emmett and Rory, and of great-grandchildren Sophie and Julien. Served in U.S. Army (WWII), long career in the automotive industry, former member of Fresh Meadow CC for 54 years, 30-year resident of Palm Beach County and actively involved in the Frenchman's Creek community. Avid golfer, bridge player and all around sports enthusiast. Good friend to many, loved by all. He made a difference. He will be sorely missed. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Research to Prevent Blindness, 645 Madison Ave., Floor 21 New York, NY 10022-1010.
