SHAPIRO--Romie. The Bezalel Academy of Arts and Design Jerusalem deeply mourns the passing of the Founder, Past President and Chairman of the Friends of Bezalel, Benefactor of The Romie and Blanche Shapiro Department of Fine Arts at Bezalel Academy, recipient of the Yakir Bezalel title. He was a true patron of the arts and supporter of education. We shall be forever grateful for his immense commitment and tireless efforts on behalf of Bezalel Academy in Jerusalem. He was an exceptional friend and will be sorely missed. We extend our most heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife Blanche, with whom he shared his commitments and interests. She herself is an inspiration to us all. Prof. Eva Illouz, President Mr. Dor Lin, Director General Mrs. Liv Sperber, Director of International Affairs & Development

SHAPIRO--Romie. The entire Hebrew Home at Riverdale community is deeply saddened at the loss of Romie Shapiro. For decades, Romie recognized the Hebrew Home's leadership in caring for older adults and was a stalwart supporter of many of the Hebrew Home's award winning services. His confidence in our work will always be an inspiration. We extend our condolences to the entire Shapiro family. May his memory be a blessing. The Hebrew Home at Riverdale Jeffery Maurer, Chairman Daniel Reingold, President and CEO

NUMEROFF--Harriet. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Harriet Numeroff, wife of the late Seymour. Our condolences to her children, Nancy (Neil) Koenig, Gil (Robin) Numeroff, and Jane Numeroff; her grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

RYAN--Joseph D.,(Joe). Col. (Ret) USA, 81 of Noblesville, IN, originally of Flushing, NY, Fordham University graduate and 29 year career US Army officer, died on July 4, 2013 following complications from leukemia.

MUMM--Elizabeth Grellene, peacefully, at home on July 7, 2013, surrounded by her family. Beloved wife of Donald, devoted mother of Thomas and Beth, sweetest "Nana" of Tommy, Kristen, Stephen and Michael. Cherished mother-in-law of Vincent and Diane, dear sister of Maureen and Sharon. Funeral mass Wednesday July 10, 2013, 11:00am at Epiphany Church, Second Ave at 22 St. NYC.

MACK--Ilene. The Board of Directors, staff and friends of the Nonprofit Coordinating Committee of New York note with great sadness the passing of our beloved Board Member, Ilene Mack. Ilene's extraordinary humor, optimism and genuine love for the nonprofit community permeated everything she did. John E. Craig, Jr., Chairman Michael E. Clark, President

LUFKIN--Cynthia. The Langone Family mourns the loss of Cynthia Lufkin. She and her beloved husband, Dan, have touched too many lives to count. We join in offering our hearts and our sympathy to Dan and her precious children, Schuyler, Aster Lee and Daniel. May the world always reflect the goodness, the kindness and the generosity of spirit Cynthia brought to it. Elaine and Ken
LEVY--Dorothy. You were always there for me. Heartfelt gratitude. Fondest love to John, Johnny, and Tom and families Will miss you madly. Ellin

LEVY--Dorothy "Dot". The brightest star in the universe has gone out and our lives have been diminished. Dot Levy was beautiful, Phi Beta brilliant, effervescent and had a genuine southern graciousness and warmth that she never lost. Her friends were legion and we were blessed to have been among those closest to her and John for over 50 years. Our lives have been so entwined that it feels like we have lost a piece of ourselves. Dearest Dot, we will miss you forever and your spirit will be with us always. Our deepest sympathy goes out to John, Johnny, Tom and Valerie, Allegra, Cameron and Sasha. We share your devastating loss and cherish all the wonderful memories. Judy and Aaron

LEVY--Dorothy. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member Dorothy Levy and extend sincerest condolences to her bereaved family. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein and President David B. Edelson, Central Synagogue of New York City

LEVY--Dorothy F.,77, died peacefully on July 8th, surrounded by her beloved husband of 55 years, John, and her two sons, John and Tom. She was the daughter of the late Eddie and Claire Felson and sister of the late Sally Fyvolent, of Jacksonville, Florida. Dot was the beloved mother-in-law of Valerie Levy and grandmother of Sasha Levy, Nathan Anderson, Allegra Levy and Cameron Levy. Dot led a very special and happy life, spreading joy and beauty in the world. She had a unique connection with people, as her many friends will attest. Her Southern upbringing in Jacksonville, Florida, informed her aesthetic; she had a keen sense of beauty, style and hospitality which she applied with charm and grace to her world in Manhattan, East Hampton and Wellington, Florida. Dot began her journey northward from Jacksonville in 1953, graduating valedictorian from Landon High School, attending Duke University, and graduating magna cum laude. She was a member of Alph Phi Epsilon sorority, Phi Beta Kappa, was named Azalea Queen at the annual Azalea Fesitval at Charleston, SC, and listed in Who's Who Among Students in American Universities and Colleges. In 1958 she moved to NYC to join the love of her life, John S. Levy, and begin married life. She was a successful model in New York, having posed for many fashion magazines as well as the national US Marines recruiting poster of 1960. In her last days she spoke of how grateful she was for the happy life she'd had, finding tremendous fulfillment from the love of family and friends. She wanted to encourage her children and grandchildren to do their best, as she always did, regretting only that she never got a chance to tell her dear friends that she was in her final days. Friends may call on Wednesday, July 10 from 5pm to 7pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY 10028, and Funeral services will be held there on Thursday, July 11th, at 9:30am, followed by internment in East Hampton at Cedar Lawn cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 633 Third Avenue, 28th Floor, New York, NY 10017.

LEVY--Dorothy "Dot". Gone but will never be forgotten, not just by her family but also by her friends, because of her charm, sincerity, warmth and enthusiasm for sharing the best aspects of friendship with friends. Bonnie and Clive

LERNER--Susan, Goodbye to our dear friend, a consummate New Yorker who lived life to the fullest. While managing real estate and other investments, Susan, a bright and curious person, also found time to travel the world and to serve for decades as a volunteer tutor in the NYC schools. She enjoyed and supported many theatre companies, museums, the New York City ballet and two synagogues. A loving wife and mother to Larry, Elizabeth, Marc, and daughter-in-law Nina. She was a great friend who was generous with her advice and counsel. Susan, we loved you and will sorely miss you. Lana and Jack

LERNER--Susan. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the death of our long time, dedicated member, Susan Lerner, part of a five generation Rodeph Sholom family. We will miss her warmth, caring and devotion to family, friends and community. Our deepest sympathy is extended to her beloved husband Laurence Lerner, their children, Elizabeth, Marc and Nina, her brother Robert and all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, DD, Senior Rabbi Karen L. Berman, President

LERNER--Susan Goodstein, 72, on July 5, 2013. Beloved wife of Laurence, mother of Elisabeth and Marc, mother-in-law of Nina Rifkind and sister of Robert Goodstein. We were fortunate to have her as part of our family for as long as we did. She shared her wealth of knowledge, kindness, compassion, grace and humor very generously. She leaves behind a legacy of love and good deeds. Graveside service Tuesday, July 9, 2013, 11:00am at Union Fields Cemetery. Shiva private. Donations in her memory may be made to: Career Transition for Dancers.

KLIGMAN--Joel. The Board of Governors and Members of the Elberon Bathing Club mourn the passing of our long time Member and dear friend, Joel Kligman, after a long and courageous fight against Parkinsons. A successful businessman and renowned member of the thoroughbred horseracing community, he loved his family, his horses and his friends. One of his other lesser known passions was body-surfing the waves at EBC. In recent years he was forced to enjoy the waves from a lounge chair facing the breakers but he never lost his fascination with that Jersey shore surf, which he could watch for hours. By passing on July 4th he made it easy for us to be reminded every Independence Day to pause for a moment and watch a wave roll in and imagine him riding it to shore. Our heartfelt sympathies go out to the entire Kligman family and particularly to our fellow Members Andy and Beth. He is already sorely missed by all of us who knew him. Robert Fagenson, President Douglas Schwartz, Secretary

HUEBSCHER--Herbert, on July 8, 2013. Beloved husband of Lucille for 61 years. Cherished father of Toni, Eric and Rob, and their spouses Jimmy, Rona and Sally. Loving grandfather of Sadie, Harry, Nathaniel, Sarah, Ben, Emily and her husband Aaron. He will be dearly missed by his wide circle of friends. Services on Wednesday at 9am at Temple Isaiah in Lexington, MA, followed by internment at Mt. Hebron cemetery in Flushing, NY.

FOX--Marvin A. September 5, 1933 - July 6, 2013. "Because nice matters". Beloved husband, brother, uncle and friend. Waiter at Reids Coffee Shop for 36 years. World traveler, public speaker and activist for gay rights and the rights of gay seniors. Loved by all who knew him. Survived by his sister Eleanor Luke, brother Seymour Miller and sister-in-law Adele Miller, his nieces and nephews, a large group of loving friends, and his husband Michael Keiran-Fox. No funeral services. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to MJHS Palliative and Hospice Care.

FISHMAN--Alice R. died July 6. Beloved wife of Dr. Melvin I. for 59 yrs. Loving mother of Barry and Charles (Nancy). Cherished grandmother of Alexa and Kimberly. Former Mayor of Russell Gardens. Chair of Great Neck Cable Commission. Funeral Wednesday 11:30am Nassau North Chapel Great Neck.

FEFERMAN--Rafael. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Rafael Feferman, a selfless philanthropist who was committed to strengthening Jewish communities in New York, in Israel, and throughout the world. As the only member of his family to survive the Holocaust, Rafael dedicated his life to helping other survivors and educating the public about this tragic period. He leaves behind a generous legacy that will enrich Jewish life for years to come. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

DALVITO--Rocco James, died suddenly on Friday July 5, 2013 due to heart complications. He was 86 years old. Born in Mamaroneck, NY in 1927 and the son of Amelia and Loreto Dalvito, he was the youngest of three siblings. Mr. Dalvito, who was a life-long resident of the village, was predeceased by his most beloved wife of 42 years Anne Numrich Dalvito, his daughter Deborah Keats McCarter, his brother Frank Dalvito and his sister Flora Mayer. He attended Mamaroneck High School and was a veteran who fought in WWII in the Pacific Theater. For most of his life he owned Dip-In Car Wash Corp. His business was one of his greatest passions and he worked up until his death. His other interests included auto racing, motorcycles, gardening and horses. He was deeply loved by his family and friends and will be greatly missed. He is survived by his children Gregory James Dalvito of New York, NY, William Keats of Bethlehem, PA, Lisa Britton of Darien, CT and his seven grandchildren, Tony, Alex, Emma, Danny, Amelia, Jamie and Charlotte. A visitation will be held at Coxe and Graziano Funeral Home, 767 East Boston Post Road Mamaroneck, NY from 4pm to 9pm on Tuesday July 9th.

BUSK--Joseph R.,86, of Palm City, FL died on June 28, 2013. Joseph is survived by his wife, Grace Chambers Busk of 38 years; and daughters Wendy Busk, Hope Reis, and Gay Thorn; son Joseph Busk III; step-children Tysh McGrail, Tye, Whitney and Alex Tilt; and many loving grandchildren and extended family. He was preceded in death by his former wife, Gladys Terbell who succumbed to cancer in 1975. Joseph graduated from St. Paul's School in Concord, NH, and received his BA in Architecture from Pratt Institute. After serving in the US Navy during WWII, Joseph co-founded Outdoor Traders in Greenwich, CT. As an avid outdoors-man, Joseph loved sailing, hunting, and cycling. A special thank you to Sand Hill Cove for their loving care of Joseph. Memorials may be made to the National Parkinson Foundation.

ZBAR--Joseph and Florence. July 10 is the 75th anniversary of the marriage of Joseph E. Zbar, MD (b. Nov. 9,1910; d. Mar. 23, 1995) and Florence Zbar (b. May 19, 1918; d. Jan 23, 2013). Survived by children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. They are greatly missed.

WOLFF--Harry, 86, a long-time book manufacturing executive, died Sunday in New York City. Mr. Wolff lived in Manhattan and Bridgehampton. He served in the Air Force during World War II. Survivors include his wife, Ruth Nagourney. A service will be held at 4:30pm on Thursday, July 11, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th Street, New York, NY.

WIENER--Rhoda L.,87, of Lake Worth, FL and Copake Lake, NY. Our hearts are heavy with extreme sadness that our matriarch has gone to her eternal rest. Cherished daughter of Dorothy and Irving. Sister of Larry. adoring wife of the late Edward. Loving mother of Hilly, Ira (Margarita), Jody (Bobby), Susan (Jeff). Proud grandmother of Matt, Ben, Elyssa, and Scott. Donations in her memory may be made to Maccabi USA, 1926 Arch Street, Philadelphia, PA 19103.

UTEVSKY--Daniel Hyam, 62, died unexpectedly after a fall in his home at Port Liberte, NJ, on June 28. Dan was a retired telecom and corporate attorney and bon vivant. He enjoyed travels, wine, good cigars, fine dining and family. He was an unreconstructed liberal and a gifted teller of jokes. Predeceased by his beloved son Stefan, Dan is survived by his adoring mother Ruth, sister Naomi and Tom Lima, brother Michael and Alexandra Utevsky, and nieces and nephew Anna, Alex and Amanda. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to the ACLU. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

UCHITEL--Rhoda, peacefully on July 7th, 2013 in her 82nd year. Beloved mother, mother-in-law, grandmother, sister, aunt and friend. A woman who was truly larger than life. She will be deeply missed. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the ALS Association, 1275 K Street NW - Suite 250, Washington, D.C. 20005. Friends may call Tuesday evening, 5-7pm at Frank E. Campbell The Funeral Chapel Madison Avenue at 81 St. Services Wednesday, July 10, 2013, 12noon at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave at 65 St.

LEVY--Dorothy F.,77, died peacefully on July 8th, surrounded by her beloved husband of 55 years, John, and her two sons, John and Tom. She was the daughter of the late Eddie and Claire Felson and sister of the late Sally Fyvolent, of Jacksonville, Florida. Dot was the beloved mother-in-law of Valerie Levy and grandmother of Sasha Levy, Nathan Anderson, Allegra Levy and Cameron Levy. Dot led a very special and happy life, spreading joy and beauty in the world. She had a unique connection with people, as her many friends will attest. Her Southern upbringing in Jacksonville, Florida, informed her aesthetic; she had a keen sense of beauty, style and hospitality which she applied with charm and grace to her world in Manhattan, East Hampton and Wellington, Florida. Dot began her journey northward from Jacksonville in 1953, graduating valedictorian from Landon High School, attending Duke University, and graduating magna cum laude. She was a member of Alph Phi Epsilon sorority, Phi Beta Kappa, was named Azalea Queen at the annual Azalea Fesitval at Charleston, SC, and listed in Who's Who Among Students in American Universities and Colleges. In 1958 she moved to NYC to join the love of her life, John S. Levy, and begin married life. She was a successful model in New York, having posed for many fashion magazines as well as the national US Marines recruiting poster of 1960. In her last days she spoke of how grateful she was for the happy life she'd had, finding tremendous fulfillment from the love of family and friends. She wanted to encourage her children and grandchildren to do their best, as she always did, regretting only that she never got a chance to tell her dear friends that she was in her final days. Friends may call on Wednesday, July 10 from 5pm to 7pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY 10028, and Funeral services will be held there on Thursday, July 11th, at 9:30am, followed by internment in East Hampton at Cedar Lawn cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 633 Third Avenue, 28th Floor, New York, NY 10017.

KAZHDAN--Naum. A renowned photographer who worked with the New York Times for 23 years, whose other pursuits included those of industrial designer, inventor, and an international ambassador of jazz culture known for his lasting efforts to popularize jazz in the USSR, died on Thursday, June 27th, in Brooklyn, NY, of heart failure. He was 74. His death was announced by his wife of 44 years, Lily Kazhdan. Mr. Kazhdan did not fit most people's image of a typical immigrant from the Soviet Union (he and his wife arrived in the US in 1977). Many fellow emigres considered him unusually acculturated to New York's elegant, jazz era-inspired style. His work, however, belied admitted inspiration from Russian art of the early 20th century, along with multiple other sources. Mr. Kazhdan's photographic work was marked by a lasting humanist influence: ever interested in depicting relations between people and objects in the frame of his camera, he integrated rich psychological drama not only into his countless group portraits, but into his nature morte and cityscape shots. Born in Leningrad (now St. Petersburg), Russia, three years before World War II, Mr. Kazhdan, as a child, lived through the horrendous Siege of Leningrad, the Nazi blockade of the city in 1942-44. Post-war he emerged as a talented young photographer, receiving his first major award at 19, at a Warsaw Poland-based jazz photo contest accompanying the International Jazz Jamboree. Another early and life-spanning passion was jazz: Naum had played double bass in home-grown bands in his early teens. Aged 18, he found himself a founding president of Leningrad's first officially permitted jazz club, D-58, which became the local epicenter of jazz life, and triggered the precipitate spread of jazz culture throughout the USSR. As a photographer, he immortalized some of the historical moments of this eastward jazz invasion, including startling images from Dizzy Gillespie's first concert tour of Russia. Many more star-studded jazz photographs followed, as well as some recognizable jazz record jackets. In 1998 he was instrumental in organizing jazz festivities in St. Petersburg, Russia in commemoration of the 40th anniversary of D-58 where Naum received the first Voice of America's Willis Conover Award. As an industrial art designer, Naum worked at the Leningrad Scientific Research Institute of Shipbuilding. Through his own initiative at the institute he pioneered the development of the first advertizing department for the USSR Ministry of Shipbuilding. After leaving the institute, he used his experience to open his own independent photography studio with which he gained prestigious contracts with the Leningrad House of Fashion, and the entertainment company Lenconcert. Shortly after immigration to the US, he landed a studio photographer's job at the New York Times. Naum made a reputation for himself as a concept photographer capable of breathing life into any content; his unconventional photo illustrations included an iconic image of a butcher's axe accompanying a tax-cutting article. Later in his American career, Mr. Kazhdan did not abandon his Russian roots. In the mid-1990s, he helped launch a festival of Russian jazz in New York; and he participated in multiple projects documenting the history of jazz movement in Russia. Until his last days, he kept close relations with St. Petersburg's jazz community among which he was treated as a revered founding father. His passionate life lived by both sides of the Atlantic was an emblematic precursor of the globally connected cultural world in which we live today. He is survived by his wife Lily, and son Alex.

JEFFREY--James B.,was born May 22, 1929 to Neill P. Jeffrey Sr. and Minnie Meade Beck Jeffrey who resided in Jeanerette, Louisiana. He is survived by brother David W Jeffrey and predeceased by brother Neil P. Jeffrey Jr. He was partner of Harold M. F. Rush from 1961 until his death on June 6, 1996 residing in East Hampton and NYC. After graduating from Tulane University in Civil Engineering in 1950 he worked for Raymond Concrete Pile Company starting as a field supervisor and later becoming assistant District Manager of the New Orleans office. In preparation for seminary he attended the University of the South in Sewanee, Tennessee. Entered General Theological Seminary in NYC graduating in 1958 and served the Church of the Incarnation NYC for four years and then as Rector of St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Eastchester, NY until 1966. After being awarded a Fellowship by the Episcopal Mission Society of the Diocese of New York in Clinical Pastoral Education he moved into institutional chaplaincy at Central Islip State Psychiatric Hospital, the Rikers Island Penitentiary of NYC, Bellevue Hospital, Juvenile Detention Center, Bronx, NY. In 1970 he became the Director of Chaplains for the East Midtown Protestant Chaplaincy Incorporated which served the East side hospitals: New York/Cornell, Memorial Sloane-Kettering, Lenox Hill and the Hospital for Special Surgery. Changing the name to The Hospital Chaplaincy, the organization expanded to a staff of six chaplains, two CPE supervisors and five residents and was sustained by internal development efforts. He obtained a Masters degree in Human Resource Development from American University, Washington D. C. in 1984 and became the Chaplain and CPE Supervisor at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital. Here he coordinated the Ministry to Persons with AIDS establishing the AIDS Ministry and continued to care for those with AIDS until retirement in 1995. James Jeffrey spent his entire ministry in the Diocese of New York and the Eastern Region of the Association for Clinical Pastoral Education (ACPE). He served the Diocese as the Dean of Institutional Clergy and for the Committee on Alcoholism and Addictions. Within the ACPE, he served on the Certification Committee and chaired the Accreditation Committee. He helped found the Gay and Lesbian Task Force and was elected the Regional Director of the Eastern Region ACPE. Mr. Jeffrey's true passion was gardening and horticulture. He was renowned for his success in acclimatizing camellias to the environment of his East Hampton home. He was Honorary Vice President of the Delphinium Society, President of the Horticultural Alliance of the Hamptons (HAH) bringing horticultural education to local schools, the elderly, and the disabled. Visitation Friday 2-4pm and 7-9pm Yardley and Pino in East Hampton. Service 10:30am Saturday St. Luke's Episcopal, East Hampton. Donations to HAH and Episcopal Relief and Development.
JAMES--Ruth Buchman, loving widow of Donald James dies at 91. She is survived by her daughters Wendy James and Roni Goldsberry, her granddaughters Maura Goldsberry and Anne Goldsberry.

HOLAND--Sidney Joshua. Beloved husband, father, saba, brother and uncle. Sidney's life is a testimony to love, resilience and integrity. He was born in Poland and fled to Siberia during World War II where he spent much of his childhood struggling to survive. He moved to Israel in 1957 and served in the Israeli Army where he met the love of his life, Tzipora Rapaport, his wife of 52 years. Sidney emigrated to the United States in 1961 speaking no English and with no formal education, initially working as a plumber's apprentice. He went on to found the ALFA Piping Corporation, one of the preeminent air conditioning and piping contractors in New York City. Under Sidney's leadership, their work has included the renovation of Carnegie Hall, the 9/11 Memorial and virtually every hospital and university in New York City. Sidney was beloved by all who knew him for his compassion, humility, wisdom and kindness. He was a generous philanthropist and a strong supporter of the Friends of the Israel Defense Forces (FIDF), which provides scholarships and assistance to former Israeli Soldiers. His greatest accomplishments, however, are his two beautiful daughters, Sharon and Adina, loving son-in-law, Jeff, and five exceptional grandchildren, Evan, Nicole, Zachary, Justin and Tyler. Many have already gone on to college educations and earn advanced degrees, things that a boy from Poland could never have imagined. Sidney lived the American dream. He would kiss the ground and pronounce "God Bless America" each time he returned home from a trip abroad. He passed away on July 4th. Funeral services will be held, Monday, July 8, 11:30am at Sinai Chapels, Fresh Meadows, NY. Donations in Sidney's honor may be made to FIDF of North Miami Beach. Sidney will be missed by all who knew him. He will never be forgotten.

FISHMAN--Alice R. died July 6. Beloved wife of Dr. Melvin I. for 59 yrs. Loving mother of Barry and Charles (Nancy). Cherished grandmother of Alexa and Kimberly. Former Mayor of Russell Gardens. Chair of Great Neck Cable Commission. Funeral Wednesday 11:30am Nassau North Chapel Great Neck.

DURKIN--William A. Jr.,age 85, passed away peacefully, on July 6, 2013 at Greenwich Hospital with his family by his side. He was born January 29, 1928 to William A. Durkin and Margaret Durkin, graduated from the University of Notre Dame in 1949, with a degree in civil engineering, and served in the US Army during the Korean War. Following his discharge, he joined the Walsh Construction Company where he became its Executive Vice President and spent his entire career working on major industrial and commercial projects throughout the US and abroad, including the United Nations and renovation of Yankee Stadium amongst others in New York. He was particularly proud of his family's long association with Walsh Construction which his father joined in 1914. Bill volunteered his engineering expertise to many non-profit organizations, guiding projects for Greenwich Hospital, Brunswick School, YMCA, and Stepping Stones Museum, to name a few. He served on several boards and chaired the Brunswick School Board of Trustees in the 1980's. In recent years, he enjoyed his service of residents at the St. Camillus Nursing Home in Stamford. Although he traveled extensively for work, volunteerism and service at home played a large role in his life which he impressed on each of his sons. An athlete, Bill's interest in team sports, whether as a participant or observer, were exceeded only by his love of golf, fly-fishing and skiing, each of which he excelled at and spent countless hours teaching his sons and grandchildren. He could shoot his age, coax a trout to a dry fly and, as recently as February, was skiing in Vermont. He was a member of the Greenwich Country Club, Ekwanok Country Club and the Beaverkill Trout Club. A true gentleman, mentor and friend to many, Bill leaves behind his wife of nearly 60 years, Ginny, sons Bill, Patrick, Tim, Tom and Dan; daughters-in- law Martha, Kristen, Liz, Sue and Susan, and fifteen grandchildren. A funeral mass will be held at St. Michael's Church, Greenwich, Connecticut, on Thursday, July 11 at 1:00pm. There will not be calling hours. Bill's family requests, that in lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Cancer Research Institute (in memory of William A. Durkin, Jr.), 55 Broadway, Suite 1802, New York, NY 10006, or the William B. Nollman Memorial Caddy Scholarship Fund, c/o the Greenwich Country Club.
DUFFY--Beatrice. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Beatrice Duffy, associated with The New York Times from October 16, 1967 until retiring on March 31, 1989.

DALVITO--Rocco James, died suddenly on Friday July 5, 2013 due to heart complications. He was 86 years old. Born in Mamaroneck, NY in 1927 and the son of Amelia and Loreto Dalvito, he was the youngest of three siblings. Mr. Dalvito, who was a life-long resident of the village, was predeceased by his most beloved wife of 42 years Anne Numrich Dalvito, his daughter Deborah Keats McCarter, his brother Frank Dalvito and his sister Flora Mayer. He attended Mamaroneck High School and was a veteran who fought in WWII in the Pacific Theater. For most of his life he owned Dip-In Car Wash Corp. His business was one of his greatest passions and he worked up until his death. His other interests included auto racing, motorcycles, gardening and horses. He was deeply loved by his family and friends and will be greatly missed. He is survived by his children Gregory James Dalvito of New York, NY, William Keats of Bethlehem, PA, Lisa Britton of Darien, CT and his seven grandchildren, Tony, Alex, Emma, Danny, Amelia, Jamie and Charlotte. A visitation will be held at Coxe and Graziano Funeral Home, 767 East Boston Post Road Mamaroneck, NY from 4pm to 9pm on Tuesday July 9th.

BRISSON--Robert Pierre. Attorney-At-Law and Village Justice in Pleasantville NY, died July 7, 2013 at age 85 in Peabody MA. He is survived by his wife Elizabeth Phillips, six children, fourteen grandchildren and one great-grandchild. He was a beloved example of integrity and excellence.

ZBAR--Joseph and Florence. July 10 is the 75th anniversary of the marriage of Joseph E. Zbar, MD (b. Nov. 9,1910; d. Mar. 23, 1995) and Florence Zbar (b. May 19, 1918; d. Jan 23, 2013). Survived by children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. They are greatly missed.

ZESIGER--Judith C. The Continuum Health Partners community is saddened by the passing of Judith C. Zesiger, our dear friend and a former Trustee of Continuum and its member hospital, The New York Eye & Ear Infirmary. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her children Carey, Nicola and Alexa, the entire Zesiger family, and all of Judith's loved ones. Steven Hochberg Chairman, Board of Trustees Joel I. Picket Sorrell Mathes Vice Chairmen Stanley Brezenoff President and CEO

ZESIGER--Judith Carey, died peacefully on July 8th, surrounded by her loving children, Carey, Nicola and Alexa. Born in Belmont, Massachusetts, she graduated from Manhattanville College and lived and worked most of her life in New York City. She was a fund-raiser for the Brearley School, longtime board member at the Stanley M. Isaacs Neighborhood Center and the Chairwoman and Honorary Director of the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary as well as a Director of Continuum Health Partners. She relocated to West Palm Beach in 2008 to enjoy the beach with her nine grandchildren. An avid traveler, she touched every continent, lived in Paris, trekked the Annapurnas, walked with gorillas in Rwanda, cycled in Vietnam, and voyaged on a Russian ice breaker to Antartica. Now she travels to a better place. A memorial service is planned at St. Vincent Ferrer Church in New York on October 4th. In lieu of flowers, please remember her with a gift to michaeljfox.org.

Robinson, Interim President The Graduate Center, CUNY

Debbie, Marc & Andrew Lemchen Jennifer Salzer Drs. Lemchen & Salzer's office staff

TURKEWITZ--Michael. We've lost our very dear friend of many decades who was also our exceptional dentist. We will miss you but we will never forget you, dear Michael. Rest in peace. Linda and Stuart and family

SCHULMAN--Arnold. The whole team at Manhattan Shade & Glass and mergence studios mourns with great sadness the passing of our former president and shareholder, Arnold "Bruce" Schulman. He touched many lives, truly made us better and was loved by all. His leadership and lessons will be sorely missed. We extend our sincerest condolences to the entire family.

SCHIFF--Dr. Alvin I. The Jewish Education Project, formerly the Board of Jewish Education of New York - SAJES, mourns the passing of Dr. Alvin I. Schiff, Executive Vice President of the agency from 1970-1991. Dr. Schiff was a true pioneer of Jewish education and a leader in the development of and advocacy for the modern Day School education movement. Dr. Schiff was a model of the scholar-practitioner. Under his leadership, the Board of Jewish Education in New York became highly influential in the spheres of both secular and Judaic education. We extend condolences to his family and loved ones. The Board of Directors and Staff of The Jewish Education Project

SABLOW--Rhoda. November 26, 1926 July 9, 2013. Longtime resident of Scarsdale, NY. Artist, wife, mother, grandmother, and friend. She was preceded by husband Dr. Lester Sablow and daughter Jane. She is survived by her son Joseph (Gudrun) and grandchildren Alexander and Alyssa of Ardsley, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made at curepc.org.

ROBINSON--Dr. Herman M.,79, of Livingston, NJ, died July 8, 2013, of complications from lung cancer. A funeral service will be held at 11am, Friday, July 12 at Bernheim Apter Kreitzman, 68 Old Short Hills Rd, Livingston; burial to follow at Beth El Cemetery, 735 Forest Ave, Paramus. Robby was born December 18, 1933 in Brooklyn. In 1957 he earned his B.S. from Brooklyn College. The following year he married Hope Naumann and enrolled in medical school. He spent the rest of his life as a loving husband, father, and grandfather, and an esteemed radiologist. From his cum laude graduation from SUNY Downstate, to residency at Montefiore Hospital, to staff positions at hospitals in New York and New Jersey, to leading his own practice, his career was marked by exceptional skill, unwavering integrity, and unfailing warmth. Respected and admired by colleagues president of several medical societies and fellow of the American College of Radiology he was beloved by staff and patients. But Robby was a renaissance man. Overcoming disability from polio, he became a swimmer, tennis player, skier, and golfer. He was also an amateur photographer, and a lover of theater, opera, sports, nature, and books. He is survived by three remaining siblings, his mother-in-law Sally, his children Lori, David, and Mitchell, his seven grandchildren, and his wife of 55 years, Hope. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Lupus Foundation of America.

PEREZ DE CUELLAR--Marcela. World Monuments Fund mourns the passing of Marcela Perez de Cuellar on July 1. Founder and energetic leader of WMF Peru, Mrs. Perez de Cuellar took an avid interest in preservation of cultural heritage and led the restoration and enhanced public recognition of beautiful Andean churches in Andahuaylillas and Huaro. The radiant first recipient of the WMF Watch Award, she was a passionate spokesperson for heritage conservation, a gracious hostess and diplomat and devoted wife, mother, and grandmother. Condolences to her husband Javier Perez de Cuellar, former Secretary-General of the United Nations and Peruvian Ambassador to France, and to her family.
NEUHAUS--Peter H.,87, died July 10. Devoted husband of Sandra and father of Rosa, Manuel, Harry, Pedro, Patty, Michael and Nancy. Peter epitomized "the good life" and leaves a legacy of love.
MEYER--Dr. George A.,radiologist, of Bedford, NH, New York, NY, died July 7, 2013. Please visit www.goodwinfh.com to sign the online guestbook.

LUFKIN--Cynthia. The 455 Central Park West Board of Managers, building manager, and it's managing agent Brown Harris Stevens mourn the loss of Cynthia Lufkin. Heartfelt condolences to her husband, Dan and their family.

LITTMAN--Eugene Isaac, beloved husband, father, grandfather and brother died peacefully with his wife and his children at his bedside on July 7th at the age of 85. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, Elfriede, devoted father of Robert Littman, Sandra Finkelstein and her husband Robert, Bonnie Gatof and her husband Peter, David Littman and his wife Constance; his grandchildren Alexander, Jessica, Harrison, Tyler and Jacqueline Lee; and his sister, Geraldine Ossakow. A graduate of Brooklyn Technical High School (Class of 1945) and Cornell University (Class of 1948), he completed his degree in three years earning Phi Beta Kappa distinction. After college, he served his country in the United States Army. Following his service, he joined his family business, ultimately transforming Lightron of Cornwall into one of the nation's leading commercial lighting manufacturers. A brilliant entrepreneur, innovator and visionary in his field, he advanced energy efficient lighting technologies that helped shape the industry for years to come. The Littman family-held companies continue to employ hundreds of local residents. His commitment to the community extended to multiple board activities, leadership positions and philanthropic endeavors. He served on the Board of Directors of: St. Luke's Hospital, Cornwall Hospital, Key Bank and Temple Beth Jacob, where he also served as President. He and his family's philanthropy led to the creation of The Littman Cancer Center and The Littman Emergency Center, providing state-of-the-art medical services to the Mid-Hudson Valley. The family is requesting that those who wish to make any contributions in his memory direct donations to either: The Littman Cancer Center at St. Luke's Cornwall Hospital, 70 Dubois Street, Newburgh, NY 12550 or Temple Beth Jacob, 290 North Street, Newburgh, NY 12550.
LEVY--Dorothy. Dearest Dot, We enjoyed our years with you and John, and will miss you so enormously. Love, Ellen and Larry
LEVY--Dorothy "Dot". Saturday mornings at Atlantic will never be the same. Your 9 hole golf and lunch buddies will miss you more than you could possibly know. Rest in peace sweet beautiful Dot.

LEVY--Dorothy (Dotsie), just know that Berte and Alan, and Christina and Donnie, will be toasting you for many days, many months, and many years to come; with lots of love. The Hirschfields The Zacharias

LEVY--Dorothy. We are deeply saddened by the loss of such a gracious and special person whose warmth and charm will be sorely missed. Our hearts go out to John and his sons and hope that their wonderful memories of Dot will help sustain them. Giovanna and Dan

JEFFREY--James B.,was born May 22, 1929 to Neill P. Jeffrey Sr. and Minnie Meade Beck Jeffrey who resided in Jeanerette, Louisiana. He is survived by brother David W Jeffrey and predeceased by brother Neil P. Jeffrey Jr. He was partner of Harold M. F. Rush from 1961 until his death on June 6, 1996 residing in East Hampton and NYC. After graduating from Tulane University in Civil Engineering in 1950 he worked for Raymond Concrete Pile Company starting as a field supervisor and later becoming assistant District Manager of the New Orleans office. In preparation for seminary he attended the University of the South in Sewanee, Tennessee. Entered General Theological Seminary in NYC graduating in 1958 and served the Church of the Incarnation NYC for four years and then as Rector of St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Eastchester, NY until 1966. After being awarded a Fellowship by the Episcopal Mission Society of the Diocese of New York in Clinical Pastoral Education he moved into institutional chaplaincy at Central Islip State Psychiatric Hospital, the Rikers Island Penitentiary of NYC, Bellevue Hospital, Juvenile Detention Center, Bronx, NY. In 1970 he became the Director of Chaplains for the East Midtown Protestant Chaplaincy Incorporated which served the East side hospitals: New York/Cornell, Memorial Sloane-Kettering, Lenox Hill and the Hospital for Special Surgery. Changing the name to The Hospital Chaplaincy, the organization expanded to a staff of six chaplains, two CPE supervisors and five residents and was sustained by internal development efforts. He obtained a Masters degree in Human Resource Development from American University, Washington D. C. in 1984 and became the Chaplain and CPE Supervisor at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital. Here he coordinated the Ministry to Persons with AIDS establishing the AIDS Ministry and continued to care for those with AIDS until retirement in 1995. James Jeffrey spent his entire ministry in the Diocese of New York and the Eastern Region of the Association for Clinical Pastoral Education (ACPE). He served the Diocese as the Dean of Institutional Clergy and for the Committee on Alcoholism and Addictions. Within the ACPE, he served on the Certification Committee and chaired the Accreditation Committee. He helped found the Gay and Lesbian Task Force and was elected the Regional Director of the Eastern Region ACPE. Mr. Jeffrey's true passion was gardening and horticulture. He was renowned for his success in acclimatizing camellias to the environment of his East Hampton home. He was Honorary Vice President of the Delphinium Society, President of the Horticultural Alliance of the Hamptons (HAH) bringing horticultural education to local schools, the elderly, and the disabled. Visitation Friday 2-4pm and 7-9pm Yardley and Pino in East Hampton. Service 10:30am Saturday St. Luke's Episcopal, East Hampton. Donations to HAH and Episcopal Relief and Development.

GOODWIN--William, of Ardsley died on July 9th, 2013 at his home after a heroic battle with pancreatic cancer. He was 62 years old. Beloved husband of Debbie and father of Matthew. He is also survived by his sister, Rita and brother Paul (Diane) and a niece Rachel and nephew Paulie. He graduated from Lehigh University with honors in 1973 and received his M.B.A. from there in 1974. Mr. Goodwin was an investment professional at the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York (MONY) and its successor companies for over 30 years. Attaining the level of Senior Vice President, he was in charge of a multi-billion dollar portfolio of Private and Public fixed income securities, venture capital investments and Agricultural loans. Under his leadership MONY Capital Management was established as a separate investment manager as part of MONY's portfolio of companies. During his tenure significant growth in the venture capital business became a major factor in the bottom line results of MONY. He also led the effort to attract outside investors to allocate money to investment vehicles managed by his investment professionals which further enhanced MONY's net income. After retiring from AXA Equitable, Bill was an adjunct professor in the school of business at Manhattan College. This opportunity to teach brought great joy to Bill and he was able to make a real connection with his students. There will be a memorial gathering at his home, 152 Heatherdell Road, Ardsley, NY on Friday July 12th from 3-8 p.m. A funeral mass will be held Saturday, July 13th at 10:00 a.m. at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, 535 Ashford avenue, Ardsley. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Bill's memory to: Manhattan College Office of Planned Giving 4513 Manhattan College Parkway Riverdale, NY 10471.

GOLDBERG--Alfred. The partners and principals of Marks Paneth & Shron LLP mourn the passing of Al Goldberg, a Senior Partner of Marks Shron & Co., a predecessor of today's firm. He was a mentor to many of the partners of the firm and the firm will always benefit from his wisdom and guidance. He will be fondly remembered by all of us and we extend our deepest sympathies to the Goldberg family.

GOLDMAN--Daniel M.,MD of Poughkeepsie, NY, 70 years old, entered into eternity on July 10, 2013. He was born in Brooklyn, NY on July 29, 1942, the son of the late Leonard and Irene Goldman. Beloved father of Julie, Rachel, Geoffrey and Jonathan. Cherished grandfather of Nicholas, Kate, Lilliana, and Patrick. Dearest brother of Jerome Goldman. Long-time companion of Debbie DiDomenico. Danny was a talented musician and a passionate and gifted surgeon. Former Chief of Surgery at Vassar Brothers Medical Center, he dedicated the last fifteen years of his career to pioneering the field of hyperbaric medicine and wound care as Director of the Vassar Brothers Wound Care and Hyperbaric Center. He was loved and respected by all his colleagues and his patients. Services: 12 noon, Friday, July 12, 2013 at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR) Great Neck, NY. Interment to follow at Mt. Golda Cemetery, Huntington, NY. A memorial service will be held at Vassar Temple, 140 Hooker Avenue, Poughkeepsie, NY 12601 on Sunday July 14, 2013 at 10:30am. In lieu of flowers, Memorial Donations may be made to the Undersea and Hyperbaric Medical Society, 21 West Colony Place, Suite 280, Durham, NC 27705. To send personal condolences or for further information, please visit our website: www.riversidenassaunorth chapels.com.

FEFERMAN--Rafael. The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum mourns the passing of Rafael Feferman. A Holocaust survivor from Poland, Mr. Feferman was a Museum Benefactor and one of its strongest supporters. Having lost his entire family in the Holocaust, Mr. Feferman was passionate about the Museum's efforts to preserve history and memory. We offer our sincere condolences to his many friends. Tom A. Bernstein, Chairman Joshua B. Bolten, Vice Chairman Sara J. Bloomfield, Director

DIRBAS--Dr. Fuad, on July 5, 2013. Cherished husband of the late Gloria (nee Zayat). Beloved father of Dr. Fredrick Dirbas of Menlo Park, California and Dr. Joseph Dirbas of Brooklyn, New York. Dr. Fuad Dirbas was a surgeon at Lutheran Medical Center for several decades. Visitation Thursday 7-9pm and Friday 2-5pm and 7-9pm at McLaughlin and Sons Funeral Home, Third Ave at 97th Street Brooklyn, New York. Religious service Saturday 10am at St. Mary's Orthodox Church.

CARR--Marilyn, 83, passed away July 8, 2013. She was a loving wife to David A. Carr who preceded her in death. Marilyn was a pioneer in her profession as a foundations fit model, mentoring both designers and other models. Her career spanned her lifetime. Marilyn is survived by her two loving daughters Andrea Albert (Allan Albert) and Beth Adler. She is also survived by her adoring granddaughter Alexandra Zolot Dell (John E. Dell II). Her radiant smile, timeless sense of style, and effervescent personality will be missed. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue on Sunday, July 14th at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County in Florida.

CANNATA--Mary Grace, 87, of New York City passed away on July 9, 2013 in Mount Vernon, NY after a long battle with cancer. She went to high school at Theodore Roosevelt High School in the Bronx and Hunter College in NYC. She earned a MS in nutrition from New York University. Mary is preceded in death by her parents, Salvatore and Carmela, and two brothers Anthony and Arthur. Mary is survived by her sister Linda (Patrick) D'Ambrosio of Cortland Manor; two children Gregory (Wende) of Mount Vernon and Arleen (Ian) Seed of Silver Spring, MD; two grandchildren Alison (John) Hendele of Dobbs Ferry and Robert Cannata of New York City; two step- grandchildren Alistair (Charlene) Seed and David (Mary) Seed and one great-grandchild Mabel Seed. Visiting July 11, 24pm and 79pm Edwards Dowdle Funeral Home, Dobbs Ferry, NY. Funeral service July 12, 10am Edwards Dowdle Funeral Home, with burial to follow at Mount Hope Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund.

BRISSON--Robert Pierre. Attorney-At-Law and Village Justice in Pleasantville NY, died July 7, 2013 at age 85 in Peabody MA. He is survived by his wife Elizabeth Phillips, six children, fourteen grandchildren and one great-grandchild. He was a beloved example of integrity and excellence.

ACKERMAN--Norman B.,Devoted and loving husband of Anne G., for over 60 years, father of Sara, Beth, Amy (Rob) and Jean (Nick), grandfather of nine and great-grandfather of one. Graduated from DeWitt Clinton High School, B.A. Harvard College, M.D. University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine, Ph.D. in Surgery University of Minnesota. Dr. Ackerman served as a Captain in the US Army, professorships at Boston University School of Medicine, Upstate Medical Center, Syracuse, New York, NY Medical College and was one of the first surgeons to do bariatric surgery. He will be missed.

STROUSSE--Marcia D. July 8, 2013 in New Canaan, CT. Marcia was born in 1925 in Philadelphia, PA, the daughter of Fanny (Abrams) and Harry Dembow, a family involved in the pioneering stages of producing, distributing, and exhibiting motion pictures. Her first job, after graduating from Bryn Mawr College in 1947, was as Assistant to the Fashion Editor at The Philadelphia Inquirer, where she was later a Feature Reporter and wrote for The Sunday Magazine. Under three different bylines, she wrote for what was then considered to be "women's pages"--fashion, beauty, food, interior decorating, and even advice to the lovelorn. Next came marriage to David Strousse, and then a move to Stamford, CT in 1955, where as a full-time mother, they raised three children in both Stamford and East Brewster, MA for Cape Cod summers. After the marriage ended, she revamped her career when she joined Golf Digest Magazine in 1968 as Assistant Promotion Manager two weeks after Golf Digest was purchased by The New York Times Company. She was subsequently named Vice President (one of the first NYT female vice presidents) of Marketing and Communications for the entire NYT magazine group. Upon her retirement in 1992, she started her own successful event/marketing company, Current Events. Marcia was active in the community, serving on the Board of Ferguson Library in Stamford, CT, and volunteering at the Stamford Museum & Nature Center, Southfield Neighborhood Village, and leading a Girl Scout troop. Her retirement days were busy with numerous book clubs, exercise classes, and volunteering at AmeriCares, and the Fairfield Alumnae of Bryn Mawr College, most recently serving on the annual Alumnae Seminar Committee. She is survived by her three children, Cynthia Strousse of Boston, MA; Tracy Strousse of Burbank, CA, and David Strousse of Hartland, VT as well as Victoria, her daughter-in-law and her two beloved granddaughters: Rose Simone and Kate Caroline. She is also survived by her sister, Shirley Bornstein of Philadelphia, PA, and her nephews, Barry Bornstein of Philadelphia and Steve Bornstein of Venice, CA. While Marcia always appreciated a well-planned event, she requested a private family memorial celebration. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The New Canaan Library, New Canaan, CT 06840, newcanaanlibrary.org or Staying Put in New Canaan, P.O. Box 484, New Canaan, CT 06840, director@stayingputnc.org. For online condolences visit www.hoytfuneralhome.com.

POWELL--Betty Durham Yeager Of Burlington, NC, passed away July 10, 2013. Born October 1, 1939 in Durham, NC, she was the daughter of the late Clarence Robertson Yeager and the late Frances Council Yeager of Attleboro, MA, and the granddaughter of the late Commodore Thomas Council, Sr., founder of the B.C. Remedy Company, and the late Betty Frances Durham Council. She was the loving wife of 48 years of Dr. Thomas E. Powell, III, who survives. Also surviving are her three children, Frances P. Barnes and husband A. Merrick Barnes, III of Elon, Thomas E. Powell, IV and wife Elizabeth F. Powell of Burlington, Caroline P. Rogers and husband Arthur H. Rogers, III of Durham, two grandchildren, Henry and Edward Rogers of Durham, and cousins, Carol Council Croom and husband William D. Croom, Jr. of San Antonio, TX, Commodore Thomas Council, III and wife Carol, and Sarah Lawson. Mrs. Powell attended the Calvert Method School in Durham, which was later to become Durham Academy. She moved with her parents to Attleboro, MA in 1947 where she attended the Attleboro Public Schools. She attended Dana Hall in Wellesley, MA for her last three years of secondary education. She began her undergraduate degree at Sweet Briar College in Sweet Briar, VA. She completed her undergraduate degree in French at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill in 1961. She was a member of the Mentor Book Club and the Town and Country Garden Club. Mrs. Powell was a past president of the Alamance-Caswell Medical Auxiliary, and a past Chairman of the annual Burlington Antiques Fair and the Burlington Antiques Preview. She was a former member of the Alamance Service League. In 1980 she was Co-Chairman of the successful Capital Campaign at the Burlington Day School. From 1987 to 1990 she served as a member of the Board of Visitors of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and a member of the Board of the Educational Foundation. Mrs. Powell was a past member and Vice Chairman of the Board of Directors of Balfour Supply Service in Bethesda, MD. She was also a past member of the Board of Directors of Bobbitt Laboratories, Inc., an associate of Carolina Biological Supply Company. For several years, she was Telemarketing Manager of Carolina Biological Supply Company. She was a past member of the Board of Directors of the Burlington Day School. She served on the Aubrey Lee Brooks Foundation County Committee of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Governor James B. Hunt, Jr. appointed her in 1984 to the North Carolina Executive Mansion Fine Arts Committee. She served on the Board of Directors of the Executive Mansion Fund. In 1991, she was appointed by Governor James G. Martin to the John Motley Morehead Memorial Commission. Mrs. Powell was a member of city and country clubs, including the Congressional Country Club in Washington, DC., and the Country Club of North Carolina in Pinehurst. She was a member of the Elon Community Church, United Church of Christ, in Elon, NC, where she was active on committees and was instrumental in the development of the Community Life Center. The family will receive friends at the Rich & Thompson Funeral and Cremation Service in Burlington on Friday, July 12, 2013 from 4 to 7pm. A private burial service will be held at Magnolia Cemetery in Elon on Saturday morning. The Celebration of Life Service will be conducted at the Elon Community Church, United Church of Christ, on Saturday, July 13, 2013 at 2pm by The Rev. Randy Orwig. A reception will be held following the service in the Community Life Center. Memorials may be made to the New Building Fund, Elon Community Church, P.O. Box 625, Elon, NC 27244. Condolences may be offered to Post Office Box 2536, Burlington, NC 27216 or at www.richandthompson.com

COASSIN--Lawrence (Larry) P.,54, of Hamden, CT, passed away peacefully on Monday, July 8, 2013, at his home surrounded by his family. He was the husband of 31 years to Emily Castiglione Coassin, proud father to Polly Coassin Franzen and her husband Jason, and Lawrence (Rence) P. Coassin, Jr., beloved grandfather to Addison Franzen, and master to dog, Shiloh. Larry was born in New Haven on August 24, 1958. He is survived by his parents, John and Joanne (Zichichi) Coassin of Hamden, and is also survived by his siblings and their families, John Coassin Jr. and Linda Woodward, Susan Coassin, Donna and Michael Pugliese (Michael, Keri, Peter and Andrew), and Michael Coassin (Maxwell, Christian, Sophie and Skylar), his devoted mother-in-law Pamela Schwab Castiglione, as well as many other dear family members, in-laws and friends. A graduate of Hamden High School ('76), Babson College ('80), and the University of Miami Law School ('83), Larry was a senior partner at Robinson & Cole LLP, where he practiced since September of 1983 as a corporate attorney. Larry was a very gifted and experienced lawyer, having a unique ability to retain clients and guide them through some of the firm's largest and most sophisticated dealings. He took pride in being a dedicated friend and mentor to his colleagues at Robinson & Cole. He was also an astute business investor who acquired several businesses in a variety of industries during his career. Larry's impact was widespread and deep. He made it his mission to advocate for and change the lives of those he cared about. He truly enjoyed their successes, while at the same time deflecting credit. Most importantly, he was extremely proud of his family and his children and grandchild. A mass of Christian burial will be held today at St. Rita Church, 1620 Whitney Avenue, Hamden. In lieu of flowers the family has requested that donations be made to the Lawrence P. Coassin and Family Fund at Choate Rosemary Hall, 333 Christian St, Wallingford, CT 06492, The Development Office, Attn: Dan Courcey (203-697-2649).

KELLOGG--Spencer II, of Old Brookville, New York, died peacefully in his sleep on June 20. He was born in Buffalo, NY on December 9, 1913, to Cyrena (Case) and Howard Kellogg Sr. After graduating from Nichols School and Cornell University with a degree in engineering, he took a job as a field engineer with Sperry Gyroscope Company. In 1942 as a Research Engineer at Sperry, he combined the gyroscope instrument with a remotely located electric flux valve, producing the first compass that accurately displayed an airplane's heading in a turn. During WWII he was on the design team for the A-5 autopilot which was installed on the B-24 bombers as well as the S-1 bombsight. In 1976 he received the Pioneer in Aviation award for developing the revolutionary "Zero Reader" (flight director). This flight instrument synthesizes input from many sources (attitude, altitude, heading, navigation aids, radio signals) into a single display dramatically reducing the pilot's workload and greatly increasing flight safety. Spen had a lifelong interest in aviation, earning his pilot's license at age seventeen, and flying for the next seventy-one years. In 2004 he was awarded the first FAA Master Pilot Award given in the New York area for 70 years of safe flying. His work at Sperry offered him the opportunity to test fly his inventions in many different airplanes, including the AT6 and the B-17. In 1966 he flew his single engine Navion to France, and back. Spencer Kellogg served as a village trustee and treasurer for Old Brookville. He was predeceased by his wife of sixty-seven years, Mary Louise Webster, and his daughter-in-law Winifred Kellogg of Erie, CO. He leaves his sons, Spencer Kellogg III of Erie, CO; Richard (Pamela) of Huntington, VT; David (Cynthia) of Oyster Bay; and his daughters Jean Pettibone (Peter) of New York City, and Mary Louise Lyman (Philip) of Gambrils, MD; fourteen grandchildren; and nine great-grandchildren. There will be a memorial service at St. John's, Cold Spring Harber, NY, on July 18 at 10:00am. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to a charity of your choice in memory of Spencer Kellogg.

KLEIN--Albert L. "Albie", born in Newark, 1917, of South Orange, NJ and Boca Raton, FL, died July 10, 2013. He was Chairman of Wharton/ Lyon & Lyon, a large, regional insurance agency located in Livingston, NJ and Tinton Falls, NJ. A prominent member of the insurance community, Albert Klein held the degree of C.L.U. (Chartered Life Underwriter) and was four times national top producer of the General American Life Insurance Co. and a life member of the Million Dollar Round Table. A very active philanthropist, Albert Klein was a long time board member of the United Jewish Communities of MetroWest New Jersey and Jewish Vocational Service, as well as former chairman of U.J.C. South Orange and Chairman of Israel Bonds, New Jersey. He also served as a founder of the scholarship program of the Jewish Vocational Service. Charities benefiting from his giving included U.J.C. of MetroWest, J.C.C. of South Palm Beach, Bucknell University, University of Pennsylvania, Memorial Sloan Kettering, the Weitzman Institute and Cooper Union. Albert Klein was educated at Bucknell University and was a graduate of the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania in 1940. During World War II, he attained the rank of 1st Lieutenant of the U.S. Army Air Corp. and became First Commander of the Weequahic Post Jewish War Veterans and well as First Commodore and Founder of the Atlantis Yacht Club of Monmouth Beach, New Jersey. He was also a member of the Green Brook Country Club of New Jersey and the Bocaire Country Club of Florida. A classic car enthusiast, he was an active member of the Classic Car Club of America and the Antique Car Club, National 1st Place winner and showed his 1931 Cadillac at Pebble Beach, California. He was a member of the " Academy " of the University of Pennsylvania. He is survived by his wife, Cynthia; his daughter, Penny Stark Bernabei; his sons, Jaime Klein, Dennis Klein anad Bruce Gilson as well as by seven grandchildren: Howard and Donald Gilson, Joseph. Becky and Evie Klein and Alex and Stephaine Bernabei. Funeral service Sunday, July 14, at 12 Noon in Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Rd., Livingston, NJ.

BUDELIS--Richard, artist and Associate Professor of Fine Arts at Pratt Institute. His sculpture appeared in many group exhibits, the Boston Elements Show in 1971, outdoor installations at Ward's Island, as well as Pratt faculty fine arts shows. He was a founder, with John Pai, of the Sculpture Department at Pratt and developed courses in sculpture using plastic materials. He taught a wide variety of undergraduate drawing and sculpture, and tech classes, as well as an art and technology class at NYU on a grant from the Howard Weiss Foundation. He served as Chair 1973-1980 of undergraduate sculpture, ceramics and jewelry, and as Head of undergraduate sculpture 1990-97, and administered the Cantor Foundation grant for Master Class in Sculpture 1994-97. He is survived by his sisters Julia Budelis and Lillian Thiede, his daughter Natalie, from his previous marriage to Maxine DeSeta, and Constance Williams Budelis, his wife of 43 years. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Department of Fine Arts - Sculpture, Pratt Institute, Brooklyn, NY 11205.

CARR--Marilyn, 83, passed away July 8, 2013. She was a loving wife to David A. Carr who preceded her in death. Marilyn was a pioneer in her profession as a foundations fit model, mentoring both designers and other models. Her career spanned her lifetime. Marilyn is survived by her two loving daughters Andrea Albert (Allan Albert) and Beth Adler. She is also survived by her adoring granddaughter Alexandra Zolot Dell (John E. Dell II). Her radiant smile, timeless sense of style, and effervescent personality will be missed. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue on Sunday, July 14th at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County in Florida.

WELSH--Mary E.,of Southampton, NY on July 9, 2013 at age 97. Known to all as "Barry". Survived by her daughters. Maribeth and Ellen of NYC and Southampton as well as many nieces and nephews. Funeral was private with a future Memorial Mass to be announced. Memorial donations to Southampton Hospital Foundation, 240 Meeting House Lane, Southampton, NY 11968 would be appreciated.
WHITFIELD--James Davis.A gentle soul unexpectedly left us, is much loved & missed on his birthday. Stephen Elson & Diane Sasaki

LUFKIN--Cynthia. We are so distressed at the loss of Cynthia. She was so very kind, beautiful, spunky and heroic. Everybody loved her and rightfully so. We send our love and sympathy to Dan. Dalia & Larry Leeds

BENSINGER--Ted. A great friend for so many years. Our parents were friends, and you were an inspirational pal, both at Yale and until now--65 years later. Teddy, nobody will ever be like you--charismatic, interesting, exciting and fun-loving. It's not going to be the same without you, especially in Jamaica. Dalia and I send our love and sympathy to John, Kerry, Tyler, Peter, Roger and Jane. Larry Leeds

KOTZEN--Lynn Andrews, peacefully on July 11 at 81 years of age. Beloved wife of the late Marvin Stanley Kotzen, mother of Elinor Kotzen Spokes and Deborah Kotzen, mother-in-law of Jeffrey Spokes, grandmother of adoring grandsons Joshua, Tobias and Isaac Spokes, sister of Joseph L. Andrews Jr., Dale Andrews Eldridge and the late Ann Andrews Paxton. Raised in Scarsdale and a graduate of Wellesley College, she resided in Larchmont and New Rochelle for nearly 50 years where she was active in many civic and religious organizations and was universally admired for her leadership, her spirit and spunk, and her commitment to making a difference in her community. Her passing leaves a huge whole in the hearts of all who knew her. Funeral will be held on Monday, July 15 at 11:30am at John J. Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY 10538. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to Planned Parenthood Federation of America.
LEWIN--Julius B. Our beloved brother Julius was blessed with his loving wife Barbara and his incredible children and grandchildren. We will miss his humor and sparkle. Connie and Joe

KATZ--Warren Leonard, on July 11, 2013, age 90, of Hauppauge, NY and formerly of Syosset, NY. Beloved husband of the late Hilma. Devoted father of Susan Collins, Barbara Katz, Peter Katz, and the late Steven Katz. Cherished father-in-law of John Collins. Loving grandfather of Kimberly Collins. Dear brother of Rita Spector. Survived by a large loving family of many adoring cousins, nieces, nephews, and life-long friends. Services: Sunday, 12 noon at "Guttermans," 8000 Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, LI.

WIENER--Rhoda L.,87, of Lake Worth, FL and Copake Lake, NY. Our hearts are heavy with extreme sadness that our matriarch has gone to her eternal rest. Cherished daughter of Dorothy and Irving. Sister of Larry. adoring wife of the late Edward. Loving mother of Hilly, Ira (Margarita), Jody (Bobby), Susan (Jeff). Proud grandmother of Matt, Ben, Elyssa, and Scott. Donations in her memory may be made to Maccabi USA, 1926 Arch Street, Philadelphia, PA 19103.

WIST--Reba Psaty. Died peacefully on July 13 at 90 years of age. She led many lives: extraordinary mother, beloved wife and companion, devoted grandmother, dear sister, favorite aunt, loyal friend, trusted advisor, gifted teacher, unstoppable civic activist, gefilte-fish maker, French-speaker, auction-stalker, world traveler. Born in Brooklyn on January 16, 1923 to Charles and Leah (Seham) Psaty, she graduated from Hunter College and earned her masters degree from Brooklyn College while working and caring for her family. She led her life with immense drive, passion and courage. Left widowed with two children, she inspired everyone by her example of how to lead an adventurous, thoughtful and honorable life. She leaves behind her children Ronda (Frank Chaney), Andrew (Maria), grandchildren Milton, Ariana, Miles and step grandson Robbie. Beloved wife of the late Milton; exuberant companion of Jerome Muchnick; joyful sister-in law to Bertha Psaty and Helen Wist; cherished aunt to many nieces and nephews. The funeral service will be held on Monday, July 15th at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in her memory may be made to the Hunter College Foundation, 695 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10065 att: Reba Wist Fund.

SYLVANE--Bessie, of Palm Beach FL, NYC, and Neponsit, NY. Wife of the late Allen Sylvane - mother of the late Ronnie Sylvane Postal (George deceased) - mother of the late Barbara Sylvane Glass (Alan). Survived by her son Marc (Barbara) and her grandchildren Brittany, Zachary, Stacie, Cori and Tara and by her great-grandchildren Brooklyn and George. Peacefully on July 8 she left her body of almost 98 years. Our sweet Bessie - always loving kind and gentle-she passed through with love and a smile. She had tremendous inner strength, moral courage, and a true sincere humility in the mind. She had the love that loves because it could not do otherwise. She constantly kept good will and love in her heart and let them pour out on all.

Service is scheduled for 1:00pm, Monday, July 15th, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue, corner of 91st Street.

Father of Fran Sherr (Robert Hess) of Wynnewood PA, and Elizabeth Sherr Sklar (Lawrence) of Ann Arbor MI. Also survived by his grandchild Jessica Sklar of Seattle, WA. Interment is private. A memorial service at the Quadrangle and in Princeton will be held in the near future. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Quadrangle Board Education Fund or a charity of the donor's choice. www.levinefuneral.com

Services by Ware Smith Woolever Funeral Home, Midland, MI.
ROBBINS--Lester. Your family and close friends are thinking of you, remembering your warmth, strength, wit and your deep abiding interest in and love for each of us. Sheila
WHITFIELD--James Davis.A gentle soul unexpectedly left us, is much loved & missed on his birthday. Stephen Elson & Diane Sasaki
MCDONALD--Violet Nagle. Missing you on your 90th birthday and every day. Your Family

WOLFF--Harry, a book manufacturing executive, died in New York City on July 7. He was 86 and lived in Manhattan and Bridgehampton. Survivors include his wife, Ruth Nagourney; a sister, Patricia Gross; and two children, Linda and Robert. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Central Park Conservancy.
BERNSTEIN--Ruben William. Always loved. Always missed.

LEVY--Dorothy F.,77, died peacefully on July 8th, surrounded by her beloved husband of 55 years, John, and her two sons, John and Tom. She was the daughter of the late Eddie and Claire Felson and sister of the late Sally Fyvolent, of Jacksonville, Florida. Dot was the beloved mother-in-law of Valerie Levy and grandmother of Sasha Levy, Nathan Anderson, Allegra Levy and Cameron Levy. Dot led a very special and happy life, spreading joy and beauty in the world. She had a unique connection with people, as her many friends will attest. Her Southern upbringing in Jacksonville, Florida, informed her aesthetic; she had a keen sense of beauty, style and hospitality which she applied with charm and grace to her world in Manhattan, East Hampton and Wellington, Florida. Dot began her journey northward from Jacksonville in 1953, graduating valedictorian from Landon High School, attending Duke University, and graduating magna cum laude. She was a member of Alph Phi Epsilon sorority, Phi Beta Kappa, was named Azalea Queen at the annual Azalea Fesitval at Charleston, SC, and listed in Who's Who Among Students in American Universities and Colleges. In 1958 she moved to NYC to join the love of her life, John S. Levy, and begin married life. She was a successful model in New York, having posed for many fashion magazines as well as the national US Marines recruiting poster of 1960. In her last days she spoke of how grateful she was for the happy life she'd had, finding tremendous fulfillment from the love of family and friends. She wanted to encourage her children and grandchildren to do their best, as she always did, regretting only that she never got a chance to tell her dear friends that she was in her final days. Funeral services were held on Thursday, July 11th at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 633 Third Avenue, 28th Floor, New York, NY 10017.

LEVY--Dorothy, "Dot" Our friend, our kids' friend and mom's great great friend. Our hearts go out to John, Johnny, Tom, Valerie, Cameron, Allegra and Sasha. Beautiful inside and out, we will miss you Dot. Lisa and Mario

LUFKIN--Cynthia. We are so distressed at the loss of Cynthia. She was so very kind, beautiful, spunky and heroic. Everybody loved her and rightfully so. We send our love and sympathy to Dan. Dalia & Larry Leeds
