Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO
LEWIN--Julius B. Our beloved brother Julius was blessed with his loving wife Barbara and his incredible children and grandchildren. We will miss his humor and sparkle. Connie and Joe

McDANIEL--Marshall, loving husband of Claire McDaniel, passed away at his home July 10. A former Marine during WWII. Retired from the Bissell Company out of Grand Rapids, and Honorary member of the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills. He leaves behind his wife Claire and their nieces and nephews Patricia, Thomas and Robert Stevens as well as Lynn Miller, Virginia Vetsikas and Peter and Alice Hellawell.

MANOCHERIAN--Amir, on June 29, 2013. Beloved husband of Rosita Mandelbaum for over 65 years. Cherished father of Alan and Nancy, Robert and Mireille and Barbara. Loving grandfather of Alissa and Gideon Schwartz, Jesse and Adrian, Matthew and Michael, Daniel, Steven and Natalie Manocherian and Ian Callender, and great- grandfather of Zoey and Violet Schwartz. Devoted brother of Fraydun, and the late Touran, Manoochehr and Eskandar. A private family service was held on July 1st at the Chapel in the Woods at Temple Kol Ami in White Plains, New York.

McGRATH--J. Paul, of Bonita Springs, FL, and Montclair, NJ, loving husband of Eileen "Honey" (Robinson) McGrath, passed away peacefully on July 9, 2013 at the age of 72 with his family at his side. Mr. McGrath was born on September 9, 1940 in Rochester, NY to Thomas McGrath and Evelyn (Regan) McGrath. Mr. McGrath graduated from McQuaid Jesuit High School in Rochester, NY; earned an AB from the College of the Holy Cross in Worcester, MA and an LLB from Harvard Law School in 1965. Following law school, Mr. McGrath's entire career in private practice was spent with the firm Dewey, Ballantine, in New York City. In 1981, Mr. McGrath was nominated by President Ronald Reagan to be an Assistant Attorney General of the United States, and served from 1981 to 1985, first as Head of the Civil Division of the U.S. Department of Justice and then as Head of the Antitrust Division. Following his career in private practice and public service, Mr. McGrath was General Counsel at AlliedSignal Engineered Materials and Senior Vice President and General Counsel at FMC Corporation. In 2000, Mr. McGrath joined American Standard Companies, Inc. and served as Senior Vice President, General Counsel and Secretary until his retirement in 2004. Mr. McGrath is survived by his wife Honey, sons John and David, daughters Trish and Robyn, a brother Ted, sisters Mary Ann and Susan. He was a loving grandfather to five grandchildren, Robert, Henry, Jack, Jamie and Payton. Paul was loved and admired, and will be remembered as a wonderful husband, father, brother and friend. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to YMCA of Southwest Florida, 27200 Kent Road, Bonita Springs, FL 34135. Visiting hours will be held on Tuesday July 16th from 6:00 pm to 9:00 pm and Wednesday July 17th from 10:00am to 12:00 pm at the Hugh M. Moriarty Funeral Home, 76 Park Street, Montclair, NJ 07042, phone (973) 744-4346.

MENAGH--Douglas D.,beloved brother of Diane, died at his home July 10, 2013; he was 63 years old. A native New Yorker, he graduated from Power Memorial Academy, Fairfield University and Fordham Law School and practiced law at his private firm. He was honored as Man of the Year (1997) by the Catholic Council of The Electrical Workers of Local 3, a union founded by his father, Donald, and his uncles, Ed and Jack. Douglas Menagh is survived by his sister and his children. Visiting Sunday 2-5pm and 7-9pm, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., NYC. Burial Monday at Woodlawn Cemetery. A memorial mass in celebration of the life of Douglas Menagh will be offered at a later date.

MIXON--Joseph Chester. Born September 18, 1947, died July 4, 2013. Son of the late Josephine Carl and Chester A. Mixon, Jr. Phillips Exeter Academy Class of 1966. Native of Jackson, Mississippi, former New Yorker. Elegance personified, gifted faux-finish artist, loyal friend.

McCOURT--David J. May 5, 1942 July 11, 2013. Born in New London, Connecticut, David McCourt, the second son of William J. McCourt and Elizabeth R. McCourt, passed away peacefully on July 11th at CT Hospice, with his devoted and loving wife, Mary Bryant McCourt at his side, after a long battle with metastatic melanoma. David leaves behind his wife Mary, two twin sons, Tavis and Stephen McCourt, two daughters, Elizabeth Smith and Kathy Paine, nine grandchildren and his sister, Mary McCourt Sheffield. David graduated from St. Francis Preparatory School in Biddeford, Maine in 1959, the University of Hartford in 1966, and Atlanta University in 1969 with a Masters in Business Administration. David was an avid baseball player in his youth playing throughout high school and college, and enlisted in the United States Marine Corps Reserves in 1963. In 1969 David joined the family business, ABCO Welding Supply, with his brother Bill and father William. David found a true passion in his sales role at ABCO and started a welding school during his tenure at ABCO. David moved to Old Saybrook, Connecticut in 1980, and enjoyed coaching Little League Baseball, skiing and running around north cove. In 1986, David and his brother Bill succeeded their father in running ABCO, and together with a group of talented and hard-working employees, grew the business consistently for 25 years before selling ABCO in 2011. In 1994, David married Ruth Clifford of Cork, Ireland, and moved to Newton, Massachussets. In 1997, David and Ruth were blessed with the birth of a daughter, Juliana Valentine. Ruth and Juliana died tragically as victims of the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001 on the World Trade Center in New York. Following the events of September 11th, David, together with the Cuomo family helped found B.R.A.V.E. Juliana, a program of HELP USA, to teach non-violence and conflict resolution to children. David became a recognized voice to the world, appearing on TV with Diane Sawyer, Larry King, Connie Chung and many others. Deepak Choprah dedicated his book, The Deeper Wound, Recovering the Soul from Fear and Suffering, to Ruth, Paige and Juliana, and invited David to travel together speaking about the greater purpose and meaning of life. David met Mary Bryant in January 2002, through a friend to help through the difficult time and lead him to creating something positive. David and Mary founded the Juliana Valentine McCourt Children's Education Fund, and their friendship grew over the years to a deep, significant love. The two were married at St. Francis Chapel in Niantic, CT in 2011. David became a prominent supporter of the Achilles Freedom Team of Wounded Veterans, which Mary had founded through Achilles International, and the McCourt Memorial Garden at the Lyman Allen Museum. David enjoyed playing the game of golf (a game he always loved if never mastered) as a member at the Black Hall, Old Lyme Country Club and Lake of Isles Country Club in Connecticut and Trump International in Florida, where he retired and took residence. David will be missed sorely for his sense of humor, laughter, and love of life, economic and political discussions, sincere generosity, and his deep belief in mulligans. A memorial service will be held for family and friends at the Old Lyme Country Club in Connecticut on July 27th from 2-4pm, with a short service and opportunity to share memories at 3pm. For details, please contact: NeilanFuneralHome.com. Donations can be made in his honor to the McCourt Memorial Garden, or Achilles International.

LEVINE--Barbara Forbes, former Ford model and longtime resident of 200 Central Park South, where her late husband, Alan Levine, was board president, was always the most elegant woman in the room. She will be remembered that way by her daughter, Elizabeth Forbes Scibelli of New York, granddaughter, Francesca Cretella, of Paris; grandson, Alessandro Cretella of Rome; and their extended family and friends on July 20, 2-4pm at the First Presbyterian Church, 12 W. 12th St. Party clothes requested.

EINHORN--Anne Alexander, 89, died peacefully at home on July 11, surrounded by her adoring family- her husband of 70 years, Marvin Einhorn, her children, Ellen Zerkin, Stephen Einhorn and Kenneth Einhorn, their spouses and seven grandchildren. In the 1950's, she was a leader of the pioneering Teaneck Civic Conference, which defeated blockbusting and stopped "white flight" in Teaneck, NJ. Inimitable, ineffable and indomitable, Annie will be sorely missed by her family and by untold others in the world of theatre, her other family. Send contributions in her name to the Einhorn School of Performing Arts, 307 West 38th Street, Suite 1510, New York, NY 10018.

FISCHMAN--Harold, loving husband of Barbara Fischman passed away July 7, 2013. Harold's consideration and regard for others was unsurpassed. His family and friends will miss his warmth and counsel. We loved him.

KENT--Barbara, Ph.D, 72, died June 24, 2013 in Hancock, Maine from complications related to a recent fall. She was born July 29, 1940 in Decatur, Illinois the daughter of William and Charlotte (Conklin) Boyer. Barbara is survived by her companion, Rita Fernando, a brother Bill Boyer, and two nephews. Barbara's courage, grace and brilliance were admired by hundreds of friends and colleagues. A Memorial Service will be held 4pm, Sunday, August 11, 2013 at the Hancock Point Chapel, Hancock, Maine. Donations in lieu of flowers should be made to the Frenchman Bay Conservancy, P.O. Box 150, Hancock, Me. 04640.

KELLEHER--Stephen P. Stephen P. Kelleher, age 64, of Fort Worth, TX, died suddenly on June 22, and will be deeply mourned by his loving wife Kathryn Dowd, sister Jeanette Kelleher (Greg Stein), and many friends and colleagues. Stephen, originally from Cambridge, MA, graduated with distinction from Boston College and Harvard Medical School. He was a talented diagnostician, compassionate healer and gifted teacher. He spent his distinguished career caring for the seriously ill and training new physicians, work that was recognized with numerous awards. Stephen was an avid outdoorsman with an enduring passion for the mountains and his beloved dogs. All who knew him will fondly recall Stephen's brilliant smile, charisma, boundless energy and discipline, prodigious intellect, and enthusiasm for all he did.

KELLOGG--Spencer II, of Old Brookville, New York, died peacefully in his sleep on June 20. He was born in Buffalo, NY on December 9, 1913, to Cyrena (Case) and Howard Kellogg Sr. After graduating from Nichols School and Cornell University with a degree in engineering, he took a job as a field engineer with Sperry Gyroscope Company. In 1942 as a Research Engineer at Sperry, he combined the gyroscope instrument with a remotely located electric flux valve, producing the first compass that accurately displayed an airplane's heading in a turn. During WWII he was on the design team for the A-5 autopilot which was installed on the B-24 bombers as well as the S-1 bombsight. In 1976 he received the Pioneer in Aviation award for developing the revolutionary "Zero Reader" (flight director). This flight instrument synthesizes input from many sources (attitude, altitude, heading, navigation aids, radio signals) into a single display dramatically reducing the pilot's workload and greatly increasing flight safety. Spen had a lifelong interest in aviation, earning his pilot's license at age seventeen, and flying for the next seventy-one years. In 2004 he was awarded the first FAA Master Pilot Award given in the New York area for 70 years of safe flying. His work at Sperry offered him the opportunity to test fly his inventions in many different airplanes, including the AT6 and the B-17. In 1966 he flew his single engine Navion to France, and back. Spencer Kellogg served as a village trustee and treasurer for Old Brookville. He was predeceased by his wife of sixty-seven years, Mary Louise Webster, and his daughter-in-law Winifred Kellogg of Erie, CO. He leaves his sons, Spencer Kellogg III of Erie, CO; Richard (Pamela) of Huntington, VT; David (Cynthia) of Oyster Bay; and his daughters Jean Pettibone (Peter) of New York City, and Mary Louise Lyman (Philip) of Gambrils, MD; fourteen grandchildren; and nine great-grandchildren. There will be a memorial service at St. John's, Cold Spring Harber, NY, on July 18 at 10:00am. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation to a charity of your choice in memory of Spencer Kellogg.

KAUFMAN--Tanya. (July 1, 1944 -- July 11, 2013). Beloved friend and noted educator, passed away peacefully at her home last Thursday. She will always be remembered for her keen sense of humor, her warmth and her generosity of spirit. For all of us who knew and loved her, our lives will never be the same. Donations can be made in her name to the Brooke Jackman Foundation. brookejackmanfoundation.org

KOTZEN--Lynn Andrews, peacefully on July 11 at 81 years of age. Beloved wife of the late Marvin Stanley Kotzen, mother of Elinor Kotzen Spokes and Deborah Kotzen, mother-in-law of Jeffrey Spokes, grandmother of adoring grandsons Joshua, Tobias and Isaac Spokes, sister of Joseph L. Andrews Jr., Dale Andrews Eldridge and the late Ann Andrews Paxton. Raised in Scarsdale and a graduate of Wellesley College, she resided in Larchmont and New Rochelle for nearly 50 years where she was active in many civic and religious organizations and was universally admired for her leadership, her spirit and spunk, and her commitment to making a difference in her community. Her passing leaves a huge hole in the hearts of all who knew her. Funeral will be held on Monday, July 15 at 11:30am at John J. Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY 10538. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to Planned Parenthood Federation of America.

KATZMAN--Florence G. July 29, 1923-July 10, 2013. Cherished wife of the late Herman B. Katzman. Beloved mother to daughters Marylyn Meyerson and Francine Katzman and late son-in-law Bob Schancupp. Her middle name was Grace, and it suited her well.

KAHN--Betty L. A long time resident of New York's east side, Betty died Friday, at age 95, in her home. She had an eye for fashion and antiques and passion and talent for bridge and golf. She leaves her beloved daughters Susan and Laurie Kahn, their life partners Jay and Michael, and grandchildren Emily Rose Kahn-Sheahan and Makani Kahn-Sky. She will be dearly missed.

GRANVILLE--John. Born March 8, 1935. The Red Fort, New Delhi, India, scholarship to Magdalen College, Oxford University, England, graduating '55 and '56. Worked in advertising and consumer marketing in London, Milan and New York. Came to the USA in 1963. Retired executive of Phillip Morris, USA, moved to Honolulu 1980's. A celebration of his Life held in Honolulu. His family held a memorial service in England. Donations may be made to Americans for Oxford Inc. 500 5th Ave. 32nd floor, New York 10110. "I'm off to eager student's hands and then, through fire, my small starstuff paddled to the ocean tides... So I, in many years to come, may fall on highest mounts, flow down the holy river, Dewali nights around, swim where Shelley swam and died, pass Verrazano's lovely span, wash up on Hampton golden dunes where love and I did lie... and come to England's green and pleasant fields, I, Rotherman, will join it's tiny stream again and drift, with cricket sounds around, pass bluebelled woods, pubs, schools and sacred stones, back here to my sweet home... These all I've lived and loved, and been loved too... So what was lost is found, was old is now brand new. To those I've loved my dearest thanks, and now adieu!" Honolulu, USA May12, 2013.

GLICKMAN--Marvin, died peacefully on July 12th, in the presence of his wife and children. Survived by his wife, Barbara Glickman, his children Joan and John, step-children Steven and Lynn, grandchildren Adam, Joel, Nidal and Dalia, step-grandchildren Nicole and Jules, and great-grandchildren Stella and Thea. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, July 17th, at 11:30am at Riverside Memorial Chapel in Hewlett.

CAPLAN--Arthur I. 92, beloved husband of Harriet for 71 years, passed away on July 5, 2013. Devoted father of Robert (Francine), Richard (Dolores) and Debra (Jack), proud grandfather of Amy, Colin, Michael, Ariel, Nicholas, Max, Emmett and Rory, and of great-grandchildren Sophie and Julien. Served in U.S. Army (WWII), long career in the automotive industry, former member of Fresh Meadow CC for 54 years, 30-year resident of Palm Beach County and actively involved in the Frenchman's Creek community. Avid golfer, bridge player and all around sports enthusiast. Good friend to many, loved by all. He made a difference. He will be sorely missed. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Research to Prevent Blindness, 645 Madison Ave., Floor 21 New York, NY 10022-1010.

BENSINGER--Ted. A great friend for so many years. Our parents were friends, and you were an inspirational pal, both at Yale and until now--65 years later. Teddy, nobody will ever be like you--charismatic, interesting, exciting and fun-loving. It's not going to be the same without you, especially in Jamaica. Dalia and I send our love and sympathy to John, Kerry, Tyler, Peter, Roger and Jane. Larry Leeds

BURTO--William Charles. William Charles Burto died peacefully in his sleep in Cambridge Massachusetts, on July 5, after five years of treatment for multiple myeloma. Born in North Creek, New York, in 1921, Burto graduated from Colgate University in 1942, where he had become a New York State Collegiate Champion skier. In his senior year he was accepted into Harvard's Ph.D. program in English literature, but upon receiving his undergraduate degree he immediately volunteered for service in the Navy. He saw action in both the Atlantic and Pacific, surviving the sinking of his ship at Guadalcanal in 1943. (He was on the bridge of the ship, operating radar equipment, when a bomb killed the captain, a few yards away). At the end of World War II he entered the graduate program at Harvard, assisted by the G.I. Bill, but in 1948 he took a two-year leave of absence to teach English at the University of Iowa, in Iowa City. He then returned to Harvard, completed his Ph.D. in 1954, and began teaching at Lowell State College, soon to become part of the University of Massachusetts, where he served as chair of the Department of English. In 1982 he retired. Burto was the co-author (with Sylvan Barnet, Morton Berman, William E. Cain, and Marcia Stubbs) of several highly successful college textbooks on literature, drama, and composition. He was also the editor of the Signet Classic Edition of Shakespeare's sonnets (with an introduction by W.H. Auden) and of Shakespeare's narrative poems (with an introduction by William Empson). In 1963 he and Sylvan Barnet (his partner since 1952) became interested in Japanese art, especially early calligraphy and Buddhist art, and in subsequent years they assembled a collection that has been exhibited at the Museum of Fine Arts (Boston), the Metropolitan Museum, the Freer/Sackler Galleries, and the Harvard Art Museum. The Metropolitan exhibition was accompanied by a catalog, The Written Image: Japanese Calligraphy and Painting (2002) by Miyeko Murase and others. As an octogenarian and then a nonagenarian he occasionally reflected on his life (especially his survival at Guadalcanal) and his imminent death; at such moments he always remarked that he had been extremely fortunate in being long-lived and very happy. A devoted gardener as well as a serious collector of art, he cherished lines by Walter Savage Landor (who lived a mere 89 years): "Nature I loved and, next to Nature, Art:/I warmed both hands before the fire of life;/It sinks, and I am ready to depart." William Burto is survived by Barnet, by a niece, Sheila Wilson, and by five Geraghty nephews, Elihu, Ennis, Jonathan, Kevin, and Sean. We wish to express our deepest gratitude to Harvard Vanguard Medical Associates and to VNA Care Network and Hospice for their unstinting tender support.
DANFORTH--Alan P.,Died July 4, 2013 in Vero Beach. Born July 6, 1926 in Orange, NJ. He leaves his wife Mallory Webb Danforth, Alan, Jr. (Kathleen) Nicholas, Kevin Crane and Penelope. Semper Fi.

BORUT--Arthur Lee, died at 72 on July 5, 2013 after a long battle with heart disease. To know him was to love him. His kindness, sense of humor and caring nature enriched the lives of all around him. He was the Director of Economic Development and Special Assistant to the Commissioner for the NYC Office of Economic Development. During his time at the PA of NY/NJ he served as Manager of Accounting Services, Senior Financial Consultant and Administrator of the Fund for Regional Development. He is survived by his loving wife, Josephine, son Adam (Shireen), grandsons Nate and Jeremy, brother Michael (Ann) Borut, and niece Rachel (Eric).

de La CHAPELLE--Don C. A native New Yorker, graduate of Horace Mann and Princeton University, went to his eternal home with Jesus on June 21st; which was also his 61st wedding anniversary with his bride Peggy. Don worked in the travel industry throughout his career; starting with Pan American Airways, then onto Atlas Travel in Houston and finally Navigant Travel in Houston until his retirement. Don was an avid gardener, faithful volunteer to various ministries, and a loyal fan of baseball. He is best known for his positive attitude in life, a great sense of humor, his faith in God and his deep love for his wife and family. Don leaves behind his wife, daughter, son, daughter-in-law and six grandchildren who will miss him the rest of their lives! A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday July 20th at 10am at Memorial Drive United Methodist Church in Houston, Texas. In lieu of flowers the family kindly requests donations made to: Alzheimer's Association (alz.org) Tribute: Chapelle Condolences can be sent to: Bill de La Chapelle billd2020@gmail.com

BUCKNER--Jean, 88, passed away on June 26, 2013. Beloved daughter of Alfred and Helen Jahr. Graduate of The Dalton School and Barnard College. Mother to Carin Hird, Joel and Barbara Conn. Wife of the late Sidney Buckner. Mother-in-law to Terry Hird, adoring grandmother to David Hird and Catherine Johnson, grandmother-in-law to Eromi and Dax and a proud great-grandmother to Elle and Asher. a native New Yorker, she loved to travel, attend opera and the theatre. She touched many lives with her kindness. She will be dearly missed.

BUDELIS--Richard, artist and Associate Professor of Fine Arts at Pratt Institute. His sculpture appeared in many group exhibits, the Boston Elements Show in 1971, outdoor installations at Ward's Island, as well as Pratt faculty fine arts shows. He was a founder, with John Pai, of the Sculpture Department at Pratt and developed courses in sculpture using plastic materials. He taught a wide variety of undergraduate drawing and sculpture, and tech classes, as well as an art and technology class at NYU on a grant from the Howard Weiss Foundation. He served as Chair 1973-1980 of undergraduate sculpture, ceramics and jewelry, and as Head of undergraduate sculpture 1990-97, and administered the Cantor Foundation grant for Master Class in Sculpture 1994-97. He is survived by his sisters Julia Budelis and Lillian Thiede, his daughter Natalie, from his previous marriage to Maxine DeSeta, and Constance Williams Budelis, his wife of 43 years. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Department of Fine Arts - Sculpture, Pratt Institute, Brooklyn, NY 11205.

BERHALTER--Richard, age 55 died suddenly in New York City on July 9. He was born June 19, 1958 to the late Edward and Irene Berhalter. Rich grew up in East Granby, CT and then graduated from Boston College. He moved to New York and started a long career in telecommunications with AT&T, Lucent and Avaya. He was the devoted partner of the late Michael Stevenson. Family members include Carl Condon of Toronto, ON; Paul Condon of North Bay, ON; Barbara Condon-Tatzel of Fonthill, ON; Edward Condon of London, ON; Nancy Berkhout of Renfrew, ON; and the Cobb family - Ty, Leigh, Chance, Chelsea, Brady and Chloe - who will miss him greatly. Rich also leaves behind an enviably wide circle of friends who will never forget many happy times at Friends Lake, Fire Island and his home in New York City. We will remember most his loyalty and deep commitment to friendship and family. A memorial service will be held at the Church of St. Francis Xavier, 46 West 16th Street, New York City on Friday, July 26 at 10am. Charitable donations in Rich's name may be made to The Hole in the Wall Gang Camp, Ashford, CT: www.holeinthewallgang.org.

Erich Spangenberg often sues companies, contending patent infringement. So it was a surprise when he took the side of a small company facing such a suit over a new phone app.

Non-practicing entities, also known as patent-assertion entities, are companies that own the patent rights for products they do not manufacture or use. They make money primarily by suing other companies for patent infringement. IPNav, Erich Spangenberg’s company, has been the most active of these firms.

WIST--Reba Psaty. Died peacefully on July 13 at 90 years of age. She led many lives: extraordinary mother, beloved wife and companion, devoted grandmother, dear sister, favorite aunt, loyal friend, trusted advisor, gifted teacher, unstoppable civic activist, gefilte-fish maker, French-speaker, auction-stalker, world traveler. Born in Brooklyn on January 16, 1923 to Charles and Leah (Seham) Psaty, she graduated from Hunter College and earned her masters degree from Brooklyn College while working and caring for her family. She led her life with immense drive, passion and courage. Left widowed with two children, she inspired everyone by her example of how to lead an adventurous, thoughtful and honorable life. She leaves behind her children Ronda (Frank Chaney), Andrew (Maria), grandchildren Milton, Ariana, Miles and step grandson Robbie. Beloved wife of the late Milton; exuberant companion of Jerome Muchnick; joyful sister-in law to Bertha Psaty and Helen Wist; cherished aunt to many nieces and nephews. The funeral service will be held on Monday, July 15th, 1:30pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in her memory may be made to the Hunter College Foundation, 695 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10065 att: Reba Wist Fund.

TOUEG--Elia, passed away on July 13 at the age of 87, following a long illness. Beloved husband, father, grandfather and uncle. Respected by all his patients and colleagues. Funeral at Riverside Memorial Chapel, July 15 at 11:15am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to HIAS.

SYLVANE--Bessie, of Palm Beach FL, NYC, and Neponsit, NY. Wife of the late Allen Sylvane - mother of the late Ronnie Sylvane Postal (George deceased) - mother of the late Barbara Sylvane Glass (Alan). Survived by her son Marc (Barbara) and her grandchildren Brittany, Zachary, Stacie, Cori and Tara and by her great-grandchildren Brooklyn and George. Peacefully on July 8 she left her body of almost 98 years. Our sweet Bessie - always loving kind and gentle-she passed through with love and a smile. She had tremendous inner strength, moral courage, and a true sincere humility in the mind. She had the love that loves because it could not do otherwise. She constantly kept good will and love in her heart and let them pour out on all.

REID--Pauline Clark, age 85, died peacefully at her home in New York City on July 12. A graduate of Vassar College class of 1949, she worked as a TWA flight attendant before marrying Jim T. Reid and living in Kansas City, MO until 2003. Among her many interests, she was head docent at the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art, active in the Vassar Club, a volunteer at Saint Luke's Hospital Auxiliary, and a member of the Altar Guild at St Andrews Episcopal Church. She is survived by sisters Phoebe Chardon and Jane Ashley, children Sarah Reid, Bill Reid, and Catherine Cox, their spouses, and six grandchildren. Interment will be private.

RAND--Karen, on July 12, 2013. Beloved wife of Cooke. Loving mother of Elizabeth, Jonathan and Rachel. Cherished daughter of the late Sylvia and Michael Rosenberg. Devoted sister of Teddi (the late Mike) Birnbaum and Robin (Ed) Virshup. A dynamic and vibrant woman, Karen was a successful entrepreneur and businesswoman, and true friend, who enriched the lives of everyone she met. The epitome of beauty and accomplishment, the world has lost one of its bright lights. Funeral service at Park Ave Synagogue (Madison & E87), Monday, July 15 at 11:30am. The family will be receiving at the Rand residence on Monday through Thursday 4-8pm and Friday 1-4pm.

RAND--Karen. We mourn the passing of our beautiful and dear friend Karen and remember her strong will and imposing presence. We will miss you. We love you still and always will. Our deepest sympathies to Cooke, Elizabeth, Jonathan and Rachel. Jacky and Jeff Clyman Judy and Alfred Friedman Francine and Albert Silverstein

MORETTI--Frank A. The Black Rock Forest Consortium mourns the loss of its long-time president and visionary leader, Dr. Frank A. Moretti. Dr. Moretti was committed to the idea of the Consortium for years before the Consortium was created in 1989, and continued to introduce new ideas to the Consortium and the Consortium to his incredibly broad circle of friends and colleagues until his death. The Black Rock Forest Consortium owes much of its growth and success to Dr. Moretti's enthusiasm, creativity, wisdom, persistence and networking. We will miss Frank more than we can say, and send our condolences to his wife Robin Stern and his entire family. Sibyl R. Golden, Chairman Dr. William S.F. Schuster, Executive Director

MENAGH--Douglas D. I mourn your passing and send my condolences to your kind and generous sister, Diane, who loved you dearly and provided you with the kind of care and support that your mother and wonderful grandmother gave you in the tradition of a true Darcey lady. May you rest in peace. Eileen Hawkins

MENAGH--Douglas D.,beloved brother of Diane, died at his home July 10, 2013; he was 63 years old. A native New Yorker, he graduated from Power Memorial Academy, Fairfield University and Fordham Law School and practiced law at his private firm. He was honored as Man of the Year (1997) by the Catholic Council of The Electrical Workers of Local 3, a union founded by his father, Donald, and his uncles, Ed and Jack. Douglas Menagh is survived by his sister and his children. Visiting Sunday 2-5pm and 7-9pm, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., NYC. Burial Monday at Woodlawn Cemetery. A memorial mass in celebration of the life of Douglas Menagh will be offered at a later date.

McCOURT--David. The Breast Cancer Research Foundation and Play for P.I.N.K. mourn the passing of David McCourt, husband of BCRF Advisory Board Member and friend, Mary Bryant McCourt. Our hearts go out to Mary and the entire McCourt family. Leonard A. Lauder, BCRF Co-Chairman Kinga Lampert, BCRF Co-Chairman Myra J. Biblowit, BCRF President Laura Lassman, Play for P.I.N.K. President Larry Norton, MD, BCRF Scientific Director

KOTZEN--Lynn Andrews, peacefully on July 11 at 81 years of age. Beloved wife of the late Marvin Stanley Kotzen, mother of Elinor Kotzen Spokes and Deborah Kotzen, mother-in-law of Jeffrey Spokes, grandmother of adoring grandsons Joshua, Tobias and Isaac Spokes, sister of Joseph L. Andrews Jr., Dale Andrews Eldridge and the late Ann Andrews Paxton. Raised in Scarsdale and a graduate of Wellesley College, she resided in Larchmont and New Rochelle for nearly 50 years where she was active in many civic and religious organizations and was universally admired for her leadership, her spirit and spunk, and her commitment to making a difference in her community. Her passing leaves a huge hole in the hearts of all who knew her. Funeral will be held on Monday, July 15 at 11:30am at John J. Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY 10538. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to Planned Parenthood Federation of America.

KLAHR--Sheldon (Shelly), September 7, 1926 - July 12, 2013. Exceptional friend to us of more than 70 years: through Bronx school days, service in WWII and compatible married couples/ friends. We loved him and will miss him. Goodnight sweet prince and may flights of angels sing thee to thy rest. Sandy Feinman, Malcolm Ratner and Arty Levy
GLICKMAN--Marvin. Beloved friend, passed away peacefully July 12th, 2013. Our deepest condolences to his lovely wife, Barbara, and families. He will be deeply missed. Rhoda and Arthur Rodbell

GLICKMAN--Marvin. High Ridge Country Club acknowledges with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Marvin Glickman. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Barbara, and their family. Stuart Albrecht, President Robert D. Lang, Secretary

GLICKMAN--Marvin. The Board of Governors and the members of The Seawane Club, record with sorrow the loss of our member Marvin Glickman. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his wife Barbara and family. Jack Irushalmi, President

GLICKMAN--Marvin, died peacefully on July 12th, in the presence of his wife and children. Survived by his wife, Barbara Glickman, his children Joan and John, step-children Steven and Lynn, grandchildren Adam, Joel, Nidal and Dalia, step-grandchildren Nicole and Jules, and great-grandchildren Stella and Thea. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, July 17th, at 11:30am at Riverside Memorial Chapel in Hewlett.

EINHORN--Anne (Alexander). Primary Stages mourns the loss of our beloved company member, Anne Einhorn who passed away on July 11, 2013. Since 1985, Anne served at Primary Stages in many capacities as public relations director, press agent, board member and trusted advisor. An essential fixture since its inception, she brought with her a wealth of experience from previous work at Actors' Equity, Society for Stage Directors and Choreographers (SDC), AMAS Repertory, Joseph Jefferson Theatre, No Smoking Playhouse, and the Foundation for the Extension and Development of American Professional Theatre (FEDAPT) which she helped establish. Known for her kindness and commitment to artists, she was a source of inspiration to decades of writers, staff, interns and audience. The Anne and Marvin Einhorn School of the Performing Arts (ESPA) was named in honor of her and her husband Marvin. We extend our love and condolences to her family. We were indeed fortunate to have been so enriched by Anne's wisdom, wit and generosity of spirit.

EINHORN--Anne Alexander, 89, died peacefully at home on July 11, surrounded by her adoring family- her husband of 70 years, Marvin Einhorn, her children, Ellen Zerkin, Stephen Einhorn and Kenneth Einhorn, their spouses and seven grandchildren. In the 1950's, she was a leader of the pioneering Teaneck Civic Conference, which defeated blockbusting and stopped "white flight" in Teaneck, NJ. Inimitable, ineffable and indomitable, Annie will be sorely missed by her family and by untold others in the world of theatre, her other family. Send contributions in her name to the Einhorn School of Performing Arts, 307 West 38th Street, Suite 1510, New York, NY 10018.

CHERENSON--Shirley Brody, of Rockville, MD, formally of Scarsdale, NY. Died peacefully at age 89 surrounded by loved ones on July 9. Beloved wife of Alan H. Cherenson of blessed memory. Devoted mother of Heidi King, Marc (Roseanne) Cherenson, Ruth (Todd) Magin, Paula ( Bruce) Koffsky, loving grandmother of Francesca, Rachel, Jordana, Zev, Jacob, Benjamin, Alexandra, and Adam. The light of her love illuminated many lives. Deeply missed, never forgotten.

BOGDANOFF--Phyllis (nee Sweed), 83, on July 11, 2013. Long time resident of Greenwich Village, NY, Monterey, MA and Sunny Isles Beach, FL. NYU graduate, former editor-in-chief of "Gifts and Decorative Accessories" magazine and expert in table-top and collectibles. Phyllis successfully balanced family and work in a life rich with travels and friends. Predeceased by all of her closest relations, her surviving family and friends will fondly remember her meals, gifts, intelligence, independence and, most of all, her love. Donations in her memory may be made to the American Cancer Society. For information about burial plans, please contact Stellato Funeral Home, Lyndhurst, NJ. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

BUCKNER--Jean, 88, passed away on June 26, 2013. Beloved daughter of Alfred and Helen Jahr. Graduate of The Dalton School and Barnard College. Mother to Carin Hird, Joel and Barbara Conn. Wife of the late Sidney Buckner. Mother-in-law to Terry Hird, adoring grandmother to David Hird and Catherine Johnson, grandmother-in-law to Eromi and Dax and a proud great-grandmother to Elle and Asher. a native New Yorker, she loved to travel, attend opera and the theatre. She touched many lives with her kindness. She will be dearly missed.

WEINER--Myron (also known as Mike Alpert), 71, on July 13, 2013. Owner of John's of 12th Street restaurant, he often said, "I love what I do, and I do what I love." He made friends for life wherever he was, and he will be deeply missed by everyone whose life he touched. Survived by his wife Judith Anderson, his sister Sondra Noskin, and many cherished family members. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, July 17 at 2pm at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

TURCHIN--Daniel, born August 12, 1921, died Sunday, July 14, 2013, at 4:15pm. He was just four weeks shy of his 92nd birthday. He was born in Brooklyn at 1560 East 22nd Street. He attended James Madison High School, class of '37, graduating at 16 years old; Brooklyn College, class of '41, which he graduated at age 20; and NYU, where he graduated with an MBA in 1943 at age 22. He completed Brooklyn Law School in 1949 and was admitted to the New York State Bar that same year, thereafter qualifying as a certified public accountant in New York State. Among his many clients, he was always proud to have served the Lawyers Guild in its youth. He counted numerous former clients as dear, life-long friends, who relied on him both for his knowledge and his calm sensible advise. Daniel Turchin took complete joy in every aspect of life. He was a violinist, an athlete, and bridge player. He played the violin in high school for the All New York City High School Orchestra, in the orchestra in India during his service there in World War II, in the Akron Ohio Symphony Orchestra, and after he retired in the Sunshine Orchestra in Fort Lauderdale, FL. He was on the swimming and diving teams at Brooklyn College, ice skated, skied, bicycled, played tennis, rode horseback, and sailed. He passed on his love of music, math, sports, and enjoyment of life to his children and grandchildren. During World War II, he was stationed in India, where he was a Powerman 166 and a Rifle Marksman and Carbine Sharpshooter. His sergeant told him, "You talk like a boy, but you shoot like a man." Dan said that he was able to shoot so straight from years of holding the violin steady. He received a Sharpshooter Medal, the American Theater Ribbon, the Asiatic Pacific Theater Ribbon, and the World War II Victory Medal. The funeral service will be held Wednesday July 17, 2013, at 12:45pm at Sinai Chapel, 162-05 Horace Harding Boulevard, Fresh Meadows, Queens. The family will be sitting shiva on Wednesday night at the home of daughter Lauren Orent in Roslyn, NY and on Thursday and Friday at the home of daughter Michele Mirman in Brooklyn, NY. Daniel Turchin is survived by his loving family who miss him already: his wife Lillian, son Lee Turchin, daughters Michele Mirman and Lauren Orent, grandchildren David Turchin, Matthew and Phoebe Mirman, Elizabeth and David Orent, daughter in law Karin Turchin and sons-in-law Richard Orent and Paul Mirman, brother-in-law Joseph Scherrer and nephews Douglas James and Daniel and Paul Scherrer.

TOUEG--Elia, passed away on July 13 at the age of 87, following a long illness. Beloved husband, father, grandfather and uncle. Respected by all his patients and colleagues. Funeral at Riverside Memorial Chapel, July 15 at 11:15am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to HIAS.

TOUEG--Eli, MD. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center community notes with sadness the passing of our dear friend and former colleague, Eli Toueg, MD, who served with great distinction as a member of our Ophthalmology staff for over 30 years. He will be greatly remembered for his steadfast commitment to quality medical care and the education of physicians in training. To his family, friends and loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Harris M. Nagler, MD President Brent Chabus, MD President, Medical Board H. Jay Wisnicki, MD Former Director of Ophthalmology

STEIN--Elaine Glaser, of Remsenburg, NY, formerly of New York City and Miami died peacefully at her home on July 11, 2013 at the age of 78. Predeceased by her husband Robert and son Adam. Elaine is survived by her son Neil, daughter-in-law Elizabeth, granddaughter Katherine, brother Allan Glaser, and cousin Victor Glaser. Memorial services will be held at a later date in Westhampton Beach and Miami. The family requests donations be made to the Cathedral School of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, NY, NY 10025.

STANLEY--Vada Shell. One of the kindest, gentlest, most loving people in the world is no longer with us. Vada Shell Stanley, 80, passed away peacefully at home in New Canaan, Connecticut on July 13 after a long illness. Many of those who knew her could think of no better word than "angel" to describe her. Wherever she went, Vada Stanley impressed people as a very special person. She might have won any beauty contest she entered, but her beauty was more than skin deep; inside there was a beautiful soul. She could be and was a charming dinner companion for people like Bill Clinton and Prince Charles, among others, but the same warm charm was there for absolutely everyone who crossed her path. A key thing that made her so very special was her way of making each of us feel we were special to her. A rare combination of compassion, acceptance and love radiated from her being. Born in 1933 in the rolling hills of Kentucky, she had a life that was charmed in many ways but with challenges as well. Hers was a loving family but not one in which people went to college. She did by earning all the money needed with jobs through her high school and college years. Not long after that she had to face the need to end a disastrous marriage with two tiny children to support, Bill and Glee, and no help from their father. At that challenging time in her life she got a job, a rare one for women then, as a marketing management trainee at the home office of Procter & Gamble. There she met and married (three years later) Ted Stanley who worked in the same office in a similar job. Their 52-year marriage was a happy one; her husband never got over his great good luck in having found her. They had one son, Jonathan, who appreciated her just as much. After their marriage in 1961, they moved to Westport, Connecticut and have lived in New Canaan, CT since 1996 with, at various times, second homes in Manhattan, Santa Fe and Vermont. Vada Stanley was quite simply one of the most wonderful people in all the world, and she will be long remembered by everyone fortunate enough to know her. May she rest in peace and find as much joy in another world as she gave to us. A memorial service to be held at a later date.

SOLOMON--Max, died July 13, 2013 in Delray Beach, Florida. Max was born October 13, 1917 in The Bronx, New York. He served his country during World War II in the South West Pacific from 1941 to 1945. On returning home, he attended night school to earn BA and LLB degrees from New York University. He spent his entire working life at the Greater New York Insurance Company, retiring at age 85. He always and often spoke about everyone with whom he worked at GNY as his second family. He married Doris Miriam Klein in 1946 and they were happily married until her death in 2003. He was beloved by his three children, Steven, the late Susan Rita Solomon and the late Cindy Beth Solomon. He is survived by his son Steven, his daughter-in-law Bess, his grandsons Matthew and David and granddaughter-in-law Amanda, and his great-granddaughter Lilah. Interment will be at Beth El Cemetery in Westwood, New Jersey. Donations in his memory may be made to Judges and Lawyers Breast Cancer Alert, www.jalbca.org, or Hospice of Palm Beach County Foundation, www.hpbcf.org.

Ann Kirschner Dean, Macaulay Honors College

Donations to JNF or the Joseph M. Schor Fellowship in Biochemistry at Florida State University.

MORETTI--Frank A. Colleagues and friends in Columbia University's Information Services/University Libraries mourn the loss of Dr. Frank A. Moretti. Frank was a leading international theorist and practitioner in the area of digital technology and education, and a distinguished teacher and scholar. He inspired us to think creatively and strategically. He reminded us always that our mission is successful students and great teachers. His work in CCNMTL and in the classroom has and will benefit generations of learners and educators. We send our condolences to his wife Robin Stern and his entire family. Jim Neal, University Librarian

MORETTI--Frank. The Armory Foundation mourns the passing of its long time devoted trustee, Dr. Frank Moretti. An educational idealist and lifelong sportsman Frank affected the lives of thousands of his students and close friends. His tireless dedication to technological innovation and new media in no manner affected his warm personal touch, which also left his door open to the lives and challenges of so many others. Our board of directors and the children and young adults influenced by the Armory's many programs will miss his presence in this great city. Our sincere condolences to his much loved wife, Robin, and his entire family. Michael Frankfurt, Chairman Norbert Sander, MD President & CEO

MORETTI--Frank A. The Black Rock Forest Consortium mourns the loss of its long-time president and visionary leader, Dr. Frank A. Moretti. Dr. Moretti was committed to the idea of the Consortium for years before the Consortium was created in 1989, and continued to introduce new ideas to the Consortium and the Consortium to his incredibly broad circle of friends and colleagues until his death. The Black Rock Forest Consortium owes much of its growth and success to Dr. Moretti's enthusiasm, creativity, wisdom, persistence and networking. We will miss Frank more than we can say, and send our condolences to his wife Robin Stern and his entire family. Sibyl R. Golden, Chairman Dr. William S.F. Schuster, Executive Director

VISCUSI--Mildred. 07/16/29 - 07/17/93. 20 years of missing you. You are in our thoughts and prayers everyday. Love, Stephen & Casey, Laura & Ross

STANLEY--Vada Shell. The Brain & Behavior Research Foundation (formerly known as NARSAD) recognizes a deep loss to our leadership and to all who benefit from our efforts in the passing of Vada Shell Stanley. She was an early leader in providing and guiding support for research in mental health. She recognized that the challenges of mental illness could be overcome through focusing outstanding scientific talents on understanding brain and behavior disorders. Together with her husband Ted, they initiated major philanthropic efforts to fund and guide the research of literally hundreds of scientists in the field through the Stanley Foundation and through their support of key institutions, including the Brain & Behavior Research Foundation (NARSAD), the Broad Institute, Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory and their own Stanley Research Institute. Their generosity has immensely progressed efforts to rebuild the lives of people suffering from mental illness. Vada Stanley's modesty and quiet support belied the powerful influence she and her husband Ted have had in the field of mental health. Her warm, caring spirit translated into a powerful drive for vital, life-giving science. Herbert Pardes, M.D., Pres. Scientific Council Stephen A. Lieber, Chairman Constance E. Lieber, President Emerita Jeffrey Borenstein, M.D., CEO, President

SCHOR--Joseph M.,Ph.D., 84, died at home peacefully after a long illness on July 14. Beloved father, brother, husband of Laura S. Schor and the late Sandra M. Schor, grandfather and friend. A brilliant man who lived many lives: biochemist, executive, astrologer, farmer, Col. NY Guard, saxophonist, archaeologist, Zionist. Retired VP of Forest Laboratories. Also survived by Esther Starry Schor; Joshua Schor and Lori; Gideon Schor and Shara; Robert Schor and Lily; Daniel, Jordan, Susannah, Noemi, Shayna, Rafaella, Sandra; Eric, Daniela and William; and Neil. Donations to JNF or the Joseph M. Schor Fellowship in Biochemistry at Florida State University.

SCHLESINGER--Ina (Petschek), 91, died July 14, 2013 in New York. She had equal passions for teaching and learning. She is survived by her sister, Eva Goldmann, her three children, Stephen (Marilyn), Ann, and Richard (John), and her two beloved grandchildren, Nora and Aaron Schlesinger. In lieu of flowers, donations are appreciated to the Center for Leaning and Living, PO Box 125, New York, NY 10044 or the Hospice of Visiting Nurse Service of New York, 1250 Broadway, New York, NY 10001.

SCHATZ--James L.,The City College Fund Board of Directors mourns the loss of James L. Schatz, who passed away over the weekend at the age of 93. The Fund's former Executive Director and long-time board member served in the United States Army as a Second Lieutenant, earning a Bronze Star for his bravery during the Battle of the Bulge. After the war, he developed a successful career in business as a stock trader and president of various companies. He was extremely active in the community: he served on the Woodmere-Hewlett branch of the Board of Education; was president of the board of the Peninsula Counseling Center, a mental health clinic; volunteering for the Cub Scouts and Boy Scouts, etc. James Schatz was a man of great humility, honor, dignity, intelligence, wit, and warmth. He is survived by his wife, Elinor, his children William, Elizabeth, Thomas, and grandchildren. He will be missed by a great many.

RAPKIN--Eva Samuel, passed away July 15, 2013 in her apartment at Stonebridge in Skillman, NJ. She was the beloved wife of sixty years of Professor Chester Rapkin. Eva Rapkin is survived by her loving son David Rapkin of New York City, her faithful daughter-in-law Ilene Goldsmith Rapkin, her devoted grandson Asher Goldsmith Rapkin of Brooklyn, New York, her sister-in-law Marietta Samuel of Jerusalem, Israel, her nieces and nephew Aliza, Nina and Josh and their beloved children. Eva was a worldly and highly cultured woman whose youth in Palestine shaped her later love of Israel where relatives still reside. Her interest in opera, art, music, world events and literature informed her lively conversations and long standing relationships with many Princeton friends. She had a wicked sense of humor and was a welcome guest at the holiday tables of her New York family. Her life with her husband was fulfilling as she traveled the world with Professor Chester Rapkin of Princeton University, an internationally renowned city planner as well as a City Planning Commissioner of the City of New York under Mayor John Lindsay. Her home was filled with books, art, and the welcoming spirit of a woman who will be deeply missed by all who knew her. A private graveside funeral will be held on Thursday only for immediate family. In lieu of flowers, the family respectfully requests donations be made to the Israel Defense Force at www.fidf.org/donate in honor of Eva Samuel Rapkin.

KAUFMAN--Paul S. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Paul S. Kaufman, who cared deeply about helping people in need and making the world a better place. We extend our sympathies to Paul's wife, Roberta Nancy; to their children, Stacy (Steven) Hoffman and Mark (Stacey) Kaufman; and to the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

KAUFMAN--Dr. Paul S.,Oral Surgeon. Beloved husband of Roberta Nancy Kaufman, beloved father and father-in-law of Stacy and Steven Hoffman, Mark and Stacey Kaufman, beloved grandfather of Scott and Rochelle Hoffman, and Ethan, Spencer and Victoria Kaufman. GROSS--Joan Helene (Kurash), of Northampton, MA died on Saturday, July 13, 2013 of complications from Scleroderma, an auto-immune disease. She is survived by her three children, Jonathan Gross, Laurey Mauck, and Jennifer Gross; her seven grandchildren, Hannah, Henry, Natasha, Nicholas, Daria, Amelia, and Oscar; and her sister, Shirley Elliott. A memorial service will be held in Northampton, MA at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Scleroderma Foundation, 300 Rosewood Drive, Suite 105, Danvers, MA 01923, or the Forbes Library, 20 West St., Northampton, MA 01060.

GORDON--Sondra Hammer. Sandy Gordon of Houston, 79, died on July 14. Sandy grew up in the Five Towns and graduated from Cornell. She is survived by her husband Harvey, sons Michael (Andrea), Bruce (Radhika), and Paul (Richard), five grandchildren, and sister Sheila (Bernard) Dilbert.

GOODMAN--Reynold. The entire Hebrew Home at Riverdale family mourns the loss of Reynold Goodman. Reynold was a delightful and warm man and we will miss his kindness. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Goodman family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. The Hebrew Home at Riverdale Daniel Reingold, President & CEO David Weinstein, EVP & COO David V. Pomeranz, EVP & COO

GARMENT--Leonard. The Brooklyn Law School community mourns the loss of Leonard Garment, distinguished member of the Class of 1949, former member of the Board of Trustees, and, most recently, Adjunct Professor of Law. His popular and unique class, "Law, Politics and Personality," called upon his experience as a litigator, Presidential advisor, and author as it introduced students to the intersection and interaction of what he regarded as the three key ingredients of legal history. His commitment to the Law School and its faculty and students will long be appreciated and remembered. We express our deepest sympathy to his wife, Suzanne, his daughter, Ann, and his entire family. Stuart Subotnick, Chairman of the Board Nicholas W. Allard, Dean

FULLER--Joyce Malm, 89. Teacher, writer, friend, peace and justice activist. Widow of Jeffrey Eastman Fuller, fondly remembered by brother Eric, daughters Anne and Cordie, grandsons Harald and Reuben, etc. Memorial service July 18, 10am, St. Mark's Church-in-the-Bowery.

FINCKE--Melvin. The congregation of Shaaray Tefila records with deep sorrow the death of Melvin Fincke. Heartfelt condolences are extended to Jane Fincke Orenstein, our Executive Director, her husband Larry, daughter Emily and their loved ones. May his memory be for blessing. Rabbi Jonathan A. Stein Michael Starr, President

ELLISON--Muriel Jonathan, 91, born in Wales, a resident of Jefferson's Ferry (former resident of Stony Brook and Hempstead) on July 15, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Edward. Loving mother of Margaret (Lee) Christiansen, Edward (Jean), Amy (Trudy) and the late James. Cherished grandmother of Christopher, Tracy, Kelly, Patrick, Kysten, Brooke and Reed. Dear great grandmother of Jacqueline, Emily, Thomas, Joseph, Samantha and Vincent. Also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. A member of the Daughters of the British Empire and a lover of all things interesting and beautiful. She will be forever missed by all who knew her. Friends may call at Bryant Funeral Home, 411 Old Town Road, Setauket. Visiting Thursday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm with a service to celebrate her life Thursday, 8pm. Funeral Friday at 10am at Bryant Funeral Home, Setauket. Interment Long Island National Cemetery, Pinelawn. www.bryantfh.com

CIFU--John Lewis, of Waxhaw, NC died suddenly on July 13. Born September 1, 1934 in Manhattan, the youngest of five sons of Saturnina (Saccocio) and Giovanni Cifu. He earned his undergraduate and Master's degrees in electrical Engineering from City College of New York and Columbia University. He worked for 35 years as an electrical engineer and program manager for Sperry/ Unisys in Lake Success, NY. In 1956, he married his college sweetheart, Rosa Schwarz with whom he had three sons. Rosa passed away from cancer in 1999. John met and married Hilda Uys in 2000. John is remembered by those who knew him as a lifelong Democrat, military history buff, an enthusiastic dancer and a lifelong New York sports fan. His dry sense of humor lives on in his sons and he will be remembered and missed by all who knew him. John leaves behind his loving wife Hilda; his three sons: John (and Annmarie), Dr. David (and Dr. Ingrid Prosser), and Douglas (and Melissa Lautenberg); step-children Adel, Matthys, Lenge and Amelia; grandchildren: Amanda, James, Gabriella, Isabelle, Rachel and Daniel; sisters-in-law Eileen and Loretta; and many nieces and nephews. Reposing Donohue Cecere Funeral Home, 290 Post Ave., Westbury, NY on Thursday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 10am at St. Brigid's RC Church Westbury, NY. Entombment to follow in Holy Rood Cemetery Westbury, NY. www.donohue-cecere.com

ALLISON--Herbert M.,Jr. In every endeavor, excellence was at his core. Herb was inspired by and dedicated to his family, his work, and our country. We treasure all that we shared together and mourn the great loss of our beloved friend. To Simin, John, Andrew and the entire family, we offer our deepest condolences. Patti and Phil

ALLISON--Herbert M.,Jr. The Board of Trustees, staff and dancers of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater mourn the passing of Herb Allison, the beloved husband of Board Vice-Chair Simin Allison. Herb was a passionate advocate and dedicated supporter of the Ailey organization. He enthusiastically joined with Simin in helping Ailey to achieve many important milestones. His leadership, wise counsel, inquisitive spirit and warm friendship will be deeply missed. Our hearts go out to Simin, sons John and Andrew, and the entire family. Joan H. Weill, Chairman; Robert Battle, Artistic Director; Bennett Rink, Executive Director

AHLGREN--John R.,of Bronxville, died on July 15, 2013. Son of Gustav Ahlgren and Lydia Konradson Ahlgren, and husband of the late Wynne G. Ahlgren, he was born in Manchester, New Hampshire, on October 9, 1920. After graduating from Dartmouth College in 1941, he entered Cornell Law School, but left after the attack on Pearl Harbor to join the United States Navy where he was assigned to Admiral Nimitz's Headquarters Staff there. He later studied Russian and was assigned to the United States Embassy in Moscow from 1946 to 1947. He settled in New York where he became a Vice President of the Irving Trust Company. Mr. Ahlgren was a member of the Reformed Church in Bronxville, the Bronxville Rotary Club, Siwanoy Country Club and the Hillsboro Club in Hillsboro, Florida. He is survived by eleven nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at The Reformed Church in Bronxville on Saturday, September 7, 2013 at 11am.

STARK--Orris H. Known as Bob, arrived May 7, 1916 in Clinton, IN; departed from his Ridgefield, CT home July 18, 2012. A lawyer, marketing executive and enthusiastic antique car buff. His first car was a six dollar purchase of Ford Model T. In subsequent years Cadillac became his marque of choice, participating in well over 40 Classic Car and Cadillac/ LaSalle tours in his 1941 or 1947 Caddy. Above all, he was a kind, warm-hearted gentleman who is greatly missed.
GLICKSMAN--Albert. Aly - dearest husband, missing you every moment since July 18th, 2005, but still sharing my life with you. Love, Fran
ZARO--Sam. "There was only one." His Friends at Montammy

LITWAK--Robert S.,M.D. Dr. Litwak, aged 88, passed away on July 16 of severe pneumonia after a brief hospitalization in Concord, Massachusetts. He was professor emeritus of cardiothoracic surgery at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York, where he established the heart surgery program, operated and taught for over four decades. In addition to his pioneering work in cardiac surgery, Litwak was an accomplished jazz drummer, who once played in the Benny Goodman band. A beloved husband and father, he was married to the late Doris Sutherland Litwak, and is survived by his children, Robert of Washington, D.C., and Barbara Lizotte and granddaughter Chloe of Concord. His burial will be private. A memorial service to celebrate his life will be held at a date to be determined. Donations to his memory may be made to the American Heart Association.

STANLEY--Vada Shell. The Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory (CSHL) Board of Trustees, faculty and administration mourn the passing of Vada Stanley, who, with her husband, Ted, was deeply devoted to helping diagnose and treat those suffering from psychiatric disorders. At CSHL, they generously established the Stanley Institute for Cognitive Genomics and have encouraged collaborations among leading scientists that have transformed our understanding of the genetics underlying schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. We at the Laboratory enjoyed visits with Vada across the Long Island Sound and admired her understated elegance at our Double Helix Medals Dinner events in Manhattan. Underlying Vada's compassionate nature was what Dr. James Watson described as her great confidence in biomedical research to improve the human condition. Our deepest sympathies to Ted, their son Jonathan and all of Vada's loved ones. Bruce Stillman, President & CEO Jamie C. Nicholls, Board Chairman James D. Watson, Chancellor Emeritus W. Dillaway Ayres, COO

SALDICK--Jerome, 92, March 24, 1921 - July 17, 2013. Husband, father, scholar, world traveler. Bon Voyage! Funeral July 19, 2013 Princeton Jewish Center 435 Nassau St. Princeton, NJ 9:30am. All our love, Evelyn, Barbara and Diane

GARMENT--Leonard. The Brooklyn Law School community mourns the loss of Leonard Garment, distinguished member of the Class of 1949, former member of the Board of Trustees, and, most recently, Adjunct Professor of Law. His popular and unique class, "Law, Politics and Personality," called upon his experience as a litigator, Presidential advisor, and author as it introduced students to the intersection and interaction of what he regarded as the three key ingredients of legal history. His commitment to the Law School and its faculty and students will long be appreciated and remembered. We express our deepest sympathy to his wife, Suzanne, his daughter, Ann, and his entire family. Stuart Subotnick, Chairman of the Board Nicholas W. Allard, Dean

DEBS--Samir (Sam), husband, father, brother, grandfather and, most of all, friend. Sam was a hero to those of us who knew how ill he was . . . never letting on about pain or discomfort. His dedication to his family was extraordinary. Sam was one of our dearest friends and we will miss his caring spirit, his infectious laugh and the friendship we were fortunate to have for more years than we can count. Judy and Marty

DATTILO--Peter Anthony. April 7, 1925, died July 15, 2013. He was the beloved husband of Gloria and father to Peter, Susan and Grandfather to Mimi. Private Memorial Service. Donations can be made to The Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research.

CIFU--John Lewis, of Waxhaw, NC died suddenly on July 13. Born September 1, 1934 in Manhattan, the youngest of five sons of Saturnina (Saccocio) and Giovanni Cifu. He earned his undergraduate and Master's degrees in electrical Engineering from City College of New York and Columbia University. He worked for 35 years as an electrical engineer and program manager for Sperry/ Unisys in Lake Success, NY. In 1956, he married his college sweetheart, Rosa Schwarz with whom he had three sons. Rosa passed away from cancer in 1999. John met and married Hilda Uys in 2000. John is remembered by those who knew him as a lifelong Democrat, military history buff, an enthusiastic dancer and a lifelong New York sports fan. His dry sense of humor lives on in his sons and he will be remembered and missed by all who knew him. John leaves behind his loving wife Hilda; his three sons: John (and Annmarie), Dr. David (and Dr. Ingrid Prosser), and Douglas (and Melissa Lautenberg); step-children Adel, Matthys, Lenge and Amelia; grandchildren: Amanda, James, Gabriella, Isabelle, Rachel and Daniel; sisters-in-law Eileen and Loretta; and many nieces and nephews. Reposing Donohue Cecere Funeral Home, 290 Post Ave., Westbury, NY on Thursday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 10am at St. Brigid's RC Church Westbury, NY. Entombment to follow in Holy Rood Cemetery Westbury, NY. www.donohue-cecere.com

ALLISON--Herbert M.,Jr. The Board of Trustees, staff and dancers of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater mourn the passing of Herb Allison, the beloved husband of Board Vice-Chair Simin Allison. Herb was a passionate advocate and dedicated supporter of the Ailey organization. He enthusiastically joined with Simin in helping Ailey to achieve many important milestones. His leadership, wise counsel, inquisitive spirit and warm friendship will be deeply missed. Our hearts go out to Simin, sons John and Andrew, and the entire family. Joan H. Weill, Chairman; Robert Battle, Artistic Director; Bennett Rink, Executive Director

ZARO--Sam. The Board of Governors and members of Montammy Golf Club express their deepest sorrow at the passing of their beloved member and extend their heartfelt sympathy to Edythe and the Peckar, Bruhim and Silleg Families. Frederic Krieger, President

ZARO--Sam. Rest In Peace our dear friend. You were truly one of a kind. Sue, Herb, Randy, and Meryl Poster

ZARATZIAN--Harry. Violin-violist has had a long and distinguished musical career. He was a member of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra and then was appointed first violist of the Philadelphia Orchestra. He subsequently left to devote himself to solo and chamber music concerts. He was a member of The New York String Trio the Kroll Quartet, The Composers Quartet. He participated in concerts at Tanglewood and the Marlboro Music Festival. He is survived by his wife Rita and his son Rafael. In lieu of flowers please send donations to one of the following: The Hastings-on-Hudson Volunteer Ambulance Corp. 7 Maple Ave., Hastings-on-Hudson NY 10706 or The Hastings PBA, 7 Maple Ave., Hastings-on-Hudson NY 10706 or The Hastings High School Alumni Association http://HOHalumni.org. The funeral will be Friday at 10:30am at Hastings Funeral Home, Inc., 15 Spring Street, Hastings-on-Hudson. Interment will be in Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson.

WROBLEWSKI--Dr. Felix. Died, June 10, 2013, at age 91 in New York City. He is survived by his children, Miriam (Luis Pinon), David, Jonathan (Joyce Klein) and Daniel (Odia), his grandchildren, Aaron (Stephanie Park), Sarah, Hannah, Kayla, Ben, Reuven, Caleb, Deborah, Elisheva, Rebecca, Stella, and Yoni, and his former wife, Dr. Rita Lifschutz Wroblewski. Born August 8, 1921, he graduated from Stuyvesant High School, NYU, and NYU School of Medicine. An internist, Dr. Wroblewski was renowned for his groundbreaking discoveries of how changes in blood enzymes could uncover disease. He received numerous honors as a researcher, educator and brilliant clinician. He was a loving, caring and generous father.

SARTORI--Geno, on July 12th at the Visiting Nurse Service Hospice. Formerly from Crystal Falls, MI, he was 89. Geno was beloved by his partner George, sister Perina, brother Chester (Charlotte), niece Liz (Carolyn), nephews Charles, Jim (Laura), David (Krittika), and many, many friends. He was predeceased by his sister Dolores (H.O.). A memorial celebration will be held later and announced in the Times.

McFADDEN--Edward J. The Board of Directors and the entire Isabella Geriatric Center community mourn the loss of our friend and colleague Edward J. McFadden, Isabella's former President/ CEO from 1991 to 1998. Ed served Isabella with dedication and distinction in many important capacities for forty years. We will always remember Ed's unique spirit and unflinching commitment to Isabella's mission. He will be missed. Our thoughts are with his wife and Isabella board member, Josephine, and the entire family. Mark Lipton, PhD, Chair Mark J. Kator, President/CEO

LAYTON--Eric G.,age 63, passed away peacefully in his home on June 29, 2013. Beloved son of Thelma and Jack Layton. Survived by his wife Hali Layton, his children Stacy and Laurie Layton, Jori Layton and Zach Paz, and brothers and sisters-in-law Alan and Caryn Layton, Peter and Paula Layton, and families. Eric will be remembered and missed by many for his funny quick witted banter, his generosity of spirit and his sincere heartfelt love for family and friends.

KLASS--Ric, of Rye, NY, passed away on July 9. Adored husband of Anne (Stadler) and devoted father of Joe and Hayley. Contributions in his memory can be made to MIT, for the Undergraduate Scholarship Fund. Send to Memorial Gifts, MIT, 600 Memorial Drive, W98-500, Cambridge, MA 02139. Please include a note stating that that your gift is in memory of Richard Klass.

HILL--Louis G.,89, former Common Pleas Court Judge and State Senator passed away on Saturday, July 13th after a lengthy illness with dementia. Born March 10, 1924, in Palm Beach, FL to Crawford Hill and Ann (Kaufman) Hill. Beloved husband for 36 years to Marilyn (Ashton) Young Hill, married in 1977. Formerly married (1951) to Jane (Cox) Hill, now MacElree for 25 years. Hill is the proud father of seven children, 10 grandchildren, four stepchildren and nine step-grandchildren. He had one sister, four stepsiblings and two half-siblings. Hill graduated from St. George's School in Newport, RI in 1942 and Harvard College in 1944 (accelerated class of 1946 due to WWII). He was an undefeated heavyweight boxer at Harvard and served with the US Marines as a captain during both WWII and Korea. He graduated from the University of Pennsylvania Law School in 1949. In the early 1950s he joined the law firm of Dilworth, Paxson, Kalish and Levy as a trial lawyer where for 27 years he never lost a case decided by a jury. Lou Hill first became active in politics as a volunteer campaigning in the 1940s for his stepfather, Richardson Dilworth, mayor of Philadelphia from 1956 to 1962. In 1966 Hill was elected to the Pennsylvania State Senate and served three terms. As Chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, a position he held for over seven years, he was deeply involved in the passage of every law. In the early 1970s Hill was responsible for driving through the legislature the first Crimes and Juvenile Code in Pennsylvania's history. Hill was also the prime sponsor or co-sponsor of hundreds of bills and over 60 became law. He consistently voted to provide funds for the State Crime Commission and the Special Prosecutor Investigating political corruption in Philadelphia. In 1975 he ran unsuccessfully as a Democrat against incumbent Mayor Frank Rizzo. Hill presided as a Common Pleas judge in Philadelphia for over 20 years. He inspired his children and friends with a love for the wilderness. On one memorable weeklong hike his wife, Marilyn, was initiated to the Appalachian Trail on their honeymoon with Hill's children. Starting in the 1950s Hill could often be found early in the morning running the bridle path in Philadelphia along the Wissahickon Creek somewhere between Lincoln Drive, Valley Green and Bell's Mill. After his run he would finish his workout in his basement home gym before going to work at a time when the term home gym was not known. His children are Crawford Hill and his wife, Suzie of Ardmore, PA; Leslie Hill, her husband Dennis Carroll of Chevy Chase, MD; Jessie B. Hill and her husband, Ming Fang of Kauai, HI; Thomas G. Hill and his wife, Nancy Hagens, of Newton, MA; Michael C. Hill and his wife, Susan Bear, of Newton, MA; Charlotte Hill and her husband, Marc Henrich, of San Francisco, CA and Ann Hill of Newtown Square, PA. His stepchildren are Anita Young of Philadelphia, PA; Edwin Germaine (deceased) of Hawaii; Michelle Peretz and her husband Amiel Peretz of Pound Ridge, NY, and Melissa Young of Jenkintown, PA. He is also survived by his half-sister, Deborah (Dilworth) Bishop, of Bryn Mawr, PA and his half-brother, Richardson Dilworth, Jr., and his wife, Leslie Dilworth, of Galisteo, NM. His sister, Marie Townsend, died in 1976. He is also survived by his stepbrother, Warden Dilworth, of Portland, ME and stepsister, Anne Hackett, of Villanova, PA. His stepbrother, Brockie Dilworth of Chicago and stepsister Patricia Lees of Philadelphia predeceased him. The Memorial Service will take place on Tuesday, July 23rd at Bringhurst Funeral Home, West Laurel Hill Cemetery, 225 Belmont Avenue, Bala Cynwyd, PA 19004. Visitation begins at 11am, Memorial Service at noon, reception immediately following. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be sent, in memory of Louis G. Hill to: Friends of the Wissahickon, 8708 Germantown Avenue, Philadelphia, PA 19118. Alzheimer's Association, Delaware Valley Chapter, 399 Market St., Suite 102, Philadelphia, PA 19106.

HESS--Lindy. The Columbia School of Journalism mourns the loss of Lindy Hess, the director of the Columbia Publishing Course, who died on July 13 after battling cancer. Lindy Hess was the light behind 25 years of remarkable leadership for the publishing course, which started at Radcliffe. Her work led thousands of young people into book and magazine publishing careers. Many top editors in New York media outlets count her as their personal mentor. "She was fanatically dedicated to her students, not just collectively but individually," said former dean Nicholas Lemann. "Her ability to steer the publishing course was remarkable, and her reward was the pleasure of seeing generations of her students rise to leadership positions. We will miss her terribly." The school will hold a memorial in her honor in September. At the request of Lindy's husband, Dr. William Appleton, the school is establishing the "Friends of Lindy Hess Fund" to benefit scholarships for the Columbia Publishing Course.

GOODMAN--Reynold Hirsch, 95, formerly of Scarsdale, NY, died July 16 at The Hebrew Home at Riverdale, where he received wonderful care thanks to Dan Reingold and his team. Born and raised on Manhattan's Upper West Side, "Ren" attended NYU and was a US Army Lieutenant during World War II. He saw battle in Okinawa and was training for the invasion of Japan when the war ended. Ren was president of Goodren Products, a pioneer in printing on cellophane, in Englewood, NJ, before retiring to Florida. He was predeceased by his first wife Betty, second wife Elinor, and son Alan. He is survived by his sister, Elaine Mainthow, and five children: John (Donna) of Tuckahoe, NY, Tom (Marie) of New York City, Ken (Carla) of Vallejo, CA, Mary (Patricio) Goodman-Valencia of Tamarac, FL and Barbara (Bob) Prince of Orange, CT. He is also survived by nine grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Donations may be made to The Hebrew Home at Riverdale, Development Office, 5901 Palisades Avenue, Riverdale, New York 10471. hebrewhome.org/donategift.

EISEMAN--Adrienne. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Adrienne Eiseman, and extend sincere condolences to her family. Alan Fischer, President

EISEMAN--Adrienne Kaster, 86, White Plains, of a lengthy illness. She is survived by brother, Lewis Kaster; son, Richard Heller, wife Max; daughters, Robin Moss, Patricia Taich, husband, Richard; grandchildren, Jason Taich, Lilli and Gabriella Vallone. Late daughter, Nancy Eiseman. Services: 12 Noon, today, Ferncliff Cemetery. Donations to Greenwich Hospital, Greenwich, CT.

DONHAUSER--Rosine Lambiotte, 88, died peacefully at her Manhattan home on July 14. Born in 1925, she grew up in the Nievre region of France, and in Brussels, Belgium, where she graduated from the Universite Libre de Bruxelles with a Master's degree in Economics. In 1958, she emigrated to the United States after marrying R. Paige Donhauser, her late beloved husband. Believing passionately in education as a source of empowerment, she first volunteered in New York public schools, later with the former Literacy Volunteers of America, and finally, with the English Speaking Union. For several years she taught French at the Nightingale-Bamford School. Those who knew her, will miss her kindness, fierce intelligence, profound love and understanding of literature, music, and art, and most of all, her warm and ready smile. She is survived by her brother Georges Lambiotte of Brussels, many nieces and nephews, and her children Caroline R. and Peter L. Donhauser, son-in-law Victor Barall, daughter-in-law Whitney W. Donhauser, and granddaughters, Amelia W. and Cecile L. Donhauser, all of New York.

DIFFRIENT--Niels. The Board of Governors and Staff of Cranbrook Academy of Art and Art Museum mourn the passing of our distinguished alumnus, friend and supporter, Niels Diffrient, who served as an Academy Governor, Life Governor, and a member of the National Advisory Council. A 1954 Academy graduate, Diffrient's career and pioneering work on ergonomics spanned 60 years. He will be missed.

CANNEL--Edward, a.k.a Ward, 84, of Gramercy Park, NYC and Paterson, NJ died July 17th. Graduated PS 20, Eastside High School, Wesleyan College (Connecticut) and the Columbia School of Journalism. His reporting career took him through North and Latin America, Sub-Saharan Africa, Middle East and Southern Europe. Received Overseas Press Club first prize for coverage of Africa. He was a syndicated columnist for New York World Telegram and Sun. On camera for CBS, NBC, PBS and BBC, he did three minute essays. He won a Rockefeller Research Fellowship and authored four books, a play; also a ground-breaking adult literacy program and one for the piano- "How to Play the Piano Despite Years of Lessons." Predeceased by wife Elaine 2004, he is survived by Doris Shulman Brenman, members of his family and friends around the world. Graveside service at Mt. Nebo Cemetery Totowa, NJ on Sunday, July 21st at 2pm. Services by Louis Suburban Chapel, Fair Lawn, NJ.
