WALLACH--Florence. Retired Executive Director of the Jewish Foundation for the Education of Women, and loving mother of Eileen Ross and wife of her late husband, Albert Wallach. She passed away on July 18, 2013 after a brief illness. She is survived by her daughter Eileen, son-in-law Alan, granddaughters Hayley and Robyn, and great-granddaughter Lily. She was beloved by all, especially her nieces and nephews. Services will be held 9am Sunday, July 21 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel in NYC.

SCHWARTZ--Lila, passed away peacefully Friday morning, July 19. She is survived by her husband Jay and daughters Lynn, Eileen, son Scott and son-in-law Steven. Lila was a licensed interior decorator and was married for 58 years. Those who knew Lila will miss her genuine kindness to everyone and special love for her three children, six grandchildren and son-in-law Steven. Funeral services will be Sunday, 1pm at Gutterman's, Woodbury, LI.
NUSSBAUM--Arnold, passed away on July 18, 2013. A wonderful kind human being. Will surely be missed. Florence and Philip Felig

KROOP--Irving, M.D. The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center is deeply saddened by the death of Dr. Irving Kroop. Dr. Kroop was a well renowned cardiologist for over 70 years. He was an excellent physician and teacher. He was a retired police surgeon. Dr. Kroop was a member of the Kings County Medical Society serving for many years as the chief censor. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Sincere condolences are extended to his entire family. E Fitzpatrick, MD, Pres G Neiderman, MD, Pres-Elect E Chapnick, MD, Secy H Adler, MD, Treas H Wasserman, MD, Past-Pres

KROOP--Irving G.,M.D. Dr. Kroop died peacefully yesterday at the age of 97. Dr. Kroop was born on November 19, 1915. He graduated City College of New York in 1935 and New York University Medical School in 1939. He was Chief of Cardiology at the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital and the Jewish Chronic Disease Hospital and a Clinical Professor of Medicine at Downstate Medical Center. Subsequently he was on the staff of Maimonides Medical Center. He was cardiologist for the New York City Police Department for 29 years and after that for New York City Employees Retirement Service. Beloved by his many patients for over 60 years. He is survived by his wife, Eugenie, his three children, Elizabeth, Steven and Susan, his four grandchildren, Benjamin and Robyn Shaffer and Jonathan and Benjamin Kroop, his son-in-law, David Shaffer, and daughter-in-law, Csilla Fuleki Kroop. The funeral will be held on July 21, 1pm at Sherman's Funeral Home, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, New York.

KOERNER--Carol Susan, age 77, passed away on July 18, 2013 at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, California. The daughter of Juliet and Edward Mintz, she was born in Stamford, Connecticut, and graduated from AB Davis High School in Mt. Vernon, New York. Carol subsequently received her Bachelor of Arts in English from the University of Connecticut in 1957. After graduation, she married Spencer Koerner, MD and they remained happily married for over 55 years. She was preceded in death by her loving sister, Barbara (Jerome) Alper. In addition to her husband, Carol is survived by her children David (Samantha) Koerner, Beth (David) Silverman and Robert (Megan) Koerner; her brother Paul Brynan; and her grandchildren Adam, Julie, Page, Zachary, Caleb, Drew, John and Shea. Carol was an accomplished pianist and enjoyed reading, opera and classical music. She and her husband traveled extensively, visiting many exotic sites. Her love of Italy led to many trips for sightseeing and visiting friends, spanning the entire country. She will be missed dearly by all who knew her. Plans are being made for a private service for the family.

KARDARAS--William P. Prominent Wall Street Attorney Dies at Age 83. Mr. Kardaras grew up in New Haven, CT and graduated from the University of Connecticut and New York Law School. While completing his education, Mr. Kardaras worked full time as an insurance investigator on the New York waterfront. He joined the maritime law firm of Bigham Englar Jones & Houston and quickly rose to senior partner and member of the executive committee of the firm. Mr. Kardaras left to form his own law firm with offices on Wall Street and in Los Angeles, San Francisco and Washington D.C. He litigated multidistrict, multinational, and multimillion dollar matters. Mr. Kardaras traveled the world in defense of his clients and loved to visit his beloved relatives in Greece. Before studying law, Mr. Kardaras joined the Air Force and was stationed in Los Alamos, New Mexico and London, England where he armed tactical nuclear weapons. He was a Renaissance Man with an amazing intellect, strong ethics and a love of teaching. His interests included crossword puzzles, Greek dancing, sailing, skiing, violin playing, billiards and was an avid fan of the New York Yankees and Giants. Mr. Kardaras was a loving and caring husband for fifty-seven years to his wife, Jean; a loving father to his two sons, Peter and Constantine; and a proud grandfather of his seven grandchildren, Kristen, Julian, Kyra, Christopher, Rebekah, Susanne and Luke. A wake will be held on July 23rd from 6:00pm to 8:00pm at Celentano Funeral Home in New Haven, Connecticut. A funeral service will be held at Saint Barbara Greek Orthodox Church in Orange, Connecticut at 11:00 am on July 24th. A celebration of his life will be held on August 3rd in Rye, New York. Flowers can be sent to Celentano's Funeral Home 424 Elm Street, New Haven, CT 06511.

HERMAN--Edward, Jr. The New York Philharmonic mourns the passing, on July 16, of Edward Herman, Jr., Principal Trombone, 195685, especially beloved by his colleagues and successors in the Orchestra's trombone section. We extend deepest condolences to his daughter, Linda Gebhardt; son-in-law, Clifford; and granddaughters, Jennifer, Gretchen, and Rachel.

GRUDZINSKI--Theodore George, of Churchville, VA passed away July 13, 2013. Born February 22, 1934, Brooklyn, NY. Graduate of Queens College and University of California, Berkeley. Survived by five children, six grandchildren. Musician, teacher, author, poet, wine connoisseur, wordsmitth and wit. Loving father and grandfather. Beloved friend. Renaissance man. 'and it's you are whatever a moon has always meant/and whatever a sun will always sing is you'. Yr. friend, Lucy Tauber

GOODMAN--Reynold Hirsch, 95, formerly of Scarsdale, NY, died July 16 at The Hebrew Home at Riverdale, where he received wonderful care thanks to Dan Reingold and his team. Born and raised on Manhattan's Upper West Side, "Ren" attended NYU and was a US Army Lieutenant during World War II. He saw battle in Okinawa and was training for the invasion of Japan when the war ended. Ren was president of Goodren Products, a pioneer in printing on cellophane, in Englewood, NJ, before retiring to Florida. He was predeceased by his first wife Betty, second wife Elinor, and son Alan. He is survived by his sister, Elaine Mainthow, and five children: John (Donna) of Tuckahoe, NY, Tom (Marie) of New York City, Ken (Carla) of Vallejo, CA, Mary (Patricio) Goodman-Valencia of Tamarac, FL and Barbara (Bob) Prince of Orange, CT. He is also survived by nine grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Donations may be made to The Hebrew Home at Riverdale, Development Office, 5901 Palisades Avenue, Riverdale, New York 10471. hebrewhome.org/donategift.

GEIGER--Howard Wilton, Jr.,of New York City, died on Saturday, July 13, 2013 at the Westfield Rehabilitation Center, in Westfield, New Jersey. He was born on April 28, 1937 in Nyack, New York. His parents were Howard Wilton Geiger, Sr. and Mabel Houldin Geiger. He graduated from Spring Valley High School in 1955 and Dartmouth College in 1959. He earned his MBA at Columbia University in 1966. He moved to Munich, Germany for three years, with his wife, Melissa and children, and served as an officer in Military Intelligence. He returned to the United States, resided in Mahwah, New Jersey, and worked at Geiger Lumber and Supply Co. until 1964. Howard began his career in finance at Morgan Guaranty and Trust as a Securities Analyst. His position led him to IDS in Minneapolis, Merrill Lynch in New York City where he followed the computer industry and The Hillman Company in San Francisco as a Venture Capitalist. He completed his career in 2013 at VCFA in New York City as a Consultant. For more than 50 years, Howard's greatest passions were spending time with his children at his Lake George camp and sunsets wherever he was. He was active in the community where he raised his children, served as president of the Board of Education, and participated in the local theater group, "Small Town & Fancy Players." During the past 25 years, he has loved his time with The University Glee Club. He was a devoted member of The Riverside Church and served as treasurer, member of The Council, member of the Task Force concerning the Israeli - Palestinian Conflict, and Chair of the Audit Committee. He served on the United Church of Christ Pension Board for several years. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Melissa, and his four children: Melissa Geiger of New York City, Skip Geiger of New York City, Christopher Geiger of Larkspur, California, and Kirsten Rider of Winnetka, Illinois. He is also survived by his nine grandchildren, brothers Charles and Richard, and beloved dog, Libby. There will be a service at The Riverside Church in the early fall, at which time his life will be celebrated.

GALE--Leo, age 97. Beloved husband and father predeceased by wife Vivian and daughter Judy, survived by daughters Amy, Amelia Ellis and Nancy (Dave Duggins), four grandchildren and one great granddaughter. Services held in Pittsburgh, PA July 16.

He touched so many lives and will be missed. So let's pour three fingers of scotch and light a fine cigar to celebrate a life well lived! We love you and will miss you. Andrew, Lois, Alex, Olivia, Stephen and Victoria.
YARVIN--Norma, 92, formerly of Great Neck, NY, died peacefully July 1. Devoted to family, cherished friend. Life-long learner and supporter of progressive causes.

WROBLEWSKI--Dr. Felix. Died, June 10, 2013, at age 91 in New York City. He is survived by his children, Miriam (Luis Pinon), David, Jonathan (Joyce Klein) and Daniel (Odia), his grandchildren, Aaron (Stephanie Park), Sarah, Hannah, Kayla, Ben, Reuven, Caleb, Deborah, Elisheva, Rebecca, Stella, and Yoni, and his former wife, Dr. Rita Lifschutz Wroblewski. Born August 8, 1921, he graduated from Stuyvesant High School, NYU, and NYU School of Medicine. An internist, Dr. Wroblewski was renowned for his groundbreaking discoveries of how changes in blood enzymes could uncover disease. He received numerous honors as a researcher, educator and brilliant clinician. He was a loving, caring and generous father.

WING--Barbara Thornton. January 31, 1932-July 10, 2013. Wife of Edgar Wing, Widow of D. Fiore Januzzi. Beloved mother of Nancy Januzzi and grandmother of Nathaniel and Isobel Weir. Love you a bushel and a peck.

WALLACH--Florence. The Board of Directors of the Jewish Foundation for Education of Women notes with sorrow the passing of Florence Wallach. Florence served the foundation with dedication and was a welcoming presence over decades. We send condolences to her daughter Eileen and grandchildren. Jill W. Smith, President Sharon L. Weinberg, Chair Elizabeth L. Kraiem, Executive Director

TURCHIN--Daniel, born August 12, 1921, died Sunday, July 14, 2013, at 4:15pm. He was just four weeks shy of his 92nd birthday. He was born in Brooklyn at 1560 East 22nd Street. He attended James Madison High School, class of '37, graduating at 16 years old; Brooklyn College, class of '41, which he graduated at age 20; and NYU, where he graduated with an MBA in 1943 at age 22. He completed Brooklyn Law School in 1949 and was admitted to the New York State Bar that same year, thereafter qualifying as a certified public accountant in New York State. Among his many clients, he was always proud to have served the Lawyers Guild in its youth. He counted numerous former clients as dear, life-long friends, who relied on him both for his knowledge and his calm sensible advise. Daniel Turchin took complete joy in every aspect of life. He was a violinist, an athlete, and bridge player. He played the violin in high school for the All New York City High School Orchestra, in the orchestra in India during his service there in World War II, in the Akron Ohio Symphony Orchestra, and after he retired in the Sunshine Orchestra in Fort Lauderdale, FL. He was on the swimming and diving teams at Brooklyn College, ice skated, skied, bicycled, played tennis, rode horseback, and sailed. He passed on his love of music, math, sports, and enjoyment of life to his children and grandchildren. During World War II, he was stationed in India, where he was a Powerman 166 and a Rifle Marksman and Carbine Sharpshooter. His sergeant told him, "You talk like a boy, but you shoot like a man." Dan said that he was able to shoot so straight from years of holding the violin steady. He received a Sharpshooter Medal, the American Theater Ribbon, the Asiatic Pacific Theater Ribbon, and the World War II Victory Medal. Daniel Turchin is survived by his loving family who miss him already: his wife Lillian, son Lee Turchin, daughters Michele Mirman and Lauren Orent, grandchildren David Turchin, Matthew and Phoebe Mirman, Elizabeth and David Orent, daughter in law Karin Turchin and sons-in-law Richard Orent and Paul Mirman, brother-in-law Joseph Scherrer and nephews Douglas James and Daniel and Paul Scherrer.

STANLEY--Vada Shell. One of the kindest, gentlest, most loving people in the world is no longer with us. Vada Shell Stanley, 80, passed away peacefully at home in New Canaan, Connecticut on July 13 after a long illness. Many of those who knew her could think of no better word than "angel" to describe her. Wherever she went, Vada Stanley impressed people as a very special person. She might have won any beauty contest she entered, but her beauty was more than skin deep; inside there was a beautiful soul. She could be and was a charming dinner companion for people like Bill Clinton and Prince Charles, among others, but the same warm charm was there for absolutely everyone who crossed her path. A key thing that made her so very special was her way of making each of us feel we were special to her. A rare combination of compassion, acceptance and love radiated from her being. Born in 1933 in the rolling hills of Kentucky, she had a life that was charmed in many ways but with challenges as well. Hers was a loving family but not one in which people went to college. She did by earning all the money needed with jobs through her high school and college years. Not long after that she had to face the need to end a disastrous marriage with two tiny children to support, Bill and Glee, and no help from their father. At that challenging time in her life she got a job, a rare one for women then, as a marketing management trainee at the home office of Procter & Gamble. There she met and married (three years later) Ted Stanley who worked in the same office in a similar job. Their 52-year marriage was a happy one; her husband never got over his great good luck in having found her. They had one son, Jonathan, who appreciated her just as much. After their marriage in 1961, they moved to Westport, Connecticut and have lived in New Canaan, CT since 1996 with, at various times, second homes in Manhattan, Santa Fe and Vermont. Vada Stanley was quite simply one of the most wonderful people in all the world, and she will be long remembered by everyone fortunate enough to know her. May she rest in peace and find as much joy in another world as she gave to us. A memorial service to be held at a later date.

SEIGER--Joseph R.,beloved husband, father, and grandfather, passed away peacefully on July 9, 2013 at his home in Los Altos Hills, CA surrounded by family. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, Randee, son Jonah, daughter Alicia, two granddaughters and his sister Marjorie Zapruder. Joe was born in Washington, D.C. on April 12, 1942 and grew up in Queens and Mamaroneck, NY. After graduating from the University of Pittsburgh and the University of Michigan Law School, he and Randee moved to San Francisco. In 1973, he co-founded Vintage Properties, which left an indelible imprint on the Bay Area. Among his projects were Golden Gateway Commons in San Francisco, University Circle with the Four Seasons Hotel in East Palo Alto and the Vintage Club in Indian Wells, CA. Joe was known as a man who approached work and life with intelligence, generosity, kindness, and humor that garnered him many loyal and life-long friendships. He relished spending time with his family, especially at their summer home on Nantucket, MA. Joe was an active member of The Contemporary Jewish Museum, where he was a director and the driving force behind the creation of the museum's new home in San Francisco.

SCHWARTZ--Rita L. Beloved wife of Donald. Devoted mother of Howard, Steven and Catalina, Susan and Barry Fried and Fredric. Dear sister of William Hoffinger. Adored grandmother of Peter, Nina, Greggory, Nicholas, Jordan, Zared, Olivia, Hannah and Matthew. To know her was to love her. Services Monday 12 noon at "Gutterman's" 8000 Jericho Tpk. Woodbury, L.I.

SCHWARTZ--Lila, passed away peacefully Friday morning, July 19. She is survived by her husband Jay and daughters Lynn, Eileen, son Scott and son-in-law Steven. Lila was a licensed interior decorator and was married for 58 years. Those who knew Lila will miss her genuine kindness to everyone and special love for her three children, six grandchildren and son-in-law Steven. Funeral services will be Sunday, 1pm at Gutterman's, Woodbury, LI.

PROUDFOOT--Wilfred ('Wilf'), 91, died July 19, 2013 surrounded by his loving family. Heartfelt condolences to Peg, Mark and Ian Proudfoot, Lyn and Michael Harvey; to James and Victoria Harvey and Marcus, Oliver and Luke Proudfoot.

SCHATZ--James L. September 24, 1919-July 12, 2013. Jim was honest, tireless, unique, kind, generous and deeply loved by his family, friends and community. He grew up in the Bronx, graduated from CCNY's Baruch College in 1943 and spent 63 years in the same home in Woodmere. He was president of the District 14 School Board, the Woodmere Merchants Association, the Inwood Country Club and the Peninsula Counseling Center. He was Scoutmaster and Little League coach for his two sons. He received CCNY's Townsend Harris Medal in November 2012. Jim was president of American Sponge and Chamois Company in Long Island City until 1983. He then volunteered for the City College Fund, which soon elected him president until he retired in 2005 at the age of 86. He subsequently joined Hofstra University's Professional Enrichment in Retirement program, where he was chairman of the membership committee. Jim was a well-respected debater and was lauded by his colleagues for his ability to forcefully defend his position without using notes. He served in WWII in the Fifth Armored Division (Patton's Army) from March 1943 to February 1946, during which he received a battlefield promotion from Second Lieutenant to First Lieutenant. He was promoted to Captain December 1945 and earned a Bronze Star for meritorious service. He fought in the Battle of the Bulge, including the infamous Hurtgen Forest, where he prevented his troops from freezing by huddling them around a half-track tank that ran through the night. He will be greatly missed by his wife Ellie; children Willie, Elizabeth and Tom; their respective spouses Molly, Adrian and Leslee; and grandchildren Chris, Doug, Kira, Cody, Samantha and Dale, and Alex; as well as the many friends he made during his very full and exceptional 93 years. Donations may be made to the City College Fund in the name of the James L. Schatz Memorial Fund, 160 Convent Avenue, Shepard Hall, Room 166, NY, NY 10031

PHILLIPS--Stephen, passed away on July 12, 2013 due to complications from pneumonia. Originally from Middleburg, Virginia, he attended St. Paul's School and the University of Virginia. Fluent in French, he acquired a graduate "certificat" from the Sorbonne while living in Paris. Growing up on a horse farm, he learn to ride at age five, continuing his passion for sports throughout his life. An accomplished skier, a life member of the Cresta Run in St. Moritz, and the brakeman of a four-man Olympic bobsled team. He even learned to drive a Formula II at Brands Hatch. He was associated with Dillon Read Investment Bank, where his father along with his Harvard roommate Clarence Dillon were among the founding partners. An opera aficionado, he enjoyed his association with the Metropolitan Opera Club. One highlight in his life was an arranged dinner with the great tenor Jussi Bjorling, a few years before Bjorling died. He was a member of the Racquet and Tennis Club, Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, The Southampton Bathing Corporation, The Meadow Club and The Bath and Tennis in Palm Beach. He was also a longtime member of The Clove Valley Rod and Gun Club where he spent many fall weekends hunting pheasants and ducks. A quiet philanthropist, he helped those who couldn't help themselves. With his wife Barbara, he established The Toy Lending Library at the Lighthouse as well as underwriting children's field trips. He will be remembered for his loyalty, decency, dry sense of humor and most importantly for his devotion to his family. He will be greatly missed by his wife Barbara, his son Andrew and his beloved Beagle Jasper. In lieu of flowers and in memory of Stephen Phillips, donations of a new, primary colored toy may be sent to The Barbara and Stephen Phillips Toy Lending Library, care of CEO Mark Ackermann, The Lighthouse 111 E. 59th St. New York, NY 10022. A Celebration of his wonderful life will be held in New York City at a later date.
NUSSBAUM--Arnold, passed away on July 18, 2013. A wonderful kind human being. Will surely be missed. Florence and Philip Felig

McKAY--Barbara Ann, 81, of New York City, died July 15th in Norwalk, CT. Born in 1932 in Worcester, NY to Elwood Jones and Marjorie Burton Jones, granddaughter of Elizabeth Powell Burton. Graduated magna cum laude, Syracuse University, former editor at Forbes, then case worker at Head Start Program until retirement in 1994. Survived by children Keith (Shona), Liz (Steve), Brian (Elizabeth), grandchildren Talia, Luke, and Katie. Donations may be made to the New York Public Library.
McCABE--Neal G. In loving memory of my dear Uncle Neal. May G-d bless his soul and protect his family always and ever. Spyro A. Jacobson

McFADDEN--Edward J. The Board of Directors and the entire Isabella Geriatric Center community mourn the loss of our friend and colleague Edward J. McFadden, Isabella's former President/ CEO from 1991 to 1998. Ed served Isabella with dedication and distinction in many important capacities for forty years. We will always remember Ed's unique spirit and unflinching commitment to Isabella's mission. He will be missed. Our thoughts are with his wife and Isabella board member, Josephine, and the entire family. Mark Lipton, PhD, Chair Mark J. Kator, President/CEO
McCABE--Neal G. We mourn the passing of Neal G. McCabe, a wonderful family friend and a brother to our father, Barry J. Jacobson. He will sorely be missed. Brette, Ari, Adam and Stefano

McCABE--Neal Graham, 60, passed away peacefully and surrounded by his family and friends at New York Presbyterian Hospital in New York, New York on July 17, 2013. Neal was born on October 26, 1952. He grew up in Needham, Massachusetts. Neal graduated from Worcester Academy in 1971 and earned a Bachelor of Arts Degree in Political Science from Brown University in Providence, Rhode Island in 1975. Neal began his career in finance at Salomon Brothers, Inc. in New York, rose rapidly in the bond department and was promoted to an expanded role in Dallas, Texas. In 1978, Neal became a Vice President of Salomon Brothers and was acknowledged as the youngest Vice President in the firm's history. In 1981, Neal became the Chairman of Shanley Oil Corporation, a publicly-held company based in Dallas, that engaged in the exploration and production of oil and natural gas in a fifteen state region. In 1988, Neal became an Executive Officer for Llama Company and Llama Asset Management Company, the investment and merchant banking and investment advisory companies owned by Alice Walton and Family members in Arkansas. Neal later served as the Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Allied Corporation in Tampa, Florida, before joining Lehman Brothers, Inc. in New York, New York in 1993 as a Senior Vice President. By 1994, Neal was made a Managing Director of Lehman Brothers and served as the Global Co-Head of Lehman's Dealer Business for more than a decade. Neal is survived by his loving mother, Alice Graham McCabe of Boca Raton, Florida; sister Gail Hackett, her husband Joseph Hackett, and their children Collin and Paige of Marshfield, Massachusetts; sister Kyle McCabe, her husband Garry O'Donnell, and their son Graham of Boca Raton, Florida; and sister Kim McCabe and her husband Charles Watts of Branford, Connecticut. Neal was predeceased in death by his father Robert V. McCabe. Neal leaves behind countless friends, including his dearest friends Stephen M. Wolf of New York, New York and Barry J. Jacobson of New York, New York. Services celebrating Neal's life will be held on Thursday, August 1, 2013, at 10:00am eastern daylight time, in the Newton Cemetery Chapel located at 791 Walnut Street, Newton Center, Massachusetts, with a reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Neal G. McCabe Memorial Scholarship Fund at Worcester Academy (please contact Frank Callahan at frank.callahan@worcesteracademy.org or call 508-754-5320 for more information).
McCABE--Neal G.,a wonderful friend and a brother for over 35 years. May G-d rest his soul and give him eternal peace. The Barry J. Jacobson Family

LITWAK--Robert S.,M.D. Dr. Litwak, aged 88, passed away on July 16 of severe pneumonia after a brief hospitalization in Concord, Massachusetts. He was professor emeritus of cardiothoracic surgery at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York, where he established the heart surgery program, operated and taught for over four decades. In addition to his pioneering work in cardiac surgery, Litwak was an accomplished jazz drummer, who once played in the Benny Goodman band. A beloved husband and father, he was married to the late Doris Sutherland Litwak, and is survived by his children, Robert of Washington, D.C., and Barbara Lizotte and granddaughter Chloe of Concord. His burial will be private. A memorial service to celebrate his life will be held at a date to be determined. Donations to his memory may be made to the American Heart Association.

LIPSTADT--Roth Miriam nee Peiman, 1915-2013, passed peacefully Saturday, July 20th. Survived by her children Helene Lipstadt Mendelsohn (Harvey), Deborah and Nat (Sheron Davis Potashner). Her grandchildren Adam and Jordan (Joanna) Lipstadt, Sophia Mendelsohn (Jon S. Landesman), great-grandchildren Isabel and Alex Lipstadt. Critic, speaker, writer, her fiercest feat, her leading role, creator. A near century of memories her legacy, memories that linger not, for they are Incised, chiseled in the granite of the books, papers, and poetry and the very being of her descendants. Her faith in the Almighty unflagging, for He did not forsake her in the time of her old age, when her strength failed. Funeral Services will be on Sunday, 11:30am, at Riverside Memorial Chapel. Shiva will be observed at her residence.

LILES--Virginia Pitts Rembert, Artist, scholar, and college professor died on July 5, 2013, at her home in Birmingham, Alabama. She is pre-deceased by her parents, United Methodist Reverend Umsted S. Pitts and Hazel Hudson Pitts, an elementary school teacher, as well as her first husband, John Lamar Rembert III. She is survived by her husband, Raeford Bailey Liles, and her sister, Carol Pitts Hovanec. Virginia earned a BA degree in Art and English from the Alabama College for Women (now University of Montevallo), an MA degree in Fine Arts Education from Teacher' College, Columbia University, an MA in Art History from the University of Wisconsin, and a PhD in Art History from Columbia University. Her teaching and administrative appointments were at Beloit College, Massachusetts College of Art, Birmingham Southern College, the University of Alabama at Birmingham, and the University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa. She was art department chair at the latter three institutions She was also Donaghly Distinguished Professor of Art at the University of Arkansas, Little Rock, and retired as Professor Emeritus from the University of Alabama. She has published two books, one on Piet Mondrian and one on Hieronynous Bosch, and has a contract on a third on artist Hans Holty. She also published numerous articles and reviews in refereed publications, such as Art news. She has also exhibited her work on many occasions. A family graveside service was held in Birmingham, on July 9, and a memorial service will be held on August 3 at 2:00pm at Rideout's Valley Chapel in Homewood, Alabama. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be sent to the Arts and Sciences scholarship funds at any of the colleges where she taught or studied.

LIFSON--Benjamin M.,Age 72, died July 3. Beloved father of Jacob (Paulina), Hannah (Jesse), brother to Matti (George), uncle to Joshua Marrow (Alexandra), grandfather to Zoja. Ben was a teacher, a writer, and a photographer, and in those pursuits and in life worked to distinguish what was good from what was not, and why. He lives on in our hearts and minds and will forever inform the way we look at and inhabit the world. A memorial service will be held on the evening of September 7 at the Howard Greenberg Gallery in NYC.

KROOP--Irving MD. The Board of Governors of the New York Cardiac Center mourns the loss of its long-time friend and colleague. Irving served our Board with energy and devotion for more than twenty-five years. He was a member of our Grants Evaluation Committee and Health Conference moderator. He was a superb physician, teacher and humanitarian. Our condolences to his family.

KROOP--Irving, M.D. The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center is deeply saddened by the death of Dr. Irving Kroop. Dr. Kroop was a well renowned cardiologist for over 70 years. He was an excellent physician and teacher. He was a retired police surgeon. Dr. Kroop was a member of the Kings County Medical Society serving for many years as the chief censor. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Sincere condolences are extended to his entire family. E Fitzpatrick, MD, Pres G Neiderman, MD, Pres-Elect E Chapnick, MD, Secy H Adler, MD, Treas H Wasserman, MD, Past-Pres

KROOP--Irving G.,M.D. Dr. Kroop died peacefully yesterday at the age of 97. Dr. Kroop was born on November 19, 1915. He graduated City College of New York in 1935 and New York University Medical School in 1939. He was Chief of Cardiology at the Brooklyn Jewish Hospital and the Jewish Chronic Disease Hospital and a Clinical Professor of Medicine at Downstate Medical Center. Subsequently he was on the staff of Maimonides Medical Center. He was cardiologist for the New York City Police Department for 29 years and after that for New York City Employees Retirement Service. Beloved by his many patients for over 60 years. He is survived by his wife, Eugenie, his three children, Elizabeth, Steven and Susan, his four grandchildren, Benjamin and Robyn Shaffer and Jonathan and Benjamin Kroop, his son-in-law, David Shaffer, and daughter-in-law, Csilla Fuleki Kroop. The funeral will be held on July 21, 1pm at Sherman's Funeral Home, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, New York.

KLASS--Ric, of Rye, NY, passed away on July 9. Adored husband of Anne (Stadler) and devoted father of Joe and Hayley. Contributions in his memory can be made to MIT, for the Undergraduate Scholarship Fund. Send to Memorial Gifts, MIT, 600 Memorial Drive, W98-500, Cambridge, MA 02139. Please include a note stating that that your gift is in memory of Richard Klass.
KOMAR--Joan M.,60, died June 14th. Loving and caring sister, sister-in-law, aunt, great-aunt and friend. She will be missed by all whose lives she touched.

KOERNER--Carol Susan, age 77, passed away on July 18, 2013 at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, California. The daughter of Juliet and Edward Mintz, she was born in Stamford, Connecticut, and graduated from AB Davis High School in Mt. Vernon, New York. Carol subsequently received her Bachelor of Arts in English from the University of Connecticut in 1957. After graduation, she married Spencer Koerner, MD and they remained happily married for over 55 years. She was preceded in death by her loving sister, Barbara (Jerome) Alper. In addition to her husband, Carol is survived by her children David (Samantha) Koerner, Beth (David) Silverman and Robert (Megan) Koerner; her brother Paul Brynan; and her grandchildren Adam, Julie, Page, Zachary, Caleb, Drew, John and Shea. Carol was an accomplished pianist and enjoyed reading, opera and classical music. She and her husband traveled extensively, visiting many exotic sites. Her love of Italy led to many trips for sightseeing and visiting friends, spanning the entire country. She will be missed dearly by all who knew her. Plans are being made for a private service for the family.

KARDARAS--William P. Prominent Wall Street Attorney Dies at Age 83. Mr. Kardaras grew up in New Haven, CT and graduated from the University of Connecticut and New York Law School. While completing his education, Mr. Kardaras worked full time as an insurance investigator on the New York waterfront. He joined the maritime law firm of Bigham Englar Jones & Houston and quickly rose to senior partner and member of the executive committee of the firm. Mr. Kardaras left to form his own law firm with offices on Wall Street and in Los Angeles, San Francisco and Washington D.C. He litigated multidistrict, multinational, and multimillion dollar matters. Mr. Kardaras traveled the world in defense of his clients and loved to visit his beloved relatives in Greece. Before studying law, Mr. Kardaras joined the Air Force and was stationed in Los Alamos, New Mexico and London, England where he armed tactical nuclear weapons. He was a Renaissance Man with an amazing intellect, strong ethics and a love of teaching. His interests included crossword puzzles, Greek dancing, sailing, skiing, violin playing, billiards and was an avid fan of the New York Yankees and Giants. Mr. Kardaras was a loving and caring husband for fifty-seven years to his wife, Jean; a loving father to his two sons, Peter and Constantine; and a proud grandfather of his seven grandchildren, Kristen, Julian, Kyra, Christopher, Rebekah, Susanne and Luke. A wake will be held on July 23rd from 6:00pm to 8:00pm at Celentano Funeral Home in New Haven, Connecticut. A funeral service will be held at Saint Barbara Greek Orthodox Church in Orange, Connecticut at 11:00 am on July 24th. A celebration of his life will be held on August 3rd in Rye, New York. Flowers can be sent to Celentano's Funeral Home 424 Elm Street, New Haven, CT 06511.

HESS--Lindy. The Columbia School of Journalism mourns the loss of Lindy Hess, the director of the Columbia Publishing Course, who died on July 13 after battling cancer. Lindy Hess was the light behind 25 years of remarkable leadership for the publishing course, which started at Radcliffe. Her work led thousands of young people into book and magazine publishing careers. Many top editors in New York media outlets count her as their personal mentor. "She was fanatically dedicated to her students, not just collectively but individually," said former dean Nicholas Lemann. "Her ability to steer the publishing course was remarkable, and her reward was the pleasure of seeing generations of her students rise to leadership positions. We will miss her terribly." The school will hold a memorial in her honor in September. At the request of Lindy's husband, Dr. William Appleton, the school is establishing the "Friends of Lindy Hess Fund" to benefit scholarships for the Columbia Publishing Course.

HAYWARD--Ruth Elizabeth Sutherlin Finney, passed away Tuesday, June 11, 2013 at home in Pasadena, California, after a seventeen-month battle with brain cancer. She was 73. Ruth was born in Indiana and raised in San Mateo, Calif. She was educated at Stanford and at Harvard universities, where she earned a PhD in cultural anthropology. Her teaching at the University of Hawaii, her career serving the United Nations in Rome, Mexico City, Katmandu, New York, and Eritrea, and her book Breaking the Earthenware Jar: Lessons from South Asia to End Violence Against Women and Girls published by UNICEF were all marked by her unsurpassed spirit of adventure, openness, and generosity. In what bore a faint resemblance to retirement in Southern California, Ruth dedicated herself to the cause of the Tibetan people. She was the prime mover for the first two shows of Tibetan furniture in American museums: Wooden Wonders at the Pacific Asian Museum in Pasadena and In the Service of the Buddha: Tibetan Furniture from the Hayward Family Collection at LACMA. Ruth also founded the Panchen Lama-Tashi Lhunpo Project (PLTL), a nonprofit dedicated to supporting Tibetan religion and culture by rebuilding a key monastery in India. This project continues under the stewardship of her husband, Dr. Robert Hayward. Ruth is grieved, celebrated, and survived by her husband Robert, brother John, sons Sean and Greg, step-daughters Wendy and Erica, first husband Ben, and many more people whose lives she has touched. The family requests that donations be made in Ruth's name to the PLTL, with the funds dedicated to finishing the prayer hall for the Tashi Lhunpo Monastery in exile.

HARNACK--Curtis. The School of American Ballet mourns the passing of our former president (1992-1997) Curtis Harnack. A respected leader and gentleman, he gracefully shaped the School's nascent residence program of the early 1990s to better support the organization's artistic mission. His warmth, wisdom, and calm were admired by all who knew him and will be greatly missed.

HALIS--Loraine, mother of Jeffrey Halis of New York and Dorene Scolnic of Hamden, Connecticut, passed away peacefully in her home in Hamden on Friday afternoon after a long illness. Born in Munich on January 2, 1926, Loraine and her sister Ruth (Schachter) escaped the horrors of Nazi Germany through the Kindertransport and lived in England with an adopted family until the end of the war, when they were re-united with their parents and older sister Martha (Leibler) in New York. She married Alex Halis, a survivor of concentration camps, in 1953, and they were happily married until Alex's untimely passing in 1992. Loraine was the proud mother of Dorene and Rabbi Benjamin Scolnic and Jeffrey and Nancy Halis, the caring and intensely interested grandmother of Rachel and David Dobin, Daniel and Lauren Scolnic, Joshua Scolnic, Jenny Halis, Sarah Scolnic and Laura Halis, and the adoring great-grandmother of Alexander and Abraham Dobin. Loraine was a sweet woman who lived for her family. She was loyal to the traditions of the Jewish people and a devoted advocate of Israel. She will be missed by her family and friends who will remember a kind and compassionate person who emerged from a terrible time and place in history to build a beautiful and wonderful life. The funeral will be Sunday, 11:30am at the Beth Israel Cemetery in Woodbridge, NJ. The family will sit shiva at the home of Jeffrey and Nancy on Sunday and at the Scolnic home in Hamden until Friday. In lieu of flowers, consider a contribution to the Alzheimer's Association.

HAAS--Felix "Phil" 1921-2013. Provost Emeritus of Purdue University, passed away on Tuesday, July 16, 2013, surrounded by his family at his daughter's home in New York. Phil Haas was born on April 20, 1921, in Vienna, Austria. He emigrated in 1938 and served as General Patton's Artillery Sergeant in the U.S. Army during World War II. He received his PhD in mathematics in 1952 from M.I.T. While at MIT, he met and married Violet Bushwick, who also received a PhD in Mathematics from MIT. He subsequently held a series of academic appointments including Fine Instructor of Mathematics at Princeton University, Phil served Purdue for more than 40 years and became the first Dean of the School of Science after its creation in 1962. In that role, he recruited many scientists at the cutting edge of their fields, and launched the country's first computer science department. He then served as University Provost (1974-86). He felt privileged to work at a Land Grant Institution whose mission it was to give all students the opportunity to pursue higher education regardless of their economic backgrounds. After retiring as Provost, Phil returned to Purdue as the Arthur G, Hansen Professor Emeritus of Mathematics and taught for 15 more years (1987-2002). He did so pro-bono in exchange for a commitment from Purdue that his teaching would relieve the load of non-tenured female faculty members with young children. In 2006, Purdue renamed one of its two Computer Science buildings in honor of Felix Haas. He was pre-deceased by his beloved first wife, Violet. He is survived by his second wife, Margaret of Westfield, NJ, by his three children and their spouses, Richard (Ann Mitchell) of Shrewsbury, MA, Elizabeth (Steven Edersheim) of Scarsdale, NY, and David (Dana Stevens) of Westfield, NJ, and seven grandchildren, Derek, Brian (Yen-Hua Yu), Andrea, Jacob, Alvin, Claire, and Violet. Donations may be made in his name to the Felix Haas Memorial Fund, Purdue University.

GRUDZINSKI--Theodore George, of Churchville, VA passed away July 13, 2013. Born February 22, 1934, Brooklyn, NY. Graduate of Queens College and University of California, Berkeley. Survived by five children, six grandchildren. Musician, teacher, author, poet, wine connoisseur, wordsmitth and wit. Loving father and grandfather. Beloved friend. Renaissance man. 'and it's you are whatever a moon has always meant/and whatever a sun will always sing is you'. Yr. friend, Lucy Tauber

GOODMAN--Reynold H.,95, formerly of Scarsdale, NY, died July 16 at The Hebrew Home at Riverdale, where he received wonderful care thanks to Dan Reingold and team. Born and raised in New York City, "Ren" attended NYU and was a US Army Lieutenant during World War II. He saw battle in Okinawa and was training for the invasion of Japan when the war ended. Ren was president of Goodren Products, a pioneer in printing on cellophane, in Englewood, NJ, before retiring to Florida. He was predeceased by his first wife Betty and their son Alan, and his second wife Elinor. He is survived by his sister Elaine Mainthow; five children: John (Donna) of Tuckahoe, NY, Tom (Marie) of New York City, Ken (Carla) of Vallejo, CA, Mary (Patricio) Goodman-Valencia of Tamarac, FL and Barbara (Bob) Prince of Orange, CT.; nine grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Donations may be made to: The Hebrew Home at Riverdale, Development Office, 5901 Palisades Avenue, Riverdale, NY 10471. www.hebrewhome.org/donategift or The Wounded Warrior Project, Box 758517, Topeka, KS 66675.
GOLD--Marty. Dean of Broadway Stage Managers. Dear and loyal friend. Shelley's Best Friend forever. Bob's biker buddy. We will miss him, his counsel and good cheer. Bob and Jayne

GOLD--Martin, passed peacefully at home in Boynton Beach, Florida on July 14, at the age of 76. A native New Yorker, a graduate of NYU, Martin was an accomplished Broadway Production Stage Manager whose 40 year career encompassed the major musicals and plays of his time, i.e., A Chorus Line, Fences, Chicago, Sophisticated Ladies and Fiddler On The Roof to name but a few. Dedicated to his craft, he was a mentor to those who had the privilege of working with him. His love of story and the written word led him to the Palm Beach Literacy Coalition where his teaching skills enabled students to better their lives. Devoted to his family, Marty leaves behind his loving wife Shelly, adored daughters Gayle and Lynn, their spouses Jeff and Chip, grandchildren Melissa, Matthew, Wyatt and great granddaughter Kyla. He will be sorely missed.
GLICKMAN--Marvin. Beloved friend, passed away peacefully July 12th, 2013. Our deepest condolences to his lovely wife, Barbara, and families. He will be deeply missed. Rhoda and Arthur Rodbell

GLEICH--Joseph Justin, died peacefully at home at the age of 91. He was predeceased by his beloved wife of 64 years, Shirley Ringelheim Gleich, and two bothers, Marvin and Sidney Gleich. He is survived by his three children, Linda Proctor and her husband Colin Jessop, Gerald Gleich and his wife Francesca Bang, Helene Rubin and her husband Howard Rubin, ten grandchildren, one great-grandchild, and his 100 year old sister Sonia Fenster. Joe served in the Marines during WW II. After the War he married and raised his family in Long Beach, NY. He earned a degree in engineering at Stevens Institute of Technology, and was a founding partner of Underhill Construction, a concrete contracting company responsible for building many large buildings in New York City including the World Trade Center. Upon retirement he and Shirley moved to Tamarac, FL where they were active philanthropists and had a large circle of friends. He loved golf and bridge and played regularly. Joe will be remembered for his sense of humor, even temperament, solid ethics and morals, loyalty, and generosity. He stood as an example for his children and grandchildren. He enriched our lives and encouraged us to pursue our dreams. He will always be in our hearts. May he rest in peace, forever reunited with Shirley, the love of his life.

GALE--Leo, age 97. Beloved husband and father predeceased by wife Vivian and daughter Judy, survived by daughters Amy, Amelia Ellis and Nancy (Dave Duggins), four grandchildren and one great granddaughter. Services held in Pittsburgh, PA July 16.

GEIGER--Howard Wilton, Jr.,of New York City, died on Saturday, July 13, 2013 at the Westfield Rehabilitation Center, in Westfield, New Jersey. He was born on April 28, 1937 in Nyack, New York. His parents were Howard Wilton Geiger, Sr. and Mabel Houldin Geiger. He graduated from Spring Valley High School in 1955 and Dartmouth College in 1959. He earned his MBA at Columbia University in 1966. He moved to Munich, Germany for three years, with his wife, Melissa and children, and served as an officer in Military Intelligence. He returned to the United States, resided in Mahwah, New Jersey, and worked at Geiger Lumber and Supply Co. until 1964. Howard began his career in finance at Morgan Guaranty and Trust as a Securities Analyst. His position led him to IDS in Minneapolis, Merrill Lynch in New York City where he followed the computer industry and The Hillman Company in San Francisco as a Venture Capitalist. He completed his career in 2013 at VCFA in New York City as a Consultant. For more than 50 years, Howard's greatest passions were spending time with his children at his Lake George camp and sunsets wherever he was. He was active in the community where he raised his children, served as president of the Board of Education, and participated in the local theater group, "Small Town & Fancy Players." During the past 25 years, he has loved his time with The University Glee Club. He was a devoted member of The Riverside Church and served as treasurer, member of The Council, member of the Task Force concerning the Israeli - Palestinian Conflict, and Chair of the Audit Committee. He served on the United Church of Christ Pension Board for several years. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Melissa, and his four children: Melissa Geiger of New York City, Skip Geiger of New York City, Christopher Geiger of Larkspur, California, and Kirsten Rider of Winnetka, Illinois. He is also survived by his nine grandchildren, brothers Charles and Richard, and beloved dog, Libby. There will be a service at The Riverside Church in the early fall, at which time his life will be celebrated.

FINNEGAN--Richard Herbert, art researcher and beloved friend, died suddenly on June 14, 2013 at age 76. A memorial mass will be held at Our Lady of Good Counsel Church, 230 East 90th Street, New York, NY on Wednesday, August 14, 2013 at 1pm.

EINHORN--Anne (Alexander). Primary Stages mourns the loss of our beloved company member, Anne Einhorn who passed away on July 11, 2013. Since 1985, Anne served at Primary Stages in many capacities as public relations director, press agent, board member and trusted advisor. An essential fixture since its inception, she brought with her a wealth of experience from previous work at Actors' Equity, Society for Stage Directors and Choreographers (SDC), AMAS Repertory, Joseph Jefferson Theatre, No Smoking Playhouse, and the Foundation for the Extension and Development of American Professional Theatre (FEDAPT) which she helped establish. Known for her kindness and commitment to artists, she was a source of inspiration to decades of writers, staff, interns and audience. The Anne and Marvin Einhorn School of the Performing Arts (ESPA) was named in honor of her and her husband Marvin. We extend our love and condolences to her family. We were indeed fortunate to have been so enriched by Anne's wisdom, wit and generosity of spirit.

DONHAUSER--Rosine Lambiotte, 88, died peacefully at her Manhattan home on July 14. Born in 1925, she grew up in the Nievre region of France, and in Brussels, Belgium, where she graduated from the Universite Libre de Bruxelles with a Master's degree in Economics. In 1958, she emigrated to the United States after marrying R. Paige Donhauser, her late beloved husband. Believing passionately in education as a source of empowerment, she first volunteered in New York public schools, later with the former Literacy Volunteers of America, and finally, with the English Speaking Union. For several years she taught French at the Nightingale-Bamford School. Those who knew her, will miss her kindness, fierce intelligence, profound love and understanding of literature, music, and art, and most of all, her warm and ready smile. She is survived by her brother Georges Lambiotte of Brussels, many nieces and nephews, and her children Caroline R. and Peter L. Donhauser, son-in-law Victor Barall, daughter-in-law Whitney W. Donhauser, and granddaughters, Amelia W. and Cecile L. Donhauser, all of New York.

DAVIS--Prof. Ellen Nancy, renowned archaeologist and art historian, died on July 15, 2013 of complications from COPD. She was born to Francis Davis and Celia Zoss of Baltimore, MD on July 20, 1937. Ellen is survived by nephew David Clark, nieces Julie Clark and Amy Dodds, all of Virginia, and two beloved cats. After receiving her Ph.D. in 1973 from the NYU Institute of Fine Arts, Davis joined the faculty of Queen's College, CUNY, where she taught art history. A specialist in Minoan and Mycenaean wall painting and metalwork, Ellen was also a founding member of the New York Aegean Bronze Age Colloquium. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The National Audubon Society. A memorial service for family, friends, and colleagues will be held in NYC this fall.

CUMMINS--David, of Knoxville, TN passed away on July 10, 2013 at age 92. He served as a meteorologist in World War II, and was a vital part of the preparations for D-Day. After a distinguished career as a chemical engineer in Amarillo, Houston and Spokane, he retired to his native Tennessee. Mr. Cummins is survived by his sister, Sara Cummins Flatau of Silver Spring, MD, his nieces Alison Flatau of Potomac, MD and Jane Flatau Ross of New York, two grandnephews and a grandniece. He was predeceased by his nephew David Cummins Flatau of Sherman, CT. A true lifelong learner, his commitment to science and reason serves as a continuing inspiration to his family and friends.

COPPOLA--Marcel Francis, age 83, died on July 17, 2013 after a long illness. He is survived by his wife, Serafina DiGiacomo Coppola; his daughters, Suzanne (Harry), Maura (Paul), and Catherine (Michael); seven grandchildren; five great-grandchildren; his brother, John B. Coppola, his wife, Camille, and their children. A memorial service will be held by the family at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Heart Association. Services entrusted to and condolences may be left for Marcel's family at: adams-perfect.com

CLARKE--William Thomas, on July 4, 2013, surrounded by his loving wife and children. Beloved husband for 57 years of Joan Clarke (nee Sheil). Loving father of Noreen Paul, Patricia Lukens, Barbara McCurdy and William Clarke, Jr. Father-in-law of John Paul, Roby Lukens, Jeffrey McCurdy and Betsy Clarke. Adored "Pops" to Matthew, Billy, Mike, Tommy, Jane, Bobby, Jack, Catherine, Emily and John. Born and raised in Bronx, NY, and a lifelong Yankees fan, Bill graduated from Xavier High School in New York in 1949. Served in the U.S. Army from 1950-1953. He graduated from Columbia University, courtesy of the G.I. Bill, in 1958. Retired after 35 years from the Sweet's Division of McGraw-Hill. Pops will be remembered for his kindness, generosity and love of family. Donations may be made to: Xavier High School, 30 West 16th Street, New York, NY 10011. Attn: Financial Aid Fund in memory of William T. Clarke '49.

CHAPPELL--Alice Merckens, pioneering businesswoman in the art world, died July 7, 2013. Founding President of Hoya Crystal, USA and Chap-pell Gallery in New York City. Wife of Dr. Richard L. Chap- pell. Mother of two daughters Carol and Dreux Chappell. More information at: www. ccgfuneralhome.com/obit/
BRIGHTMAN--Ezra. Died July 14. He lived with mental illness for most of his life, he never hurt a soul, he was witty, gentle and kind. We will always love you.

BENSON--Paul Oehler. January 21, 1940, died June 30, 2013. Husband of Eileen Erickson. Brother to John and Stephany (Creamer). Services July 27, Tucson AZ. Donations suggested to Adler Aphasia Center, 60 W Hunter Ave., Maywood, NJ 07607.

AHLGREN--John R.,of Bronxville, died on July 15, 2013. Son of Gustav Ahlgren and Lydia Konradson Ahlgren, and husband of the late Wynne G. Ahlgren, he was born in Manchester, New Hampshire, on October 9, 1920. After graduating from Dartmouth College in 1941, he entered Cornell Law School, but left after the attack on Pearl Harbor to join the United States Navy where he was assigned to Admiral Nimitz's Headquarters Staff there. He later studied Russian and was assigned to the United States Embassy in Moscow from 1946 to 1947. He settled in New York where he became a Vice President of the Irving Trust Company. Mr. Ahlgren was a member of the Reformed Church in Bronxville, the Bronxville Rotary Club, Siwanoy Country Club and the Hillsboro Club in Hillsboro, Florida. He is survived by eleven nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at The Reformed Church in Bronxville on Saturday, September 7, 2013 at 11am.

MALOFF--Rubin. In loving memory of Rubin Maloff July 22, 1998.

ZIMMERMAN--Samuel H. Died peacefully on July 20 in Baltimore, age 94. Predeceased by Louise, his wife of 62 years and three sisters. Survived by his three sons and their spouses Michael (Barbara), Edward (Andrea), Robert (Myrna), and by seven grandchildren. Child of the Depression, veteran of WWII, part of the "Greatest Generation." Memorial contributions may be made to the Brooklyn Heights Synagogue or Chizuk Amuno Congregation.

Zaro--Sam. A great husband, father, brother, grandfather, great-grandfather and cherished friend. He was a hero to all who knew him and was always there when someone needed a helping hand. He touched so many lives and will be missed. So let's pour three fingers of scotch and light a fine cigar to celebrate a life well lived! We love you and will miss you. Andrew, Lois, Alex, Olivia, Stephen and Victoria.

SHUMAN--George F.,91, former Postmaster, New York City, World War II Veteran. West Yarmouth, MA - George F. Shuman passed away on July 15, 2013. He was a native of Northumberland, PA. He was employed by the US Postal Service for forty years. He entered the Postal Service in Harrisburg, PA, as a Railway Mail Clerk. Mr. Shuman served as a Postal Inspector in New Hampshire, and Boston, MA, in the 1960's, and as District Manager in the 1970's. In 1973, he became Assistant Regional Postmaster General in the Northeast Region. From 1979 until his retirement in 1985, he was District Manager and Postmaster for New York City, the largest post office in the world. In 1984, Mr. Shuman was named Postmaster of the Year by the Postmaster General. During World War II, he served in the US Army as a Warrant Officier in the Southwest Pacific Theatre of Operations. During his 30 years on Cape Cod he was active in the Osterville Men's Club, where he served on the Scholarship committee for 18 years. Mr. Shuman is survived by his wife, the former Joan Natvig. He has five daughters, one son, and two stepdaughters. He leaves nine grandchildren, and four great-grandchildren.

SCHATTNER--Dr. Joseph David, devoted husband to Harriet, father to Elaine, Gail, Paul and Marshall, brother to Gerald and grandfather to Aaron, Ethan, Laura and Nina, on July 20. He was a physician who cared with words, generosity and knowledge. His concern for patients and passion for medicine survive him. Joseph's support for Israel never faltered. His strong spirit remains as guide to his beloved family, friends and others fortunate to have known him.

ROSEN--Robert A.,of Boynton Beach, Florida passed away on Friday July 19th. He was 90 years old. Known to all as Bobby, he was the beloved husband of predeceased Claire; father of Lynda Rosen Obst, Richard Rosen, Michael Rosen; grandfather of Oliver Obst, Jonathan Rosen, Sally Rosen, Molly Jane Rosen, Carrie Rosen and Nicky Rosen; and great grandfather of Sunny and Marlowe Obst. Bobby will always be remembered for the devotion, fierce and unconditional love he showered upon his family and they all gave back to him in return. His generosity of spirit, and terrific sense of humor brought laughter to all who knew him and enriched each of their lives. He saw people for who they were, for their character and soul, regardless of class or stature. He will be missed more than words can describe, but our memories of him will live forever. A gravesite funeral service will be held at 11am on Tuesday morning at the Independent Stamford Lodge cemetery located across from 300 Hoyt Street in Darien Connecticut. From Manhattan it's exit 36 off the Merritt Parkway and right on Hoyt Street. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Autism Speaks.
NUSSBAUM--Arnold, passed away on July 18, 2013. A wonderful kind human being. Will surely be missed. Florence and Philip Felig

LIPSTADT--Roth Miriam nee Peiman, 1915-2013, passed peacefully Saturday, July 20th. Survived by her children Helene Lipstadt Mendelsohn (Harvey), Deborah and Nat (Sheron Davis Potashner). Her grandchildren Adam and Jordan (Joanna) Lipstadt, Sophia Mendelsohn (Jon S. Landesman), great-grandchildren Isabel and Alex Lipstadt. Critic, speaker, writer, her fiercest feat, her leading role, creator. A near century of memories her legacy, memories that linger not, for they are Incised, chiseled in the granite of the books, papers, and poetry and the very being of her descendants. Her faith in the Almighty unflagging, for He did not forsake her in the time of her old age, when her strength failed. Funeral Services will be on Sunday, 11:30am, at Riverside Memorial Chapel. Shiva will be observed at her residence.

KROOP--Irving G.,MD, Maimonides Medical Center mourns the loss of our esteemed colleague and friend. Dr. Kroop touched countless lives during his long career as a cardiologist and will be greatly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Eugenie, and the entire Kroop family. Martin D. Payson, Chairman, Board of Trustees Pamela S. Brier, President and CEO

KOHN--Aaron, of Rockville, MD, passed away on Friday, July 19th, 2013. Beloved husband of Ruby Kohn, devoted father of Judith Kohn Brown and Rabbi Jonathan Kohn, beloved brother of Rebekah Mosenkis and the late Tuvya Kohn and Theresa Silber, cherished grandfather of Ariel, Eran, Sophia, Riva, Elisheva, and Zachary. Funeral services will be held on Monday, July 22nd, at Congregation Beth Emeth, 12523 Lawyers Road, Herndon, VA, followed by internment at King David Memorial Gardens, Falls Church, VA. Family will be observing shiva at the residence of Judy and Nathan Brown starting Monday afternoon through Sunday morning. Contributions may be made to the Kehilat Lev Shalem/Woodstock Jewish Congregation. Services handled by Hines Rianldi Funeral Home Inc., under Jewish Funeral Practices Committee of Greater Washington Contract.

KOERNER--Carol Susan, age 77, passed away on July 18, 2013 at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, California. The daughter of Juliet and Edward Mintz, she was born in Stamford, Connecticut, and graduated from AB Davis High School in Mt. Vernon, New York. Carol subsequently received her Bachelor of Arts in English from the University of Connecticut in 1957. After graduation, she married Spencer Koerner, MD and they remained happily married for over 55 years. She was preceded in death by her loving sister, Barbara (Jerome) Alper. In addition to her husband, Carol is survived by her children David (Samantha) Koerner, Beth (David) Silverman and Robert (Megan) Koerner; her brother Paul Brynan; and her grandchildren Adam, Julie, Page, Zachary, Caleb, Drew, John and Shea. Carol was an accomplished pianist and enjoyed reading, opera and classical music. She and her husband traveled extensively, visiting many exotic sites. Her love of Italy led to many trips for sightseeing and visiting friends, spanning the entire country. She will be missed dearly by all who knew her. Plans are being made for a private service for the family.

HARNACK--Curtis. The School of American Ballet mourns the passing of our former president (1992-1997) Curtis Harnack. A respected leader and gentleman, he gracefully shaped the School's nascent residence program of the early 1990s to better support the organization's artistic mission. His warmth, wisdom, and calm were admired by all who knew him and will be greatly missed.

HALIS--Loraine, mother of Jeffrey Halis of New York and Dorene Scolnic of Hamden, Connecticut, passed away peacefully in her home in Hamden on Friday afternoon after a long illness. Born in Munich on January 2, 1926, Loraine and her sister Ruth (Schachter) escaped the horrors of Nazi Germany through the Kindertransport and lived in England with an adopted family until the end of the war, when they were re-united with their parents and older sister Martha (Leibler) in New York. She married Alex Halis, a survivor of concentration camps, in 1953, and they were happily married until Alex's untimely passing in 1992. Loraine was the proud mother of Dorene and Rabbi Benjamin Scolnic and Jeffrey and Nancy Halis, the caring and intensely interested grandmother of Rachel and David Dobin, Daniel and Lauren Scolnic, Joshua Scolnic, Jenny Halis, Sarah Scolnic and Laura Halis, and the adoring great-grandmother of Alexander and Abraham Dobin. Loraine was a sweet woman who lived for her family. She was loyal to the traditions of the Jewish people and a devoted advocate of Israel. She will be missed by her family and friends who will remember a kind and compassionate person who emerged from a terrible time and place in history to build a beautiful and wonderful life. The funeral will be Sunday, 11:30am at the Beth Israel Cemetery in Woodbridge, NJ. The family will sit shiva at the home of Jeffrey and Nancy on Sunday and at the Scolnic home in Hamden until Friday. In lieu of flowers, consider a contribution to the Alzheimer's Association.

GURFEIN--Mendel, July 21, 2013. Devoted brother of Helen Ingerman and Elisha. A brilliant mind, Phi Beta Kappa, editor extraordinaire, speech writer for NYC mayor Robert Wagner. Kind, loyal and caring brother, friend who wished for peace and harmony. He shall be missed.

GROSSBERG--Carol. Carol Grossberg, nee Baron, 1923. Beloved wife of the late Jerome; mother of Jim and Shelley; grandmother of Jillian; sister of Sue Rauch (Marvin), Sam Baron (Virginia), and Dorothy Marsh (Lee). A woman of valour. Memorial service to be announced.
GOLD--Marty. Dean of Broadway Stage Managers. Dear and loyal friend. Shelley's Best Friend forever. Bob's biker buddy. We will miss him, his counsel and good cheer. Bob and Jayne

CUMMINS--David, of Knoxville, TN passed away on July 10, 2013 at age 92. He served as a meteorologist in World War II, and was a vital part of the preparations for D-Day. After a distinguished career as a chemical engineer in Amarillo, Houston and Spokane, he retired to his native Tennessee. Mr. Cummins is survived by his sister, Sara Cummins Flatau of Silver Spring, MD, his nieces Alison Flatau of Potomac, MD and Jane Flatau Ross of New York, two grandnephews and a grandniece. He was predeceased by his nephew David Cummins Flatau of Sherman, CT. A true lifelong learner, his commitment to science and reason serves as a continuing inspiration to his family and friends.

BRADY--Geraldine K.,on July 17, 2013. Beloved sister of the late Suzanne. Gerry is deeply missed by her cousins in England, Northern Ireland, and in the United States. Gerry was a talented artist who became an associate fashion designer with Vera Maxwell. Gerry was devoted to her family and especially to her sister Suzanne. Gerry is remembered by all her relatives, friends, and business associates as a kind and generous person. We are blessed to have known her. May she rest in peace. Funeral mass Tuesday 11am St. Saviour Church in Brooklyn. Donations may be made in Gerry's memory to St. Francis of Assisi Bread Line, 135 W. 31st St. New York, NY 10001.

BLACK--Page Morton, The Board of Directors, the staff, the supporters, and the many hundreds of scientists funded by the Parkinson's Disease Foundation (PDF) mourn the passing, and cherish the memory, of an exemplary, passionate and indefatigable leader. For three decades since the death of her husband (and our founder), William Black, Page served brilliantly as our Chairman- strengthening us with her inspired nominations to our Board, enriching us with her deft leadership of our annual Bal du Printemps, and energizing us with her single-minded devotion to the reputation, success and financial health of our organization. She and her vivid persona may be irreplaceable, but the memory of her indomitable spirit will carry us forward. We will not fail her. Howard DeWitt Morgan, Chair; Robin Anthony Elliott, President

ZIMMERMAN--Samuel H. Died peacefully on July 20 in Baltimore, age 94. Predeceased by Louise, his wife of 62 years and three sisters. Survived by his three sons and their spouses Michael (Barbara), Edward (Andrea), Robert (Myrna), and by seven grandchildren. Child of the Depression, veteran of WWII, part of the "Greatest Generation." Memorial contributions may be made to the Brooklyn Heights Synagogue or Chizuk Amuno Congregation.
ZARO--Sam, Godfather to the meat industry. My mentor. Forever grateful. Edward Holland

SCHATTNER--Dr. Joseph. Congregation Or Zarua mourns the death of our member, Dr. Joseph Schattner. May He who consoles the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem bring comfort to his family. Rabbi Scott N. Bolton, Rabbi Diane Okrent, President

ROBERTSON--Cheryl Ann, 60, passed away suddenly at her home in Cambridge, MA, on July 7th. A widely respected museum curator and lecturer with a vast knowledge of 19th and 20th Century Decorative Arts, her 30-year career included positions at Winterthur; Milwaukee Art Museum; Sotheby's; the National Heritage Museum and the Wadsworth Atheneum. A memorial service will be held at the Old North Church in Boston, July 27th at 6:00 pm. Please contact Marilee Meyer at mbm0044@aol.com.

QUILL--James Andrew "Hoody", passed away July 17 at his home in Tiburon, CA after living triumphantly through many battles with cancer. Due to his extraordinarily positive outlook, he was featured in the New Yorker, ABC's 20/20 and Marin Magazine, where he called himself the "luckiest man on earth." He is survived by his wife Laura and five children: Andrew, Caroline "Muffin", Peter "Pistol", Caitlin "Coco", and Patrick "Patch"; his five siblings Tina (Mike) Scarrone, Teresa (John) Pfifle, Katherine (Chris) Quill, Timothy Quill, and Leonard (Denise) Quill. He is predeceased by beloved parents Leonard and Martina Quill and sister-in-law, Lisa Quill. He was the adored son-in-law to Ann and Peter Danis. Born on June 1, 1965 in Delaware, Hoody grew up in Wilmington with his parents and five siblings. At 17, he was diagnosed with non-Hodgkins lymphoma, receiving treatment at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York. He later attended the William Esper Studio for acting, performing in off Broadway productions and as an extra in over 100 movies. He moved to San Francisco in 1997, staying active at St. Hilary Catholic Church in Tiburon and St. Ignatius College Prep. His annual Hoody Open golf tournament in Delaware will be played again this September. The family asks that contributions be made to the Quill Family Education Fund (to make a confidential donation, please contact Leonard at quillfamily5educationfund@ gmail.com) and the Tiburon chapter of the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society.

MANNION--Anne M.,age 77 of Stony Brook, New York. Associate Professor "Emerita" of History at Fordham University (Lincoln Center) for 53 years. Member of Alpha Sigma Nu (Jesuit Honor Society). Passed away peacefully on July 16, 2013. Preceded in death by husband, Lawrence. Survived by brothers James Convery (Amy) and Michael Convery (Lynn) and five nieces and nephews. Friends may call the St. James Funeral Home, 829 Middle Country Road, St. James (Route 25) on Thursday (July 25) 2-4 and 7-9pm and Friday (July 26) 9-10:30am. Mass of Christian Burial will be Friday at 11am at Sts. Philip & James R.C. Church, 1 Carow Place, St. James. Memorials preferred to Fordham College at Lincoln Center.

LEINFUSS--Adele, 88, passed away on July 19, 2013 in Sarasota, FL. She joins her husband of 63 years, Paul, who died on April 19 of this year. She was a retired New York City schoolteacher. Daughters Ellen and Emily, son-in-law Myles and grandchildren Ian and Ben remember her love of music, theater, finger puppets, chocolate, picnics and her family.

Kastor--Anne Sarah, of Brooklyn, died at 49 on July 5 of ovarian cancer. Compassionate physician and teacher, life-long advocate for justice. Survived by wife Jill Dearman and daughter Holly; parents Mae and John of Baltimore; siblings Elizabeth and Peter; countless relatives, friends and patients. Autumn NYC memorial service. Donations: Holly Dearman-Kastor College Fund, c/o Jill Dearman, Morgan Stanley, 31 West 52nd St., 23rd floor, New York, NY 10019.

GRUNDFAST--Dr. Samuel, of Boynton Beach, FL (formerly Lake Worth, FL) passed July 19, 2013 at the age of 92, with his wife of by his side. At a young age, Dr. Grundfast was an accomplished Eagle Scout. He proudly served as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy during WWII and was awarded the Purple Heart of Bravery. Post WWII, Dr. Grundfast graduated dental school then passionately treated his dental patients in his own practice on Long Island, New York for over 40 years. Dr. Grundfast was an active swimmer, avid golfer, and artistic stone sculptor, but most of all, Dr. Grundfast was a family man. He and his wife raised a daughter, Myra Fink, who was the true joy of his life. Dr. Grundfast loved to Skype with his grandsons and great grandchildren on Sundays. Dr. Grundfast battled Neuropathy throughout the years. Always the self-taught researcher, he managed his illness through nutrition, daily activity and supplements, and he chronicled his findings and shared his experiences with thousands of fellow sufferers through a monthly newsletter. Dr. Grundfast will be sadly missed by so many: the fellow Neuropathy sufferers whom he mentored, the residents of Gefion Court in Lake Worth, FL where he and his wife resided for over 30 years and where he served as President of the Building Association, and most dearly, by his beloved wife, devoted daughter, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Dr. Grundfast was the cherished husband of 68 years of Phyllis Grundfast of Boynton Beach, Florida. Beloved Father of Myra Fink and son-in-law Stephen Fink of Florida. Loving brother of Lila Bordens and the late Alan Grundfast. Adoring Grandfather of Lindsay, Andrew and Matthew Fink. Great Grandfather to Jacob, Remi, Matthew, Chloe, Benjamin, Malia, Mikayla, Max, Alex, and Brett. Brother-in-law of Ellin Bauman. Uncle to nephews Ronald and Kenneth Bordens, and Jim and Jon Bauman. A military funeral to honor Lieutenant Samuel Grundfast will be held on July 22, 2013 at 2:15pm. In lieu of flowers, donations in the memory of Dr. Grundfast may be made to the American Cancer Society.

GROSSBERG--Carol. Carol Grossberg, nee Baron, April 6, 1923 July 19, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Jerome; mother of Jim and Shelley (Howard Norton); grandmother of Jillian; sister of Sue Rauch (Marvin), Sam Baron (Virginia), and Dorothy Marsh (Lee). A woman of valour. She attended Brooklyn College at age 16, certifying as an RN at Kings County Hospital in 1944. During WWII she served as an officer of the U.S. Army Nurse Corps in the South Pacific, first on Tinian, and then Hiroshima. She served as a public nurse for Nassau County and finished her academic career at Columbia University and Teacher's College, becoming a school-nurse-teacher for BOCES. Her penetrating intelligence, passion, and public spiritedness will always be with us. Memorial service to be announced.

GALLAGHER--Charles A.,SJ, entered eternal life July 21, 2013. Survived by his sister Therese Sweeney and niece Meghan Sweeney. Visitation on Wednesday, July 24, 3-5pm and 7-9pm at St. Aedan's, the St. Peter's University Church: 800 Bergen Avenue, Jersey City, NJ 07306. Funeral Mass July 25, 10:30am.
FARINA--Dennis. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Dennis Farina. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family

DENSEN--Barbara. American Friends of The Hebrew University (AFHU) and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem are profoundly saddened by the passing of Barbara Densen, beloved wife of esteemed AFHU leader Robert Densen and loving mother of Arielle (Brian), Dan and Sam. Barbara was a humanitarian who maintained an abiding commitment to Israel, the Jewish people and higher education. A compassionate role model, her concern for others was manifest in a lifetime of good works. Over the years, the Densen family has provided generous support for the Lautenberg Center for General and Tumor Immunology at The Hebrew University. At this time of inestimable loss, we extend our deepest sympathies to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The Hebrew University of Jerusalem President Menahem Ben-Sasson American Friends of The Hebrew University Michael S. Kurtz, Chairman Daniel I. Schlessinger, President Peter T. Willner, National Executive Director

BLACK--Page Morton, The Board of Directors, the staff, the supporters, and the many hundreds of scientists funded by the Parkinson's Disease Foundation (PDF) mourn the passing, and cherish the memory, of an exemplary, passionate and indefatigable leader. For three decades since the death of her husband (and our founder), William Black, Page served brilliantly as our Chairman- strengthening us with her inspired nominations to our Board, enriching us with her deft leadership of our annual Bal du Printemps, and energizing us with her single-minded devotion to the reputation, success and financial health of our organization. She and her vivid persona may be irreplaceable, but the memory of her indomitable spirit will carry us forward. We will not fail her. Howard DeWitt Morgan, Chair; Robin Anthony Elliott, President

BLACK--Page Morton. Columbia University Medical Center mourns the passing of Page Morton Black, whose friendship, advocacy and philanthropy were indispensable in our fight against Parkinson's disease. As Chair of the Board of Directors of the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, Mrs. Black carried the mantle established by her late husband, William Black -- their generosity made possible the construction of the William Black Medical Research Building on our campus, and the creation of our Center for Parkinson's Disease and Other Movement Disorders, which continues its pioneering research and patient care. All of us at Columbia extend our condolences to her friends and family. Lee Goldman, MD Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine and Executive Vice President, Columbia University Richard Mayeux, MD, MSc Gertrude H. Sergievsky Professor of Neurology, Psychiatry & Epidemiology Chairman, Department of Neurology

BLACK--Page Morton, on Sunday, July 21, 2013 at age 97. She was a great lady, known for her philanthropy, shrewd intellect and deep caring for all those who had contact with her. The widow of William Black, founder of Chock Full o' Nuts company, she served on the Board of Directors of Chock for many years, was for 30 years the active Chairman of the Board of the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, and was involved with many other charitable organizations. She was also a professional singer who performed at many of the top New York venues, and was known to millions as the one who reminded them that "Chock Full o' Nuts is that heavenly coffee". She was a great friend who will be sorely missed. Interment will be private and a memorial service will be held at a later date.

WINARICK--Jules, passed away at the age of 95 on July 20, 2013 after a short illness. Jules, along with his father Arthur, built the Concord, one of the great Jewish hotels of the Catskills. He is survived by his wife Jody of 42 years, four children, four grandchildren, and one great-granddaughter. A memorial service will be held at 11:30am Saturday at the Follett and Werner Funeral Home, Westhampton New York. Donations can be made to Peconic Bay Medical Center.

Proud World War II Veteran of the Women's Army Corps. Memorial service will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at noon on Wednesday, July 24, 2013. 630 Amsterdam Ave. (at 91st St.) New York, NY 10024, (212) 769-4400. Contributions in Rose's memory can be made to Hadassah or Disabled American Veterans.
