O'HARA--Alison. Chairman of the Board, Follett Corporation Follett Chairman Alison O'Hara passed away unexpectedly on Saturday, July 20, 2013, from complications of breast cancer. Alison was a graduate of Oak Park and River Forest High School in Illinois and went on to receive a bachelor of arts from Colorado College, and a juris doctor from the University of Colorado Law School. She began her public sector law career as an Assistant State's Attorney with the Cook County State's Attorney Office in 1988, and in 1991 became an Assistant Attorney General with the Illinois Attorney General's Office. From 1995 to 1997, Alison served as Senior Counsel with the Attorney Registration & Disciplinary Commission of the Illinois Supreme Court. In private practice in Chicago during the 1990s, Alison served as an associate at Jackson Lewis and as Co-Chair of the Appellate Department of Cassiday Schade. Between 1996 and 1998, she was also an adjunct professor at Loyola University's Chicago School of Law. In the late 1990s, Alison began her corporate sector legal career joining privately-held Follett Corporation as Senior Counsel in the company's legal department, and she was later promoted to Assistant General Counsel. She was named to Follett's Board of Directors in 1999. In 2011, Alison was elected as the first female Chairman of the Board in Follett's 140 year-history. In 2012, she served as acting President and CEO following the retirement of Chuck Follett, and subsequently led the Board's search for a successor. Alison was the catalyst behind the Company's pursuit of emerging opportunities in education, particularly in digital content and technology. Alison will be greatly missed by all who knew her. She is survived by her husband, James A. Barasa, her children, Amanda, Trevor, and Tucker, her stepchildren, Gina, Eliza, and Jimmy; her mother, Ariel Follett O'Hara, her father, J. Philip O'Hara (Patricia), her siblings, Keith (Dena), Julie (Dennis White), and John (Amy); and her entire extended family including nieces, nephews, aunts, uncles, and cousins. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions be made to the Follett Educational Foundation, 2233 West Street, River Grove, Illinois 60171-1817.

McKENNA--Owen E.,83, died on June 2 at Morristown Medical Center. Born in Ireland, he came to the U.S. in 1957 and settled in Queens, NY. He lived in Hackensack for 16 years before moving to Parsippany in 1974. Owen was a retired pressman for The New York Times. He was a member of the Knights of Columbus 3680 of Parsippany and the Irish American Association of Northwest Jersey. Owen is survived by his sons, John and his wife, Linda, Daniel and his wife, Mary; daughter, Kathleen Meigs and her husband, Scott; and eight grandchildren. He was predeceased by his wife, Nora A. (Warren), February 17, 2012. Donations in his memory can be made to Multiple Sclerosis Society - The Greater New Jersey Chapter, 1 Kalisa Way, Suite 205, Paramus, NJ 07652.

We will miss her deeply, but her strength, goodness, and optimism will live on in us and all who knew her.

KANE--Irene, of Sarasota Florida, formerly of Queens NY, passed away in her home on Sunday July 21, 2013. She is survived by her husband of 62 years, Herbert Kane, daughter Diane Kane of Sarasota, FL, son Steven, daughter-in-law Cindy and grandchildren Derrick and Dylan Kane of Houston Texas. Private arrangements have been made for family only. In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorial contributions be made to Tidwell Hospice Inc in Sarasota, FL who were instrumental in providing comfort and aide in Irene's final days.

WATTS--Philip. The French department of Columbia University is deeply saddened by the loss of Professor Philip Watts, 52, who died at his home in Morningside Heights, New York, on Saturday, July 20, 2013. Phil Watts was a beloved member of the Columbia community and will be dearly missed by the many people who had the opportunity to work with him. His warmth, generosity, intelligence, erudition, sense of humor, and tact were unparalleled. A native Californian, he received his BA in 1982, from the University of California, Santa Barbara, and his PhD from Columbia in 1991. From 1992 to 2006 he taught at the University of Pittsburgh, where he became Chair of the department of French and Italian. In 2006 he returned to Columbia, where he was Professor of French. As Chair from 2007 to 2012, he led the department with intellectual rigor and professional dedication and, above all, a deep sense of humanity. He was a specialist of twentieth-century French literature and film who published on numerous subjects in this area. His book "Allegories of the Purge" (Stanford, 1999) won the MLA's Scaglione Prize. He is survived by his wife, Sophie Queuniet, also a faculty member in the French department, and two young daughters, Madeleine and Louise. A memorial will be held at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University in September. Details of the memorial will be posted on the Columbia French Department website when finalized.

McNALLY--John J. "Jack", of Bronxville, NY, on July 23, 2013. Beloved husband of Sally Greeley McNally, loving father of Martha Kerney, Sarah (William) Lynn, Lisa (William) Cassidy, Julie (Christian) Daher and Thomas (Molly) McNally. Devoted grandfather of 15, brother of Sr. Virginia McNally and Mary Alice Githens and the late Richard J. McNally. After serving in the US Navy during WWII Jack graduated from the College of the Holy Cross, 1950 and Harvard University Law School, 1953. Jack joined White & Case in NYC practiced law there until his retirement in 1994. Jack was active on the boards of All Hallows Foundation, Lavelle Fund for the Blind, Lawrence Hospital and Mohawk Paper. Prior board service included work with the Community Fund of Bronxville, Eastchester and Tuckahoe, Holly Sugar Corporation, Waterman Steamship Corporation, and Caedmon Montessori School. Calling Hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home between the hours of 2 to 4 and 6 to 8pm Friday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Saturday July 27, 2013 at 10:45am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Jack's memory to All Hallows HS, 111 E 164th St., New York, NY 10452 or Lawrence Hospital Center, Bronxville, NY.

LOMBARDI--Dr. Angelo R.,passed peacefully on July 19th, age 90. He was a founder of the orthodontic program at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey where he taught for over 30 years, a creator of their cleft lip/palate program, and served as Chairman of the Department. He served as President of the New Jersey Association of Orthodontists. He implemented programs for free access to dental screening for school age children and practiced for sixty years. He graduated from the University of Maryland School of Dentistry, served in the Air Force during the Korean War, rank of Captain, stationed in French Morocco where he co-headed the dental clinic. He has Columbia University School of Dentistry degree specializing in orthodontics. He started two orthodontics practices, in Fort Lee and Jersey City, which his son Drew joined in 1984 and both are still active today. He lived in Leonia with his late wife Virginia for nearly 40 years retiring to Naples, FL and Loveladies, NJ. Survived by four children, five grandchildren and a sister. A private memorial is planned in celebration of his life.

FREEMAN--Doreen Doreen Sheila (Brown) Freeman was born on February 28, 1923, in Liverpool, England. She subsequently lived in Ohio, USA, until 1933 when she and her parents and her brother, Freddie, returned to England. Doreen attended a convent in London, followed by boarding schools in Cheshire and Sussex. After a short stint as a flight attendant with an emerging new airline, at the age of 18, Doreen became a journalist and reporter for the London paper, "The Daily Sketch." During World War II, she served in the Women's Auxiliary Air Force (WAAF) where she served for three years. In late 1947, Doreen met Houghton "Buck" Freeman and they were married shortly thereafter on April 21, 1948, at the Savoy Chapel in London. They left the next day for Shanghai, China, where their first child, Linda, was born in September, 1949. Evacuated two weeks later, the family moved to Japan which they called their home for 21 years. It was during that time that their son, Graeme, was born in 1955. Doreen and Buck moved to New York City where they lived from 1970 to 1990, and after an additional two years in Japan, they retired to Stowe, Vermont, where they established the Freeman Foundation in 1993. The Honolulu, Hawaii, office opened in 2000. Doreen served as a trustee and was actively involved with the Foundation until her death on July 12, 2013. Doreen leaves behind her daughter, Linda, and son-in-law Don Post, grandchildren Tyler and wife Stacie, Alexi, and Graham, all of Stowe; son, Graeme and wife Nancy Freeman, grandsons Alec and Colin of Honolulu, Hawaii; and two stepgrandsons, David and Scott DeCristo. She also leaves her brother, Frederick Brown and wife, Sandra, godsonephew, Toby Brown, stepnephew Sebastian Brown, of England; and nephew, Kelvin Carlyle, of Bali. After 62 years of marriage, her husband, Buck, predeceased her in 2010. A private family service will be held in Vermont at a later date. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested donations to be made to either the American Red Cross, Hawaii State Chapter, 4155 Diamond Head Rd., Honolulu, Hawaii 96816; or Meals on Wheels of Lamoille County, 24 Upper Main St., Morrisville, Vermont 05661.

SOLAS--Bernard. The Bronx High School of Science community is deeply saddened by the passing of alumnus Bernard Solas '49, beloved husband of Elaine Mandell Solas, alumna and former member of the Bronx Science faculty and our Board of Trustees. We extend our sincere condolences to Elaine, daughter Amy Solas and her husband Richard Klein. The Alumni Association of the Bronx High School of Science

ROTHSCHILD Hon. Dora Prestup. Mark Wallace, Trudy Wallace and their families mourn the passing of their beloved Aunt Dora and extend condolences to her son William and his family. May her memory be for blessing.

ROTHMAN--Doris Hazelcorn. Her spirit passed on July 24th in Florida. Doris excelled as a teacher, science coordinator, and Ecology Center Director at District 22 in Brooklyn, receiving the Presidential Award for Excellence in Education. Doris married Lester Rothman on January 26, 1992 and their deep love and affection for each other was evident to all. Funeral services will be held in Florida.

MININBERG--David T.,MD, 77, died July 22, 2013 in New York. Son of Benjamin and Mildred Mininberg, he is survived by his wife of 56 years, Anne, brother Elliot, sons Gustav and Julien; and five grandchildren Benjamin, Emily, Mark, Lena and Gabriel. Following his distinguished clinical career as a pediatric urologist and professor at New York-Presbyterian Hospital Weill Cornell Medical College, Dr. Mininberg, Yale '57, earned an MA in Middle Eastern Studies from NYU in 2003. He was a long-time volunteer at the Metropolitan Museum's Dept. of Egyptian Art. A family graveside service will be held July 28. A memorial service at Central Synagogue will be held in September.

MOHR--Lucille, nee Boosin, on Wednesday, July 24th, 2013. A long time resident of Philadelphia, PA. Raised in Woodmere, NY. Survived by her brother, James Boosin. aunt to Kari Sobel and Michael Boosin, and great-aunt Ceo to Hunter and Ethan Sobel. Memorial services to be held at Boulevard-Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway Hewlett, NY, on Friday July 26th, 2013 at 12:30pm.

McNALLY--John J. "Jack", of Bronxville, NY, on July 23, 2013. Beloved husband of Sally Greeley McNally, loving father of Martha Kerney, Sarah (William) Lynn, Lisa (William) Cassidy, Julie (Christian) Daher and Thomas (Molly) McNally. Devoted grandfather of 15, brother of Sr. Virginia McNally and Mary Alice Githens and the late Richard J. McNally. After serving in the US Navy during WWII Jack graduated from the College of the Holy Cross, 1950 and Harvard University Law School, 1953. Jack joined White & Case in NYC practiced law there until his retirement in 1994. Jack was active on the boards of All Hallows Foundation, Lavelle Fund for the Blind, Lawrence Hospital and Mohawk Paper. Prior board service included work with the Community Fund of Bronxville, Eastchester and Tuckahoe, Holly Sugar Corporation, Waterman Steamship Corporation, and Caedmon Montessori School. Calling Hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home between the hours of 2 to 4 and 6 to 8pm Friday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Saturday July 27, 2013 at 10:45am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Jack's memory to All Hallows HS, 111 E 164th St., New York, NY 10452 or Lawrence Hospital Center, Bronxville, NY.

MAKK--Andrew Francis. Born December 23, 1969 in Louisville, KY, died July 20, 2013 in New York City after a prolonged battle with cancer. Predeceased by parents Laszlo Makk, MD and Carolyn Cooke Makk. Survived by wife Catherine and daughter Hannah of New York City; brothers Laszlo, Stephen and Christopher of Louisville, KY. BSM, Tulane University; MBA, Duke University. Principal, Energy Capital Partners of Short Hills, NJ. Trustee, Graham Windham; parishioner, Grace Church; member, The Union Club of New York. Memorial donations to Memorial-Sloan Kettering Cancer Center Head and Neck Department, with gratitude to David G. Pfister, MD and Nicole Leonhart, NP. Services July 27 at 11:00am at Grace Church.

LEBOUTILLIER--Pamela Tower. of Old Westbury, NY, died at the age of 91 on July 16 after a two-year illness. The most loving, dedicated and self-sacrificing mother of Timothy J. Secor, Mimi Secor, Nicholas T. Secor, Susan Secor Humes, John LeBoutillier and Pamela LeBoutillier Miles, she was a devoted wife to her late husband, Thomas LeBoutillier, and a loyal sister to Whitney Tower, Flora Biddle and Leverett S. Miller. She was the indefatigable leader of a huge and disparate family. She adored her mother, Flora Whitney Miller, and valued and cared for all her nieces, nephews, cousins, Godchildren and friends as well as her staff and pets and never thought of herself. Services were held at Church of the Advent in Westbury, July 19.
KNITTLE--Rosemary(Russell). beloved wife of Dr. Jerome Knittle and mother of Hilary died on July 19, 2013 after a long illness. Funeral on Monday, July 29th at 10am St. Monica Church 413 E.79th St.

KAPLAN--Hirsch, died peacefully at the age of 85. He is survived by his beloved wife Linda, his sister Raychelle, his children Marjorie, Jane and Michael; Thomas, Mush and Donna and his grandchildren Molly Rose, Sean, Elizabeth, Justin and Lindsay. He walks with the angels. Memorial Service to celebrate his life will be held Sunday, July 28, 12pm at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd St., New York City. Donations to Raymond Hill School (that serves neglected and abused youth), 345 Linwood St., New Britain, CT 06052 or Congregation Rodeph Sholom.

GRAHAM--Arthur Jr. The Board of The Columbia University Alumni Club of Westchester County deeply mourns the passing of its dear friend and President Arthur Graham, Jr. Arthur was our guiding light and the reason for our success. He will be surely missed.

GRAHAM--Arthur. The JCC of Mid-Westchester is extremely saddened by the sudden passing of its past board member, Arthur Graham. Among his many contributions to the JCC, Arthur was instrumental in founding the JCC's special needs program. Arthur, an avid swimmer until the day of his passing, will be missed by both patrons and staff. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Ruth and the entire family.
GLENN--Thomas E. Artist, painter, designer, creator. This gentle, kind, loving man passed away on July 21.

BARTRAM--Jeannette Gardner Norton. Beloved wife, mother, and grandmother, 84, of Bloomfield, CT, and Glenora, NY, on July 24, 2013. Vassar College, Class of 1950. She is survived by her husband of 60 years, Maynard C. Bartram; their children, Carey Meltzer (Harland), Peter Bartram, Sarah Noyes (Jon), and Amy Bartram; and grand- children Amory, Nathaniel, Jacob, and Abigail. Private burial in Sharon, CT, with a memorial service at a later date. Memorial gifts to Vassar College or First Congregational Church, Bloomfield, CT.

BARKIN--Dudley, 85, of Floral Park, NY. Passed away peacefully on Wednesday, July 24, 2013 surrounded by family. Beloved husband of Louise, devoted and loving father of Stephanie, Dale and Michael, father-in-law of Steven Cherniak, Eric Chaikin and Beth Barkin, cherished grandfather and "poppy" of grandchildren Harlan and Tracy, Seth and Alexis, Spencer and Andrea, Dane, Brooke and Jeremy, Sloane and Mark, great grandfather of Lucas, loving son and devoted brother. He will be sorely missed. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Long Island Jewish Medical Center Service Guild, The Lustgarten Foundation or The Central Park Zoo.
PATSNER--Neva. You have been gone four terribly long years; yet we all felt your presence at our son's wedding last week. You will be loved and missed forever by all of us. Your Husband Bruce.

SPANIER--Rose Peterson (Petey), of Mt. Vernon, NY. Beloved and cherished wife of the late Henry "Hank" Spanier; mother of Miriam (Michael), Orli (Neil), and Gene; adored Grannie of Jennie and Daniel; loving sister and aunt, and adopted sister and mother to Leona and Nuru. Proud World War II Veteran of the Women's Army Corps. Memorial service will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at noon on Wednesday, July 24, 2013. 630 Amsterdam Ave. (at 91st St.) New York, NY 10024, (212) 769-4400. Contributions in Rose's memory can be made to Hadassah or Disabled American Veterans.

RAPPL--Frank Paul, on July 25, 2013, age 89, WWII U.S. Marine Veteran, Bronze Star, Purple Heart. Four invasions, Iwo Jima, Saipan, Tinian and the Marshall Islands. Beloved husband of the late Bertha. Loving father of Karin (David), Heidi (Nathaniel) and Susan (Joel). Cherished grandfather (Opa) of Lauren (Randy), Adam, William, David, Elizabeth and Benjamin. Great-grandfather of Cameron. Contributions in his memory may be made to: WoundedWarriorProject.org.

LITWAK--Robert S. The Mount Sinai community is deeply saddened by the passing of Robert S. Litwak, MD, Professor Emeritus of Cardiothoracic Surgery. Dr. Litwak joined Mount Sinai in 1962 as Chief of the new Division of Cardiothoracic Surgery, becoming Professor of Surgery when our medical school was created. Among many outstanding contributions to Mount Sinai, he reestablished the open heart surgery program, initiated the cardiothoracic surgery residency program, and opened the first dedicated cardiac surgical operating room suite and cardiac surgical intensive care unit. A true pioneer of modern cardiac surgery, he authored more than 200 articles in peer-reviewed journals. The Mount Sinai community extends its condolences to Dr. Litwak's family and friends. Peter W. May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, The Mount Sinai Medical Center; Kenneth L. Davis, MD, President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Medical Center; and Dennis S. Charney, MD, Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and Executive Vice President for Academic Affairs at The Mount Sinai Medical Center.

KAUFMAN--Stanley L.,90, passed away peacefully July 25, 2013 in Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Born in Brooklyn, NY, he was a long-time resident of Great Neck, NY. A U.S. Army veteran, he received three Purple Hearts for courageous infantry service in Europe during World War II. A graduate of the Wharton School, he co-founded Tempo Jewelry. In 2004, he created The Andy Kaufman Award, a talent competition in honor of his son. He enjoyed art and travel and really enjoyed life. His playful spirit and endearing charm brought a smile to hearts everywhere. Twice widowed, he was preceded in death by wives Janice Kaufman and Mildred Kalter, and by son Andy Kaufman, and brother Jack Kaufman. He is survived by his children Michael Kaufman (wife Pru Kaufman), Carol Kaufman-Kerman (husband Rick Kerman); grandsons Tyler Kaufman, Adam, Jason and Joshua Kerman; granddaughter Maria Colonna (husband Joe Colonna); great-granddaughter Brittany Colonna; nieces Jill Kaufman and Margot Goldberg; stepsons Andrew and John Terner; and dear and close friend, Paulette Roy. Funeral Services will be held on Monday July 29 at 11:30am at Riverside-Nassau North Chapel - 55 North Station Plaza - Great Neck, NY 11021 - Phone: 516-487-9600. Donations can be made to: Palm Beach Pet Rescue - 378 Northlake Blvd PMB#

WEMYSS--Nina, died April 19, 2013 at Huntington Hospital surrounded by family, after a brief illness. She died as she lived with courage, peace, grace. Born 1922 in Pogranichnaya, China, Nina and her Russian parents Gregory and Catherine Mekhonoshin (Meek) moved to Brisbane, Australia 1926 where she was raised and educated. She met her future husband, Walter F.J. Wemyss, a U.S. Naval officer in Brisbane. In 1946 she moved to the U.S. where she married and settled in Lloyd Harbor, LI raising four children. Nina was an accomplished artist, intrepid traveler, avid bridge player who loved to dance, sing, walk and care for her animals. She was a talented tennis player, sailor, pianist. Predeceased by her husband of 34 years, Nina is survived by four children, Vivian Farren, Nina Wemyss, Marie Kennedy, Wally Wemyss, five grandchildren and four great grandchildren. Her happiest times were with family.

WANDELT--Frederick H. Long time admissions director Frederick H. "Ferdie" Wandelt III dies at 65. February 10, 1948 July 25, 2013. For more than 30 years, Ferdie Wandelt was the face of the Taft School in Watertown, CT. He traveled the globe seeking the best and brightest students. He died Thursday due to sudden complications of acute lymphoblastic leukemia, surrounded by family and friends. "From the outset, Ferdie understood two interrelated principles," said Taft Headmaster Emeritus Lance Odden. "First, that attracting the best mix of diversely talented students would create a uniquely spirited community; and second, that the vibrancy so created would elevate Taft's place in the community of schools." No school has ever had a finer admissions leader. The son of Fred and Susie Wandelt, Ferdie grew up in Princeton, New Jersey. A graduate of Taft and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, he returned to Taft, after service with the National Guard, in the fall of 1971 to join the Admissions Office, earning an MALS degree at Wesleyan University. In 1976, he succeeded Joe Cunningham as director of admissions. "He transformed our school," said Odden. "It is impossible to capture all Ferdie was to Taft and to thousands who knew and loved him," said current Taft headmaster Willy MacMullen. "With his death, we have lost a great man, someone who will join the list of legendary educators who devoted their lives to our school, and someone who served with an unparalleled love, passion, and loyalty." For the next four decades, he was a beloved figure on campus, but his service to the larger educational community meant he was also a globally respected leader. He was a board member of ASSIST (American Secondary Schools for International Students and Teachers); president of the SSATB (Secondary School Admissions Test Board); and a trustee for the Challengers Boys and Girls Club of Los Angeles. Other scholarship organizations, like Prep for Prep and the Wight Foundation, knew Ferdie as a supportive and visionary leader. Peer schools were made better because he helped open doors in international recruitment, and he shared his best ideas with them. "It's about helping all schools and kids," he said often. "He was much more than just the finest admissions director in the country," said MacMullen. "Ferdie had a unique humor, warmth, and grace. After you met him in an interview, you wanted to attend Taft. And in those twenty minutes, Ferdie could 'read' a candidate with a sensitivity and insight that was astonishing. Those who were admitted felt blessed, and somehow, those who were not felt that he cared deeply and personally, and indeed, Ferdie regularly counseled families and helped them find another school that was a better fit." He traveled the world telling the Taft story. He was a superb girls' lacrosse coach, and scores of young teachers sought him for advice. Ferdie changed Taft, and he changed lives. He is survived by his wife Joanna, brother Joseph "Sandy" Wandelt of Sicklerville, NJ, daughter Allison Halsell her husband Benjamin, of New Canaan, CT, son Christopher Wandelt and his wife Erin of Redding, CT, and five grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Frederick H. Wandelt III '66 Scholarship Fund, The Taft School, 110 Woodbury Road, Watertown, CT 06795. There will be a memorial service at Taft on Saturday, September 28.

SACHAR--Michael Paul, was born in Brooklyn, NY on August 1st, 1946, passed away on July 23, 2013 in San Francisco, CA. He leaves his wife Sherry, children Taryn, Nicole and Max, his sister Randy, son-in-law Marc, two grandchildren Naphtalia and Jude, the Brilliant family, Aunt Benice, cousins Marc, Nicole and Susan, cousin-in-law, mourns Michael's untimely passing. SCHATTNER--Dr. Joseph David, devoted husband to Harriet, father to Elaine, Gail, Paul and Marshall, brother to Gerald and grandfather to Aaron, Ethan, Laura and Nina, on July 20. He was a physician who cared with words, generosity and knowledge. His concern for patients and passion for medicine survive him. Joseph's support for Israel never faltered. RYBAK--Mary Ellen, M.D. 63, Thousand Oaks, CA and Princeton, NJ passed away at home suddenly on July 20. Beloved wife of Thomas Griffin, M.D. for thirty-seven years, Dr. Rybak was a senior medical researcher specializing in hematology and oncology. She worked in cancer research and new drug development in both academia and the pharmaceutical industry for over thirty years. A graduate of Canisius College in Buffalo, NY and Harvard Medical School, she was formerly Vice President, Oncology at Johnson & Johnson in Raritan, NJ; Chief Medical Officer of Genitope Corporation in Fremont, CA; and most recently Vice President of p53 Inc. of Houston. TX. Born in Buffalo, NY, Dr. Rybak was predeceased in death by her parents, Joseph and Marie Rybak. In addition to her husband, Dr. Griffin, she is survived by her uncle, Leo Rybak of Depew, NY, an aunt, Joan Ansbrow Rockwitz of Darien Center, NY, brothers and sisters-in-law Peter and Mary Ellen Griffin of Colts Neck, NJ, Kathleen and Thomas McGuinness of Needham, MA, Marilyn Begley of Freehold, NJ and many nieces and nephews to whom she was devoted. Visitation will be held at the Kimble Funeral Home in Princeton, NJ on July 30, 7 to 9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at St. Paul's RC Church, Princeton, July, 31 at 10am., followed by internment at Princeton Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that donations be made to the American Cancer Society. Services were made with the assistance of Griffin Family Funeral Chapels, Thousand Oaks. (805) 230-2800

PETERSON--Dr. Hart (Pete) DeCoudres, 80, of Scituate, MA and formerly of NY, NY passed away surrounded by his family on July 24, 2013. Dr. Peterson was a pioneer in the study of pediatric neurology with a specialty in the field of Epilepsy and Muscular Dystrophy. Much of his career was spent at New York Hospital, Cornell University Medical Center where he was chairman of the department of Pediatric Neurology until he went into private practice - 1963 till 1998. His great passion in the medical field was teaching the next generation of Doctors. He was an avid reader, consuming two to three books a week and several newspapers each day. His passion for music ranged from old time Banjo to Opera. His hunger for creativity lead him to become a master Nantucket Basket weaver, and enjoyed teaching classes on weaving at the Norwell Science Center. He was also an ardent photographer and writer, he and his wife Deborah produced numerous articles on seaside gardening. Dr. Peterson's love for his community and surroundings can also be seen by the numerous boards and community positions he has held through his life from being president of neighborhood associations to sitting on towns boards. He is survived by his wife Deborah of 55 years of Marriage, two children Earl and Pamela, eight grandchildren and three brothers; Bruce, Mark and Joel. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers donations should be made the Norwell Visiting Nurses, 120 Longwater Dr, Norwell, MA 02061. For information and online condolences visit: www.richardsongaffeyfuneralhome.com

RAMBHARAN--Imran Mark, September 11, 1968 - July 17, 2013, philosopher and friend, dies at 44. Imran will be remembered for all the lives he touched and wisdom he shared. He is survived by his mother Zabeeda Rambharan, two sisters Bibi Ramdayal and Farida Rambharan; brother-in-law Frank Ramdayal; nieces Mia and Bella Ramdayal and pet Coco.

MOULTON--Elizabeth W. (Day), died unexpectedly on July 21, 2013, in Ashby, MA. She was born in Cambridge, MA in November, 1924, and attended Shady Hill School, Concord Academy and Radcliffe College, Class of 1946. She married Henry H. Moulton, Harvard '46. They settled in New York City where Mrs. Moulton worked as a feature assistant on Mademoiselle Magazine (where she was known as Betsy Day), and from 1949 as a freelance writer. Her short stories appeared in "Mademoiselle," "Redbook," "McCall's," "The Virginia Quarterly Review," and elsewhere. She published articles in "The Sewanee Review," "Mademoiselle," and in "Flair," "American Artist," the "VQR," "Gourmet" and other magazines. Her first novel, "Fatal Demonstrations," was published by Harper & Row in 1980 under the name Elizabeth Moulton. She had completed five more by the time of her death. She was a life-long amateur watercolor painter. Elizabeth Moulton lived in Manhattan from 1946 to 1981 where her volunteer activities included local Democratic Party politics, the Radcliffe Club of New York, the New York Public School Volunteer Program, and St. George's Church on Stuyve- sant Square for which she wrote a parish history. Mr. Moulton, who worked for Fiduciary Trust International, and Mrs. Moulton moved to Los Angeles in 1981, were headquartered in London from 1985-1988, and returned from California to Cambridge in 1991. She leaves her husband of sixty seven years, her daughters Anne W. Moulton, M.D, Sara S. Moulton, master chef and television personality, Peter H. Moulton. a judge in the New York State court system, and six grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, September 7, at Christ Church, Zero Garden Street, Cambridge, at 3pm with a reception to follow. Memorial donations may be made to Shady Hill School, 178 Coolidge Hill, Cambridge, MA 02138, or to Schlesinger Library, Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study, 10 Garden Street, Cambridge, MA 02138-3600.

MININBERG--David T.,MD, 77, died July 22, 2013 in New York. Son of Benjamin and Mildred Mininberg, he is survived by his wife of 56 years, Anne, brother Elliot, sons Gustav and Julien; and five grandchildren Benjamin, Emily, Mark, Lena and Gabriel. Following his distinguished clinical career as a pediatric urologist and professor at New York-Presbyterian Hospital Weill Cornell Medical College, Dr. Mininberg, Yale '57, earned an MA in Middle Eastern Studies from NYU in 2003. He was a long-time volunteer at the Metropolitan Museum's Dept. of Egyptian Art. A family graveside service will be held July 28. A memorial service at Central Synagogue will be held in September.

He is a graduate of the U. of Penn, with a B.S. in Economics from the Wharton School and served as CFO to several corporations. Richard is survived by his wife, Laurie and his beloved dog, Morgan.

LERNER--Selma, died July 4, 2013, at home in Riverdale, NY, with family at her side. Selma was born December 14, 1929, in the Bronx, NY, to the late Rose (Wasserman) and Harry Levack. She graduated in 1947 from Evander Childs High School and was a "Grand Concourse girl" when she married Meyer ("Mike") Lerner, who predeceased her in 2000 after 51 years of marriage. Selma and Mike raised their family in Brooklyn, NY, except for a brief interval in White Plains, NY, then lived in Manhattan and Milford, PA, for two decades before retiring fully to their winter home in Hollywood, FL. Beginning in the 1960's, Selma pursued and achieved her dream of becoming a buyer of women's clothing, starting out as a retail department store manager, then a buyer for Alexander's, in New York City, and being recruited, finally, as a buyer for New Jersey's Bamberger's department stores division of R.H. Macy and Co. She retired from the garment industry to a successful career as a commercial real estate broker in New York City with The Lerner Organization, Inc., founded by her son and husband. Her volunteer life ranged from PTA president as a young mother to post-retirement volunteer activities in Hollywood, FL. She moved back to New York in 2011. She is survived by her three children, Sharon Lerner Golden, of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY; Jack Lerner, of New York City; and Lorraine Lerner, of Oakland, CA; son-in-law John Golden; daughter-in-law Evelyne Lerner; sister Wallis Berkson, of Pompton Lakes, NJ; and beloved grandchildren Roget and Kimberly Lerner. A tenaciously loving mother and grandmother and loved and cherished mother-in-law and loyal friend, she was a devotee of the arts, avid reader and gardener, and active hostess throughout her working life and retirement. Her love of life, so generously and enthusiastically shared with others, will be missed, as will such recollected culinary delights as her chicken cutlets and "blintzes for 10." A private family service was held on July 8 at Menorah Gardens Chapel in Fort Lauderdale, Florida. Selma's life will be celebrated on Wednesday, July 31, 7pm., at Arno Ristorante, 141 W 38 St., over cocktails.

LEBOUTILLIER--Pamela Tower. of Old Westbury, NY, died at the age of 91 on July 16 after a two-year illness. The most loving, dedicated and self-sacrificing mother of Timothy J. Secor, Mimi Secor, Nicholas T. Secor, Susan Secor Humes, John LeBoutillier and Pamela LeBoutillier Miles, she was a devoted wife to her late husband, Thomas LeBoutillier, and a loyal sister to Whitney Tower, Flora Biddle and Leverett S. Miller. She was the indefatigable leader of a huge and disparate family. She adored her mother, Flora Whitney Miller, and valued and cared for all her nieces, nephews, cousins, Godchildren and friends as well as her staff and pets and never thought of herself. Services were held at Church of the Advent in Westbury, July 19.

KNAPP--Leonard. 1925-2013. Beloved brother of Ruth Swerdlow, brother-in-law of Monroe Swerdlow, Uncle of Linda Reif and Michael Swerdlow passed on July l7, 2013. He was a talented artist and a kind, caring man. He will be deeply missed.

KAUFMAN--Stanley L.,90, passed away peacefully July 25, 2013 in Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Born in Brooklyn, NY, he was a long-time resident of Great Neck, NY. A U.S. Army veteran, he received three Purple Hearts for courageous infantry service in Europe during World War II. A graduate of the Wharton School, he co-founded Tempo Jewelry. In 2004, he created The Andy Kaufman Award, a talent competition in honor of his son. He enjoyed art and travel and really enjoyed life. His playful spirit and endearing charm brought a smile to hearts everywhere. Twice widowed, he was preceded in death by wives Janice Kaufman and Mildred Kalter, and by son Andy Kaufman, and brother Jack Kaufman. He is survived by his children Michael Kaufman (wife Pru Kaufman), Carol Kaufman-Kerman (husband Rick Kerman); grandsons Tyler Kaufman, Adam, Jason and Joshua Kerman; granddaughter Maria Colonna (husband Joe Colonna); great-granddaughter Brittany Colonna; nieces Jill Kaufman and Margot Goldberg; stepsons Andrew and John Terner; and dear and close friend, Paulette Roy. Funeral Services will be held on Monday July 29 at 11:30am at Riverside-Nassau North Chapel - 55 North Station Plaza - Great Neck, NY 11021 - Phone: 516-487-9600. Donations can be made to: Palm Beach Pet Rescue - 378 Northlake Blvd PMB#

KAPLAN--Hirsch, died peacefully at the age of 85. He is survived by his beloved wife Linda, his sister Raychelle, his children Marjorie, Jane and Michael; Thomas, Mush and Donna and his grandchildren Molly Rose, Sean, Elizabeth, Justin and Lindsay. He walks with the angels. Memorial Service to celebrate his life will be held Sunday, July 28, 12pm at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd St., New York City. Donations to Raymond Hill School (that serves neglected and abused youth), 345 Linwood St., New Britain, CT 06052 or Congregation Rodeph Sholom.

ISRAEL--Leo, 90, died July 26, 2013, peacefully at his home after suffering a long illness with his wife of 67 years, Deborah at his side. Mr. Israel who was born in New York City in 1923 to immigrant parents, was an American success story. After serving as a soldier in the US Army, Mr. Israel attended City College of New York for his BBA on the GI bill and went on to Columbia University for his MA in 1954. Mr. Israel had a long industrious career as a CPA and was the founding partner of the Leo Israel & Co., a successful accounting firm on Long Island. He moved to Glen Cove, NY and was committed to serving his community as the Commissioner of Finance. In addition, he held various City Council positions. As a devoted husband to Deborah for 67 years, Mr. Israel was a loving father to four sons, Fred, Steve, Michael, and David. He was a devoted grandfather to Samantha, Isa, Jake, Harrison, Sam, Sarah, Blake, William, and Daniel. He was beloved by his daughters-in-law Marsee, Michele, and Lucretia. Services will be at Guttermans Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, NY at 11am on Monday, July 29.

HUDGINS--Alvin C.,83, of Southampton, NY, (Sarasota, FL) passed away early in New York on Friday morning, July 19, 2013. Al attended Morehouse College in Atlanta, GA. Al was a successful real estate investor and entrepreneur. He was also one of the original founders of Freedom National Bank in New York. Al was an active member of the Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Gamma XI Boule Sigma Pi Phi Fraternity and the Guardsman. He considered his anonymous philanthropy part of his greatest legacy. Al also gave his time by acting as a big brother to boys in Florida. He is survived by his loving wife of 63 years, Rosa Hudgins; along with their four children: William (Mine), AC (Thelma), James (Lisa) and Kindall (Saleem); six grandchildren and many other loving relatives. A memorial service will be held in mid September in New York City. Services entrusted to J. Foster Phillips Funeral Home, Jamaica, NY 11434. www.jfosterphillips.com

HOGAN--John F. "Jack", Sr.,passed away July 25th, 2013, at the age of 83 in Naples, FL. Formerly of Eastchester, NY and Harwich Port, MA, he was predeceased by his wife Joan (nee Vail) in 2001. A loving father to Joan, Patricia (Diana), Anne (Bob), John, Courtney (Reid), David (Meg), Christopher (Elizabeth), and Mark (Julie) and proud Grandpa to Joan, James, Claire, Connor, Juliana, Jeremy, Audrey, Olivia, Vail, and Ryan. Born in his beloved Bronx, NY, Jack graduated from All Hallows, the College of the Holy Cross in Worcester, MA and Columbia University Graduate School. Jack had a long and distinguished career in advertising, holding senior executive positions at Erwin Wasey, Ruthrauff & Ryan; BBDO; Rumrill-Hoyt; and DePalma & Hogan Advertising where he retired as Chairman and CEO in 1985. Jack was a devout Catholic, a gifted raconteur, mentor, athlete, and friend. One-of-a-kind, Jack will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2 to 4pm and 6 to 9pm Tuesday, July 30. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at Church of the Annunciation, Crestwood on Wednesday, July 31 at 10:00am. In lieu of flowers, it was Jack's wish that donations instead be made to All Hallows High School c/o Development Office, 111 East 164th Street Bronx, NY 10452.

HIRSCH--Lawrence W.,82, died July 24 following a long illness. Larry was at heart a dedicated and committed educator who spent most of his professional career teaching in elementary schools in the South Bronx. One of the founders of the United Federation of Teachers, Larry loved his work and the children he taught. Larry lived for several years in Jerusalem, where he continued his teaching career before returning to the US. A fine singer and self-taught banjo and guitar player, Larry sang with Pete Seeger on WNYC in 1947. Larry is survived by his wife Liselotte D. Hirsch (nee Roberts), and was the father of David (Esther) of Passaic, Jan (Elijah "Sonny" Bonneau) of Manhattan, Jordan (Marjorie) of Teaneck, and the late Adam Hirsch of Brooklyn. He is also survived by seven grandchildren: Shaindee, Meyer, Dovie, Sarah, Naima, Akiva and Yakir, and a great-granddaughter, Pharrah.

HEMINWAY--Willard "Spike" Sands Heminway, Jr.,a long-time resident of Greenwich, CT, died peacefully Wednesday, July 24th, at his summer home in Kennebunkport, ME, at the age of 79. A resident of Hobe Sound, FL, Mr. Heminway had many passions but especially loved his family; golf and tennis; and reading. Born August 3, 1933, in Rye, NY, Mr. Heminway graduated in 1951 from The Taft School in Watertown, CT, and in 1955 from Middlebury College in Middlebury, Vermont. He served in the US Army, stationed mostly in Alaska. He was President of Heminway & Bartlett Manufacturing Company, which had been in his family for five generations. He was past president of the Round Hill Club in Greenwich, CT, and past president of the United States Senior's Golf Association. He was well known for wearing colorful socks, a fashion trend adopted by his great friend, George H.W. Bush. The 41st president, when asked by a reporter about why he wore such outlandish socks, credited his good friend Spike for enhancing and broadening his sock portfolio. Mr. Heminway is survived by his wife of 50 years, Betsy Rowland Heminway; his daughter Alexandra Anderson and her husband John of Washington, DC; his beloved grandchildren, Jay and Bentley Anderson; his sister Betsy Dineen of Rye, NY, and many friends. A memorial service will be held at 4:30pm November 7th at the Jupiter Island Chapel in Hobe Sound, FL. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the Hospice of Southern Maine; The Boys and Girls Club of Greenwich, CT; or the Jupiter Island Clinic in Hobe Sound, FL. To send a condolence to the Heminway Family, visit bibberfuneral.com.

GRAHAM--Arthur Jr. The Board of The Columbia University Alumni Club of Westchester County deeply mourns the passing of its dear friend and President Arthur Graham, Jr. Arthur was our guiding light and the reason for our success. He will be surely missed.

GRAHAM--Arthur, Jr.,The Society of Columbia Graduates deeply mourns the passing of Arthur Graham, Jr., our beloved friend, Vice President and Director. He served on the Society's Great Teacher Award Committee for many years. Mr. Graham received the University's Alumni Medal for his long service to his alma mater. Arthur will be remembered with affection and esteem.

GOLDFINGER--David. David Goldfinger, passed away peacefully in his sleep on July 9, 2013 at his home in Laguna Woods, CA. A native New Yorker, he was a graduate of Morris High School in the Bronx, class of '42 and Pace College in New York City. He began his career in advertising at the publications "Men's Reporter" and "Television Age." For the next 25 years his "G and G Variety Stores" were very popular and successful in the Bronx and on Avenue U in Brooklyn. A World War Two veteran he served as a Sargent in the Air Force. After the war he met and fell in love with Irma Giniger and they were married for 65 years. An accomplished athlete he once bowled a 299 at Long Beach Bowl in Long Beach, NY. He loved golf, bridge, coin collecting and spending time with his many friends. His spirit and humor shined when he was with his family; celebrating many happy occasions often dressing up in costume with his great-grandchildren for Halloween. He will be greatly missed by his wife Irma, brother Chuck, sister-in-law, Roz; his children Janice Crystal her husband Billy, son Howard and his wife Michelle Angel and daughter Karena Goldfinger. He was "Grandpa" to Jenny, Lindsay, Uriah, Samantha and Jesse and was affectionatley called "Papa" by his seven great-grandchildren, Ella, Dylan, Kate, Collin, Hudson, Griffin and Sophie. Loved by everyone who knew him, he was 89 and he went too soon. Donations in his name can be made to the Starkey Hearing Foundation.Org and Gods Love We Deliver.Org.
GLENN--Thomas E. Artist, painter, designer, creator. This gentle, kind, loving man passed away on July 21.

GILLMAN--Arthur, E.,MD, 86. Born on June 6, 1927 in New York City, died July 26, 2013. Beloved husband of Harriet Oster, father of Ted Gillman (Joan) and of Sarah Gillman (David Marchiony). Stepfather of Abby O'Connell and Lisa O'Connell Mazzei. Grandfather of Benjamin, Gabriel, Allison and Zachary. Dr. Gillman was a child psychiatrist in New York area schools, hospitals and in private practice. He graduated from the University of Vermont in 1947 and New York Medical College in 1950. In 1970, Dr. Gillman received a commendation from the White House Conference on Children. Dr. Gillman was an avid skier, sailor, and traveler who loved the mountains and his homes in Larchmont NY, Stowe VT, and East Hampton NY. Funeral at Larchmont Temple, Sunday July 28th at 11:30am. Donations in his memory to the Stowe Land Trust.

FOX--Margery Quitzau, of West Palm Beach, Florida died on Sunday, July 21st at age 85. She wrote the following for her Smith College Class of 1949 50th reunion. "Married Frederick Fox in 1954, had two children, Peter and Hugh and lived happily ever after. Did manage to get through graduate school PhD Social Anthropology 1973 NYU. after working with Fred in the theatre for about 10 years. Taught Anthropology and Sociology at Fairleigh Dickinson for about 20 years. Lots of research into women's friendship. Co-directed Women's Center and founded women's studies Minor. Now finishing musical with college setting about popular social issues. Full circle at last." Dr. Fox is survived by her sons Peter Fox of Matawan NJ, Hugh Fox of West Palm Beach Fl, stepson Frederick Fox Jr. of Ridgewood NJ, stepdaughter Deborah Fox Miller of New York, NY and six grandchildren. She will be missed for her intellect, wit and humor by all whom she touched during her wonderful life. A memorial service will be held in Englewood, NJ in September.

FOX--Lillian J.,(Nee Siegel) of Jamaica Estates. Died peacefully in her sleep at age 93, on July 25th. Loving wife of Leonard, mother of Joyce and Leslie, grandmother of Brian, Eric and Lindsay, great-grandmother of Lily Anne, and sister of Florette King. Funeral Services at Schwartz Bros. Forest Hills. 9:30am Sunday, burial follows at Mt. Carmel cemetery.

FELDMAN--George. March 24, 1924 (Bronx) July 24, 2013 (Manhattan). Devoted husband of Delores for 67 years, loving father of Geoffrey, Lori (d. 2006), Melissa; grandchildren Joshua, Michael, Anna; and great-grandsons Jacob and Max. Survived also by sister Charlotte. Direct marketing maverick, magician, bon vivant.

DOLGENOS--Sally Ashley. Sally, known to her family as "Hawkeye," died of cancer on July 10, 2013 at age 78. She died at her own home, surrounded by loved ones. As a teenager in the Midwest, Sally accompanied her father on business trips to Manhattan and fell in love with the city. At age 19 she left home to work in New York at Life magazine in the 1950's "Mad Men" era- living at women's hotels like the Barbizon where gentlemen callers had to be checked out by the downstairs matron. On a blind date Sally met handsome young David Dolgenos and they quickly fell in love. Protestant Sally broke cultural barriers when, in 1956, she married David, a Jewish man, despite intense family objections. The couple moved to Pleasantville, NY, for life in the suburbs: four children born in under five years. Sally somehow managed to get the kids through school while participating in local amateur theater and, later, politics. She sang in The Music Man, contacted the dead in Blithe Spirit, and channeled Marilyn Monroe in her portrayal of Helen of Troy. In the 1960's, inspired by the women's movement, Sally returned to college, earning a BA from Sarah Lawrence College and a master's degree from Columbia University. She went back to theater at another level, performing in plays by Ibsen and Beckett. She studied with Gerda Lerner and Santha Rama Rau, and ran for County Legislator and Town Clerk. Throughout her life, Sally wrote: stories and poems, movie reviews for the local paper. Writing was a passion and an avocation for her. At age 42, Sally returned to live in New York City, the place she'd loved best since childhood. She never moved away again. Amicably divorced from David, she lived in her own book-filled apartment on the Upper West Side. She took her children and grandchildren to Broadway and introduced them to opera- she particularly loved Italian opera. In New York, Sally formed a company with best friend Judy Paine. She published a book: "Connecting: A Handbook for Housewives Returning to Paid Work" and appeared on the Today Show. The first book was followed by a biography of Franklin P. Adams and "The Devil's Cradle," a ripping supermarket paperback in which, among other things, a pack of wild dogs attacks a librarian. Sally used her literary skills to help others, teaching reading to illiterate adults in New York City as center director at Literacy Partners. Her children grew up and moved to California, Philadelphia and England, but Sally always had a home for them in New York with laughter and political talk late into the night. Her grandchildren adored her. She faced colon cancer at age 70 and beat it. She met with another form of abdominal cancer at age 78 and fought hard but couldn't defeat it again. Sally was a proud American patriot, great-granddaughter of radical congressman James M. Ashley I who wrote the 13th amendment to the Constitution-the amendment that freed the slaves. In that same spirit, Sally always took the part of the underrepresented, the disenfranchised, the weak and the sick and the lonely. She was a passionate advocate and had a generous spirit. One of Sally's last projects was a short video in which she portrayed the mother in "Psycho"- she saw the ridiculous even in infirmity and disease and we'll remember how she laughed. A memorial service will be held at 4pm on Tuesday, August 13, 2013, at Marshall Field, Sarah Lawrence College, Bronxville, NY. Goodbye to Sally, Mom, Hawkeye from her loving family. A fine life.

DRIER--Edward, 92, died July 25, in Delray Beach, FL. Ed came home from the war to his sweetheart Marilyn. She survives him after 67 years of marriage, along with sons, Kenneth and Jeffrey, and nieces, Linda and Carol Greenhouse and Barbara Ann Halpin. Predeceased by sweet Janet, a sorrow too deep for words. Uncle Ed, you did your job and you've earned your rest.

DENTI--Dawn Anderson, 49, passed away peacefully at home surrounded by the ones she laughed with, lived for and loved on July 24, 2013. Beloved daughter of Doris and the late David R. Anderson. Loving and devoted mother of Alexandria, Joseph and Victoria. Caring sister of Dale Anderson (Eamon) Kelly and David. Cherished friend to many. Beautiful on the inside and out, Dawn truly touched the lives of everyone she knew. She was most recognized for her dedication to raising her children and her avid love of sports. Dawn taught us many life lessons; most importantly, that quitting is NEVER an option. Visiting hours will be held at David J. Hodder & Son, 899 McLean Ave., Yonkers on Sunday, July 28 from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Religious services will be held at the funeral home on Monday, July 29 at 10am with interment to follow at Kensico Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to: Hospice Westchester Putnam Valley (designated for VNA Home Health Services) or LUNGevity.

De MARIA--Walter. It is with great sadness that Gagosian Gallery acknowledges the death of Walter De Maria on July 25, 2013. For more than five decades, De Maria has been a singular figure whose rigorous and visionary works, including the permanent installations The Lightning Field (New Mexico, 1977), The New York Earth Room (New York, 1977), The Vertical Earth Kilometer (Kassel, Germany, 1977), and The Broken Kilometer (New York, 1979), have changed the very parameters of art history. Combining precise geometry with vast scale, his remarkable installations gave fresh impact and new meaning to our experience of looking at art, while enhancing and expanding our appreciation of the world around us. Remembering De Maria, Larry Gagosian said, "Walter and I worked together for more than twenty-five years. He was an acutely insightful artist whose integrity was unquestionable. His sense of space, and the meticulous yet intuitive way in which he approached art making, were unparalleled. I was proud to exhibit his work, and to count him as a friend." We extend our deepest condolences to Walter De Maria's family and friends.

CLAY--Esther Tierney. "Hot Tea Grandma". Born in Corofin, Ireland April 1912, died July 2013, Chicago, IL. A dedicated nurse and volunteer at St. Francis Hospital, Evanston, IL for more than forty years. She is survived by her daughters Margaret and Nancy Clay, her son-in-law Silvio Dobry, her grandson Jason Clay Dobry, and his fiance Breheney O'Connell. She is loved and will be missed by all who knew her. If you wish, you may make a donation to your favorite charity in Esther's name.

Davis--Garry, died peacefully on July 24, 2013, in Burlington, VT. He is survived by two of his siblings, Virginia Wexler-Davis and Emery Davis, as well as his four children, Kristina, Troy, Athena and Kim, his grand-child, Emma Davis, and his former wife, Esther Peter-Davis. Born in Bar Harbor, ME to musician Hilda Emery and bandleader Meyer Davis on July 27, 1921, Davis was World Citizen #

CAUST--Leonard, 91, of Goldens Bridge, NY, passed away peacefully on July 27, 2013. He served in the army during WWII (102nd division) and attended Colby College and Harvard University (MBA '49). For many years he worked for Lever Bros. He was a fine chess player and a natural wit. He is survived by his loving wife, Ruth Dombrow, five daughters and their families, of whom he was very proud.

BERGIN--John F.,died of natural causes on July 19, 2013. Mr. Bergin was one of advertising's most influential creative leaders in the history of advertising. He began his career in 1950 as a copywriter at BBDO, New York. During his 23 years a that agency, he directed the creative work on Pepsi-Cola, Dodge, Campbell's Soup, The New York Times, ABC Television, Gillette, B.F. Goodrich and many others. Two of his many award-winning campaigns, "The Pepsi Generation", and "The Dodge Rebellion" were among BBD's most famous of the time. He then joined McCann-Erickson as Vice Chairman and Worldwide Director of the Coca-Cola account. His "Coke is it!" campaign ran in most of the 150 countries around the world in which the brand was sold. He was depended upon by clients and agencies for his creative genius and wrote hundreds of speeches during his career and today he is often referred to as The Real Mad Man. Bergin has served on the board of directors of the American Association of Advertising Agencies (AAAA) and the American Advertising Federation (AAF). He is a noted and most articulate spokesman on and for the advertising industry. Born in New Haven, CT 1924, Bergin is a graduate of Amherst College. He served in the Air Force during World War II. Bergin is predeceased by his wife of more than 50 years Constance Bergin, and his son Frank Gilbert Bergin, he is the father of five children, Conni Carrozelli, Barbara Read, Katherine Dreyer and John F. Bergin Jr. He has 10 grandchildren.

BRUEGGEMANN--Lillian S.,on July 25, 2013. Life-long resident of Northport, LI. Retired executive secretary to five superintendents and 15 year board member of the Northport/East Northport School District. Co-founder of the Brueggemann Funeral Home, Inc. Avid cook, baker, seamstress and artist; she amazed all those she met with her talents and youthful energy. Beloved wife of the late Robert E. Brueggemann. Loving mother of David Brueggemann and his wife Linda, Dennis Brueggemann and his wife Ann, Douglas Brueggemann and his wife Martha and the late Dana Mark Brueggemann. Cherished grandmother of Danny Brueggemann, Dianna (Anthony) Brueggemann-LoBue, Robert (Carmela Candiloro) Brueggemann, Peter (Lana Cohen) Brueggemann, Christopher (Lyndsay Fox) Brueggemann, Eric (Michelle) Antonello, Dustin (Sarah) Antonello and Michael (Julie Spangle) Antonello. Adored great-grandmother to Izabella Marie LoBue. Dear sister of Georgianna Schroeder and the late Marion Conklin and the late Henry Straub. Visiting Tuesday and Wednesday 2-4pm and 7-9pm at the Brueggemann Funeral Home, 522 Larkfield Road, East Northport, LI. Funeral Service Thursday, 11am at St Paul's Lutheran Church, 120 Vernon Valley Road, East Northport. Interment Genola Rural Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Lillian S. Brueggemann Educational Scholarship Fund, c/o The Brueggemann Funeral Home, 522 Larkfield Road, East Northport, NY 11731 would be greatly appreciated. www.BFHLI.com

BARTRAM--Jeannette Gardner Norton. Beloved wife, mother, and grandmother, 84, of Bloomfield, CT, and Glenora, NY, on July 24, 2013. Vassar College, Class of 1950. She is survived by her husband of 60 years, Maynard C. Bartram; their children, Carey Meltzer (Harland), Peter Bartram, Sarah Noyes (Jon), and Amy Bartram; and grand- children Amory, Nathaniel, Jacob, and Abigail. Private burial in Sharon, CT, with a memorial service at a later date. Memorial gifts to Vassar College or First Congregational Church, Bloomfield, CT.

BATES--Leo James, age 69, beloved husband of Ellen Arch Levinson Bates, of Westport, CT passed away on July 11, 2013 in Norwalk Hospital. From Pittsburgh, PA, Leo resided in New York City, Brooklyn, and Hastings before moving to Westport in 2007. Leo Studied art at Carnegie Mellon University, Class of 1966, and attended Yale's Summer Studies program. A painter's painter, Leo's work was well recognized by other artists of his generation. His "trompe l'oeil" technique sometimes employed the philosophical underpinnings of mathematical fractals, but are breathtakingly visual. He won the Creative Artist Public Service Award by the New York State Council of Arts in 1973. His artwork was shown at the Whitney Museum Art Resources Center, the Albright Knox Art Gallery and the Brooklyn Museum.

ASSAEL--DR. IRVING, OD of Walnut Creek, CA formerly of Woodmere, NY passed bravely July 20, 2013 with his beloved wife Marilyn and children at his side. His unconditional love gave us wisdom and faith. Dearest Pasha- you are in Hashem's embrace. May Irving's name always be for a blessing. Condolences at ma24good@aol.com

ARONSON--Dr. Miriam K.,73, Dr. Miriam K. Aronson, 73, of Old Tappan, died July 25, 2013, with her family by her side. Dr. Aronson was a nationally renowned social gerontologist, and a founder of the National Alzheimer's Association. Dr. Aronson's career was dedicated to guiding elderly individuals, their families and eldercare facilities through the caregiving process. She led a landmark ten-year study on aging and dementia, and was a Clinical Associate Professor at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, a Fellow of the Gerontological Society of America and a distinguished member of numerous other organizations. She was honored with numerous awards including the Genesis Award from the National Alzheimer's Association, New Jersey Caregiver of the Year and the Women in Science & Health Care. Dr. Aronson lectured locally, nationally and internationally, and taught at several universities. Her many writings included the books Understanding Alzheimer's Disease: A Handbook for Families and the award winning Aging Parents, Aging Children: How to Stay Sane and Survive. She also authored a chapter on Depression and one on Family Caregiving in the Handbook of Geriatric Care Management. She was a proud graduate of Columbia University, receiving her undergraduate degree from Barnard, and graduate degrees from Teachers College. But of all of her accomplishments, Dr. Aronson's most prized title was Grandma! She was the adoring grandmother of Jake, Max, Samantha, Danny, Elyssa, Scarlett and Ryan. With them she shared her passions for food, books, art and travel. In them her legacy of caring, nurturing and service will live on. Dr. Aronson is also survived by sons, Eric (Dina), Andrew (Robin) and Elliott (Shannon); her sister Ellen (Edwin) Weiss, her niece, nephews, cousins and friends; and countless colleagues, caregivers and families whose lives she touched. She will never be forgotten. Funeral services will be Sunday, July 28, at 11am, Robert Schoem Menorah Chapel in Paramus, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, we suggest donations in honor of Dr. Aronson to the Alzheimer's Association or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center at mskcc. convio.net/goto/miriamaronson as her way to support her beloved granddaughter Scarlett who is battling cancer.

ANTONOFF--Betty Lazarus, 77, of Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Beloved wife of Richard F. Antonoff (deceased). Survived by her daughter Joanne Wineman Little, son-in-law Donald Little, stepdaughter Andrea Antonoff, four grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Memorial services to be held in West Palm Beach and Cincinnati. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Lung Association or the Loggerhead Marinelife Center.

SZILARD--Paul, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater celebrates the life of Paul Szilard (1912-2013), our international impresario for over 40 years. A friend to Alvin Ailey and a spirited champion of the Ailey organization, he will be greatly missed by us all. Joan H. Weill, Chairman; Robert Battle, Artistic Director; Masazumi Chaya, Associate Artistic Director; Judith Jamison, Artistic Director Emerita

Stade--Dorothy, age 78, passed away on July 19, 2013, in her home. The daughter of Elmer and Laura Fletcher, she was born in Floral Park, New York. Dolly graduated as the valedictorian of Sewanhaka High School and received her BA in English from St. Lawrence University, graduating Summa Cum Laude and Phi Beta Kappa. She was the devoted wife to George Stade and the loving mother to four children: Bjorn (Barry), Eric, Nancy and Kirsten. She is also survived by her sister, Nancy Graham. She lit the lives of those she loved with her fierce intelligence, biting wit, and endless generosity and creativity. Dorothy's family is holding a private service on August 1, at Francis Collins Funeral Home. Her ashes will be interred at the Congressional Cemetery in Washington D.C.

SZILARD--Paul. With great sorrow, we note the passing of our wonderful Board of Trustees member, advocate and benefactor. The Martha Graham Dance Company, the staff of The Martha Graham Center and all their supporters remember his enthusiasm for the work and his presentation of the Company in European theaters and in New York City. We will miss him. LaRue Allen, Executive Director Janet Eilber, Artistic Director
SROLE--Esther, died peacefully at the age of 92 on July 22. Beloved by five generations. Her star shone brightly with music guiding her path. Contributions may be made to the Phelps Hospital Hospice.

SIEGFRIED--Peter C. 1943-2013, 70, a true New Yorker, passed away on the morning of July 23rd. Peter is survived by his wife, Mary, his children, Melissa and Andrew, his brother, Paul as well as countless friends and colleagues all of whom he cherished. He was a scholar and a traveler. He was a lover of animals, conversation and debate. Peter was an epic compiler of lists, documents, files, receipts and above all, of people. His immense talent for worrying was exceeded only by his generosity and devotion to his family and friends. He will be remembered by all for his thin attempts at projecting a gruff exterior that could barely contain one of the sweetest men on earth. There will be a memorial at a later date.

RUBIN--William. A Patriarch of the Rubin/Abrams clan died peacefully at home at the age of 84- six months to the day after his beloved wife Audrey passed. A loving, generous, kind soul. Father to Jim, Jane, John and his rescue dog George. Grandfather to Woody, Marci, Tessa and Will. Great-grandpa to Noah and Toby. Memorial service to honor his life and many achievements to be held Saturday, August 17th at 1pm at 6 Branch Brook Rd. White Plains 10605.

ROTHENBERG--Selma (Ernstoff), on July 27, 2013 at age 95. Beloved wife of the late Jack Ernstoff and the late Herman Rothenberg, devoted mother of Robert, Barry and Steven. Ernstoff and step-mother of Michael Rothenberg, loving grandmother and great-grandmother, dear sister of Leanore Schamberg. Funeral service: Monday, July 29, at 11:30am, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel Amsterdam Avenue and 91st Street.
KAUFMAN--Stanley L. "Nos te amamos muito" Always in our hearts... Andrew, Nane and Miles

ITZKOWITZ--Murray. With profound sorrow, the board, staff and clients of The Bridge mourn the death of Murray Itzkowitz, our treasured Executive Director Emeritus. For 31 years Murray worked to fulfill his vision of providing compassionate care and services so that men and women with serious mental illness could live productive, meaningful lives in the community. HEMINWAY--Willard "Spike" Sands Heminway, Jr.,a long-time resident of Greenwich, CT, died peacefully Wednesday, July 24th, at his summer home in Kennebunkport, ME, at the age of 79. A resident of Hobe Sound, FL, Mr. Heminway had many passions but especially loved his family; golf and tennis; and reading. Born August 3, 1933, in Rye, NY, Mr. Heminway graduated in 1951 from The Taft School in Watertown, CT, and in 1955 from Middlebury College in Middlebury, Vermont. He served in the US Army, stationed mostly in Alaska. He was President of Heminway & Bartlett Manufacturing Company, which had been in his family for five generations. He was past president of the Round Hill Club in Greenwich, CT, and past president of the United States Senior's Golf Association. He was well known for wearing colorful socks, a fashion trend adopted by his great friend, George H.W. Bush. The 41st president, when asked by a reporter about why he wore such outlandish socks, credited his good friend Spike for enhancing and broadening his sock portfolio. Mr. Heminway is survived by his wife of 50 years, Betsy Rowland Heminway; his daughter Alexandra Anderson and her husband John of Washington, DC; his beloved grandchildren, Jay and Bentley Anderson; his sister Betsy Dineen of Rye, NY, and many friends. A memorial service will be held at 4:30pm November 7th at the Jupiter Island Chapel in Hobe Sound, FL. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the Hospice of Southern Maine; The Boys and Girls Club of Greenwich, CT; or the Jupiter Island Clinic in Hobe Sound, FL. To send a condolence to the Heminway Family, visit bibberfuneral.com.

FOX--Margery Quitzau, of West Palm Beach, Florida died on Sunday, July 21st at age 85. She wrote the following for her Smith College Class of 1949 50th reunion. "Married Frederick Fox in 1954, had two children, Peter and Hugh and lived happily ever after. Did manage to get through graduate school PhD Social Anthropology 1973 NYU. after working with Fred in the theatre for about 10 years. Taught Anthropology and Sociology at Fairleigh Dickinson for about 20 years. Lots of research into women's friendship. Co-directed Women's Center and founded women's studies Minor. Now finishing musical with college setting about popular social issues. Full circle at last." Dr. Fox is survived by her sons Peter Fox of Matawan NJ, Hugh Fox of West Palm Beach Fl, stepson Frederick Fox Jr. of Ridgewood NJ, stepdaughter Deborah Fox Miller of New York, NY and six grandchildren. She will be missed for her intellect, wit and humor by all whom she touched during her wonderful life. A memorial service will be held in Englewood, NJ in September.

DENTI--Dawn Anderson, 49, passed away peacefully at home surrounded by the ones she laughed with, lived for and loved on July 24, 2013. Beloved daughter of Doris and the late David R. Anderson. Loving and devoted mother of Alexandria, Joseph and Victoria. Caring sister of Dale Anderson (Eamon) Kelly and David. Cherished friend to many. Beautiful on the inside and out, Dawn truly touched the lives of everyone she knew. She was most recognized for her dedication to raising her children and her avid love of sports. Dawn taught us many life lessons; most importantly, that quitting is NEVER an option. Visiting hours will be held at David J. Hodder & Son, 899 McLean Ave., Yonkers on Sunday, July 28 from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Religious services will be held at the funeral home on Monday, July 29 at 10am with interment to follow at Kensico Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to: Hospice Westchester Putnam Valley (designated for VNA Home Health Services) or LUNGevity.

De MARIA--Walter. It is with great sadness that Gagosian Gallery acknowledges the death of Walter De Maria on July 25, 2013. For more than five decades, De Maria has been a singular figure whose rigorous and visionary works, including the permanent installations The Lightning Field (New Mexico, 1977), The New York Earth Room (New York, 1977), The Vertical Earth Kilometer (Kassel, Germany, 1977), and The Broken Kilometer (New York, 1979), have changed the very parameters of art history. Combining precise geometry with vast scale, his remarkable installations gave fresh impact and new meaning to our experience of looking at art, while enhancing and expanding our appreciation of the world around us. Remembering De Maria, Larry Gagosian said, "Walter and I worked together for more than twenty-five years. He was an acutely insightful artist whose integrity was unquestionable. His sense of space, and the meticulous yet intuitive way in which he approached art making, were unparalleled. I was proud to exhibit his work, and to count him as a friend." We extend our deepest condolences to Walter De Maria's family and friends.

SCHEUER--Thomas (Tom), age 85, of Greenwich, CT, passed away on July 27, 2013. Beloved husband and love of his life of Ann Fimmano Scheuer, he will be greatly missed by his brothers Robert (Gloria, decreased) and James (Ruth); his children Todd (Luciana), Gwenn [Bill] and Chris (Noz); and stepchildren Carl (Ande), Rindy (David, deceased) and Jerry [Mary]; and his eleven grandchildren. Tom was one-of-kind, whose love of family and friends was never ending. He lived a vibrant and diverse life, driven and defined by his passion for intellectual growth and his personal ethical code. A graduate of Columbia Law School in 1953, he deeply enjoyed practicing law well into the last years of his life, most recently as Chief Council of Louis Dreyfus Commodities. He also served as Chairman of the National Committee for Effective Congress, as an advisor to the Columbia Law School Association and president of their Board of Visitors, and as the chair of the Ethical Culture Fieldston School. Throughout his life, Tom was an active athlete. He was an avid horseman for many years and a dedicated cyclist, runner, swimmer and skier. Tom was a wonderful man who will always be remembered for his love of life, generosity, intellect and eloquent command of the written and spoken word. A private celebration to honor Tom's life will be held at a later date.

THOMAS--Richard, known affectionately as Dick, master ballet teacher, mentor, willful iconoclast, sublimely human and adored by umpteen generations of dancers, is said to have died on Saturday morning July 27. For those of us who knew him, who were privileged to brush against his vital and provocative nature, he lives on! The ripples from his kindness, wisdom, sensibility and wit endure. So too, his divine lickety-split petit allegros, even his excesses, which were excessive, his passion for dancing and dancers, and his knowledge of ballet technique combined with his intellect and his gift for cajolery to impart the lesson to we who were eager, so eager. He lives forever within us. He has become a part of who we are. Indelible. It seems only appropriate that Dick should have the last word, as was his wont and dessert deserved. Accordingly: in ballet class, half a century plus ago, though it seems like yesterday, at the conclusion of the Grand Allegro, he opined to the class and to the Gods if they would only listen and learn "the cow jumped over the moon but he was still a cow". Eliot Feld, Christine Sarry, Daniel Levans, we three his students, and all at Ballet Tech, past, present and future. With love.

PLATOVSKY--Leo (Arye Leib), 83, passed away suddenly July 28, 2013 and was buried in Benei Brak, Israel. He was born in Poneviz where his father, Rabbi Binyamin Platovsky was Rabbi Kahanaman's best friend and chevrusa. The Platovsky family were exiled to Siberia during the War years and settled in the Upper Westside in the 1950s. Leo was ordained at Yeshiva University by Rabbi Solovietchick in 1954. He was known for his love of family, Torah study, kindness, and charity. He is survived by his devoted wife Sara, children Etty Burk (Robbie), David (Edit) and Jonathan (Sheri) and twelve grandchildren. He will be missed by all. The family is sitting Shiva in Israel.
