TOBIN--Bernard, on July 29, 2013. Beloved husband of Evelyn of 67 years, loving father of Robin and Maxine. Cherished grandfather of Andy, Logan, and Michael. Devoted to his family and community. Services: 9:30am this Thursday, August 1, 2013 at Riverside Nassau North Chapels. www.riverside nassaunorthchapels.com

THOMAS--Richard, known affectionately as Dick, master ballet teacher, mentor, willful iconoclast, sublimely human and adored by umpteen generations of dancers, is said to have died on Saturday morning July 27. For those of us who knew him, who were privileged to brush against his vital and provocative nature, he lives on! The ripples from his kindness, wisdom, sensibility and wit endure. So too, his divine lickety-split petit allegros, even his excesses, which were excessive, his passion for dancing and dancers, and his knowledge of ballet technique combined with his intellect and his gift for cajolery to impart the lesson to we who were eager, so eager. He lives forever within us. He has become a part of who we are. Indelible. It seems only appropriate that Dick should have the last word, as was his wont and dessert deserved. Accordingly: in ballet class, half a century plus ago, though it seems like yesterday, at the conclusion of the Grand Allegro, he opined to the class and to the Gods if they would only listen and learn "the cow jumped over the moon but he was still a cow". Eliot Feld, Christine Sarry, Daniel Levans, we three his students, and all at Ballet Tech, past, present and future. With love.

SCHOENFELD--Dotty, passed away at home on July 29, 2013 at age 98. She was the beloved wife of the late Fred Schoenfeld. Like many of her generation she eventually journeyed to New York after fleeing Europe. She is survived by her son, Peter and daughter-in-law, Charlotte. She was adored by her granddaughters, Caroline Greenwald and Jaclyn Boulan and rejoiced in the presence of her great-grandchildren, Vanessa and Charlie Greenwald and Daniel and Madeline Boulan. Funeral service will be private.

SCHEUER--Thomas (Tom). Purchase College and members of the Purchase College Foundation Board of Trustees and The Performing Arts Center extend their heartfelt condolences to Ann Scheuer and family. Tom will be remembered for his devotion to Ann, his intellect and never ending curiosity and support of the College. We will miss his presence at our events.

SCHEUER--Thomas (Tom), age 85, of Greenwich, CT, passed away on July 27, 2013. Beloved husband and love of his life of Ann Fimmano Scheuer, he will be greatly missed by his brothers Robert (Gloria, decreased) and James (Ruth); his children Todd (Luciana), Gwenn [Bill] and Chris (Noz); and stepchildren Carl (Ande), Rindy (David, deceased) and Jerry [Mary]; and his eleven grandchildren. Tom was one-of-kind, whose love of family and friends was never ending. He lived a vibrant and diverse life, driven and defined by his passion for intellectual growth and his personal ethical code. A graduate of Columbia Law School in 1953, he deeply enjoyed practicing law well into the last years of his life, most recently as Chief Council of Louis Dreyfus Commodities. He also served as Chairman of the National Committee for Effective Congress, as an advisor to the Columbia Law School Association and president of their Board of Visitors, and as the chair of the Ethical Culture Fieldston School. Throughout his life, Tom was an active athlete. He was an avid horseman for many years and a dedicated cyclist, runner, swimmer and skier. Tom was a wonderful man who will always be remembered for his love of life, generosity, intellect and eloquent command of the written and spoken word. A private celebration to honor Tom's life will be held at a later date.

ROSENBERGER--Walter. The New York Philharmonic mourns the passing, on July 27, of Walter Rosenberger, Principal Percussion, 197285, after joining in 1946. "Walter was a consummate professional: intelligent, pragmatic, quick-witted, and kind," said Associate Principal Percussion Daniel Druckman. "His smile, humor, and humanity stand out most in my mind. His disarming inclusivity made everyone feel comfortable, qualified, and worthy, and really brought out the best in all of us." We extend deepest condolences to his family.

QUINTO--Leon J.,on July 25, 2013. After a short illness. Son of the late Henry and Frieda. Life long New Yorker. Former "IBMer". Funeral Mass Friday, August 2, 2013, 10am at Blessed Sacrament RC Church, West 71st St. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery.

PLATOVSKY--Leo (Arye Leib), 83, passed away suddenly July 28, 2013 and was buried in Benei Brak, Israel. He was born in Poneviz where his father, Rabbi Binyamin Platovsky was Rabbi Kahanaman's best friend and chevrusa. The Platovsky family were exiled to Siberia during the War years and settled in the Upper Westside in the 1950s. Leo was ordained at Yeshiva University by Rabbi Solovietchick in 1954. He was known for his love of family, Torah study, kindness, and charity. He is survived by his devoted wife Sara, children Etty Burk (Robbie), David (Edit) and Jonathan (Sheri) and twelve grandchildren. He will be missed by all. The family is sitting Shiva in Israel.

LIPSHIE--Norman, born July 11, 1923, died July 29, 2013. Devoted husband of Geraldine (deceased). Father of Beth, Greg, Amy, Tamara and Cara. Grandfather of Jo, Emily, Lyla, Aaron, Melissa, William, Madeleine and Claire. Private family graveside service.

LEBOUTILLIER--Pamela Tower. of Old Westbury, NY, died at the age of 91 on July 16 after a two-year illness. The most loving, dedicated and self-sacrificing mother of Timothy J. Secor, Mimi Secor, Nicholas T. Secor, Susan Secor Humes, John LeBoutillier and Pamela LeBoutillier Miles, she was a devoted wife to her late husband, Thomas LeBoutillier, and a loyal sister to Whitney Tower, Flora Biddle and Leverett S. Miller. She was the indefatigable leader of a huge and disparate family. She adored her mother, Flora Whitney Miller, and valued and cared for all her nieces, nephews, cousins, Godchildren and friends as well as her staff and pets and never thought of herself. Services were held at Church of the Advent in Westbury, July 19.

JOHNSON--F. Coit II, educator, died July 26 in Lawrenceville, NJ. Headmaster of the Little Red School House and Elizabeth Irwin H. S. in NYC, and subsequently The Foxcroft School, Middleburg, VA. Known for flair on the tennis court and dance floor and for intellectual intensity, Coit had an abiding connection to the works of CG Jung and loved art, literature and music. He was a member of the choir of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, NYC of which he was a trustee. A graduate of Groton School, Princeton and Columbia Universities, he served as a Lieutenant in the U. S. Army, and as a founding member of the Wynant Clayton Volunteers. Born January 2, 1930 to the late Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Holmes Johnson of Locust Valley, NY he is survived by his beloved wife, Holly Harrison Johnson, sons, Timothy and Christian Johnson, daughters, Sarah Johnson Doenmez, Rebecca Johnson Dibb, Priscilla Johnson Bender, Holly-Katharine Johnson, nine grandchildren, and his beloved nieces, nephews, and sisters Eunice Winslow and Priscilla McMillan, all of whom will greatly miss his gracious and effervescent spirit.

KATCHEN--Seymour Zachary (1923-2013), died July 29 at home with his loving family by his side. He is survived by Doreen, his wife of 65 years. Father to Gail, Tricia and Brad. Proud grandfather to Juliet Margot, Stacy, Adam and Rachel. Funeral services will be at 11am July 31st at Gutterman's Funeral Home in Woodbury, NY.

HOLZER--William. Lazard mourns the passing of our colleague and friend William (Willy) Holzer. A pioneer in thematic investing, he was a Portfolio Manager/Analyst for Global Thematic Equities for the past 30 years, the last 10 with Lazard Asset Management. His investment vision and insights, sense of humor, warmth and personality will be sorely missed. Our profound sympathies are with his family, friends and colleagues during this difficult time.

FLANIGAN--Peter M. June 21, 1923 - July 29, 2013. Mr. Flanigan was a Navy carrier pilot in World War II. He graduated Summa Cum Laude from Princeton University in 1947 and joined Dillon, Read & Co. Inc. in the fall of that year. His tenure at Dillon Read was interrupted in 1949 to serve as an economic analyst for the Economic Reconstruction Administration in Britain for two years, returning thereafter to Dillon Read. In 1960 Mr. Flanigan served as Executive Director of Volunteers for the Nixon-Lodge Presidential campaign and in 1968 as Deputy Campaign Manager of the Nixon campaign. In 1969 Mr. Flanigan left Dillon Read upon his appointment as Assistant to the President of the United States under President Nixon, with White House responsibility for domestic commercial and economic matters. In 1972 he was also appointed Director of the Council of International Economic Policy, with responsibility for development and coordination of the Administration's international economic policy. Mr. Flanigan returned to Dillon Read as Managing Director at the beginning of 1975 and continued in that capacity until December 1992. In 1984, Peter Flanigan and his wife adopted the second class in the "I Have a Dream" Program, subsequently becoming a Board Member of that program. In 1985, Mr. Flanigan founded The Student Sponsor Partners, a private voucher program which combines tuition support with one-on-one mentoring. S/SP has helped over 5,000 inner-city high school students. Based on comparative graduation rates and college attendance rates, this program has been a dramatic success. In 1987, he started the Patrons Program to encourage individuals to take responsibility for inner-city Catholic grammar schools which were in danger of being closed for financial reasons. Mr. Flanigan was a Board member of St. Ann's School in Harlem, a small grammar school with 315 students. Upon his death, Mr. Flanigan was Board Member of American Federation for Children - Alliance for School Choice, a nation-wide organization to promote legislation to give parents the ability to send their children to the schools, public or private, of their choice. To research and implement new programs to improve education, Mr. Flanigan founded the Center for Education Innovation of The Manhattan Institute. He was a Board member of the Catholic University of America, and previous Chairman of the Board of Portsmouth Abbey School. Mr. Flanigan was also a member of the Board of Trustees of the John M. Olin Foundation, Inc. and a member of the Board of the Richard M. Nixon Library & Birthplace. In 1954, Mr. Flanigan married Brigid Snow, daughter of the legendary Carmel Snow who was founding editor of Harpers Bazaar, a position she held for 23 years, and grand niece of the equally legendary Bishop McQuade of Dublin, known to his flock as the Holy Terror. His wife, Brigid, passed away in 2006. Brigid and Peter's five children include Sister Louise Marie of the Sister Servants of the Eternal Word. His other children, Brigid, Tim, Megan and Bob are the parents of Peter's 16 grandchildren. Five years ago, Peter was blessed by his marriage to Dorothea von Oswald. He lived half of the year in Austria with Dorothea and her five daughters Maido, Theresa, Mariella, Sophie and Nina. The von Oswald family warmly embraced their new father and grandfather. Peter's great loves in life were his family, his Roman Catholic faith, and his country. Friends may visit at 220 Anderson Hill Road, Purchase, NY, from 4:30pm to 8pm on Sunday, August 4. A Mass of Christian Burial will be said at the Church of the Resurrection, 910 Boston Post Rd, Rye, NY, at 10am on Monday, August 5. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to the Student Sponsor Partners at www.SSPNYC.org.

DeROSA--Dr. Gerard, died in Malba, NY on July 30 at age 94. Beloved husband of Rose (deceased), father of Patrick, Rosemary Hays and Denise. Leaving four grandchildren (Jerry, Laurie, Matt, Julie), three great-grandchildren and sister Angela Fiordalisi. Jerry was born in Italy, graduated Manhattan College and Marquette University School of Dentistry. He was a US Naval officer during WWII and later practiced dentistry in Astoria, NY. Services are at Gleason Funeral Home, Whitestone and Mass is at Holy Trinity RC Church, Whitestone, NY on August 2, at 10:45am. Donations can be made to (alzfdn.org) or (www.holytrinityrcparish.org).

SHAFER--Dr. Nathaniel, 85, beloved husband of Eve passed away July 29, 2013. Cherished father to Robert and Jennifer, stepfather to Amy and Julie, proud grandfather of Cosette. He was born in Brooklyn, NY on December 28, 1927 to Jesse and Rebecca Shafer. He graduated from NYU School of Medicine in 1954 and served as Chief Cardiologist at Valley Forge Army Hospital, Pennsylvania between 1956 and 1960. This was followed by a long career in private practice of Internal Medicine in NYC until his retirement in 2012. Dr. Shafer was active with the New York County Medical Society, served as a consultant to the US Public Health Service and was affiliated with several NYC hospitals, including Beth Israel Hospital, Cabrini Medical Center and Lenox Hill Hospital. Among his numerous honors, he was appointed Honorary Co-Chairman of a Congressional Health Committee and honored by the Medical Society in the State of New York in recognition of 50 yrs devoted service to the public in the practice of medicine. His work ethic was greatly inspired by a lifelong commitment and dedication to his patients. Funeral Service 11:30am Friday, August 2, 2013 at Frank Campbell's, 81st and Madison Ave., NYC.

SCHECTMAN--Oscar (Ossie). The National Basketball Association mourns the loss and celebrates the life of Oscar "Ossie" Schectman, the player credited with scoring the first basket in NBA history, an original New York Knickerbocker and the team's first captain. Schectman passed away Tuesday, July 30. He was 94. On November 1, 1946, the 6-0 guard, who had signed with his hometown team in the fledgling Basketball Association of America (BAA) the predecessor to the NBA was on the court in Toronto for the tip off of the league's inaugural game between the Knickerbockers and Toronto Huskies. Moments after the tip, Schectman entered the history books, scoring the league's first basket on an underhand layup. He finished the game with 11 points in a 68-66 New York victory. Schectman appeared in 54 games for the Knicks in 1946-47, his lone season in the league. He averaged 8.1 points and ranked third overall with 2.0 assists per game. He began his professional basketball career in the American Basketball League (ABL), playing five seasons for the Philadelphia Sphas from 1941-46. Following his one-year stint in the BAA, Schectman returned to the ABL as a member of the Paterson Crescents. Born on May 30, 1919, in New Brunswick, NJ, Schectman starred at Brooklyn's Samuel J. Tilden High School and at Long Island University. At LIU, he was a member of the 1939 NIT championship team, and earned Converse First Team All-America honors in 1941, leading LIU to another NIT title. Schectman was inducted into the National Jewish Sports Hall of Fame in 1998 and the Long Island University Athletic Hall of Fame in 2001. The NBA family has lost a true pioneer and we send our condolences to the entire Schectman family. He is survived by his sister Sunny, sons Peter and Stu, sister-in-law Dorothy, daughters-in-law Rotha and Lauren, and grandchildren Imani and Alex, as well as several nieces and nephews. His wife Evelyn, with whom he was married 70 years, preceded him in death. Services will be held Friday at Schwartz Brothers Jeffer Memorial Chapel on 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, N.Y., 11375.

ROBOFF--Phyllis Fern Robinson, 88, on July 18. Loved for her spirited, tenacious, and forthright intelligence. Beautiful and beloved wife of the late Stanley, devoted mother of Gary, Sari, and Annie and sister to Grace, and loving grandmother of Mark and Daniel and mother-in-law to Farron and Joe. Born in Boston, Phyllis graduated from Girls Latin School and Simmons College. She was a steadfast, lifelong friend to many; an avid Red Sox fan; and a lover of music, art, and theater. She was a committed activist, campaigning for national and New York Democratic candidates, volunteering for women's reproductive health and other progressive advocacy and self-help organizations, and serving on the United Hospital Fund's City Hospital Visiting Committee. PRENTICE--William C.H.,Rhodes Scholar, distinguished professor and college president, died Sunday, July 28 in Schenectady, NY. His generosity, humor and wisdom will be deeply missed by all. Born in East Aurora, NY, 1915, son of Bryant H. Prentice and Susan (Dimmock) Prentice, he was a graduate of Swarthmore College with High Honors in 1937. He studied at Oxford University, before earning his M.A. and PhD in Psychology from Harvard University (42). Following war-time service for the clandestine National Defense Research Committee, early teaching posts included the University of Vermont, The College of William & Mary, and The Johns Hopkins University. He returned to Swarthmore College in 1947, serving as full professor, department chairman, and dean prior to service as president of Wheaton College, in Norton, MA from 1962-75. He was president and co-chair, of Bryant & Stratton Business Institutes from 1974-84. He was awarded honorary degrees from Swarthmore, Stonehill, Wheaton, and Hartwick colleges, and Southeastern Massachusetts University. He served on the Board Of Managers of Swarthmore College 1978-82 and was a Trustee at Hartwick College 1980-89; Citizens Scholarship Foundation of America 1979-83, and the College Entrance Examination Board (CEEB) 1970-74, and chairman 1972-74. He was a science advisor to Research to Prevent Blindness, contributing editor to the American Journal of Psychology, Guggenheim Fellow; Fellow of the American Psychological Association, and the author of numerous academic and scientific papers. Memberships included: Psychonomic Society, Eastern Psychological Association, United World Federalists, Phi Beta Kappa, Sigma Xi, Phi Kappa Psi, and the Harvard, Moorings, and Acoaxet Clubs. He was predeceased by his devoted wife and partner of 70 years, Elsie (Benton) Doty, and siblings Bryant H. Prentice Jr., and Susan S. (Dunbar, Cochran). Survivors include his brother, Colgate S. Prentice, of Medford Leas, NJ, children; Dorothy (Richard) Ziegler, of Rutland, VT, Susan (Richard) Brainard, of Niskayuna, NY, William C.H. Prentice, Jr., of Vero Beach, FL, Benton (Charissa) Prentice, of Providence, RI, eight grand, and eight great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the William C.H. and Elsie Prentice Faculty Fund at Wheaton College, Norton, MA. 02766 or a college scholarship of your choice.

SHAFER--Dr. Nathaniel, 85, beloved husband of Eve passed away July 29, 2013. Cherished father to Robert and Jennifer, stepfather to Amy and Julie, proud grandfather of Cosette. He was born in Brooklyn, NY on December 28, 1927 to Jesse and Rebecca Shafer. He graduated from NYU School of Medicine in 1954 and served as Chief Cardiologist at Valley Forge Army Hospital, Pennsylvania between 1956 and 1960. This was followed by a long career in private practice of Internal Medicine in NYC until his retirement in 2012. Dr. Shafer was active with the New York County Medical Society, served as a consultant to the US Public Health Service and was affiliated with several NYC hospitals, including Beth Israel Hospital, Cabrini Medical Center and Lenox Hill Hospital. Among his numerous honors, he was appointed Honorary Co-Chairman of a Congressional Health Committee and honored by the Medical Society in the State of New York in recognition of 50 yrs devoted service to the public in the practice of medicine. His work ethic was greatly inspired by a lifelong commitment and dedication to his patients. Funeral Service 11:30am Friday, August 2, 2013 at Frank Campbell's, 81st and Madison Ave., NYC.

Memorial contributions may be made to Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra or Walnut Hills High School Alumni Foundation.
SCHWARTZ--Dr. Eugene, died July 29th at age 92. Memorial tribute at 2:00pm Monday, August 5th, at Temple Emanuel, 150 Hicks Lane, Great Neck, NY 11024.

SCHEUER--Thomas (Tom). 85, of Greenwich, CT passed away on July 27, 2013. A celebration of his life will be held on Wednesday September 11, 2013 at 11am at the Greenwich Country Club, Greenwich, CT. In his memory please make donations to The Purchase College Foundation Scholarship Fund.

SCHECTMAN--Oscar (Ossie). The National Basketball Association mourns the loss and celebrates the life of Oscar "Ossie" Schectman, the player credited with scoring the first basket in NBA history, an original New York Knickerbocker and the team's first captain. Schectman passed away Tuesday, July 30. He was 94. On November 1, 1946, the 6-0 guard, who had signed with his hometown team in the fledgling Basketball Association of America (BAA) the predecessor to the NBA was on the court in Toronto for the tip off of the league's inaugural game between the Knickerbockers and Toronto Huskies. Moments after the tip, Schectman entered the history books, scoring the league's first basket on an underhand layup. He finished the game with 11 points in a 68-66 New York victory. Schectman appeared in 54 games for the Knicks in 1946-47, his lone season in the league. He averaged 8.1 points and ranked third overall with 2.0 assists per game. He began his professional basketball career in the American Basketball League (ABL), playing five seasons for the Philadelphia Sphas from 1941-46. Following his one-year stint in the BAA, Schectman returned to the ABL as a member of the Paterson Crescents. Born on May 30, 1919, in New Brunswick, NJ, Schectman starred at Brooklyn's Samuel J. Tilden High School and at Long Island University. At LIU, he was a member of the 1939 NIT championship team, and earned Converse First Team All-America honors in 1941, leading LIU to another NIT title. Schectman was inducted into the National Jewish Sports Hall of Fame in 1998 and the Long Island University Athletic Hall of Fame in 2001. The NBA family has lost a true pioneer and we send our condolences to the entire Schectman family. He is survived by his sister Sunny, sons Peter and Stu, sister-in-law Dorothy, daughters-in-law Rotha and Lauren, and grandchildren Imani and Alex, as well as several nieces and nephews. His wife Evelyn, with whom he was married 70 years, preceded him in death. Services will be held Friday at Schwartz Brothers Jeffer Memorial Chapel on 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, N.Y., 11375.

RAFF--Emanuel, passed away peacefully at 93 on July 17, 2013. Survived by his wife of 65 years, Ruth, his sons and daughters-in-law Joshua Raff and Michele Fillion and Hershel and Judy Raff and his grandchildren, Jonathan Raff, and Simone, Camille and Luc Fillion-Raff. Manny was a quiet, thoughtful and dignified person who lived a long and rich life. He and Ruth loved to read widely, travel extensively and attend the theater, dance, lectures and art exhibits. He served admirably in World War II as an infantryman in the South Pacific, and was awarded a Bronze Star and a Purple Heart, among other commendations. After graduating from Montclair State Teachers College, he earned his M.A. from Columbia University and did post-graduate work at the University of Pennsylvania before starting his teaching career. Manny was for many years Chairman of the English Department at Carle Place High School. In addition to service at several professional organizations, he was a long-time member and one of the founders of the local branch of the Workmen's Circle. After his retirement, he was an active and effective volunteer in his community. Per his wishes, no services were held. He will be greatly missed.

WIENER--Michael A. Dearest Mikey, It's hard to know how I go on without you. You mean so much to so many. People talk about you with affection, emotion and loss even now. I thank the angels for giving me so much time with you. Of course, it's never enough. Each day I say a loving prayer for you. I will always love you and you will always be mine. Love, Zee
SELIGMAN--Benjamin D. 7/10/04 - 8/03/07. In remembrance of your wisdom, strength and devotion. Your loving family.
McGUIRE--William A. Happy Birthday big brother. Here's to you ! Love, Sissy
GAINES--Nancy L. Remembering Nancy L. Gaines with love and gratitude, mother of Cathy, Wendy and Chris. Sidney

YANKS--Robert, 72, of Franklin Lakes, passed away on August 2, 2013, surrounded by his loving family. Devoted husband of 45 years to Marjorie (nee Schack), loving father of Nancy Pellegrini (Jeffrey) and David Yanks (Samantha), cherished grandfather of Sadie Yanks, Benjamin Pellegrini, and Abigail Pellegrini, dear brother of Laura Bench (Michael). Services will be 2pm, Monday, August 5, 2013 at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Route 4, Paramus, NJ.

SWARTE--Rae M.,really lived and loved life. She died peacefully at age 89 on July 30th. Rae is survived by her nephew Peter Schneider, his wife Sue, and Josh and Alix, her niece Elizabeth Lindenfeld, husband Michael, and Sharon, Rachel, and Sara, niece-in-law Dr. Terry Root, and great-nephew Adam Schneider, and great-niece Becca Cherba, and husband Mike and son Nikolai, as well as her lifelong friends Edie Mannella and Marge Caruso and god-daughter Marjorie Caruso. Her loyal friend and advisor, Meena Lachman watched out for her, and her caregiver Mariah Forbes, kept her spark glowing. As Director of Manhattan Technical Institute, Rae touched and changed many lives. And as a resident of Williams Island, she was part of a wonderful family. We'll always remember Rae's positive attitude, classy style, and bouncy step.

WEISS--Nathan M.,born October 18, 1927, life-long New Yorker, passed away at home after a long illness on July 31st. Esteemed lawyer, beloved friend and mentor to many major musical talents and others, his genius, wit and friendship will be greatly missed. May he rest in peace. Services at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (91st St.), on Sunday, August 4th, at 11am.

SELONICK--Peggy. Died peacefully at home July 30th after a long illness. Loving wife of the late James B. Selonick, mother of Ellen and David Berick, Jamie and Andrea Selonick and Bill Selonick and Sona Wang, grandmother of Rebecca (Lois), Sam, Julia, Rachel, Hannah, Anna and Lillian. Memorial contributions may be made to Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra or Walnut Hills High School Alumni Foundation.

SACKS--Larry. Dr. Larry Sacks died suddenly on July 23 in Portland, Oregon. He was a devoted father and a dedicated psychiatrist. He is survived by his daughter Lita; parents George and Harriet; and brothers Steven and Ken. Donations can be made to Big Brothers Big Sisters Northwest. Please send remembrances to sacksmemorial@gmail.com.

LOMBARDO--Joseph L. (Joe), 74, of Brooklyn, NY on August 1, 2013. Loving and faithful husband of 46 years to Linda (nee Lambruschi). Devoted father to Daniella Sarkis (James) and Christina Fraser (David). Cherished grandfather of Harry, Stella, and Delilah. Chief Market Relations Officer, Senior Advisor and Consultant for 52 years at AON Risk Solutions. Member of the Board of Directors of the Spencer Educational Foundation, active member of Columbus Citizens Foundation, St. Vincent's Services, Metropolitan Opera Association, The Humane Society, and The Smithsonian Foundation. In June, Joe was the recipient of a Lifetime Achievement Award for his many years of service to the UJA- Federation's General Insurance Division. Visiting Friday from 7-9pm and Saturday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11209. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 9:45am at St. Anselm R.C. Church, 356 82nd Street, Brooklyn, NY 11209. Burial to follow in Green-Wood Cemetery. Donations to the UJA-Federation of New York. Donations can be made online at www.ujafedny.org/ honor-someone.
FURMAN--Jonathon. On August 2, 2013. Brave. Loving. Missed and mourned by family and friends. Service graveside Sunday 11am, Mount Ararat Cemetery.

FRIEDMAN--Robert B.,of Woodbury, NY passed away on July 31st at the age of 74. Beloved husband of Sandy, adored father of Jane, doting grandfather of Hannah and cherished father-in-law of Dennis. A graduate of Woodmere Academy and the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania. Managing partner of the Inn at Middletown and the Nathan Hale Inn, both in Connecticut. Board member of the Good Speed Opera House. Passionate collector of baseball memorabilia. Memorial service will be held on Sunday, August 4th at 2pm at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY.

DEMENY--Margaret Kelemen, passed away on August 1, 2013. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. She is survived by her daughter Marian, son-in-law Mark, grandchildren Elizabeth and Daniel, grandson-in-law Joshua, great-grandson Aryeh. A Holocaust survivor earning a PhD in Hungary during the war, she was a researcher and faculty member at Mt. Sinai Hospital and NYU Medical Center before retiring to help raise her grandchildren. She was a wonderful person and will be sorely missed. Funeral service Sunday 11:15 at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

Davis--Garry, died peacefully on July 24, 2013, in Burlington, VT. He is survived by two of his siblings, Virginia Wexler-Davis and Emery Davis, as well as his four children, Kristina, Troy, Athena and Kim, his grand-child, Emma Davis, and his former wife, Esther Peter-Davis. Born in Bar Harbor, ME to musician Hilda Emery and bandleader Meyer Davis on July 27, 1921, Davis was World Citizen #

ACS--George. The Mount Sinai Medical Center is deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and colleague George Acs, MD, PhD, Professor Emeritus in the Department of Biochemistry. Dr. Acs was an accomplished scientist who published seminal papers on topics such as the link between transfer RNA and amino acids, and the replication of the Hepatitis B virus. The Mount Sinai community extends heartfelt condolences to his wife Hedda Acs, MD, and his family. His incisive mind, humor, and dignity will be remembered. Peter W. May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, The Mount Sinai Medical Center; Kenneth L. Davis, MD, President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Medical Center; and Dennis S. Charney, MD, Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and Executive Vice President for Academic Affairs at The Mount Sinai Medical Center.

YANKS--Robert, 72, of Franklin Lakes, passed away on August 2, 2013, surrounded by his loving family. Devoted husband of 45 years to Marjorie (nee Schack), loving father of Nancy Pellegrini (Jeffrey) and David Yanks (Samantha), cherished grandfather of Sadie Yanks, Benjamin Pellegrini, and Abigail Pellegrini, dear brother of Laura Bench (Michael). WITMEYER--John J.,III. Born in New Orleans, LA on December 18, 1946, died at his home in New York City after a year- long battle with cancer. He was the son of John J. Witmeyer Jr. (a decorated World War II veteran) and Thais Witmeyer. He is survived by his father, three brothers, Michael, Kurt and Eric, and two nephews, Michael Jr. and Robert, as well as a number of cousins and grand nieces and nephews. Mr. Witmeyer graduated from Tulane University in 1968 with a Bachelors of Science degree, and after graduating from Duke University Law School in 1971, he began practicing law in New York City. On June 1, 1976, Mr. Witmeyer founded the law firm of Ford Marrin Esposito Witmeyer & Gleser, LLP. He continued to practice law there until the day of his death. A remarkable lawyer with incredible energy, Mr. Witmeyer was very successful representing his clients during the course of his career. But perhaps, the professional accomplishment of which he was most proud of was his mentoring of many young lawyers, who themselves are now very successful and remember him fondly and call him friend. Mr. Witmeyer also served in the U.S. Army and at the time of his retirement had attained the rank of Colonel. He served in leadership positions in both professional and philanthropic organizations, which include the Gregorian University Foundation, Tulane College Dean's Colloquium Endowment Fund, the Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulchre (Eastern Lieutenancy), and Cristo Rey New York High School- Board of Trustees. Visitation will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue (81st St.), Monday, 2-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral mass will be Tuesday at the Holy Trinity RC Church at 213 West 82nd Street at 10am. The family requests donations in John's memory to: Wounded Warrior Project.

WEISS--Nathan M. October 18, 1927 - July 31, 2013. Esteemed lawyer, beloved friend and mentor to many major musical talents and others, one-time business partner of Brian Epstein, Nat was a man of startling wisdom, knowledge, sophistication and charm. He was devoted to living in the present while still maintaining his friendships from earlier years. He will be remembered for his exceptional wit, genius, integrity and willingness to help - always. He was a game-changer - offering opportunities, support and counsel to friends, family and colleagues. Nat was a graduate of Hobart College and the University of Virginia Law School, where he enjoyed some of the happiest days of his life. Loving son of Hyman and Gertrude (Rosensaft), loving brother of Donald (deceased), he is survived by two nieces, two adopted sons and many cherished life-long friends. He will be greatly missed. May he rest in peace. Services at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (91st St.), Sunday, August 4th at 11am. A memorial service will be planned for the fall.

SIMON--Martha N. age 72, died at home in Setauket, NY on July 18, 2013, after long illness. She was born in New York City, December 31, 1940, and raised in Ridgewood, NJ. She spent most of her professional life in the Biology Department of Brookhaven National Lab (BNL), after obtaining degrees from Radcliffe College (A.B., Chemistry, 1962) and Cornell University (Ph.D., Chemistry, 1968), followed by a post-doc at the California Institute of Technology. She was co-author of an important paper that described a general method for the visualization of DNA by electron microscopy (1971). She continued throughout her career to work productively on a variety of topics in molecular biology, and her later years were spent using the Scanning Transmission Electron Microscope at BNL. She married Michal Simon (1963, divorced 1980) and Alan H. Rosenberg (1981), who survives her. She is also survived by her brother, James H. Nichols, Jr., of La Canada-Flintridge, CA and by her son, Daniel W. Simon, of Locust Valley, NY and his wife, Mary Louise (Valentine) Simon, and three grandchildren, Katherine (age 11), Clare (age 8), and Thomas (age 3). Martha read widely and had a deep appreciation of music and literature. She was a fine swimmer, ran half-marathons when she was in her 40's, liked to hike (often in the White Mountains of New Hampshire), and loved to 'putter around' the house and yard. She entertained all with her keen sense of humor. Martha was a member of many organizations devoted to health and education in this country and abroad. There was a gathering of family and friends in her honor at home. Alan Rosenberg Daniel Simon

RAFF--Emanuel, passed away peacefully at 93 on July 17, 2013. Survived by his wife of 65 years, Ruth, his sons and daughters-in-law Joshua Raff and Michele Fillion and Hershel and Judy Raff and his grandchildren, Jonathan Raff, and Simone, Camille and Luc Fillion-Raff. Manny was a quiet, thoughtful and dignified person who lived a long and rich life. He and Ruth loved to read widely, travel extensively and attend the theater, dance, lectures and art exhibits. He served admirably in World War II as an infantryman in the South Pacific, and was awarded a Bronze Star and a Purple Heart, among other commendations. After graduating from Montclair State Teachers College, he earned his M.A. from Columbia University and did post-graduate work at the University of Pennsylvania before starting his teaching career. Manny was for many years Chairman of the English Department at Carle Place High School. In addition to service at several professional organizations, he was a long-time member and one of the founders of the local branch of the Workmen's Circle. After his retirement, he was an active and effective volunteer in his community. Per his wishes, no services were held. He will be greatly missed.

PRENTICE--William C.H.,Rhodes Scholar, distinguished professor and college president, died Sunday, July 28 in Schenectady, NY. His generosity, humor and wisdom will be deeply missed by all. Born in East Aurora, NY, 1915, son of Bryant H. Prentice and Susan (Dimmock) Prentice, he was a graduate of Swarthmore College with High Honors in 1937. He studied at Oxford University, before earning his M.A. and PhD in Psychology from Harvard University (42). Following war-time service for the clandestine National Defense Research Committee, early teaching posts included the University of Vermont, The College of William & Mary, and The Johns Hopkins University. He returned to Swarthmore College in 1947, serving as full professor, department chairman, and dean prior to service as president of Wheaton College, in Norton, MA from 1962-75. He was president and co-chair, of Bryant & Stratton Business Institutes from 1974-84. He was awarded honorary degrees from Swarthmore, Stonehill, Wheaton, and Hartwick colleges, and Southeastern Massachusetts University. He served on the Board Of Managers of Swarthmore College 1978-82 and was a Trustee at Hartwick College 1980-89; Citizens Scholarship Foundation of America 1979-83, and the College Entrance Examination Board (CEEB) 1970-74, and chairman 1972-74. He was a science advisor to Research to Prevent Blindness, contributing editor to the American Journal of Psychology, Guggenheim Fellow; Fellow of the American Psychological Association, and the author of numerous academic and scientific papers. Memberships included: Psychonomic Society, Eastern Psychological Association, United World Federalists, Phi Beta Kappa, Sigma Xi, Phi Kappa Psi, and the Harvard, Moorings, and Acoaxet Clubs. He was predeceased by his devoted wife and partner of 70 years, Elsie (Benton) Doty, and siblings Bryant H. Prentice Jr., and Susan S. (Dunbar, Cochran). Survivors include his brother, Colgate S. Prentice, of Medford Leas, NJ, children; Dorothy (Richard) Ziegler, of Rutland, VT, Susan (Richard) Brainard, of Niskayuna, NY, William C.H. Prentice, Jr., of Vero Beach, FL, Benton (Charissa) Prentice, of Providence, RI, eight grand, and eight great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the William C.H. and Elsie Prentice Faculty Fund at Wheaton College, Norton, MA. 02766 or a college scholarship of your choice.

KOURKOUTAS--Kiki N.,nee Skaphidas, 88, of Denville, NJ, died peacefully on July 31, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Nicholas for 59 years, devoted mother of Margo and Vickie, respected mother-in-law of Dennis and Nick, and grandmother of Katie and Dean. Born in Athens, Greece, Kiki graduated from Russell Sage College in Troy, NY in 1948 with a BS degree. Later in 1953, as one of the first Greek Fulbright scholarship award- ees in the United States she completed a MS in Nutrition from Columbia University's Teachers College. A Registered Dietitian, Kiki directed the dietary department of what is today's Jewish Home Lifecare's Bronx Campus for seventeen years -- a job she relished. During retirement, Kiki divided her time between nursing home dietary consulting and philanthropic work with the Greek Orthodox Ladies Philoptochos Society. Given her appreciation for the opportunities bestowed her, donations may be made in her honor to Greek United States Fulbright Foundation, account #

JOSLIN--Raymond E.,former president and group head of Hearst Entertainment & Syndication and senior vice president and member of the board of directors of Hearst Corporation, died Friday, August 2, in Greenwich, CT. The cause was stomach cancer. He was 76. Joslin was a cable television pioneer, a US media ambassador and a corporate entrepreneur, having carved successful careers in both the cable television systems and cable programming industries. For more than 35 years, he built a career with a vision for growth, an eye for quality and a commitment to corporate excellence. "There is no doubt that Ray left a remarkable imprint through his work in cable television," said Steven R. Swartz, president & CEO, Hearst Corporation. "He was a major player in the expansion of our company beyond a print-centric organization to a leader in cable networks, programming and syndication." "I had the great pleasure of recruiting Ray to Hearst and working with him for more than 20 years," said Frank A. Bennack, Jr., executive vice chairman, Hearst Corporation. "He was key to Hearst's collaboration in the founding of the A&E and Lifetime networks and was one of the most respected leaders in the industry. He was unrivaled in his success. Plus, he was a true gentleman and a loyal friend." After Joslin arrived at Hearst Corporation in 1980 as group head of its Cable Communications Group, the unit realized substantial growth. In 1981, Hearst joined ABC in developing several of the world's leading cable networks, including Lifetime, Lifetime Movie Network, Lifetime Real Women, and A&E Networks including HISTORY, BIO and The History Channel International, the latter with both ABC and NBC, Inc. Subsequently, Joslin oversaw Hearst's investment in ESPN and its portfolio of networks. He was founding co-chairman of the boards of directors of A&E Networks and Lifetime and served as a director on the board of ESPN. Most recently, Joslin served as CEO and chairman of the board of directors of CAD Sciences, a company creating technology designed to enable early detection of breast and prostate cancers. He is survived by his wife, Alicia, children, Jennifer, David and Jeffrey, and six grandchildren. A memorial service, to be announced at a later date, will be held the second week of September at Christ Church in Greenwich, Conn. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Joslin Family Scholarship fund at Trinity College, 300 Summit Street, Hartford, CT 06106, phone: 860-297-2000. The fund, which the Joslin family established in 1999, has to date provided 90 scholarships to assist students with college costs. With Appreciation, Hearst Corporation Board of Directors Steven R. Swartz, President & Chief Executive Officer William R. Hearst III, Chairman of the Board Frank A. Bennack, Jr., Executive Vice Chairman

JOHNSON--F. Coit II, educator, died July 26 in Lawrenceville, NJ. Headmaster of the Little Red School House and Elizabeth Irwin H. S. in NYC, and subsequently The Foxcroft School, Middleburg, VA. Known for flair on the tennis court and dance floor and for intellectual intensity, Coit had an abiding connection to the works of CG Jung and loved art, literature and music. He was a member of the choir of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, NYC of which he was a trustee. A graduate of Groton School, Princeton and Columbia Universities, he served as a Lieutenant in the U. S. Army, and as a founding member of the Wynant Clayton Volunteers. Born January 2, 1930 to the late Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Holmes Johnson of Locust Valley, NY he is survived by his beloved wife, Holly Harrison Johnson, sons, Timothy and Christian Johnson, daughters, Sarah Johnson Doenmez, Rebecca Johnson Dibb, Priscilla Johnson Bender, Holly-Katharine Johnson, nine grandchildren, and his beloved nieces, nephews, and sisters Eunice Winslow and Priscilla McMillan, all of whom will greatly miss his gracious and effervescent spirit.

JEFFERY--Anne. Anne Burr Fairchild Jeffery. Born in Glen Ridge, NJ on September 4, 1931, died peacefully at her Greenwich, CT home on July 25, 2013. She was the daughter of Louis Fairchild, President and Publisher of Fairchild Publications - parent company of Women's Wear Daily and Margaret Suydam. Anne was also the step-daughter to Richard Suydam and Gertrude Fairchild. She is survived by her brother John Fairchild, of New York City, her two daughters, to whom she devoted her life; Wendy Hubbell of Greenwich, CT and Jill Garvin and her husband, Mark of Andover, MA. Her four adored grandchildren; Jamie Hubbell, Kaitlyn Hubbell, Jennifer Garvin, and Annie Garvin. She is predeceased by her loving husband, Carleton Jeffery who passed away in 1978 after only 21 years of marriage. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, July 31, at 11am at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church 954 Lake Ave., Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Greenwich Hospital's neo-natal intensive care unit, 5 Perryridge Road, Greenwich CT 06830. To leave an online condolence please visit leopgallaghergreenwich.com

HEGY--Eugene A. Jr.,Died on July 28th at home with his family. Born in New York City Gene lived most of his life in or near the City he loved. He was a retired LTC of the Seventh Regiment of New York, an infantry veteran of WWII, and a member of Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. During his life he received many awards and honors for his contributions to the community. Gene is survived by his second wife, Gloria; two daughters, Nancy Hegy Martin and Sandra Bolanowski; stepson Paul Caliandro; and six grandchildren. His first wife, Marcella, died in 1993. Contributions to the Central Park Conservancy are suggested.

HAUPTFUHRER--George J. Jr.,87, of Vero Beach, Florida, passed away on August 2, 2013, as a result of congestive heart failure. He was born on August 1, 1926 in Abington Memorial Hospital in suburban Philadelphia and was predeceased by his wife Barbara shortly before their 59th anniversary. He is survived by brother Bob of Wayne, PA, sons George III (Sally) of Atlanta and Barnes (Cammie) of Charlotte, grandchildren Barbara Roland (Andy), Tuck, Lawson, Barnes and Dillon, and great-grandchild Charlotte Roland. He is also survived by his loving fiance, Patsy Daniels of Vero Beach, FL and Raleigh, NC. George graduated with honors from William Penn Charter School in Philadelphia, where he earned nine varsity letters in football, basketball, baseball and track. He captained the baseball and basketball teams and set school and league records for points and rebounds. Upon graduation in June 1944, George entered the U.S. Navy and was sent to the Officer Training Unit (V-12) at the University of Louisville. In his two years there, he earned varsity letters in baseball, track and basketball and set university records for scoring and rebounding. In 1946 George transferred to Harvard, where he again participated in football, track and basketball. He set the college's scoring and rebounding records and was captain of the basketball team. He played in the East-West All-Star game in the old Madison Square Garden and was selected by the Boston Celtics as their first pick in the 1948 NBA draft. Instead of playing professional basketball, George went to law school at the University of Pennsylvania. He graduated in 1951 with honors and was an editor of the Law Review and a member of the Order of the Coif. In 1950 George married Barbara Barnes of Durham, North Carolina. After graduating from law school, he joined the law firm now known as Dechert LLC in Philadelphia. He became a partner eight years later, and his practice focused largely on trusts and estates. Over the years, he held a variety of administrative assignments and in 1984 was elected Chairman and CEO of the firm. He served as chairman of the Real Property, Probate and Trust Law section of the American Bar Association, the Pennsylvania Bar Association and the Philadelphia Bar Association. He served on the Pennsylvania Joint State Government Advisory Committee for many years, including as chairman. George was active with a number of corporate, civic and athletic organizations. He was a director of the West Company and several large private companies. For almost 40 years, he was a director of Abington Memorial Hospital. He was president of the Harvard Club of Philadelphia, a director of the Association of Harvard Alumni and president of the William Penn Charter School Alumni Association. He was a co-founder and director of the Princess Grace Foundation-USA, president of the Eastern Pennsylvania Chapter of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, the first chairman of the Abington Township Environmental Control Committee, and president of the Meadowbrook School. George was a member of Pine Valley Golf Club (NJ), the Honorable Company of EdinburghGolfers (Muirfield, Scotland), Huntingdon Valley Country Club (PA), John's Island Club (FL), Roaring Gap Club (NC) and the U.S. Seniors Golf Association. He served on the boards of Pine Valley, Roaring Gap, John's Island and the USSGA. George was also a member of the Union League of Philadelphia, the Philadelphia Racquet Club and the Philadelphia Club. George was elected to the Athletic Hall of Fame at William Penn Charter School, University of Louisville and Harvard University. George's entire family loved travel as well as sports, and he visited more than 60 different countries on five continents. In Vero Beach, where George and Barbara moved in 1991, their principal interests were golf, Community Church of VB, Riverside Theatre, Vero Beach Art Museum, and Indian River Memorial Hospital. A memorial service will be held at the Community Church of Vero Beach on Wednesday, August 14th at 2:00pm. Following the church service, a reception will be held at the John's Island Club. A later graveside service in NC will be private. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Community Church of Vero Beach, 1901 23rd Street, Vero Beach, FL 32960 or Abington Memorial Hospital, 1200 Old York Road, Abington, PA 19001, or the charity of your choice. An online guestbook is available at www.strunkfuneralhome.com

HAMMER--Marjorie Colef, passed away July 31, 2013, of natural causes, at almost 95 years of age. Raised in Chicago, Marjorie was a long-time resident of the Great Neck, NY, and then Longboat Key, FL. She and her husband, Robert Hammer, enjoyed a long and productive marriage. They are survived by their children, Mark (Janet), Suzanne (Steve) and Jeff (Gloria). She was the beloved grandmother of, Bonnie, Todd (Liz), Jill (Michael), Peter (Lana), Andy (Samantha), Megan (Alex), Lily and Phoebe. Marge was an avid reader, Mahjong player and needlepoint artist. She and her husband enjoyed traveling and had many wonderful trips to all parts of the world. But it was Longboat Key that they loved the most, built their dream house, and where they lived a happy life for over thirty years. Her greatest pleasure was seeing the family gather together during vacations and trips to Florida, and she will be missed by all of us. In lieu of flowers, please send a contribution in her name to your favorite charity. A private memorial service will be held at her daughter's home in Weston, Connecticut.

GOLUB-EVANS--Dr. Jeffrey. May 2, 1941 - August 1, 2013. Dr. Jeffrey Golub-Evans, founder and Director of the New York Center for Cosmetic Dentistry, died Thursday at New York-Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. He was 72. Described as a "Renaissance Man" by his friends and colleagues, Jeff's passion for arts, culture, and travel instilled his professional work with extraordinary depth. His joie de vivre and legendary storytelling ability made him a much-loved figure in the lives of thousands. Although widely sought after for his smile artistry, Jeff always found time for his family, his friends, and his delighted activities: sculpting, hiking, kayaking, yoga, concerts, and theatre. In addition, he was a celebrated mixed-media artist and printmaker with paintings in galleries in New York City and abroad. Born in NYC on May 2, 1941, Jeffrey was the son of artist Eva Brown and attorney Irving Golub. A 1963 graduate of Hamilton College, he spoke French fluently and spent his final year of college in Paris studying French literature, his major. In 1966, Jeff received a degree from NYU College of Dentistry. Shortly thereafter, he enlisted in the Army and participated in a dental training rotation at Walter Reed Army Hospital, gaining tremendous experience in all areas of dentistry including crown and bridge, oral surgery, and endodontics. He subsequently spent a year in Vietnam as a MASH unit team member as well as running his own dental clinic. After returning, he began his private dental practice at 57 E. 72nd St., later moving to 128 E. 71st St., the Dental Duplex. In 1975, Jeff married Laine Jastram and had two children with her, Kristina and Chad. Dr. Jeffrey Golub-Evans parlayed his artistic talents into becoming one of the most revered cosmetic dentists in the country replete with a celebrity clientele. Vogue Magazine famously lauded Dr. Golub-Evans as the "Guru of Cosmetic Dentistry." He was invited to travel the world to teach his brand of high-art cosmetic dentistry utilizing the latest bonding and veneer technologies. In collaboration with his artistic sensibilities, he created a new genre of cosmetic dentistry called "smile design." In addition, Dr. Golub-Evans created dental costuming for Broadway and Hollywood productions. Dr. Jeff was Past President of the Academy of Cosmetic Dentistry (AACD) and was founding president of the New York Academy of Cosmetic Dentistry. AACD co-founder Dr. Morley said, "He was admired and loved by many. Jeff's contribution to the development and 'soul' of the AACD is immeasurable and transcends his many accomplishments." In 2001, Jeff Golub-Evans married Alecia Adams and took residence in Warren, CT, where they raised their daughter, Eva. This beautiful property and new community became his sanctuary. A dedicated, doting father who lived life to the fullest, he and his family could be found enjoying Knicks games, Tanglewood in the Berkshires, Jazz Fest in New Orleans, and dancing at Midsummer Night's Swing at Lincoln Center. Jeff will be sorely missed by us all. His funeral will be held on Sunday, August 4th at 3pm at the First Congregational Church, 6 Kirby Rd, Washington, CT. A memorial service will be held in Manhattan in the coming weeks. Details will be posted on the website to https://www.facebook.com/DrJeffGolubEvans

Also survived by four nieces and nephews. Funeral and Mass were held in Quincy, Mass, on July 22, 2103. Interment was with Full Military Honors at Blue Hill Cemetery, Braintree, Mass. Donations in Theresa's honor may be made to the Pike County Humane Society, 186 Lee Road, Shohola, Pa 18458. A gathering in her honor will be held in NYC in the near future.
FURMAN--Jonathon. On August 2, 2013. Brave. Loving. Missed and mourned by family and friends. Service graveside Sunday 11am, Mount Ararat Cemetery.

FRIEDLANDER--Sidney, of Roslyn, NY. Died peacefully August 3rd at age 96. FLANIGAN--Peter M. The board, staff and students of Student Sponsor Partners mourn the passing of our beloved founder, trustee and generous benefactor. FLANIGAN--Peter M. June 21, 1923 - July 29, 2013. Mr. Flanigan was a Navy carrier pilot in World War II. He graduated Summa Cum Laude from Princeton University in 1947 and joined Dillon, Read & Co. Inc. in the fall of that year. His tenure at Dillon Read was interrupted in 1949 to serve as an economic analyst for the Economic Reconstruction Administration in Britain for two years, returning thereafter to Dillon Read. In 1960 Mr. Flanigan served as Executive Director of Volunteers for the Nixon-Lodge Presidential campaign and in 1968 as Deputy Campaign Manager of the Nixon campaign. In 1969 Mr. Flanigan left Dillon Read upon his appointment as Assistant to the President of the United States under President Nixon, with White House responsibility for domestic commercial and economic matters. In 1972 he was also appointed Director of the Council of International Economic Policy, with responsibility for development and coordination of the Administration's international economic policy. Mr. Flanigan returned to Dillon Read as Managing Director at the beginning of 1975 and continued in that capacity until December 1992. In 1984, Peter Flanigan and his wife adopted the second class in the "I Have a Dream" Program, subsequently becoming a Board Member of that program. In 1985, Mr. Flanigan founded The Student Sponsor Partners, a private voucher program which combines tuition support with one-on-one mentoring. S/SP has helped over 5,000 inner-city high school students. Based on comparative graduation rates and college attendance rates, this program has been a dramatic success. In 1987, he started the Patrons Program to encourage individuals to take responsibility for inner-city Catholic grammar schools which were in danger of being closed for financial reasons. Mr. Flanigan was a Board member of St. Ann's School in Harlem, a small grammar school with 315 students. Upon his death, Mr. Flanigan was Board Member of American Federation for Children - Alliance for School Choice, a nation-wide organization to promote legislation to give parents the ability to send their children to the schools, public or private, of their choice. To research and implement new programs to improve education, Mr. Flanigan founded the Center for Education Innovation of The Manhattan Institute. He was a Board member of the Catholic University of America, and previous Chairman of the Board of Portsmouth Abbey School. Mr. Flanigan was also a member of the Board of Trustees of the John M. Olin Foundation, Inc. and a member of the Board of the Richard M. Nixon Library & Birthplace. In 1954, Mr. Flanigan married Brigid Snow, daughter of the legendary Carmel Snow who was founding editor of Harpers Bazaar, a position she held for 23 years, and grand niece of the equally legendary Bishop McQuade of Dublin, known to his flock as the Holy Terror. His wife, Brigid, passed away in 2006. Brigid and Peter's five children include Sister Louise Marie of the Sister Servants of the Eternal Word. His other children, Brigid, Tim, Megan and Bob are the parents of Peter's 16 grandchildren. Five years ago, Peter was blessed by his marriage to Dorothea von Oswald. He lived half of the year in Austria with Dorothea and her five daughters Maido, Theresa, Mariella, Sophie and Nina. The von Oswald family warmly embraced their new father and grandfather. Peter's great loves in life were his family, his Roman Catholic faith, and his country. Friends may visit at 220 Anderson Hill Road, Purchase, NY, from 4:30pm to 8pm on Sunday, August 4. A Mass of Christian Burial will be said at the Church of the Resurrection, 910 Boston Post Rd, Rye, NY, at 10am on Monday, August 5. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to the Student Sponsor Partners at www.SSPNYC.org.

FARER--Henry. 88, of Scotch Plains, NJ, died August 1, 2013, after a long and brave struggle with esophageal cancer. Beloved husband (of 65 years) of Selma (Wurtzel), devoted and loved father of David and Leslie, adored father-in-law of Elisa King Farer. A deeply respected real estate and business lawyer, he was the founding partner of the highly regarded boutique law firm Farer Fersko, of Westfield NJ There he practiced with his son David, an environmental lawyer, and a close knit group of lawyers and staff (most of whom recently joined Greenbaum Rowe, Smith & Davis along with Henry and David) who will miss him profoundly for his passion for the law, his skills, mentoring, kindness, compassion, integrity, elegance, love of family, music and golf, and his love of life. Services: 11:30am on Monday, August 5 at Bernheim Apter Kreitzman Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills, Rd., Livingston, NJ.

DEMENY--Margaret Kelemen, passed away on August 1, 2013. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. BRICE--Michel Gilles, died at his home on July 16 of lung cancer. He was 86 years old. Michel will be remembered for his resilience, courage and humanitarian values. Michel emigrated to New York City from France fleeing the Holocaust and became a U.S. citizen by enlisting in the U.S. Army and joining the Timberwolves. He helped liberate France. Throughout his life he maintained strong personal and professional links to his birth country which he loved. He is survived by his wife Betty; two children, Marc and Kim, and their spouses; his nieces as well as his family in France. He will be greatly missed.

Owner of Lady Jane, Bloomfield, NJ. Past President, Temple Ner Tamid Bloomfield, NJ. Beloved husband of the late Harriet Lazarus Bilus, beloved brother of the late Shirley Neuman. Fabulous father of Jane Bilus Gould (Kenneth), Patricia Bilus Lager (Martin), and Frann Bilus (Richard Feldman). ALEXANDER--George Jonathon, Of Los Altos Hills, CA passed away on Monday evening, July 29, 2013. His family was by his side. Professor Alexander was the Dean Emeritus of Santa Clara University School of Law, having taken the helm of a 300 student, 12 full-time faculty institution in 1970 and helped the law school grow considerably in stature and triple in size during his 15-year tenure. Professor Alexander taught law for fifty two years, at the University of Chicago, Syracuse University, and Santa Clara Law, focusing his classroom teaching primarily on antitrust, Constitutional law, and law and psychiatry. He proposed the idea of a living will for protecting not only property rights, but also the control of health care issues, in a Stanford Law Review article. He then worked with the California Law Revision Commission in shaping their proposal for such a statute, the first to be passed in the United States. He also authored 13 books, including "Honesty and Competition" about false advertising regulation, "The Aged and the Need for Surrogate Management" (with Professor Travis H. D. Lewin), "Writing a Living Will: Using a Durable Power of Attorney" "International Perspectives on Aging," "Commercial Torts," and many book chapters as well as over fifty articles in refereed scholarly journals in the United States and abroad. Following his term as Dean, Professor Alexander was awarded the Elizabeth H. and John A. Sutro Professor of Law chair -- the first endowed chair in Santa Clara Law School's history. Additionally, he was named Director of the Institute of International and Comparative Law, a program he conceived to expand Santa Clara's legal studies to twelve countries and bring Visiting Scholars to the law school. Prior to coming to Santa Clara Law, Professor Alexander received a grant from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to research legal issues related to space exploration. He was active in the New York Civil Liberties Union (Vice-President) and the American Association of University Professors (Syracuse University Chairman). Beginning in 1976, he served as a consultant to the Comptroller General of the United States for several decades. In 2000, he received the Thomas Szasz Award for Civil Liberties. He was also President of the National Society of American Law Teachers and in 2002, received their award for Founding Board Member and Visionary Activist for Equality, Access and Diversity throughout Law and Society. In 2004, Professor Alexander and his beloved wife generously reinvigorated the East San Jose Community Law Center. In recognition of their gesture, the ESJCLC was officially renamed the Katharine & George Alexander Community Law Center. Today, the Alexander Community Law Center educates law students by guiding them in providing pro bono representation to low-income individuals in consumer law, immigration law, workers' rights, and tax matters, serving about 1,000 clients on-site per year. The Center also reaches out to about 1,200 individuals through mobile workshops on consumer rights, workers' rights, and tenant-landlord rights, as well as advocating for low-income individuals with legislators and law reform committees. In 2008, the Alexanders established the Katharine & George Alexander Law Prize, designed to bring recognition to lawyers who have used their legal careers to help alleviate injustice and inequity. Over the past six years, the Prize has recognized and supported the courageous human rights work of Bryan Stevenson (founder and executive director of the Equal Justice Initiative in Alabama), Mario Joseph (Managing Attorney of the Bureau des Avocats Internationaux in Haiti), Shadi Sadr (an Iranian lawyer who launched the "End Stoning Forever" program and a center for women's rights in Iran), Paul Van Zyl (former Executive Secretary of South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, co-founder of the International Center for Transitional Justice, and CEO of PeaceVentures), Almudena Bernabeu (lead prosecutor against Salvadoran officials for the massacre of Jesuit priests in 1989), and Chen Guangcheng (blind Chinese dissident and self-taught lawyer who fights for the rights of rural poor in China). Professor Alexander was born in 1931 and grew up in Philadelphia. He received his undergraduate and law degrees from the University of Pennsylvania, and an LL.M. and J.S.D. from Yale Law School. Between college and law school, he served in the United States Navy. He was a member of the Board of Trustees of the San Jose Opera and the Arts Council of Silicon Valley, and a member of the Union Presbyterian Church of Los Altos. Professor Alexander is survived by his law school sweetheart, Katharine. They were married for fifty five years and shared a passion for their family, travel, and great food. He is also survived by his children, Suzi Alexander and her husband Gary Stolzoff, and Chip Alexander and his wife Laurie Alexander, as well as his grandchildren, Simone, Sam, and Kate. In lieu of flowers, the family would be grateful for contributions to the Katharine & George Alexander Community Law Center, 1030 The Alameda, San Jose, CA 95126, (408) 288-7030. A memorial service will be held on September 20, 2013 at 4pm at the Santa Clara Mission Church.

AHLGREN--John R.,Kane Lodge No. 454 F. & A.M. mourns with profound sorrow the death of our esteemed brother and Trustee Emeritus John R. Ahlgren on July 15, 2013. He was raised by Kane Lodge on May 3, 1960. Bro. John served his Lodge for many years as a Trustee and also was a Trustee of the Kane Lodge Foundation from its creation 51 years ago until his death. A memorial service will be held at The Reformed Church of Bronxville on Saturday, September 7, 2013 at 11 am. He was a true gentleman who answered the call to duty after Pearl Harbor and served his country with honor as a member of the U.S. Navy. He served his Lodge with distinction for more than half a century. He will be fondly remembered. Alan G. Moore, Secretary W. James A. Habacker, Master

LESMAN--Howard. Your light was so bright that it continues to shine. The beach is beautiful and I'm missing you. Love Jan

WITMEYER--John J.,III. Born in New Orleans, LA on December 18, 1946, died at his home in New York City after a year- long battle with cancer. He was the son of John J. Witmeyer Jr. (a decorated World War II veteran) and Thais Witmeyer. He is survived by his father, three brothers, Michael, Kurt and Eric, and two nephews, Michael Jr. and Robert, as well as a number of cousins and grand nieces and nephews. Mr. Witmeyer graduated from Tulane University in 1968 with a Bachelors of Science degree, and after graduating from Duke University Law School in 1971, he began practicing law in New York City. On June 1, 1976, Mr. Witmeyer founded the law firm of Ford Marrin Esposito Witmeyer & Gleser, LLP. He continued to practice law there until the day of his death. A remarkable lawyer with incredible energy, Mr. Witmeyer was very successful representing his clients during the course of his career. But perhaps, the professional accomplishment of which he was most proud of was his mentoring of many young lawyers, who themselves are now very successful and remember him fondly and call him friend. Mr. Witmeyer also served in the U.S. Army and at the time of his retirement had attained the rank of Colonel. He served in leadership positions in both professional and philanthropic organizations, which include the Gregorian University Foundation, Tulane College Dean's Colloquium Endowment Fund, the Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulchre (Eastern Lieutenancy), and Cristo Rey New York High School- Board of Trustees. Visitation will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue (81st St.), Monday, 2-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral mass will be Tuesday at the Holy Trinity RC Church at 213 West 82nd Street at 10am. The family requests donations in John's memory to: Wounded Warrior Project.

UDELL--Howard, 72, on August 2, 2013. Beloved husband and soul mate of Judith for 49 years. Cherished father to Jeffrey and Andrew; father-in-law to Lucy and Sheryl; and "Papa" to grandchildren Micaela, Nina, Max, Alec, Adam and Daniela. Born in Brooklyn, New York, he graduated from Hunter College and NYU School of Law. After 15 years in private practice at the law firm Millard Green & Udell, in 1979 he assumed the role of General Counsel to the pharmaceutical company now known as Purdue Pharma, where he remained for 30 years. Trusted and wise counselor and friend, known for his character, integrity, sagacity and sense of humor, he was also active in civic life, and served on the board of Sackler School of Medicine at Tel Aviv University for over 25 years. In 2009, he co-founded the Connecticut Veterans Legal Center (CVLC), which provides free legal services to hundreds of veterans each year. Until his untimely death this week, he served on CVLC's board and regularly counseled veterans. Donations in his memory to the CVLC will be greatly appreciated.

THOMAS--Liliane. Our beautiful friend Lily has died and we are all so sad. Liliane was sleek and stylish, warm and wonderful. She loved a good time and she made sure everyone around her enjoyed one too. A loving wife, mother, grandmother, a devoted daughter, sister, friend, Lily was francaise to her fingertips and we all loved her for it. We will miss her forever. Maggie and Don

SMITH--Mary Ann E.,(nee Jenney), on August 3rd, 2013, of Forest Hills, NY. Beloved wife of Robert G. Loving mother of Robert, John, Dennis, Maria, Peter, Thomas and Matthew Smith. Survied by siblings Margaret, Patricia and John. Loved by ten grandchildren and two great-granddaughters. Reposing Fox Funeral Home, Forest Hills, NY, Monday 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass at Our Lady Queen of Marters Church, Tuesday 9:30am. Interment Sacred Heart Parish Cemetery, Cutchogue, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to your favorite chairty appreciated.

SIGNORILE--Frances M.,89, of Manhasset, NY and New York City, passed away peacefully on July 29, 2013. Frances married high school sweetheart, Anthony J. Signorile in 1945 and were married for 68 years. Signorile founded the New York accounting firm of A. J. Signorile & Co. She is survived by spouse Anthony J. Signorile, her two children, Linda S. Ehrlich and Stephen A. Signorile; brother, Gerald F. Tucci, as well as five grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren. Visitation will be held at Fairchild Sons Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset on Monday, August 5 from 3-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral at Lutheran Church of Our Savior, 12 Franklin Ave, Port Washington, NY on Tuesday, August 6 at 11am.

SIEGEL GELBART--Mona, (nee Stouman), passed peacefully after a short, but heroic battle with cancer. Loving mother of sons Jay and Stephen and daughters-in-law Kristine and Martha. Adoring grandmother of Annie, Brett, Greg, Bradley and Carolyn, and doting great-grandmother to Gabrielle. Loving stepmom to Carol, Paul, Stephen, Mary, Bill and Nina and all of their families. She had a wonderful long marriage to Harold and a delightful, but too short, marriage to Abe. Predeceased by her five siblings. She had a full life of love, joy and success. Her loss will be felt by her extended families and numerous friends who relied on her caring, love and wisdom. Services Sunday 11:45am at Riverside Chapel.

MOSS--Lloyd. Brooklyn boy, WQXR announcer, author of "Zin! Zin! Zin! A Violin." Lloyd asked that donations be made in his name to: The Innocence Project, 40 Worth Street, Suite 701, New York, NY 10012 www.innocenceproject.org

JOSLIN--Raymond E.,former president and group head of Hearst Entertainment & Syndication and senior vice president and member of the board of directors of Hearst Corporation, died Friday, August 2, in Greenwich, CT. The cause was stomach cancer. He was 76. Joslin was a cable television pioneer, a US media ambassador and a corporate entrepreneur, having carved successful careers in both the cable television systems and cable programming industries. For more than 35 years, he built a career with a vision for growth, an eye for quality and a commitment to corporate excellence. "There is no doubt that Ray left a remarkable imprint through his work in cable television," said Steven R. Swartz, president & CEO, Hearst Corporation. "He was a major player in the expansion of our company beyond a print-centric organization to a leader in cable networks, programming and syndication." "I had the great pleasure of recruiting Ray to Hearst and working with him for more than 20 years," said Frank A. Bennack, Jr., executive vice chairman, Hearst Corporation. "He was key to Hearst's collaboration in the founding of the A&E and Lifetime networks and was one of the most respected leaders in the industry. He was unrivaled in his success. Plus, he was a true gentleman and a loyal friend." After Joslin arrived at Hearst Corporation in 1980 as group head of its Cable Communications Group, the unit realized substantial growth. In 1981, Hearst joined ABC in developing several of the world's leading cable networks, including Lifetime, Lifetime Movie Network, Lifetime Real Women, and A&E Networks including HISTORY, BIO and The History Channel International, the latter with both ABC and NBC, Inc. Subsequently, Joslin oversaw Hearst's investment in ESPN and its portfolio of networks. He was founding co-chairman of the boards of directors of A&E Networks and Lifetime and served as a director on the board of ESPN. Most recently, Joslin served as CEO and chairman of the board of directors of CAD Sciences, a company creating technology designed to enable early detection of breast and prostate cancers. He is survived by his wife, Alicia, children, Jennifer, David and Jeffrey, and six grandchildren. A memorial service, to be announced at a later date, will be held the second week of September at Christ Church in Greenwich, Conn. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Joslin Family Scholarship fund at Trinity College, 300 Summit Street, Hartford, CT 06106, phone: 860-297-2000. The fund, which the Joslin family established in 1999, has to date provided 90 scholarships to assist students with college costs. With Appreciation, Hearst Corporation Board of Directors Steven R. Swartz, President & Chief Executive Officer William R. Hearst III, Chairman of the Board Frank A. Bennack, Jr., Executive Vice Chairman

HAUPTFUHRER--George J. The Princess Grace Foundation-USA mourns the death of George J. Hauptfuhrer, Jr. During his tenure as an attorney at Dechert LLP, George helped establish the Princess Grace Foundation-USA as a non-profit organization and we remain eternally grateful for his efforts. George continued to serve as a member of the Board of Trustees of the Foundation, guiding us for more than fifteen years. His hard work endures and impacts the many artists supported by the Princess Grace Awards. Our heartfelt sympathies go out to his son and Foundation Trustee, George J. Hauptfuhrer, III and his family.

HARDWOOD--Jeremy John Olivier, 55, of Larchmont, New York, died suddenly at home on Thursday, August 1. Born in Beirut, Lebanon to English parents, he was educated at Charterhouse School. After R.M.A Sandhurst, he served in the First Royal Tank Regiment in West Germany. He graduated from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, where he was a Morehead Scholar, and then received a law degree from Oxford University. He was called to The Bar by the Honourable Society of the Inner Temple. Listed in International Who's Who Legal as one of the world's "ten most highly regarded" shipping and maritime lawyers, he was a partner at Blank Rome LLP. Devoted husband, father, and friend to many, Jeremy loved people and lived life to the fullest. He was an avid traveler and collector, a dapper dresser, and had a keen sense of humor. He will be deeply missed. He is survived by his wife Mary Ann Cate, children Kathleen and Henry, his father, and two sisters. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, August 7, at 12:30pm at Larchmont Avenue Church, Larchmont, New York. Memorial contributions may be made to Morehead-Cain Scholarship Fund, PO Box 690, Chapel Hill, NC 27514.

FRIEDLANDER--Sidney, of Roslyn, NY. Died peacefully August 3rd at age 96. He is survived by his loving wife of 66 years, Shirley, his children David, Alan and Naomi, his grandchildren Franklin, Paul, Aaron, Jeremy, Sara and Jesse, and great-granddaughters Francesca and Penelope. Sidney was a brilliant, thoughtful and dignified man, who lived a rich, full life. Sidney was a decorated military veteran who participated in the D-Day +1 Normandy invasion. He worked for more than 50 years at United Merchants and Manufacturers as Quality Control Manager. Services will be held on Monday at 11:30am at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, Great Neck, NY. He was loved by all and will be greatly missed.
