UDELL--Howard R. The Board of Directors, officers, and staff of the Sackler School of Medicine New York State/American Program and of American Friends of Tel Aviv University are deeply saddened by the loss of our valued friend, Howard Udell. As Board member and General Counsel to the Sackler School of Medicine New York State/American Program, his wisdom and steady guidance helped shape its success and set the course for future growth. We extend deepest sympathies to his wife, Judy, sons Andrew and Jeff, and the entire family. American Friends of Tel Aviv University Jon Gurkoff, Chairman Gail Reiss, President and CEO Sackler Faculty of Medicine New York State/American Program Dr. Isadore Rosenfeld, Chairman Dr. Stephen H. Lazar, Executive Dean

STERNLIEB--Dr. Peter, a brilliant physician and beloved husband, father and grandfather, died on Saturday, August 3, at Winthrop University Hospital in Mineola, where he had been an internist on staff for more than 50 years. He was 81. Born in Dresden, Germany on May 9, 1932, Dr. Sternlieb emigrated to Pittsburgh with his parents, David and Elsa Sternlieb in 1938. A quick study, he was one of the youngest students to graduate from the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine at the age of 23. After an internship at the US Naval Hospital in St. Albans and in Newport, he became a distinguished physician in private practice in Long Island, New York. Scuba diving, underwater photography, squash, swimming and jazz music were lifelong passions, but all paled in comparison to the 40-year romance he shared with his beloved wife, Sybil Sternlieb, to whom he wrote love poems every week. Together they enjoyed international travel, art, ballroom dancing and thousands of games of Scrabble. A consummate family doctor, he bestowed loving attention on family, friends and patients whose lives were forever touched and who will treasure him always. Dr. Peter Sternlieb is survived by his loving wife, Sybil Sternlieb, a Senior VP at Merrill Lynch. He also leaves two daughters, Susan (Edward) Novick and Debra Morris (Holly Haygood); two sons, David (Barbara) Rosenberg and Michael Sternlieb; and four grandchildren, Myles and Olivia Novick, and Jennifer and Daniel Rosenberg (April Branson), who adored and were adored by him. He will never be forgotten.

SEID--Walter, died peacefully on August 4, 2013 at the age of 91. A devoted husband and a loving father, he was born in Brooklyn, NY on August 6, 1921. He is survived by his two sons, Robert Seid (Shelley) and Andrew Seid, two daughters, Elizabeth Silber (Gary) and Kathy Seid-Eriksson (Mikael), and five grandchildren, David Seid (Rebecca), Max Seid, Allison Silber, Lauren Silber and Jacob Eriksson. Following his service in WWII, he married Geraldine Katz and began a lifelong career at '21' Brands, Inc. After retiring at the age of 55 he spent time with his family, played golf, enjoyed art, and charmed the world around him. He sat on the board of the Schneider Children's Medical Center at LIJ and played an active role at his synagogue. These are the memories we will choose to cherish. A Memorial Service will be held on Tuesday, Aug. 6, 2013, at 3:00pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th (entrance between 75th and 76th St. on Amsterdam Ave.) in Manhattan. Donations may go to American Friends of Hebrew University, 1 Battery Park Plaza, New York, NY 10004

RABINOWITZ--William. Beloved husband of Harriet, devoted father of David and Erika Rabinowitz, Caryn and David Osterman, and Robin Rabinowitz. Loving grandfather of Amy and Danny Rabinowitz and Lewis and Rachel Osterman. Brother of Maureen and Harvey Lerner.

MOSS--Lloyd. The Board of Trustees and staff of New York Public Radio mourn the loss of Lloyd Moss. For five decades, Lloyd was a beloved host on New York's classical music station WQXR. He was known for his quick wit, his joyful spirit and his everlasting love of music. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Anne, his family and his many friends.

Our organization continues to benefit from his years of outstanding leadership and unwavering commitment to improving the lives of New York's older adults. Respectfully, Nicola M. SCHEUER--Thomas. The Board of Directors and the members and staff of The National Committee for an Effective Congress are deeply saddened by the death of our Chairman, Thomas Scheuer. Tom's modest leadership and keen intelligence will be sorely missed. Tom was a strong Liberal Democrat. He never failed to be the first to respond when important causes were under political threat. His skills were always in demand. Tom was a brilliant lawyer. His love of family and his community were equaled by his determination to leave the world in a place better than he found it. Knowing the time and attention he gave to our legal system and to education, one wonders how he found time for athletics, for government and for politics. Tom was nationally recognized as an athlete, especially in horsemanship. To say that Tom was loved, respected, and admired by all who knew him is an understatement. Our hearts go out to his wife, Ann, to his children, and to his brothers. Russell Hemenway, National Director, National Committee for an Effective Congress

LOW-BEER--Audrey, died peacefully in her 90th year. She is survived by her children Michael and Lissa, her grandchildren Zachary, Andrew, Mark, Sara, and Jason. Audrey was a vibrant, charming, elegant and unique woman who loved her family, the beach, and all things beautiful. Witty, well read and intelligent, she loved her native New York and its wonderful theater, opera, and museums. She will be missed.

LEVINE--Michael D. Board Members, staff and volunteers of the Alzheimer's Association, NYC Chapter mourn the loss of Michael D. Levine, brother of Jed Levine, Executive Vice President. KNOWLES--Clayton P.,Jr., 72, a New York entertainment lawyer whose clients included the actress Erin Gray, jazz keyboardist Kim Pensyl, and many 1980s rock groups including Twisted Sister, died on August 5. The cause of death was complications following pneumonia. Clay himself was an accomplished professional musician. Over the years he played guitar and sang at clubs from Greenwich Village to the Upper East Side, and his band played at functions and venues across the city and New Jersey. Clay was a graduate of Montclair High School in Montclair, NJ, Hobart College, Geneva, NY, and New York Law School. He served as a Second Lieutenant in the Army's 1st Air Calvary Division during the Vietnam War, from 1965 to 1966. He was awarded the Bronze Star and Air Medal. Clay always said that his guitar saved his life in Vietnam. While playing for a group of officers when he first arrived there, he caught the attention of an Army colonel who six months later recruited Clay as a liaison officer. Two weeks after Clay started his new job, 16 members of his platoon were killed in an enemy ambush including the lieutenant who replaced him. The tragedy marked Clay for life. Clay was the son of the late Clayton P. Knowles, a reporter for The New York Times, and the late Ruth Knowles, a civic activist. He is survived by his wife, Renata Renner Knowles, an industrial minerals consultant, his brother, Jeffrey Knowles, a lawyer in Washington, D.C., and his sister, Laurie Knowles, a lawyer in Santa Fe, NM. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the Fender Music Foundation, which provides instruments to music education programs. The foundation's website is fendermusicfoundation.org.

Devoted and cherished grandfather of Andrew and Stephanie Haul and Justin Rubino. You are our inspiration, and we will forever cherish and love you. DOUGLAS--Albert R.,served in the US Navy (LtJG) and Harvard class of '42, died on July 27, 2013. He served in World War II, which included piloting torpedo bombers from the escort carrier USS Savo Island. While flying reconnaissance at US landings at Leyte Gulf in the Philippines, he discovered a major Japanese fleet trying to sneak up on the landings. The major U.S. fleet had been lured well to the north to attack the major Japanese ships not realizing that the Japanese carrier planes had all been destroyed. That left the US escort carriers at Leyte to fight off the unexpected Japanese fleet by themselves. It is a dramatic and successful episode in U.S. Naval history. After having discovered the Japanese fleet, Douglas made it back to his carrier with all of his crew. Later at Leyte he was on a mission over Cebu Island when his plane was severely shot up, including its steering control. He was able to nurse the fifty foot plane back to the carrier safely with all three crew members. Douglas said he was most concerned the plane would catch fire. The plane was so badly riddled with bullet holes that it was promptly thrown overboard. For his service he was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Air Medal. Douglas was born on September 23, 1920 to Major Richard and Madeleine Dabo Douglas. He graduated from the Kent School in Connecticut in 1938 and from Harvard with a BA degree in 1942. He then enlisted in the Navy and underwent flight training as carrier pilot in Florida, and then on a training deck built for the Navy into Lake Michigan near Chicago. After the war he remained in the Navy for a time, flying virtually every kind of propeller plane in the Navy while ferrying VIP's. After leaving the Navy he worked as a stock broker and investment advisor with E.F. Hutton, among others. He continued this work until his death. Most recently he has been affiliated with A.J. Weed & Co. and R.M Stark & Co. He and his wife Celeste Murray Bartlett Douglas, known to family and friends as Murray, lived in Manhattan with a second home in Old Chatham, New York. They have been married since June 14, 1963. Mrs. Douglas was the chief designer and part owner of the famous fabric and wallpaper house of Brunschwig et Fils. Mr. and Mrs. Douglas were active in The Shaker Museum & Library, where Mrs. Douglas was a long time board member, and the Old Chatham Hunt Club. Mr. Douglas was a sixty-eight year member of the Harvard Club of New York. Albert Douglas is survived by his wife, Murray Douglas, and his step-son Francis Russel Lyons of Seattle, WA. He is also survived by his brother-in-law, Keith Lockhart of San Rafael, California and Mr. Douglas's nephews, Frank Lockhart of Olympia, WA and Douglas Lockhart of Napa, CA. His sister Jean Lockhart, MD died in 2011. A time for family and friends to share together memories of Albert's life will be held August 10, 2013, at 1pm at the Douglas's house, the School House, at the corner of County Route 13 and Ford Rd in Old Chatham, NY. Interment of his ashes will take place at a date still to be determined.

CROES--Ruth Bial. April 23, 1917-August 5, 2013. A remarkably loving, kind, intelligent woman who made a happy home. Our family mourns the loss of this witty, insightful, resilient matriarch and her extraordinary culinary skills. Beloved mother of Marjorie Silverman (David) and Jane Croes (Edward Fitzelle); devoted sister to Helene Schechter (Seymour); adoring grandmother to Elizabeth Falk (Jeremy), Michael Silverman (Nora), Benjamin Fitzelle and Laura Fitzelle; and a great auntie.

DOLGENOS--Sally Ashley. Author, Actor, Activist. January 30, 1935 - July 10, 2013. Mother to Peter, Peggy, Carey & Tom. Mother in law to Chris Neklason, Sarah Ricks and Luca Padulli. Grandmother to Jake, Kate, Annika, Carly, Charlie and Camillo. Sister to James M. Ashley IV and Susan Ashley Coss. Always in our hearts. Memorial service Tuesday, August 13, 4pm, at Marshall Field, Sarah Lawrence College, Bronxville, NY. Donations to Hospice of NY and to Planned Parenthood in honor of George TIller.

BERGER--Elizabeth. The Association for a Better New York mourns the passing of Liz Berger. Liz was a passionate and determined advocate for Lower Manhattan and all of New York. Her impact is lasting and her spirit has touched us all. Bill Rudin, Chairman Jennifer Hensley, Executive Director

BERGER--Elizabeth, Elizabeth Berger was a great civic leader and champion of Lower Manhattan. As the President of the Alliance for Downtown New York and President of the Downtown-Lower Manhattan Association she helped shape the reimagining and rebuilding of Lower Manhattan after the 9/11 attacks and recently led an effort to assist Lower Manhattan businesses and residents recover from the effects of Superstorm Sandy. She died on August 5th at Bellevue Hospital Center. She turned 53 this past Saturday. Under Ms. Berger's leadership, the Alliance and the Downtown-Lower Manhattan Association successfully advocated for full funding and timely completion of the Fulton Street Transit Center, the reconstruction of Fiterman Hall and the enactment of post-9/11 commercial leasing incentives. Rather than focus on the district as the location of a terrible tragedy, Ms. Berger, renowned for her indefatigable energy and exacting intellect, was driven by a vision of Lower Manhattan as a place teeming with vitality and potential and a proving ground for municipal innovation. "Liz Berger's passion, sophistication and drive shaped Lower Manhattan as surely as any skyscraper or bulldozer," said Robert R. Douglass the Chairman of the Alliance for Downtown New York and the Downtown-Lower Manhattan Association. "Her strength as an advocate and strategist was only exceeded by her loyalty as a friend and her dedication as a mother and wife. She will be sorely missed." Elizabeth Harrie Berger was born on August 3, 1960 in New York City. Ms. Berger had decades of experience in government, community affairs and strategic planning. Prior to her time with the Alliance she established and built government relations practices at the law firms Lord Day & Lord Barrett Smith and LeBoeuf, Lamb Greene & MacRae and the Law Offices of Claudia Wagner. Ms. Berger is also credited with creating the Department of Government and External Affairs at Lincoln Center. She served as an Assistant Mayoral Representative to the New York City Council during the Koch administration. A graduate of Yale College where she created her own major, The Study of the City, Ms. Berger was also involved with a variety of civic organizations in New York City beyond her professional obligations. She was at various times a board director of The Municipal Art Society, Film Forum, Second Stage Theatre, American Museum of Natural History Planetarium Authority and the New York Building Congress. She was also a mayoral appointee to the board of the Trust for Governors Island. In a statement Mayor Michael Bloomberg said of Ms. Berger "Liz Berger loved our City with passion and gave her great intelligence and inventiveness to New York without reserve. She was more than an advocate for Lower Manhattan, she was a partner in building its future. As new transit hubs, skyscrapers, full access to our waterfront and a fresh vitality emerge downtown, Liz's influences are everywhere to be seen. We shared a vision of Lower Manhattan as a model 21st century business and residential district, and thanks to her tireless work, it's being realized before our eyes. The City mourns the loss of a great civic leader." She is survived by her husband Frederick Kaufman, daughter Phoebe, son Julian, her mother Anita, and brother Gideon. The family will hold a private gathering for immediate family and close friends and a public memorial will be planned for the early fall. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Liz's memory to Film Forum or the Bowery Residents' Committee. For more information contact abreslau@downtownny.com

BERGER--Elizabeth. The entire Grand Central Partnership family mourns the passing of our colleague and dear friend, Liz Berger, whose vision, strength and energy inspired us everyday, and whose love of our city will continue to be felt through all of her countless contributions. Our hearts and thoughts go out to her entire family and her many friends at this time. Peter S. Kalikow, Chairman Alfred C. Cerullo, III, President/CEO

BERGER--Elizabeth. Lower Manhattan and all of New York City has lost a visionary in Liz Berger. So many of us at CBRE have been lucky to count Liz as a business partner and a friend. A decades-long resident of Lower Manhattan, Liz helped shepherd Downtown's rebirth and transformation, and gave inspiration to so many through her efforts and passion for her community. We mourn her loss, and extend heartfelt condolences to her husband, Frederick Kaufman, and their two children.

BERGER--Elizabeth, was a passionate advocate for Lower Manhattan and all of New York City and she contributed significantly to its livability and resilience. The Municipal Art Society was privileged to have Liz serve as a Board Member for the past 11 years and we will miss her greatly. Our thoughts go out to her husband Fred and her family. MAS Chair Eugenie L. Birch, President Vin Cipolla, Board and Staff

BERGER--Elizabeth H. The NYC BID Association, representing 67 business improvement districts, wishes to express its great sadness over the passing of our friend and colleague, Elizabeth H. Berger, who in her personal and professional life was a tireless advocate for Lower Manhattan, most recently as the leader of the Alliance for Downtown New York. Her energy, spirit and resilience matched her beloved neighborhood and were an example to us all. Our sympathy to her family and many friends; she will be greatly missed.
BERGER--Elizabeth, a great friend to FILM FORUM and to all downtowners. A delightful, gracious woman. Karen Cooper Director, Film Forum

BERGER--Elizabeth H. The Officers and Directors of the New York Building Congress join in remembering the extraordinary accomplishments of Liz Berger, our esteemed Director, who led the Alliance for Downtown New York with commitment and distinction. Her passion for New York was incomparable. John M. Dionisio, Chairman Richard T. Anderson, President

ASIEL--E. Nelson (Bill), age 96, died peacefully at home in White Plains, NY on August 5, 2013. He was predeceased by his wife of fifty eight years, Betty Lehman Asiel, and by his sister, Doris Asiel Meyer. He was born and raised in NYC and Elberon, NJ. Graduated from Yale University in 1939 and Yale Law School in 1942 after which he worked for the law firm, Simpson, Thatcher and Bartlett for close to ten years. He subsequently joined the family business, Asiel and Company, started by his grandfather in 1878, becoming a senior managing member. The firm later joined with Tradition (NA) Inc. He retired at age 90 after a career of over fifty years in the industry. He served on the Boards of the Burke Rehabilitation Center and the Child Daycare Center in White Plains. An avid golfer and long-time New York Yankees fan, he will be deeply missed by family and friends. Survived by three children: Harold (Pat), Terri (Henry) and John (Diane), two grandchildren: Carrie (Dennis) and Scott (Maureen) and five great grandchildren. Visiting hours will be at McMahon Lyon Hartnett Funeral Home 4-6pm on Friday. Funeral private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Lighthouse International in NYC or The Burke Rehabilitation Center in White Plains 785 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, NY 10605. Funeral services handled by McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett FH 491 Mamaroneck Ave White Plains, NY 10605 (914)949-7777.

WHALEY--Barton, PhD, 85, on 3 August 2013 in Pacific Grove, CA. Born in San Francisco on 26 May 1928, a pioneer in the field of military deception. Survived by his wife Susan Stratton Aykroyd, and stepsons David and Jim Woodle. He will be sorely missed and never forgotten. Any donations on his behalf may be made to the Special Operations Warrior Foundation at specialops.org.

TREISMAN--Dorothy C. The Trustees, faculty and staff of The Mount Sinai Medical Center are deeply saddened by the passing of Dorothy C. Treisman. Mrs. Treisman was the granddaughter of Mount Sinai Trustee Joseph F. Cullman, Jr., in whose honor The Joseph F. Cullman, Jr. Institute for Patient Care was named by Mrs. Treisman's father, Joseph F. Cullman III, and her uncles, Trustee Edgar M. Cullman and Lewis B. Cullman. For generations, the generosity of Mrs. Treisman and the entire Cullman family has made a significant impact on Mount Sinai. We are truly grateful for their support and extend our heartfelt condolences to her sons, Joel and Jeffrey, and the entire family. Peter W. May, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, The Mount Sinai Medical Center; Kenneth L. Davis, MD, President and CEO, The Mount Sinai Medical Center; and Dennis S. Charney, MD, Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and Executive Vice President for Academic Affairs at The Mount Sinai Medical Center.

TREISMAN--Dorothy (nee Cullman), on August 6, 2013. Beloved mother of Joel and Jeffrey. Loving grandmother of Rachel, Maya and Jordana. Family will receive friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. on Thursday evening, 5-8pm.

SMITH--Mary Ann. The New York State Health Foundation Board and staff are saddened by the passing of Mary Ann Smith, beloved wife of our Board member Robert G. Smith. We extend our sympathies to the entire family: Bob and their 7 children, 10 grandchildren, and 2 great-granddaughters. Carl Weisbrod, Chair Jim Knickman, CEO

REARDON--Robert P.,of Garden City, NY, formerly of Rockville Centre, NY, on August 7, 2013. Beloved husband of Lorraine (nee: Hartz). Loving and devoted father of Brian (Elizabeth), Keith (AnnMarie), Julia (Daniel) Englander, Mary (Woody) Weldon, Maureen (Jay) Coyle, Robert (Sara) and Morgan. Adored grandfather of twenty-one. Dear brother of Marie Pusak, Anne Mayer, John (Jack) and the late Charles Reardon. Also survived by several nieces and nephews. Reposing Saturday and Sunday Macken Mortuary, Rockville Centre Chapel, 52 Clinton Avenue 2-4, 7-9pm. Funeral Mass St. Agnes Cathedral, Monday 10am. Interment Cemetery of the Holy Rood, Westbury, NY. mackenmortuary.com

McNAMER--Ronald, of New York City and Ft. Lauderdale, FL, passed away peacefully at home in New York on Sunday, August 4, 2013. He is survived by his partner of 35 years Charles Cuomo, a sister Nina Cain and numerous nieces and nephews. Ron was a veteran of the United States Navy and an internationally known jewelry designer for Montreaux, Cartier, Tiffany and Zolotas, private clientele, as well as a costume designer for both the theater and ballet. Friends may call Friday, August 9, 5-8pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Audubon Society. Memorial Services to be held in New York and Ft. Lauderdale at a later date.

OLAN--Frances Zeller, died August 6th, 2013. Born February 2nd, 1917. A fiercely independent woman, Frances enjoyed following the stock market, was an avid card player, an exuberant dancer, and a proud and loving parent, grandparent, and great-grandparent. Frances will be greatly missed by her son, Neil Olan, her daughter, Sherry Olan Berner, her granddaughters Brett Iimura, Dru Finley and Erin Finley, and her six great-grandchildren. She was predeceased by her husband, Phil Olan, who died in 1973. Services will be held at noon on Friday, August 9th, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. (at W. 91st St.), in Manhattan.

LICHTER--George. We lost our dear friend George Lichter last week. Because of his modesty and lack of self celebration few appreciate how he changed so many lives for the better. He was a bona fide hero in World War II, a highly decorated fighter pilot of extraordinary bravery, devoted to his fellow pilots, many of whom never came home. He was among the handful of founders of the Israeli Air Force, carrying world Jewry on his wings from the devastation of Nazism to that country's pride and excellence. He lived life well. "How are you, George?" His answer always was, "Fantastic!" He was a great friend to all his friends, always a cheerleader, always generous. What he was most proud of, deservedly so, was that he was a fabulous father and grandfather. We are grateful that George Lichter showed up on our doorstep 63 years ago and became part of our lives. We will miss him always. Elaine and Alan London

KESSLER--Stacey. On August 6, 2013, of Melville, NY, age 34. Beloved daughter of Ronnie and Ira. Loving sister of Shari and Mark Braverman and Jamie and John Finnegan. Special aunt to Lucas. Services Today 10am at "Gutterman's", 8000 Jericho Tpke. Woodbury, LI.

GUZOV--Irwin. In his 88th year on August 4, 2013. Beloved husband of Bella for 64 years. Loving father of Susan (James Calo) and Debra. Devoted and cherished grandfather of Andrew and Stephanie Haul and Justin Rubino. You are our inspiration, and we will forever cherish and love you. Services Thursday, 11:30am at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

BERGER--Elizabeth. Lower Manhattan and all of New York City has lost a visionary in Liz Berger. So many of us at CBRE have been lucky to count Liz as a business partner and a friend. A decades-long resident of Lower Manhattan, Liz helped shepherd Downtown's rebirth and transformation, and gave inspiration to so many through her efforts and passion for her community. We mourn her loss, and extend heartfelt condolences to her husband, Frederick Kaufman, and their two children. Friends at CBRE

BERGER--Elizabeth. Lower Manhattan Cultural Council is greatly saddened by the loss of Liz Berger. We all at LMCC have been inspired by Liz's leadership, dedication to ensuring culture was an intrinsic part of Downtown's rebirth, and vision for the future of the district. The Board and staff mourn her loss and extend our condolences to her family and colleagues at the Downtown Alliance.
BERGER--Elizabeth, a great friend to Film Forum and to all downtowners. A delightful, gracious woman. Karen Cooper Director, Film Forum

BERGER--Elizabeth. Liz's contribution to America's most dynamic CBD will live on forever. Her support and guidance was always of great value. My heart goes out to her family as well as the fine board and staff at the Downtown Alliance. Eric J. Deutsch

ASIEL--E. Nelson (Bill), age 96, died peacefully at home in White Plains, NY on August 5, 2013. He was predeceased by his wife of fifty eight years, Betty Lehman Asiel, and by his sister, Doris Asiel Meyer. He was born and raised in NYC and Elberon, NJ. Graduated from Yale University in 1939 and Yale Law School in 1942 after which he worked for the law firm, Simpson, Thatcher and Bartlett for close to ten years. He subsequently joined the family business, Asiel and Company, started by his grandfather in 1878, becoming a senior managing member. The firm later joined with Tradition (NA) Inc. He retired at age 90 after a career of over fifty years in the industry. He served on the Boards of the Burke Rehabilitation Center and the Child Daycare Center in White Plains. An avid golfer and long-time New York Yankees fan, he will be deeply missed by family and friends. Survived by three children: Harold (Pat), Terri (Henry) and John (Diane), two grandchildren: Carrie (Dennis) and Scott (Maureen) and five great grandchildren. Visiting hours will be at McMahon Lyon Hartnett Funeral Home 4-6pm on Friday. Funeral private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Lighthouse International in NYC or The Burke Rehabilitation Center in White Plains 785 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, NY 10605. Funeral services handled by McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett FH 491 Mamaroneck Ave White Plains, NY 10605 (914)949-7777.
LEVY--Arthur. 6 years today. Loved and missed every day. Now and forever, Barbara
